PREFACE
This city code of the city of Lewistown, as supplemented, contains ordinances up to and including ordinance 1744A, passed September 4, 2012.
Ordinances of the city adopted after said ordinance supersede the provisions of this city code to the extent that they are in conflict or inconsistent
therewith. Consult the city office in order to ascertain whether any particular provision of the code has been amended, superseded or repealed.
Sterling Codifiers
Coeur d'Alene, Idaho
ADOPTING ORDINANCE
AN ORDINANCE
FOR REVISING, CODIFYING AND COMPILING THE GENERAL ORDINANCES OF THE CITY OF LEWISTOWN, MONTANA.
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE MAYOR AND COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF LEWISTOWN, That:
Section 1. From and after the date of passage of this Ordinance the Municipal Code of the City of Lewistown, prepared by Sterling Codifiers, Inc., and
hereby approved and accepted shall be the Official Code of all Ordinances of a general and permanent character of the City.
Section 2. There is hereby adopted, as a method of perpetual codification, the loose leaf type of binding together with the continuous supplement service
whereby each newly adopted Ordinance of a general nature, amending, altering, adding to, or deleting provisions of the Municipal Code is identified by the
proper catch line, and following preparation by Sterling Codifiers, Inc., is inserted in the proper place in each of the official copies. Each such insertion shall
be made within thirty (30) days following the date of adoption by the Council, and each new provision shall become effective upon such insertion.
Section 3. At least one (1) official copy of said official Municipal Code of the City of Lewistown shall at all times be on file and available for inspection in the
office of the Clerk.
Passed and Approved by the Mayor and Council this 4th day of December, 1961.
Title 1
ADMINISTRATIVE
Chapter 1
MUNICIPAL CODE
1-1-1: TITLE:
This compilation and codification of the general ordinances of the city of Lewistown is hereby declared to be and shall hereafter constitute the official
municipal code of the city of Lewistown. Any reference to the number of any section contained herein shall be understood to refer to the position of the
same under its appropriate title heading, its chapter heading, and its section heading, and to the general penalty clause relating thereto, as well as to the
section itself, when reference is made in this code by title in any legal document. In any complaint for the violation of any of the provisions of this code, a
reference to such code provision by its section number shall be sufficient. (1961 Code)
1-1-2: ACCEPTANCE:
This municipal code of the city as hereby presented in printed form, shall hereafter be received without further proof in all courts and in all administrative
tribunals of this state as the ordinances of a general and permanent effect of the city. (1961 Code)
1-1-3: AMENDMENTS:
Any ordinance amending this code shall set forth the title, chapter and section number of the section or sections to be amended, and this shall constitute a
sufficient compliance with any statutory requirement pertaining to the amendment or revision by ordinance of any part of this code. All such amendments
or revisions by ordinance shall be immediately forwarded to the codifiers and the said ordinance material shall be prepared for insertion in its proper place
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 2/283
in each copy of this code. Each such replacement page shall be properly identified and shall be inserted in each copy of this code within thirty (30) days
from the date of its final passage. (1961 Code)
1-1-4: CONSTRUCTION OF WORDS:
Whenever any word in any section of this code importing the plural number is used, in describing or referring to any matters, parties, or persons, any
single matter, party, or person shall be deemed to be included, although distributive words may not have been used.
When any subject matter, party or person is referred to in this code by words importing the singular number only, or the masculine gender, several matters,
parties, or persons and females, as well as males, and bodies corporate shall be deemed to be included. Provided, that these rules of construction shall
not be applied to any section of this code which contains any express provision excluding such construction or where the subject matter or content may be
repugnant thereto. (1961 Code)
1-1-5: DEFINITIONS:
KNOWINGLY: A person acts knowingly with respect to conduct or to a circumstance described by an ordinance defining an offense when he is aware of
his conduct or that the circumstance exists. A person acts knowingly with respect to the result of conduct described by a statute defining an offense when
he is aware that it is highly probable that such result will be caused by his conduct. When knowledge of the existence of a particular fact is an element of
an offense, such knowledge is established if a person is aware of a high probability of its existence. Equivalent terms such as "knowing" or "with
knowledge" have the same meaning.
NEGLIGENTLY: A person acts negligently with respect to a result or to a circumstance described by an ordinance defining an offense when he
consciously disregards a risk that the result will occur or that the circumstance exists or when he disregards a risk of which he should be aware that the
result will occur or that the circumstance exists. The risk must be of such a nature and degree that to disregard it involves a gross deviation from the
standard of conduct that a reasonable person would observe in the actor's situation. "Gross deviation" means a deviation that is considerably greater than
lack of ordinary care. Relevant terms such as "negligent" and "with negligence" have the same meaning.
OFFICER: Shall include officers and boards in charge of departments and the members of such boards, and such reference as use of the word "city" shall
mean this municipality, "clerk" or "treasurer" and others shall mean the city clerk or city treasurer, as the case may be applicable.
OWNER: Applied to a building or land shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, joint tenant or lessee of the whole or of a part of such
building or land.
PERSON: To include any person, firm, association or corporation, or any organization of any kind.
PERSONAL PROPERTY: Includes every description of money, goods, chattels, effects, evidence of rights in action, and all written instruments by which
any pecuniary obligation, right or title to property is created, acknowledged, transferred, increased, defeated, discharged or diminished, and every right or
interest therein.
PURPOSELY: A person acts purposely with respect to a result or to conduct described by an ordinance defining an offense if it is his conscious object to
engage in that conduct or to cause that result. When a particular purpose is an element of an offense, the element is established although such purpose is
conditional, unless the condition negatives the harm or evil sought to be prevented by the law defining the offense. Equivalent terms such as "purpose"
and "with the purpose" have the same meaning.
STREETS: Includes alleys, lanes, courts, boulevards, public ways, public squares, public places, sidewalks, public parking areas, within the corporate
limits of the city and contained within the limits of the Lewistown City-County airport.
TENANT OR OCCUPANT: Applied to a building or land shall include any person who occupies the whole or any part of such building or land whether
alone or with others.
WRITTEN AND IN WRITING: May include printing. (1961 Code; amd. Ord. 1590, 10-1-1990)
Words prohibiting anything being done, except in accordance with a license or permit or authority from a board or officer, shall be construed as giving such
board or officer power to license or permit or authorize such thing to be done. (1961 Code)
If, in this code the term "wilfully" is used or found, such word shall be construed and interpreted in accordance with the definition of "purposely" as
contained herein. (Ord. 1590, 10-1-1990)
1-1-6: INTERPRETATIONS:
In the determination of the provisions of each section of this code the following rules shall be observed:
(A) Intent To Defraud: Whenever an intent to defraud is required in order to constitute an offense, it shall be sufficient if an intent appears to defraud any
person.
(B) Liability Of Employers And Agents: When the provisions of any section of this code prohibit the commission of an act, not only the person actually
doing the prohibited act or omitting the directed act, but also the employer and all other persons concerned with or in aiding or abetting the person shall
be guilty of the offense described and liable to the penalty set forth. (1961 Code)
Chapter 2
SAVING CLAUSE
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 3/283
1-2-1: REPEAL OF GENERAL ORDINANCES:
All general ordinances of the city, the subject matter of which is covered, contained or modified by this code, and passed prior to the adoption of this code
are hereby repealed, except such as are referred to herein as being still in force or are by necessary implication herein reserved from repeal (subject to the
saving clauses contained herein), from which are excluded the following ordinances which are not hereby repealed: tax levy ordinances, appropriation
ordinances, ordinances relating to boundaries and annexations, franchise ordinances and other ordinances granting special rights to persons, contract
ordinances and ordinances authorizing the execution of a contract or the issuance of warrants, salary ordinances, ordinances establishing, naming, or
vacating streets, alleys or other public places, improvement ordinances, bond ordinances, ordinances relating to elections, ordinances relating to the
transfer or acceptance of real estate by or from the city, and all special ordinances. (1961 Code)
1-2-2: PUBLIC UTILITY ORDINANCES:
No ordinance relating to railroads or railroad crossings with streets and other public ways, or relating to the conduct, duties, service or rates of public
utilities shall be repealed by virtue of the adoption of this code or by virtue of section 1-2-1 of this chapter, exception as this code may contain provision for
such matters, in which case this code shall be considered as amending such ordinance or ordinances in respect of such provisions only. (1961 Code)
1-2-3: PENDING SUITS:
No new ordinance shall be construed or held to repeal a former ordinance, whether such former ordinance is expressly repealed or not, as to any offense
committed against such former ordinance or as to any act done, any penalty, forfeiture or punishment so incurred, or any right accrued or claim arising
under the former ordinance, or in any way whatever to affect any such offense or act so committed or so done, or any penalty, forfeiture or punishment so
incurred or any right accrued or claim arising before the new ordinance takes effect, save only that the proceedings thereafter shall conform to the
ordinance in force at the time of such proceedings, so far as practicable. If any penalty, forfeiture or punishment be mitigated by any provision of a new
ordinance, such provision may be, by the consent of the party affected, applied to any judgment announced after the new ordinance takes effect.
This section shall extend to all repeals, either by express words or implication, whether the repeal is in the ordinance making any new provisions upon the
same subject or in any other ordinance.
Nothing contained in this or the preceding section shall be construed as abating any action now pending under or by virtue of any general ordinance of the
city herein repealed; or as discontinuing, abating, modifying or altering any penalty accrued or to accrue, or as affecting the liability of any person or as
waiving any right of the city under any ordinance or provision thereof in force at the time of adoption of this code. (1961 Code)
Chapter 3
GENERAL PENALTY
1-3-1: GENERAL PENALTY:
Any person convicted of a misdemeanor or a violation of any section of this code wherein a specific penalty is not imposed, shall be fined in a sum not
exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) for one offense, or confined in the municipal or county jail not more than six (6) months, or both such fine and
imprisonment, recoverable with costs, and in default of payment of any fine imposed shall be imprisoned in the municipal or county jail for a period of one
day for each ten dollars ($10.00) of such fine. Whenever a defendant is sentenced to imprisonment or is imprisoned for nonpayment of a fine or costs, he
may be put to work for the benefit of the municipality for the term of his imprisonment. (Ord. 1591, 10-1-1990)
1-3-2: TO WHAT ACTS PENALTY SHALL ATTACH:
Any person who shall commit any unlawful act, or who fails to perform any act or discharge any obligation or duty required by or imposed upon him by any
of the provisions of this code shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and shall be subject to the penalty fixed for the violation with like effect as if such
penalty were specifically declared in the section forbidding such act or declaring the same to be unlawful or prescribing the duty or imposing the obligation
and where any duty is prescribed or obligation imposed, or where any act which is of a continuing nature is forbidden or declared to be unlawful, a
separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues.
In all cases where the same offense is made punishable or is created by different clauses or sections of this code the prosecuting officer may elect under
which to proceed; but not more than one recovery shall be had against the same person for the same offense; provided, that the revocation of a license or
permit shall not be considered a recovery or penalty so as to bar any other penalty being enforced. (1961 Code)
1-3-3: LIABILITY OF OFFICERS:
No provision of this code designating the duties of any officer or employee shall be so construed as to make such officer or employee liable for any fine or
penalty provided for a failure to perform such duty, unless the intention of the commission to impose such fine or penalty on such officer or employee is
specifically and clearly expressed in the section creating the duty. (1961 Code; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
Chapter 4
CITY LIMITS
1-4-1: OFFICIAL CITY LIMITS:

https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 4/283
The city limits shall be the outermost limits of the outermost additions duly and regularly annexed to the city according to the laws of the state or any
addition or subdivision which has been generally considered to be an addition or subdivision to the city for twenty five (25) or more years last past; or any
addition to the city duly and regularly annexed after the enactment of this code. (1961 Code)
1-4-2: OFFICIAL MAP:
The exact legal description of all additions or subdivisions referred to above shall be as shown on the official plats thereof on file and of record in the office
of the county clerk and recorder, except for the so called "P and D addition", officially known as the report of the commissioners on partition and
distribution in the matter of the estate of Francis E. Janeaux, deceased, which said plat is on file and of record in the office of the clerk of the district court
of the tenth judicial district of the state of Montana, in and for the county of Fergus. (1961 Code)
Chapter 5
WARDS
1-5-1: DIVISIONS:
The city shall be divided into three (3) wards for the purpose of municipal government. (1961 Code)
1-5-2: FIRST WARD:
All that portion of the city lying and being northerly of Main Street and westerly of Fourth Avenue to the truck bypass road to First Street; southerly from
Main Street and westerly of Ninth Avenue to Little Casino Creek as shown on the official ward boundary map of the city shall constitute the first ward. (Ord.
1615, 1-18-1994)
1-5-3: SECOND WARD:
All that portion of the city lying and being northerly of Main Street and easterly of Fourth Avenue to the truck bypass to First Street; southerly of Main Street
and easterly of Third Avenue as shown on the official ward boundary map of the city shall constitute the second ward. (Ord. 1615, 1-18-1994)
1-5-4: THIRD WARD:
All that portion of the city lying and being southerly of Main Street and westerly of Third Avenue to Ninth Avenue to Little Casino Creek and southerly from
Little Casino Creek as shown on the official ward boundary map of the city shall constitute the third ward. (Ord. 1615, 1-18-1994)
1-5-5: OFFICIAL WARD BOUNDARY MAP:
The city is hereby divided into three (3) ward districts as shown on the official ward boundary map, which is hereby adopted by reference to be part of this
title.
The official ward boundary map shall be identified by the signature of the mayor attested by the city clerk, except that any official ward boundary map
prepared after January 1, 1998, shall be signed by the city manager and attested by the city clerk. It shall bear the words:
The Official Ward Boundary Map of the City of Lewistown, Montana.
(Ord. 1662, 1-3-2000)
Chapter 6
CITY MANAGER
1-6-1: APPOINTMENT:
The manager, who shall be the chief executive and chief administrative officer of the city, shall be appointed by the commission for an indefinite term on
the basis of merit only and may be removed only by the affirmative vote of four (4) members of the commission. (Ord. 1663, 1-3-2000)
1-6-2: DUTIES:
The manager shall:
(A) Enforce laws, the city charter, and resolutions;
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 5/283
(B) Perform the duties required by the city charter, ordinance, or resolution;
(C) Administer the affairs of the city government;
(D) Direct, supervise, and administer all departments, agencies, and offices of the city except as otherwise provided by law, the city charter or ordinance;
(E) Carry out policies established by the commission;
(F) Prepare the commission agenda;
(G) Recommend measures to the commission;
(H) Report to the commission on the affairs and financial condition of the city government;
(I) Execute bonds, notes, contracts, and written obligations of the commission, subject to the approval of the commission;
(J) Report to the commission as the commission may require;
(K) Attend commission meetings and may take part in the discussion, but may not vote;
(L) Prepare and present the budget to the commission for its approval and execute the budget adopted by the commission;
(M) Appoint, suspend, and remove all employees of the city except as otherwise provided by law or ordinance;
(N) Appoint members of temporary advisory committees established by the manager. (Ord. 1663, 1-3-2000)
1-6-3: ADMINISTRATIVE DUTIES:
Employees appointed by the manager and his or her subordinates shall be administratively responsible to the manager. Neither the commission nor any of
its members may dictate the appointment or removal of any employee whom the manager or any subordinates are empowered to appoint. Except for the
purpose of inquiry or investigation under the city charter, the commission or its members shall deal with the city employees who are subject to the direction
and supervision of the manager solely through the manager, and neither the commission nor its members may give orders to any such employees, either
publicly or privately. (Ord. 1663, 1-3-2000)
1-6-4: COMPENSATION:
The compensation of the manager shall be set by resolution of the city commission. (Ord. 1663, 1-3-2000)
Chapter 7
CITY COMMISSION
1-7-1: DUTIES OF THE CITY COMMISSION:
Commissioners as members of the city commission, the legislative and policy making branch of the government of the municipality, shall devote so much
of their time to the duties of their office as an efficient and faithful discharge thereof may require. They shall attend all meetings of the city commission
unless lawfully excused therefrom, and perform all duties which by the nature of their office they should reasonably perform, such as passing of
ordinances, resolutions, and the investigation and study of work done for the municipality according to the character of committee upon which they may
severally be appointed. (Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
1-7-2: COMPOSITION:
The city commission shall consist of seven (7) members, two (2) of whom shall be elected from each of three (3) wards and one who shall be elected at
large. Each city commission member, except the one member at large, must be a resident of the ward from which the member is elected, and reside
continuously in such ward during that member's term of office. The city commission member elected at large may reside within any ward in the city. (Ord.
1664, 1-3-2000)
1-7-3: TERM:
Members of the city commission shall be elected for four (4) year overlapping terms of office or until their successors are elected and qualified. (Ord. 1664,
1-3-2000)
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 6/283
1-7-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
(A) The city commission shall be the legislative and policy determining body of the city. All governing powers of the city shall be vested in the city
commission except as otherwise provided by law or the city charter, and the city commission shall provide for the exercise thereof and for the
performance of all duties and obligations imposed by law or the charter.
(B) All members of boards, other than temporary advisory committees established by the manager, shall be appointed by the city commission. (Ord. 1664,
1-3-2000)
1-7-5: VACANCY; HOW FILLED:
A commissioner may be removed from office by a finding, adopted by the affirmative vote of four (4) commissioners, that the office has become vacant as
prescribed by section 7-4-4111, Montana Code Annotated, or by the recall of the commissioner by the electors of Lewistown, as prescribed by law. In the
event an office of commissioner shall become vacant the position shall be considered open and subject to nomination and election at the next general
municipal election, except the term of office shall be limited to the unexpired term of the person who originally created the vacancy. Pending such election
and qualification the city commission shall appoint within thirty (30) days of the vacancy, by affirmative vote of four (4) city commission members, a person
possessing the qualifications for office required by law to hold the office until the successor is elected and qualified. (Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
1-7-6: TIME AND PLACE OF MEETING:
The city commission shall hold regular sessions in the city commission chambers on the first and third Mondays of each month at a time to be determined
by the city commission. Should any scheduled meeting fall on a legal holiday, such meeting shall be held on the next day at such time as the city
commission may prescribe. (Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
1-7-7: ELECT CHAIRMAN OF THE CITY COMMISSION:
At the time of taking office, the city commission shall elect one of the members of the city commission who shall be the chairman of the city commission
and who shall preside at all meetings of the city commission; and, in the absence of the chairman of the city commission, to elect one of their own body to
occupy this place temporarily, who shall be styled acting chairman of the city commission. (Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
1-7-8: LEGISLATIVE ACTION:
The affirmative vote of four (4) members of the city commission shall be required for all official actions of the city commission. A minimum of four (4) city
commission members must be present when official actions are taken by the city commission. (Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
1-7-9: PROCEDURE:
The city commission shall establish its rules of procedure and the time and place of meetings by resolution. (Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
1-7-10: COMPENSATION:
The compensation of the city commission shall be set by resolution of the city commission. (Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
1-7-11: FORM AND PROCEDURES OF RESOLUTIONS:
All resolutions presented to the city commission shall comply with the following:
(A) Resolutions shall be identified by number.
(B) Resolutions shall have a title, which shall clearly express its purpose or subject. Resolutions shall contain only one purpose or subject.
(C) The subject or purpose of a resolution shall be explained or described in one or more paragraphs; each paragraph beginning with the word, "whereas".
(D) Immediately following the descriptive or explanatory paragraphs, there shall be one or more paragraphs stating the action taken by the city
commission; such paragraphs shall begin with the words "Now therefore, be it resolved".
(E) Upon passage and approval, all resolutions shall be entered in the minutes and signed and dated by the chairman or person acting in that position,
and the city clerk shall attest such due passage and approval. (Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
1-7-12: EFFECTIVE DATE OF RESOLUTIONS:
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 7/283
All resolutions, unless otherwise specified within a resolution, shall be effective immediately upon passage and approval and due execution. (Ord. 1664, 1-
3-2000)
1-7-13: REPORTS TO THE CITY COMMISSION:
The city commission may require the city manager to submit written reports on any subject or activity within the city. The city commission may prescribe
the form and substance of any such report, and may require reports on a periodic basis. (Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
Chapter 8
CITY CLERK
1-8-1: OFFICE OF CITY CLERK:
The city manager shall appoint a city clerk who shall keep a history of the city of Lewistown, maintain public records and perform such other duties by
direction of the city manager or as required by law. (Ord. 1665, 4-17-2000)
Chapter 9
LEGAL DEPARTMENT
1-9-1: LEGAL DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
A department of law is hereby created. The city manager shall appoint a city attorney, qualified under Montana law, to administer the department of law.
The department shall render legal services in all civil and administrative matters for the city and prosecute all charges in city court, and perform such other
duties by direction of the city manager or as required by law. (Ord. 1666, 4-17-2000)
Chapter 10
POLICE DEPARTMENT
1-10-1: POLICE DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
A police department is hereby created. The city manager shall appoint a police chief to administer the police department. The department shall enforce the
laws of the city and state to protect life and property, to control traffic, and perform such other duties by direction of the city manager or as required by law.
(Ord. 1667, 4-17-2000)
Chapter 11
FIRE DEPARTMENT
1-11-1: FIRE DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
A fire department is hereby created. The city manager shall appoint a fire chief to administer the fire department. The department shall provide firefighting,
rescue operation, fire investigation and fire prevention services for the city and perform such other duties by direction of the city manager or as required by
law. (Ord. 1668, 4-17-2000)
Chapter 12
FISCAL CONTROL DEPARTMENT
1-12-1: DEPARTMENT CREATED:
A fiscal control department is hereby created. The city manager shall appoint a director to administer the department. The department shall render
budgeting, data processing, accounting, revenue collection, including utility billing, accounts payable, investment services and special project functions for
the city and perform such other duties by direction of the city manager or as required by law. (Ord. 1677, 4-17-2000)
1-12-2: BOND:
Before assuming any duties, the director shall post a bond in the sum of twenty five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) for faithful performance of duty. (Ord.
1677, 4-17-2000)

Chapter 13
PARK AND RECREATION DEPARTMENT
1-13-1: DEPARTMENT CREATED:
A park and recreation department is hereby created. The city manager shall appoint a director to administer the park and recreation department. The
department shall manage all parks, recreational facilities and programs and perform such other duties by direction of the city manager or as required by
law. (Ord. 1678, 4-17-2000)
Chapter 14
BUILDING INSPECTOR
1-14-1: APPOINTMENT:
The city manager may appoint some suitable person as building inspector who shall be ex officio inspector of public sewers, plumbing, gas connections
and electric wiring. (Ord. 1670, 1-3-2000)
1-14-2: DUTIES:
It shall be the duty of the building inspector from time to time to issue permits for any and all connections to be made with the public sewers, permits for
gas connections, plumbing permits, building permits and electric wiring for all buildings where permits have been issued and wherein wiring will be done
and when such permits have been issued to make the proper instructions as required by law. (Ord. 1670, 1-3-2000)
1-14-3: ADDITIONAL POSITION:
It shall be permissible for the person so appointed as building inspector to also hold some other position, either remunerative or otherwise, in the city or its
government or departments, providing there is no conflict between the duties of the two (2) positions. (Ord. 1670, 1-3-2000)
Chapter 15
HEALTH AND SANITARY OFFICERS
(Rep. by Ord. 1671, 1-3-2000)
Chapter 16
PUBLIC WORKS DEPARTMENT
1-16-1: PUBLIC WORKS DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
A public works department is hereby created. The city manager shall appoint a director to administer the public works department. The department shall
administer capital improvements, maintenance, operations, and utilities and perform such other duties by direction of the city manager or as required by
law. (Ord. 1672, 4-17-2000)
Chapter 17
BONDS OF OFFICERS
1-17-1: BONDS:
All elected or appointed city officers and employees shall be bonded in accordance with the sums provided in this chapter, and shall be in a form and
contain the conditions as required by the laws of the state of Montana. The city may require bonding in specific amounts for individual officers or
employees, or may provide for a blanket bond to cover several officers or employees. The city commission shall pass upon and approve all such bonds,
and may require further any additional bonding or other security at any time from any city officer or employee when, for any reason, the bond theretofore
filed by such officer or employee shall be deemed insufficient. (Ord. 1673, 1-3-2000)
1-17-2: BOND AMOUNTS:
All elected or appointed city officers and employees shall be bonded in the amount of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00); except that the city treasurer shall
be bonded in the amount of twenty five thousand dollars ($25,000.00). (Ord. 1673, 1-3-2000)

1-17-3: BOND PREMIUMS:
The premiums for all bonds required by this chapter shall be paid by the city, and such shall be a proper charge against the general fund budget or other
budget of the city where the officer or employee renders service. (Ord. 1673, 1-3-2000)
Chapter 18
CORPORATE SEAL
1-18-1: CORPORATE SEAL; DESIGN:
The corporate seal of the city shall be circular in form with inner circles of rope design. The outer circle shall be one and eleven-sixteenths inches (111/16")
in diameter and the inner circle shall be one and one-eighth inches (11/8") in diameter. It shall bear upon the upper portion of the space between the inner
and outer circles the words, "CITY OF LEWISTOWN" and upon the lower portion of said space the words, "FERGUS CO. STATE OF MONT." Upon the
upper portion of the space within the inner circle shall be the word, "OFFICIAL", in the middle of the space within the inner circle shall appear a suitable
spacing device or figure, and in the lower portion of said space the word, "SEAL". All lettering shall be in a suitable gothic style type.
A facsimile of the above described seal is as follows:
(1961 Code)
Chapter 19
CITY COURT; JUDGE
1-19-1: CITY COURT:
There is hereby established within the city a city court pursuant to the provisions of title 3, chapter 11 of the Montana Code Annotated; said court to have
all powers, duties, authorities, responsibilities and jurisdiction therein provided. (Ord. 1474, 6-3-1981)
1-19-2: CITY JUDGE:
(A) There is hereby created the position of city judge. Upon resolution by the city commission, the board of county commissioners for Fergus County may
be requested to constitute a justice's court in the city. Once approved by the county commissioners by resolution, the justice of the peace of the court
so constituted shall act as the city judge. The effective date of the position of city judge created by this subsection (A) shall be January 3, 1994. (Ord.
1613, 8-16-1993; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 10/283
(B) In the event a vacancy in the position of city judge is not filled as provided in subsection (A) of this section, the position shall be filled by election.
(C) The city judge shall hold office pursuant to, and have all powers, authorities, responsibilities and duties of a city judge pursuant to the provisions of title
3, chapters 1 and 11 (part 2), and all other sections applicable thereto of the Montana Code Annotated. (Ord. 1613, 8-16-1993)
1-19-3: CITY COURT PROCEDURES:
Said city court shall be and is hereby granted full power, authority and duty to utilize those procedures authorized, required and permitted pursuant to the
provisions of title 3, chapter 11, part 3 of the Montana Code Annotated; and all other specifically applicable sections thereof. (Ord. 1474, 6-3-1981)
1-19-4: QUALIFICATIONS OF CITY JUDGE:
The city judge shall be qualified in the same manner as are justices of the peace as provided under title 3, chapter 10, part 2 of the Montana Code
Annotated.
The presiding officer of the city court shall be the city judge. If none is elected or appointed by the municipality, the justice of the peace of the township in
which the municipality is situated shall be the city judge. (Ord. 1474, 6-3-1981)
1-19-5: CITY JUDGE TO KEEP DOCKET:
The city judge shall keep a docket of proceedings in said court; in it shall be entered, daily as they occur, a synopsis of the proceedings in each case, from
the arrest or complaint to final judgment, and an entry of the appeal, if any appeal be taken. (Ord. 1474, 6-3-1981)
1-19-6: PROCEDURE IN INSTITUTING AN ACTION:
Actions for the violation of any law of the city or state within the jurisdiction thereof must be commenced in one of the following methods:
(A) First: When the offense is committed in the presence of the chief of police or any police officer, he may arrest the offender without a warrant and bring
him forthwith before the police judge.
(B) Second: In all cases a complaint must be filed and verified by the party making the same, which shall contain the name of the party to be arrested, if
known, and if not known, the complaint may designate him by any other name. The complaint shall also contain a brief statement of the acts
constituting the offense for which the person is arrested, with the date of the offense, if known, and a reference to the title, chapter and section number
he is charged with violating. (Ord. 1474, 6-3-1981)
1-19-7: ISSUANCE OF WARRANT:
Upon filing the complaint, the city judge shall, if the complaint charges the violation of any city or state law, issue a warrant to any police officer, and the
officer must serve the warrant by taking the defendant into custody and bringing him before the city judge. (Ord. 1474, 6-3-1981)
1-19-8: DUTY OF OFFICER ARRESTING:
The officer making the arrest shall make due return thereof on his warrant; and if any officer arrests a person without a warrant, said officer shall forthwith
file in the city court a complaint against the person arrested as provided in this chapter. (Ord. 1474, 6-3-1981)
1-19-9: BAIL:
Any person arrested for a violation of a city or state law may be admitted to bail by giving bonds with security, to be approved by the city judge, and if he
cannot act, then by the chief of police, in such sum as he or either of them may specify. The bond shall be conditioned that the defendant will appear at the
time named therein before the city court and answer to the charge for which he has been arrested. The bond shall be filed in the city court and if the
defendant fails to appear at the time mentioned in the bond, the city judge may declare the bond forfeited.
Any person arrested for the violation of a city or state law, in lieu of the bond mentioned in this section, may deposit with the police judge or chief of police,
such sum as may be specified by either of said officers, who shall give to the person arrested a receipt for the money so deposited in lieu of bail; if the
person depositing the money appears before the city court at the time of the first setting thereof after the money was so deposited, the said money shall be
returned to the person depositing it, but if he fails to appear, the city judge shall declare the deposit forfeited to the city and cause the same to be paid into
the treasury. (Ord. 1474, 6-3-1981)
1-19-10: POWER OF CITY JUDGE:
Any person found guilty of a violation of any city or state law within the jurisdiction of the city court shall be punishable by fine or imprisonment upon the
police judge rendering judgment that the defendant pay such fine, or be so imprisoned in the city jail facility, or may be imprisoned in the city jail until the
fine be satisfied, in the proportion of one day's imprisonment for every two dollars ($2.00) of the fine or as otherwise provided by state law. In all cases
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 11/283
where a fine is imposed the police judge shall issue a warrant of commitment for the number of days the defendant is to be confined in pursuance of this
chapter. (Ord. 1474, 6-3-1981)
1-19-11: RECEIPTS MUST BE MADE IN TRIPLICATE:
When a fine imposed by the city judge for the violation of a city law be paid in money, he shall issue a receipt therefor in triplicate on blanks to be furnished
him by the clerk, one receipt to be given to the person paying the fine, another to accompany the police judge's monthly report to the council, and the other
to remain with the city court as part of its report. (Ord. 1474, 6-3-1981)
1-19-12: REPORT FILED WITH CLERK:
The city judge shall make out and file in the office of the clerk, monthly, a report of the number of cases tried, the persons convicted, the fine and costs
imposed, and whether the same has been paid, the number of days any person convicted has been sentenced to confinement in the city jail facility, by the
city judge, and before filing the same, he shall pay over to the treasurer all monies received in payment of fines and make a receipt therefor, which receipt
shall be attached to the report filed with the clerk. (Ord. 1474, 6-3-1981)
1-19-13: MANNER OF CONDUCTING TRIALS:
All proceedings in the city court shall be conducted in the same manner as are trials in criminal cases before justices of the peace under the laws of the
state, and all persons tried before the police court shall have the same remedies and rights of appeals as now are or may hereafter be prescribed by law in
criminal cases before justices of the peace. The police judge shall have the same right and authority to punish for contempt and maintain order in his court
that justices of the peace have and as provided in the Montana Code Annotated. But nothing in this section provided shall be construed as allowed any
party a change of venue in cases of a violation of any city law, both civil and criminal, which must be prosecuted in the name of the city. (Ord. 1474, 6-3-
1981)
Chapter 20
OFFICIAL NEWSPAPER
1-20-1: OFFICIAL NEWSPAPER DESIGNATED:
The Lewistown News Argus, a newspaper printed and published in the city of Lewistown, Fergus County, Montana, and of general circulation in said city
and county, be, and it is hereby designated as the official newspaper for the city of Lewistown. (Ord. 1353, 9-5-1972)
Chapter 21
SALARIES
(Rep. by Ord. 1674, 1-3-2000)
Chapter 22
PERSONNEL
1-22-1: SICK LEAVE:
Each employee of the city who shall have been in continuous employment and service of the city for a period of one year from the date of employment is
entitled to and shall be granted sick leave at the rate of one working day for each month of service. The following rules and regulations shall be observed:
(A) Such sick leave may accumulate indefinitely so long as the person is employed by the city.
(B) An employee who is separated from the service of the city, voluntarily or otherwise, is not entitled to any cash compensation whatsoever for unused
sick leave.
(C) An employee who is absent from work for more than two (2) days by reason of illness shall furnish a medical certification to the clerk, signed by a
physician, attesting to the illness of such employee.
(D) Absence from employment by reason of illness shall not be chargeable against annual vacation leave; provided, however, if the sick leave of the
employee is used up entirely, said employee can elect to use annual vacation leave up to the amount due. Upon such election, said employee can be
compensated to the extent of such annual vacation leave.
(E) Sick leave shall not accrue during a leave of absence without pay, the duration of which exceeds fifteen (15) days.
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 12/283
The term "employee" as used herein does not refer to or include an elected city official. (Ord. 1299, 3-3-1969)
1-22-2: OLD AGE AND SURVIVORS' INSURANCE COVERAGE:
The city is hereby authorized to execute and deliver to the social security division, public employees' retirement system, state of Montana, a plan, or plans,
and agreement requiring under section 3 of said enabling act, to extend coverage to employees and officers of the city and do all other things necessary to
effectuate coverage of employees and officers under the old age and survivors' insurance system.
The clerk is hereby authorized to establish a system of payroll deductions to be matched by payments by the city to be made into the contribution fund of
the social security act through the public employees' retirement system, and to make charges of this contribution to the fund, or funds, from which wage or
such payments are issued to employees of the city. Such payments are to be in accordance with the provisions of section 1400 of the federal insurance
contribution act on all services which constitute employment within the meaning of that act. Payments made to the social security division, PERS, state of
Montana, shall be due and payable on or before the fifteenth day of the month immediately following the completed calendar quarter, and such payments
which are delinquent shall bear interest at the rate of one-half of one percent (0.5%) per month until such time as payments are made.
Appropriation is hereby made from the proper fund, or funds, or the city in the necessary amount to pay into the contribution fund as provided in section 5
of the enabling act, or section 6(c), chapter 270, 1955 Session Laws of Montana, and in accordance with the plan, or plans and agreement. Authority is
given to the city manager and the clerk of the city to enter into an agreement with the public employees' retirement system of the state of Montana, which
agreement shall be in accordance with chapter 44, 1953 Session Laws of Montana, or chapter 270, 1955 Session Laws of Montana, and with paragraph
218 of the social security act. Such plan and agreement shall provide that the participation of this city shall be in effect as of January 1, 1975. (Ord. 1442,
10-16-1978)
1-22-3: CIVIL ACTION; INDEMNIFICATION:
That in any civil action brought against any public official or employee of the city alleging a violation of initiative 75, the city shall defend the action on
behalf of the official or employee and indemnify the official or employee for any liability resulting from the alleged violation of initiative 75. (Ord. 1654, 1-4-
1999)
Chapter 23
CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT PROGRAM
1-23-1: ESTABLISHMENT OF CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT PROGRAM AND FUND:
There is hereby established a program within the city known as "the capital improvement program". This program is developed pursuant to the authority
found in section 7-6-4134, Montana Code Annotated. There is also hereby established a fund to be known as "the capital improvement program fund". The
funds or monies which shall from time to time be placed into the capital improvement program fund shall be managed and invested in accordance with
section 7-6-4135, Montana Code Annotated. (Ord. 1586, 6-18-1990)
1-23-2: ADMINISTRATION:
The city manager shall be charged with overall administration of the capital improvement program and the capital improvement program fund. The duties
and responsibilities of administering such program and fund may be delegated to such officers and employees as the city manager sees fit. (Ord. 1586, 6-
18-1990; amd. Ord. 1663, 1-3-2000)
Appropriation and expenditure of money to and from the capital improvement program fund shall be by the city commission in accordance with the above
cited state statutes, the municipal budget law, and any all other applicable laws, rules or regulations. (Ord. 1586, 6-18-1990; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
1-23-3: APPROPRIATIONS:
The city commission may, on an annual basis, appropriate money to be placed in the capital improvement program fund. The amount of any annual
appropriation shall not exceed five percent (5%) of the money received by the city from and as a part of the all purpose mill levy. (Ord. 1586, 6-18-1990;
amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
1-23-4: EXPENDITURES:
All of the money contained in or appropriated to the capital improvement program fund is hereby earmarked for the replacement or acquisition of property,
plant, and equipment costing in excess of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) and with a life expectancy of five (5) years or more. (Ord. 1586, 6-18-1990)
The city commission may on an annual basis and in accordance with the budgeting process, expend any portion or all of the money contained in the
capital improvement program fund for the purchase or acquisition of the items described above. Such money shall not be spent or expended otherwise.
(Ord. 1586, 6-18-1990; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
Eligible expenditures could consist not only of a single item of property, plant, and equipment costing greater than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00); but
could also consist of like items which individually cost less than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), but collectively cost greater than five thousand dollars
($5,000.00); provided, however that the individual like items are typically or usually replaced or acquired collectively. (Ord. 1586, 6-18-1990)
The eligibility of expenditures shall be in the sole discretion and judgment of the city commission. (Ord. 1586, 6-18-1990; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 13/283
1-23-5: INSTALLMENT PURCHASES:
Expenditures for any item of property, plant, and equipment may occur over a term of years as authorized by section 7-5-4306, Montana Code Annotated.
(Ord. 1586, 6-18-1990)
1-23-6: INVENTORY:
Each department head of the city and other persons in charge of or responsible for the care and maintenance of capital property, plant, or equipment,
shall, on or before November 1, 1990, provide to the city manager a written report on the inventory or items of capital property, plant, or equipment in their
charge, custody or care. The report shall identify each such item by manufacturer, model, serial number, or other descriptive or identifying information. As
to each item, the report shall state the date of acquisition, the cost at the time of acquisition, the estimated life of such item and the estimated cost of
annual or future repairs, the estimated or projected time of replacement and the cost thereof, and any other information deemed necessary or helpful. The
report shall also indicate the priorities of the department head or other person among the various items under his or her control and management. (Ord.
1586, 6-18-1990; amd. Ord. 1663, 1-3-2000)
1-23-7: ANNUAL ANALYSIS:
Each department head and other persons in charge of or responsible for the care and maintenance of capital property, plant, or equipment, shall, on April
1 of each year, submit a report in writing to the city manager and to members of the city commission. Such annual report shall describe any changes or
additions to the inventory report required in section 1-23-6 of this chapter. Such annual report shall further define or describe in detail the needs or
requests for replacement or acquisition of capital items for the coming fiscal year.
The city manager shall analyze the information in the annual reports provided for herein, and shall consider and gather any other information he deems
necessary. The city manager shall then, during the budgeting process present recommendations to the city commission regarding replacement or
acquisition of capital items. (Ord. 1586, 6-18-1990; amd. Ord. 1663, 1-3-2000; Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
If the city commission decides to expend funds from the capital improvement program fund, the annual budget shall specifically identify the capital item to
be replaced or acquired. (Ord. 1586, 6-18-1990; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
Title 2
COMMISSIONS AND BOARDS
Chapter 1
CITY-COUNTY PLANNING BOARD
2-1-1: CREATION OF BOARD:
There is hereby created a combined city and county planning board pursuant to and under the provisions of title 11, chapter 38, Revised Codes of
Montana, 1947, as amended by chapters 189 and 190 of the laws of the thirty ninth legislative assembly of the state of Montana, 1965, to be designated
and known as "the Lewistown city-county planning board". (Ord. 1232, 6-8-1965)
2-1-2: BOARD MEMBERSHIP:
A city-county planning board shall consist of not less than nine (9) members to be appointed as follows:
(A) Two (2) official members shall be appointed by the board of county commissioners who may in the discretion of the board of county commissioners be
employed by or hold public office in the county. (Ord. 1232, 6-8-1965)
(B) Two (2) official members shall be appointed by the city commission who may in the discretion of the city commission be employed by or hold public
office in the city. (Ord. 1232, 6-8-1965; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
(C) Two (2) citizen members to be appointed by the city manager of the city. (Ord. 1232, 6-8-1965; amd. Ord. 1663, 1-3-2000)
(D) Two (2) citizen members shall be appointed by the board of county commissioners. The two (2) members may reside outside the city limits but within
the jurisdictional area of the planning board. (Ord. 1232, 6-8-1965)
(E) The ninth member shall be selected by the eight (8) officers and citizen members hereinabove provided for with the consent and approval of the board
of county commissioners and the city commission. (Ord. 1232, 6-8-1965; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
2-1-3: TERM OF OFFICE:
The terms of the members who are officers of any governmental unit represented on the board shall be coextensive with their respective terms of office to
which they have been elected or appointed; the terms of the other members shall be two (2) years, except that the terms of the first members appointed
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 14/283
shall be fixed by agreement and rule of the governing bodies represented on the board for one or two (2) years in order that a minimum number of terms
shall expire in any year. Nothing herein contained shall prevent the reappointment of a member whose term has expired. (Ord. 1232, 6-8-1965)
2-1-4: VACANCIES:
Vacancies occurring on the board of official members and by death or resignation of citizen members, shall be filled by the governing bodies having
appointed them for the unexpired term. (Ord. 1232, 6-8-1965)
Vacancies occurring in citizen members on the board at the end of a term shall be filled alternately by the city manager and the board of county
commissioners, commencing with the city manager. (Ord. 1232, 6-8-1965; amd. Ord. 1663, 1-3-2000)
Absence from three (3) consecutive regular meetings of the board shall constitute a resignation from the board and upon request of the president such
vacancy shall be immediately filled as above set forth. (Ord. 1232, 6-8-1965)
2-1-5: QUALIFICATIONS OF CITIZEN MEMBERS:
The citizen members shall be qualified by knowledge and experience in matters relating to the development of the city and county. (Ord. 1232, 6-8-1965)
2-1-6: MEETINGS:
The board shall fix the time for holding regular meetings but it shall meet at least once each month during the year. (Ord. 1232, 6-8-1965)
2-1-7: SPECIAL MEETINGS:
Special meetings of the planning board may be called by the president or by two (2) members upon written request to the secretary. The secretary shall
send to all members, at least two (2) days in advance of a special meeting, a written notice fixing the time and place of the meeting.
Written notice of a special meeting is not required if the time of the special meeting has been fixed in a regular meeting, or if all members are present at
the special meeting. (Ord. 1232, 6-8-1965)
2-1-8: QUORUM; OFFICIAL ACTION:
A majority of members shall constitute a quorum; no action of the planning board is official, however, unless authorized by a majority of members of the
board at a regular or properly called special meeting. (Ord. 1232, 6-8-1965)
2-1-9: PRESIDENT AND VICE PRESIDENT:
As soon as practicable after their appointment, the board shall meet and organize by electing from its members a president and a vice president; and
thereafter at its first regular meeting in each year, the board shall elect from its members a president and a vice president. The vice president shall have
authority to act as president of the board during the absence or disability of the president. (Ord. 1232, 6-8-1965)
2-1-10: SECRETARY; CONTRACTS FOR SERVICES:
The board may appoint and prescribe the duties and fix the compensation of a secretary, and such employees as are necessary for the discharge of duties
and responsibilities of the board. (Ord. 1232, 6-8-1965)
2-1-11: JURISDICTIONAL AREA:
The jurisdictional area shall include the area within the incorporated limits of the city and such contiguous unincorporated area outside the city as bears
reasonable relation to the development of the city. The jurisdictional area shall not exceed more than four and one-half (41/2) miles beyond the city limits of
the city of Lewistown, Montana. (Ord. 1232, 6-8-1965)
2-1-12: BUDGET:
At the proper time as required by law the board shall submit to the county and the city a budget of its requirements for the fiscal year, which said budget
shall be approved by the board of county commissioners and the city commission. In case of a disagreement between said county and city, as to the
budget submitted, the same shall be submitted to a committee composed of the board of county commissioners and three (3) members of the city
commission, who shall then make such recommendations to their respective governmental units as may be agreed upon. (Ord. 1232, 6-8-1965; amd. Ord.
1664, 1-3-2000)
2-1-13: EXPENSES; PAYMENT:
All expenses of the board shall be contributed to by the county and the city in such proportions as may be agreed upon by the city commission and the
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 15/283
board of commissioners, but any funds so appropriated by the county shall be paid to the city treasurer who shall disburse the same as city funds. All
receipts of said board shall be paid to the city and county in the proportion so agreed upon. (Ord. 1232, 6-8-1965; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
2-1-14: POWERS:
The Lewistown city-county planning board shall possess and have all powers and authority granted by the provisions of title 11, chapter 38, Revised
Codes of Montana, 1947, as amended by chapters 189 and 190 of the laws of the thirty ninth legislative assembly of the state of Montana, 1965, and shall
perform all duties required thereunder. (Ord. 1232, 6-3-1965)
Chapter 2
POLICE COMMISSION
2-2-1: POLICE COMMISSION ESTABLISHED:
The city manager shall nominate and, with the consent of the city commission, appoint three (3) residents of Lewistown who shall have the qualifications
required by law to hold a municipal office therein and shall constitute a board to be known by the name of "police commission". (Ord. 1581, 5-7-1990; amd.
Ord. 1663, 1-3-2000; Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
2-2-2: TERMS AND COMPENSATION:
(A) The appointees to the police commission shall hold office for three (3) years, and one such member must be appointed annually at the first regular
meeting of the city commission in May of each year. However, a member serving on the police commission during a hearing or deciding of a case
under section 2-2-4 of this chapter shall continue to serve on the police commission for that case until a decision has been made; a new member may
not sit on the police commission for such business. (Ord. 1581, 5-7-1990; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
(B) The compensation of the members of such board shall be ten dollars ($10.00) per day, not to exceed fifty dollars ($50.00) per month for any month for
each member. (Ord. 1581, 5-7-1990)
2-2-3: EXAMINATION OF APPLICANTS FOR POLICE FORCE:
It shall be the duty of the police commission to examine all applicants whose applications have been referred to the police commission as to their age,
legal, mental, moral and physical qualifications and their ability to fill the office as a member of the police force. It shall also be the duty of the police
commission, subject to the approval of the city manager, to make such rules regarding such examinations not inconsistent with this chapter or the laws of
the state. (Ord. 1581, 5-7-1990; amd. Ord. 1663, 1-3-2000)
2-2-4: HEARING AND DECIDING CHARGES AGAINST POLICEMEN:
(A) The police commission shall have the jurisdiction and it shall be its duty to hear, try and decide all charges brought by any person or persons against
any member or officer of the police department, including any charge that such member or officer:
1. Is incompetent or has become incapacitated, by age, disease, or otherwise is unable to discharge the duties of his office;
2. Has been guilty of neglect of duty, of misconduct in his office, or of conduct unbecoming a police officer;
3. Has been found guilty of any crime; or
4. Whose conduct has been such as to bring reproach upon the police force.
(B) It is the duty of the police commission, at the time set for hearing a charge against a police officer, to forthwith proceed to hear, try and determine the
charge according to the rules of evidence applicable to courts of record in the state. (Ord. 1581, 5-7-1990)
2-2-5: CHARGES TO BE IN WRITING:
Any charge brought against any member of the police force must be in writing in the form required by the police commission, and a copy thereof must be
served upon the accused officer or member at least fifteen (15) days before the time fixed for the hearing of such charge. (Ord. 1581, 5-7-1990)
2-2-6: RIGHTS OF ACCUSED POLICEMEN:
The accused shall have the right to be present at the trial in person and by counsel and to be heard and to give and furnish evidence in his defense. (Ord.
1581, 5-7-1990)
2-2-7: POLICE COMMISSION TRIALS OPEN TO PUBLIC:
All trials shall be open to the public. (Ord. 1581, 5-7-1990)
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 16/283
2-2-8: SUBPOENA AUTHORITY OF POLICE COMMISSION:
The chairman or acting chairman of the police commission shall have power to issue subpoenas, attested in its name, to compel the attendance of
witnesses at the hearing, and any person duly served with a subpoena is bound to attend in obedience thereto. The police commission shall have the
same authority to enforce obedience to the subpoena and to punish the disobedience thereof as is possessed by a judge of the district court in like cases;
provided, however, that punishment for disobedience is subject to review by the district court of Fergus County. (Ord. 1581, 5-7-1990)
2-2-9: DECISIONS BY POLICE COMMISSION; VETO POWER OF CITY MANAGER:
(A) The police commission must, after the conclusion of the hearing or trial, decide whether the charge was proven or not proven and shall have the
power, by a decision of a majority of the police commission, to discipline, suspend, remove or discharge any officer who shall have been found guilty of
the charge filed against him. (Ord. 1581, 5-7-1990)
(B) Such action of the police commission shall, however, be subject to modification or veto by the city manager, made in writing and giving reasons
therefor, which shall become a permanent record of the police commission; provided, however, that where and when the police commission decides
the charge not proven, the decision is final and conclusive and is not subject to modifications or veto by the city manager or to any review.
(C) Where the police commission decides the charge proven, the city manager, within five (5) days from the date of filing of such findings and decision with
the city clerk, may modify or veto such findings and decision.
(D) When a charge against a member of the police force is found proven by the board and is not vetoed by the city manager, the city manager must make
an order enforcing the decision of the board of the decision as modified if modified by the city manager. Such decision or order shall be subject to
review by the district court of Fergus County on all questions of fact and all questions of law. (Ord. 1581, 5-7-1990; amd. Ord. 1663, 1-3-2000)
2-2-10: HEARING REQUIRED PRIOR TO DISMISSAL OF POLICEMAN:
In no case shall any officer or member of the police force be discharged without a hearing or trial before the police commission as provided herein. (Ord.
1581, 5-7-1990)
2-2-11: TEMPORARY SUSPENSIONS:
The city manager or chief of police, subject to the approval of the city manager, shall have the power in all cases to suspend a policeman or any officer for
a period not exceeding ten (10) days in any one month, such suspension to be with or without pay as the order of suspension may determine. Any officer
suspended, with or without pay, is entitled to appeal such suspension to the police commission. (Ord. 1581, 5-7-1990; amd. Ord. 1663, 1-3-2000)
2-2-12: DISTRICT COURT REVIEW:
The district court of Fergus County shall have jurisdiction to review all questions of fact and all questions of law in a suit brought by any officer or member
of the police force, but no suit to review such hearing or trial or for reinstatement to office shall be maintained unless the same is begun within a period of
sixty (60) days after the decision of the police commission or order of the city manager has been filed with the city clerk. (Ord. 1581, 5-7-1990; amd. Ord.
1663, 1-3-2000)
Chapter 3
PARK AND RECREATION BOARD
2-3-1: CREATION:
There is hereby created and established an official body of the city to be known as the Lewistown park and recreation board, which shall have all of the
duties and responsibilities as specified in title 7, chapter 16, parts 41 and 42, and title 20, chapter 7, part 8, Montana Code Annotated. (Ord. 1572, 6-6-
1988)
2-3-2: MEMBERSHIP:
The park and recreation board shall be composed of the city manager and six (6) other persons to be appointed by the city manager with the approval of
the city commission. One of the six (6) appointees shall be a commission member of the Lewistown city commission. (Ord. 1578, 12-4-1989; amd. Ord.
1663, 1-3-2000; Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
2-3-3: TERM:
The term of office of each board member shall be two (2) years from and after May 1 of the year in which he or she is appointed. However, the term of the
city commission appointee shall terminate upon his or her vacancy or removal from office as a city commission person. The terms of the six (6) appointees
shall be staggered so that on May 1 in each year, only three (3) members shall have terms which expire. Any vacancy occurring during any member's term
shall be filled in the same manner as the original appointment, with such appointee to serve out the term of the member he succeeds. (Ord. 1578, 12-4-
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 17/283
1989; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
Any board member who shall refuse or neglect for a period of three (3) consecutive months to attend the meetings of the board without leave of absence,
or who shall fail for a period of twenty (20) days from and after his or her appointment to qualify as provided by law shall be deemed to have vacated his or
her office, and thereupon, a successor may be appointed. (Ord. 1578, 12-4-1989)
2-3-4: ORGANIZATION:
On the first Monday in May in each year, the board shall meet and organize by electing one of their number president and one of their number vice
president, who shall hold their offices for the term of one year. (Ord. 1572, 6-6-1988)
2-3-5: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The board shall have the powers and duties as prescribed by law. (Ord. 1572, 6-6-1988)
2-3-6: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The board may adopt rules and regulations not inconsistent with this chapter or the laws of the state of Montana. (Ord. 1572, 6-6-1988)
Chapter 4
DESIGN REVIEW BOARD
2-4-1: PURPOSE:
It is declared to be the intent of the city to protect and promote the general welfare of the citizens and their quality of life by establishing a design review
board. (Ord. 1655, 1-19-1999)
2-4-2: ESTABLISHMENT:
The design review board (or "board") is hereby established pursuant to this chapter. (Ord. 1655, 1-19-1999)
2-4-3: AUTHORITY OF THE BOARD:
(A) The board is given the authority and responsibility of furthering the stated purposes of various ordinances which the city commission may pass which
provide for design review. Those areas of development which affect surrounding properties and should be reviewed by the board shall include, but not
be limited to:
1. Site conditions.
2. Building design.
3. Exterior lighting.
4. Landscape plans.
5. Parking plans.
6. Signage requests.
(B) To further promote the health, safety and general welfare of the city, the design review board shall have the authority to review projects assigned to the
board by the commission via ordinances, resolutions and city policy. The board, in harmony with all applicable ordinances, resolutions, policies of the
city commission approved review criteria, may approve or deny, in whole or in part, or may modify and set conditions for approval, or provide advice
and counsel, for any request pursuant to this chapter. (Ord. 1655, 1-19-1999)
2-4-4: MEMBERSHIP:
(A) All members of the board shall be residents of the city. Four (4) volunteer members shall be appointed by the city commission, with an effort to achieve
a diversity of expertise, background and interest. Such diversity preferably should include:
1. An architect; and
2. Three (3) individuals chosen for their demonstrated interest in and knowledge of the cultural, historical and environmental heritage of Lewistown.
(B) The planning director will be appointed with voting privileges. (Ord. 1655, 1-19-1999)
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 18/283
2-4-5: TERMS OF MEMBERSHIP:
All volunteer members of the board shall be appointed by the city commission. The terms shall be three (3) years. The expiration of initial terms of board
members will be staggered to assure continuity. (Ord. 1655, 1-19-1999)
2-4-6: REVIEW OF BOARD DECISIONS:
Upon written request to the board's secretary within fifteen (15) days of any official board decision, any aggrieved party may petition the city commission to
rehear the request and overrule the board's decision. A majority vote of the city commission shall be required in order to place the appeal on the
commissioners' agenda for formal action. Any city commission action shall be considered preemptive of the design review board's decisions, unless such
decisions are upheld. (Ord. 1655, 1-19-1999)
2-4-7: CITY STAFF SUPPORT:
(A) Director Of Planning: The board shall be served primarily by the director of planning, or designee, who shall act as secretary. The staff member may
request assistance from any other city department for advice and counsel, in order to lend additional expertise to the board.
(B) Meetings: The secretary of the board shall schedule all meetings of the board as required by law and applicable city ordinances.
(C) Records: The secretary shall keep a summary of all actions of the board in the form of minutes or reports of the board's actions. (Ord. 1655, 1-19-
1999)
2-4-8: OPERATION OF THE BOARD:
(A) A quorum shall be three (3) members of the board.
(B) The board may adopt its own rules and bylaws, consistent with its powers and duties under the provisions of this chapter.
(C) No member of the board may vote on any project in which he/she or any partner has worked or has a financial, personal, or other direct interest. (Ord.
1655, 1-19-1999)
Chapter 5
BOARD OF ELECTRICAL EXAMINERS
2-5-1: BOARD CREATED:
There is hereby created and established a board of electrical examiners which shall be composed of the engineer and two (2) members who shall be
practical electricians, one of whom shall be a master electrician engaged in an established electrical contracting business in the city, the other to be a
journeyman electrician, both of whom shall carry a city individual certificate as provided for herein, and the building inspector of the city shall be an ex
officio member of the board. The city manager shall name, and by and with consent of the city commission, appoint the board of examiners; provided,
however, that any electrical board of examiners heretofore appointed under any ordinance repealed hereby shall act as the board of electrical examiners
under the provisions of this chapter until the expiration of his term for which he was heretofore appointed. All board members other than city members
shall be entitled to compensation for any meeting held for the purpose of examination of applicants at the rate of five dollars ($5.00) per meeting. The term
of office of appointed members shall be for two (2) years, one for one year and one being for two (2) years at the time of the first appointment of members
thereof, and thereafter one member shall be appointed each year as his term expires, this routine to be followed in regards to members that may now be
acting under similar ordinances and who may be acting by reason thereof under this chapter. (Ord. 898, 3-7-1949; amd. Ord. 1663, 1-3-2000; Ord. 1664,
1-3-2000)
The board shall designate the time and place for examination of all applicants for individual wireman's certificates as herein provided for. The engineer
shall serve as secretary of the board and keep all records of said board. (Ord. 898, 3-7-1949)
2-5-2: CERTIFICATE; FEE:
Any person who now is or in the future may become engaged in the business of master electrician or contracting electrician or in the work of journeyman
electrician, including all electricians working for such master or contracting electricians, in the installation or repair of electrical wiring or equipment in or
about buildings in the city is required to have an individual wireman's certificate.
Any such master electrician or contracting electrician must pay the sum of ten dollars ($10.00) as an initial fee for his wireman's certificate which shall be
issued for one year and each year thereafter must pay two dollars fifty cents ($2.50) for a renewal of such certificates; a journeyman electrician must pay
the sum of two dollars ($2.00) as an initial fee for his wireman's certificate which will be issued for one year and each year thereafter he must pay one
dollar ($1.00) for a renewal. In the event that a journeyman electrician leaves the service of any master or contracting electrician to enter service of
another master or contracting electrician in the city, he must obtain a new individual fireman's certificate from the board, paying the renewal fee therefor
provided herein. Apprentice cards may be issued by the board if signed by a master electrician for the period of one year for the fee of one dollar ($1.00),
and thereafter the holder must pay one dollar ($1.00) a year for renewal for wireman's certificate which will then be issued to him.
Individual wireman's certificates will contain the following information: classes of certificate, whether master, journeyman, or apprentice card, signature of
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 19/283
individual holding card, signature of master electrician employing holder of card, signature of the secretary of the board, and date of validity of the
certificate.
Any outside master or contracting electrician with his principal place of business outside of the city coming into the city for the purpose of doing electrical
work, together with all members of his crews who do not reside in the city and who do not hold Lewistown wireman's certificates must take an examination
before the board and pay for permits and all journeyman members must be qualified and take out individual wireman's certificates before doing any work
within the city, in the same manner as provided for inhabitants of the city. (Ord. 898, 3-7-1949)
2-5-3: EXAMINATIONS:
The board shall examine all applicants for individual wireman's certificates as to his practical and theoretical knowledge of wiring installation and electrical
business in general and shall submit the applicant to some satisfactory form of practical test, the form and type of examination to be prepared and
submitted by the board. And when satisfied of the competency of any applicant, shall advise and authorize the treasurer to issue an individual wireman's
certificate to such applicant, and such action will be certified on the board secretary's minutes; provided, however, that persons now actively engaged in
the work of master, contracting, or journeyman electricians and as such making installations for the general public in the city as their principal business
who have been engaged in such work in the city for two (2) years prior to the passage of this chapter shall not be required to pass an examination before
having an individual wireman's certificate issued to them which shall be issued on the order of the board as heretofore provided in the case of those who
pass examinations. All other persons must take examinations before engaging in any branch of the work or trade of electricians. Each person taking an
examination under the terms hereof shall pay a fee of ten dollars ($10.00). (Ord. 898, 3-7-1949)
2-5-4: ELECTRICAL BOARD FUND:
A fund is hereby created to be known as the electrical board fund, into which all fees for examination and individual wireman's certificates shall be paid,
said fund to be handled by the treasurer as other funds of the city are handled and to be used only for paying the expenses of the board of electrical
examiners. (Ord. 898, 3-7-1949)
2-5-5: AUTHORITY TO OPERATE:
After the issuance by said board of any individual wireman's certificate provided for here, and only after receiving such a certificate, the holder of such
certificate shall be entitled to operate as an electrician as provided in this code, after obtaining the license provided for therein and only upon compliance
with the provisions of said code. (Ord. 898, 3-7-1949)
Chapter 6
LIBRARY BOARD
2-6-1: STATUTE PROVISIONS:
Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, or applicable collective bargaining agreement, the provisions of title 22, chapter 1, part 3 of the Montana
Code Annotated, as amended, relating to free public libraries shall apply to the operation and conduct of the Lewistown public library. (Ord. 1715A, 12-3-
2007)
2-6-2: ESTABLISHMENT OF PUBLIC LIBRARY:
There is hereby established a free public library for the use of the citizens under such regulations as may be prescribed by a board of trustees hereinafter
provided and subject to the approval of the commission. (Ord. 1715A, 12-3-2007)
2-6-3: BOARD OF TRUSTEES; APPOINTMENT AND TERM:
The city manager, with the advice and consent of the city commission, shall appoint a board of trustees for the public library. The library board shall consist
of five (5) trustees. One, but not more than one, member of the city commission shall be a member of the board. Trustees shall serve without
compensation, but their actual and necessary expenses incurred in the performance of their official duties may be paid from library funds. Trustees shall
hold their office for five (5) years from the date of appointment and until their successors are appointed. Trustees shall serve no more than two (2) full
terms in succession. Appointments shall be staggered so that one trustee's term of office expires each year. Following such appointments, in July of each
year, the trustees shall meet and elect a chairperson and other such officers as they deem necessary for one year terms. Vacancies on the board of
trustees shall be filled for the unexpired term in the same manners as original appointments. (Ord. 1715A, 12-3-2007)
2-6-4: RECORD OF EXPENSES:
All claims for expenses incurred in the operation of the library, including all accounts of director and employees for salaries and compensation, all accounts
for library materials purchased and all other expenses of the library, shall be made within the approved fiscal budget. Claims against the library shall be
submitted to the city clerk and processed according to city purchasing policy. Each claim will be paid out of the designated library account as indicated by
the library director and as noted on each claim. (Ord. 1715A, 12-3-2007)
2-6-5: ANNUAL REVENUES:
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 20/283
The trustees of the library shall not, without permission from the commission, hereafter incur any indebtedness or liability on account of the library in
excess of the amount of money available for the payment of such indebtedness or liability, but shall so manage the affairs of the library so that the annual
revenues shall be ample to pay all expenses and obligations of the library. Any loan of city funds to satisfy an indebtedness incurred by the library in
excess of its budgeted authority shall accrue interest at ten percent (10%) per year. (Ord. 1715A, 12-3-2007)
2-6-6: ANNUAL REPORT:
The board of trustees shall make an annual report to the city commission on the condition and operation of the library, which shall include a complete
