financial statement. Such report shall be due no later than July 31. The financial statement shall include, but not be limited to, a listing of all sources of
revenues received or pledged, including in-kind contributions and gifts, along with the amounts or value of each contribution. The terms and conditions of
all gifts, bequests or pledges shall also be described. A description of all expenditures shall be listed by account. (Ord. 1715A, 12-3-2007)
Chapter 7
ZONING COMMISSION
(Rep. by Ord. 1394, 9-15-1975, eff. 10-15-1975)
Chapter 8
BOARD OF HEALTH
2-8-1: BOARD OF HEALTH CREATED:
There is hereby created a board of health which shall consist of three (3) members to be appointed by the city manager, by and with the consent of the
commission. The members so appointed shall hold their office for one year, or until their successors are appointed and qualified. The members of said
local board shall be removable at the pleasure of the city manager, by and with the consent of the commission. One of the members of said local board
shall be a physician legally qualified to practice medicine and surgery in the state of Montana. (Ord. 197, 11-11-1910; amd. Ord. 1663, 1-3-2000; Ord.
1664, 1-3-2000)
2-8-2: HEALTH OFFICER; DUTY TO ADVISE:
It shall be the duty of the health officer to advise the local board in all matters relating to the public health of the city and superintend the enforcement of
the provisions of this code and perform such duties as now are or hereafter may be prescribed. (Ord. 197, 11-11-1910)
2-8-3: REGULAR AND SPECIAL MEETINGS:
A majority of the members of the board of health shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. The board shall meet on the Monday preceding
the first commission meeting in each month. The health officer shall be present at all meetings of the board. Special meetings may be called by the
president of the board when deemed necessary. (Ord. 197, 11-11-1910; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
2-8-4: DUTIES OF SECRETARY:
The board shall elect one of its members as secretary. The secretary shall keep accurate records, in a book provided therefor, of the proceedings of such
meetings. He shall keep accurate records of all communicable diseases reported to him, and for this purpose the board shall provide, at the expense of
the city, a book printed in proper blank form for the notation of such facts and data as may be prescribed by the regulations of the state board of health.
This record shall be the property of the city and must be turned over by the secretary to his successor in office. (Ord. 197, 11-11-1910)
Chapter 9
INDUSTRIAL COMMISSION
2-9-1: CREATION:
There is hereby created and established an official body of the city to be known as the "Lewistown industrial commission". (Ord. 1266, 6-19-1967)
2-9-2: INDUSTRIAL COMMISSIONER:
The city manager, with the approval of the city commission, will appoint an industrial commissioner to serve a one year term and who will be up for
reappointment annually. It is suggested that the executive director of New Industries, Inc., whoever he may be, be appointed as the city industrial
commissioner. It is expressly provided herein that the commissioner shall not have a vote at any of the industrial commission meetings. His official title
shall be "the industrial commissioner of the city of Lewistown, Montana". (Ord. 1266, 6-19-1967; amd. Ord. 1663, 1-3-2000; Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
2-9-3: MEMBERSHIP:
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 21/283
Said industrial commission shall consist of nine (9) members; the city manager and chairman of the city commission shall be members; one member shall
be appointed from the city-county planning board; one member shall be appointed from the city-county airport commission; one member shall be
appointed from the Northwestern Bank of Lewistown; one member shall be appointed from the First National Bank; one member shall be appointed from
industry in the Lewistown area; two (2) members shall be nominated from the citizens of Lewistown. All appointments shall be made by the city manager
and confirmed by the city commission; all members must be twenty one (21) years of age. (Ord. 1266, 6-19-1967; amd. Ord. 1663, 1-3-2000; Ord. 1664,
1-3-2000)
2-9-4: TERM:
The city manager and chairman of the city commission shall serve so long as they occupy their respective offices; the members appointed from the citycounty
planning board and the city-county airport commission shall serve at the pleasure of the city manager; the terms of the remaining members of the
said city commission shall be for a period of three (3) years except for those members first appointed, which shall be as follows: Two (2) members shall be
appointed for a period of one year, two (2) members for a period of two (2) years and one member for a period of three (3) years. Any vacancy occurring in
the membership of said industrial commission shall be filled in the same manner as the original appointment; such appointee to serve out the unexpired
term of the member he succeeds. (Ord. 1266, 6-19-1967; amd. Ord. 1663, 1-3-2000; Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
2-9-5: ORGANIZATION:
The members of the industrial commission shall meet within ten (10) days after receiving notice of their appointment, and organize by the election of a
chairman and vice chairman from their own number, and they shall designate a secretary who may be either a member of the city commission or another
suitable person. (Ord. 1266, 6-19-1967; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
2-9-6: MEETINGS:
The industrial commission shall fix the time for holding regular meetings and shall meet on a regular basis in the manner prescribed by the industrial
commission in fixing its meeting dates. (Ord. 1266, 6-19-1967)
2-9-7: SPECIAL MEETINGS:
Special meetings of the commission may be called by the chairman or by at least two (2) members upon written request to the secretary. The secretary
shall send to all members, at least two (2) days in advance of a special meeting, a written note affixing the time and place of the meeting.
Written notice of a special meeting is not required if the time of the special meeting has been fixed at a regular meeting, where if all members are present
at the special meeting. (Ord. 1266, 6-19-1967)
2-9-8: QUORUM:
A majority of the members shall constitute a quorum; no action of the industrial commission is official, however, unless authorized by the majority of the
members of the industrial commission at a regular or properly called special meeting. (Ord. 1266, 6-19-1967)
2-9-9: PURPOSE:
The purpose of the industrial commission is to investigate and report to the city commission and make recommendations with respect to sections 11-4101
through 11-4110 Revised Codes of Montana, 1947, which said state statutes by their terms contemplate the city becoming involved in industrial
development projects; said industrial commission will act and meet with the city-county planning commission, and any other group of individuals or
corporations, such as New Industries, Inc., and will discuss and formulate with such groups policies concerning the industrial development of the
Lewistown area; all such meetings and discussions will be strictly for the purpose of making recommendations by the industrial commission to the city
commission; the city commission will continue to be the only authorized body to transact business with respect to industrial development; the industrial
commission is created to relieve the city commission of preliminary duties and investigations with respect to industrial development and to lessen the
workload of the city commission in this regard. (Ord. 1266, 6-19-1967; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
2-9-10: DISBURSEMENT:
There are no funds from the city available for use for the industrial commission; any and all disbursements of monies are to be made solely by the city
commission as required by law; there shall be created a separate fund consisting of private donation and funds otherwise privately acquired. This separate
fund shall be under the jurisdiction and control of the industrial commission and may be disbursed as they may determine without direction or authority of
the city council. (Ord. 1266, 6-19-1967; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
2-9-11: EXPENSES; PAYMENT:
The industrial commission is not authorized to incur any expense; all members appointed to the industrial commission are to serve in a strictly gratuitous
capacity; all members are to receive no compensation and will be reimbursed for no expenses unless expressly authorized by the city. (Ord. 1266, 6-19-
1967)
2-9-12: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 22/283
The industrial commission shall adopt such reasonable rules and regulations not inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter, which are necessary for
the orderly conduct of the business of the industrial commission or the activity carried on by the said industrial commission. (Ord. 1266, 6-19-1967)
Chapter 10
LEWISTOWN PARK AND TREE BOARD
2-10-1: CREATION:
Pursuant to the authority found in title 7, chapter 16, part 42, Montana Code Annotated, the Lewistown city commission has created a board of park
commissioners. Such board constitutes a department of the city and is governed by the provisions of Montana law cited herein. (Ord. 1732, 3-7-2011)
2-10-2: TREE RESPONSIBILITY:
In addition or in connection with the other duties and responsibilities provided for in title 7, chapter 16, part 42, Montana Code Annotated, the board shall
have the additional responsibilities to develop a list of trees suitable for planting as well as study, investigate, counsel, and develop written plans for the
care, preservation, trimming, planting, replanting, and removal of trees and shrubs located in the public ways, streets, and alleys. (Ord. 1732, 3-7-2011)
2-10-3: BOARD'S NAME:
Notwithstanding anything contained herein or in title 7, chapter 16, part 42, Montana Code Annotated, the board of park commissioners shall be officially
known as the Lewistown park and tree board. (Ord. 1732, 3-7-2011)
2-10-4: ADVISORY COMMITTEE:
The park and tree board may establish a volunteer committee of up to five (5) local individuals to each serve two (2) year terms to assist the park and tree
board with tree activities and problems. This volunteer group will be known as the tree advisory committee, and will be selected by majority vote of the
park and tree board. The park and tree board may further develop written rules concerning the operation and function of the tree advisory committee. (Ord.
1732, 3-7-2011)
2-10-5: REPORTING:
The park and tree board will present an annual report on the condition of Lewistown's tree resources and an annual work plan of tree educational activities
to the city commission for their acceptance. The board and its advisory committee, when requested by the city commission, shall consider, investigate,
make findings, report, and recommend upon any special matter or question coming within the scope of its work. The board shall promote and supervise
the establishment of a tree inventory for street and park trees. The inventory shall be updated with the results of ground inspections every fifteen (15)
years. (Ord. 1732, 3-7-2011)
Title 3
DEPARTMENTS
Chapter 1
POLICE DEPARTMENT
3-1-1: POLICE DEPARTMENT AUTHORIZED AND REQUIRED:
There shall be in the city of Lewistown a police department which shall be organized, managed and controlled as provided in this chapter. (Ord. 1582, 5-7-
1990)
3-1-2: SUPERVISION OF POLICE DEPARTMENT:
The city manager shall have charge of and supervision over the police department thereof. He shall appoint all the members and officers thereof. Subject
to the provisions of this chapter, he shall have the power to suspend or remove any member or officer of the force. He shall make rules, not inconsistent
with the provisions of this chapter, the laws of the state or the ordinances of the city commission, for the government, direction, management and discipline
of the police force. (Ord. 1582, 5-7-1990; amd. Ord. 1663, 1-3-2000; Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
3-1-3: ADDITIONAL REGULATIONS BY CITY COMMISSION:
In addition to the provisions herein contained, the city commission may make any ordinances, not inconsistent with this chapter or any law of the state, for
the government of the police department and for regulating the powers and duties of its officers and members. (Ord. 1582, 5-7-1990; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-
2000)
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 23/283
3-1-4: LIST OF ACTIVE AND ELIGIBLE POLICEMEN:
(A) The city commission shall have absolute and exclusive power to determine and limit the number of police officers and members to comprise the police
force, to reduce the number of the police force at any time, and to divide the police membership into two (2) lists: (Ord. 1582, 5-7-1990; amd. Ord.
1664, 1-3-2000)
1. One, an active list, who are to be actually employed and receive pay while so employed; and
2. One, an eligible list, who shall not receive pay while not actually employed as an officer or member.
(B) Officers or members of the active list temporarily relieved from duty shall become members of the eligible list without pay and shall be first entitled to
reinstatement on the active list in case of vacancy, according to their seniority in the service, and all others on the eligible list shall be entitled to fill a
vacancy in the order of their appointment. (Ord. 1582, 5-7-1990)
(C) Such action of the city commission shall not be subject to review by any court. (Ord. 1582, 5-7-1990; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
(D) In no event shall there be any officers or members placed on the eligible list, except in case of temporary reduction of the police force, when the
number already on the eligible list shall equal in number twenty percent (20%) of the active list. (Ord. 1582, 5-7-1990)
3-1-5: APPOINTMENT TO POLICE FORCE:
All appointments to the police force must be appointed by the city manager, and confirmed by the city commission. No such appointment must be made
until: (Ord. 1582, 5-7-1990; amd. Ord. 1663, 1-3-2000; Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
(A) An application for such position on the police force has been filed with the city manager and referred by him to the police commission.
(B) Such applicant has successfully passed the examination required to be held by the police commission and a certificate from the police commission that
the applicant has qualified for such appointment has been filed with the city manager. (Ord. 1582, 5-7-1990; amd. Ord. 1663, 1-3-2000)
3-1-6: EXAMINATION OF APPLICANTS FOR POSITION ON POLICE FORCE:
(A) All applicants for positions on the police force whose applications shall have been referred to the police commission shall be required to successfully
undergo an examination before the police commission that the applicant is qualified for such appointment for the probationary period upon the police
force.
(B) Any applicant who shall make any false statement to the police commission as to his age or other required qualifications at his examination before the
police commission shall be subject to suspension or dismissal from the police force after trial. (Ord. 1582, 5-7-1990)
3-1-7: QUALIFICATIONS OF POLICEMEN:
(A) The members of the police department on the active list at the time of their appointment under this chapter may not be less than eighteen (18) years of
age or more than thirty five (35) years of age, but this restriction does not apply to any member of any police department as of July 2, 1973, to
honorably discharged persons who served in the armed forces of the United States in time of war, providing such time of service is not less than three
(3) months, or to applicants for reinstatement under state law.
(B) A police officer must be a citizen of the United States and meet the minimum qualifying standards for employment promulgated by the board of crime
control for the state of Montana. (Ord. 1582, 5-7-1990)
3-1-8: PROBATIONARY PERIOD AND CONFIRMATION OF APPOINTMENT:
(A) Every applicant who has passed the examination and received the certificate referred to in section 3-1-5 of this chapter must first serve for a
probationary term of not more than one year. At any time before the end of such probationary term, the city manager may revoke such appointment.
(Ord. 1582, 5-7-1990; amd. Ord. 1663, 1-3-2000)
(B) After the end of such probationary period and within thirty (30) days thereafter, the appointment of such applicant must be submitted to the city
commission and if such appointment is confirmed by the city commission, such applicant becomes a member of the police force and shall hold such
position during good behavior unless suspended or discharged as provided by law. (Ord. 1582, 5-7-1990; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
3-1-9: RESTRICTIONS ON ACTIVITIES OF POLICEMEN:
(A) No member of the police force may hold any other office or be employed in any other department of the city government.
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 24/283
(B) The fact that a person is an officer or member of the police department does not deprive his spouse or any member of his family of the right to
participate in political activity or to hold public or political office.
(C) An officer or member of the police department may participate in political activity provided he does not do so while on duty or in uniform or that it does
not otherwise interfere with the performance of his duties. (Ord. 1582, 5-7-1990)
3-1-10: EXEMPTIONS OF MEMBERS OF POLICE FORCE:
No member of the police force shall be liable to military or jury duty or to arrest on civil process while actually on duty. (Ord. 1582, 5-7-1990)
3-1-11: WORK PERIOD; DAYS OFF DUTY WITHOUT LOSS OF COMPENSATION:
(A) The chief of police may establish the work period for officers and other personnel in the department and may establish a work period other than that
provided in state law for determining when an employee must be paid overtime compensation. The total hours in all work periods in a calendar year
may not exceed two thousand eighty (2,080).
(B) Each officer or other employee of the police force in each calendar year shall be given a minimum of one hundred four (104) days off duty without loss
of compensation, not including holidays, sick leave, vacation leave or other types of compensated time off duty. (Ord. 1582, 5-7-1990)
3-1-12: POLICE OFFICER ARREST AUTHORITY:
All officers of the city, pursuant to sections 7-32-4301, Montana Code Annotated, shall have the authority to make arrests of persons charged with crime
within the limits of the city, within five (5) miles thereof and along the lines of water supply of the city. This provision shall not supersede the arrest authority
of police officers provided for in any state statute or other city ordinance, rather this provision shall only add to the authority of police officers under such
statutes or ordinances. Furthermore, this provision shall not be construed to require or obligate the police force of the city to patrol or otherwise provide
service to the area within five (5) miles of the city limits. (Ord. 1582, 5-7-1990)
Chapter 2
FIRE DEPARTMENT
(Rep. by Ord. 1668, 4-17-2000)
Chapter 3
WATER SYSTEM REGULATIONS
3-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
COMMERCIAL UNIT: Any enterprise where those served or employed enter upon the premises or where water is used in the process of providing goods
or services.
CUSTOMER: Any individual, partnership, association, firm, public or private corporation or governmental agency receiving water service from the utility.
Residential customers are those receiving water service solely for domestic purposes in a residential dwelling unit. Commercial customers are those
receiving water service for use in connection with a business, industry or commercial enterprise. Multi-family dwelling units, such as apartment houses
receiving metered service through one meter are regarded as commercial customers. When a structure is used both for commercial and residential
purposes, then it is regarded as a commercial building.
CUSTOMER'S FACILITIES: All service pipe, meter box or pit, inside piping, appliances and apparatus on customer's side of the point of delivery, except
utility's meter and other equipment owned by the utility.
FAMILY: An individual or two (2) or more persons related by blood or marriage or a group of not more than five (5) unrelated persons living together in a
dwelling unit.
METER: The complete assemblage, including auxiliary devices and equipment, if any, used to measure the water supplied to a customer. To exclude
fittings or piping necessary to modify existing plumbing to allow installation of meter assemblage.
METROPOLITAN SERVICE AREA AND SUBURBAN SERVICE AREA: The areas defined by boundaries as shown on maps forming a part of this tariff
within which the utility will furnish water service in accordance with the provisions of the applicable rate schedule.
POINT OF DELIVERY: The point at which the utility's facilities connect physically to customer's facilities, that location shall be the utility's curb stop or the
public easement or public property line, whichever is nearest the utility's water main line, unless otherwise defined in the service agreement.
PRIVATE WATER SYSTEM: Any source of water and means of delivery other than utility's municipal water system.
RESIDENTIAL DWELLING UNIT: Any room or combination of rooms, including trailers and mobile homes, with facilities for cooking, designated for
occupancy by one family, which contain living facilities, including provisions for sleeping, eating, cooking and sanitation for not more than one family.
ROOM: On flat rate service, where the charge is based on the number of rooms, any finished room with an area of eighty (80) square feet will be
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 25/283
considered a room. Bathrooms shall have no minimum area requirements.
SERVICE AGREEMENT: The agreement or contract between utility and customer pursuant to which service is supplied and taken.
SERVICE LINE: Utility service line is that portion of the installation including the corporation stop, curb stop, curb box and piping between the corporation
stop and curb stop or portions of these components placed within the public right of way or public easement, whichever is most near the water main
providing water to the installation.
Customer's service line is that portion of the service installation downstream of the curb box or beyond the public right of way or public easement,
whichever is most near the water main providing water to the installation.
SERVICE SIZE: The diameter of the meter assemblage port or the nominal diameter of the immediately adjacent connecting piping, whichever is larger,
but not less than three-fourths inch (3/4"), being that piping which principally provides water for use other than fire sprinkling systems within a building.
UTILITY: The city of Lewistown, Montana, and its water service division, engaged in the business of providing water and supplying water service to its
customers on its system in the state.
WATER SERVICE: The supplying of or availability, at the point of delivery, of water and also the water delivered or used. (Ord. 1630, 12-4-1995)
3-3-2: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
(A) Coverage: These service regulations govern the supplying by the utility, and taking by its customers, of water service from the utility's water system.
These regulations are subject to revision, and supersede all regulations, whatever term designated, which may heretofore govern the supplying and
taking of water service.
(B) Purpose: These service regulations are intended to define good practice which can normally be expected, but are not intended to exclude other
accepted standards and practices not covered herein. They are intended to ensure adequate service to the public and protect the utility from
unreasonable demands.
(C) Information Available To Public: There shall be made available to the public, at the principal offices of the utility, copies of these service regulations and
the rate schedules, forms of agreement for water service and service standards of the utility. (Ord. 1630, 12-4-1995)
3-3-3: SERVICES TO BE PROVIDED:
(A) Utility Will Furnish Water Service, For Certain Specific Purposes, For Specific Sum, On Metered Or Nonmetered Basis: The utility agrees to furnish
water and water services for certain specified purposes as contained in the service agreement, for a certain specified sum based either on a metered
or nonmetered rate as provided in this chapter.
(B) Water Utility System; Unauthorized Taps Prohibited: With the exception of special installation approved by the utility, no person or other entity, other
than agents, representatives or employees of the utility, shall tap into the utility's transmission or distribution system or service lines attached thereto.
(C) Access To Premises: The utility's employees or representatives, or other authorized persons, shall have access, at reasonable hours, to enter any
premises where water is used, for the purpose of making inspection or investigation; and operating, removing, replacing or repairing utility property.
(D) No Person Or Entity Shall Activate A Line Connected To The Utility's System, Or Allow Any Other Person To Do So, Except Upon Specific, Written
Permission Of The Utility: Activation of any line, for testing purposes, or otherwise, shall obligate the individual performing the test to turn off the water
service at the curb stop.
(E) Violations: Customers violating any requirements of this section or their service agreements may have their water service discontinued until such time
as the estimated charge for additional service has been paid, together with actual expenses incurred by the utility in discontinuing, reconnecting or
connecting such water service. (Ord. 1630, 12-4-1995)
3-3-4: SERVICE AGREEMENTS:
(A) Application For Service: All customers and applicants for service shall sign a utility service agreement. The application or agreement shall be binding
only after the utility completes an inspection of the premises for which service is requested, and the form is signed by the duly authorized assistant
clerk.
For services provided prior to the binding agreement, the customer shall pay for the service so furnished in accordance with the applicable rate
schedule or schedules in force and shall abide by these regulations.
(B) When Required: A new utility service agreement is required when any of the following occur:
1. First time service to a property or customer.
2. Change of owner for property served.
3. Restoration of service to a property when service has been discontinued for more than one hundred eighty (180) consecutive days.
4. Request for change in billing rate.
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 26/283
5. When a permit is issued for work which will change the occupancy classification of the premises, or increase or decrease the floor area or quantity of
plumbing fixtures.
(C) Rented Or Leased Property: In situations where property is served, or is to be served, and such property is rented or leased, the utility may require the
owner of the property to sign a service application. The utility shall consider the owner as primarily responsible for timely payment of service charges as
well as any other fee or assessment authorized in this chapter. The utility shall establish billing procedures accordingly. (Ord. 1630, 12-4-1995)
3-3-5: ESTABLISHMENT OF CREDIT; CUSTOMER DEPOSIT FOR GUARANTEE PAYMENT:
(A) When Required: The utility may, at any time, require from any customer or prospective customer, a deposit intended to guarantee payment of bills.
Such deposit shall not exceed twice the customer's actual or estimated maximum monthly bill.
(B) Interest: Simple interest at a rate based upon the average of those rates paid for passbook savings by those lending institutions located within the city
not to exceed six percent (6%) per annum. Interest to be paid on the amount of the deposit shall be paid to the customer upon refund of such deposit,
or shall be paid annually to the customer upon demand, provided said deposit remains intact with the utility for a period of at least six (6) months.
Interest shall cease on the date of termination of service.
(C) Refund: The utility may refund any customer's deposit or a part thereof at any time and interest shall be paid to the date of refund. The utility may
refund customer's deposit or a part thereof by personally delivering or mailing a check to customer or by giving customer notice at his last known
address that deposit will be paid to customer at the utility's office. Interest on the deposit shall cease after notice of refund if customer does not call for
or accept the deposit.
(D) Application Of Deposit: The utility may apply customer's deposit to the payment of all amounts due and owing the utility for service, and if customer
shall fail to restore any such deposit upon ten (10) days' notice, the utility may discontinue service until the deposit is restored.
(E) Record Of Customer's Deposit: The utility will keep a "customer's deposit record", showing:
1. The name of customer making a deposit.
2. The address of the customer.
3. The amount and date the deposit was made.
4. A record of each transaction concerning the deposit such as payment of interest and interest credited.
(F) Receipt, Refund, When Lost: The utility will issue to customer from whom a deposit is received a nonassignable receipt. However, the utility will provide
reasonable ways and means whereby a deposit may be returned to a customer who is unable to produce the original receipt. (Ord. 1630, 12-4-1995)
3-3-6: SERVICE CONDITIONS:
(A) Supplying Of Service:
1. Rules And Regulations: Service will be supplied only pursuant to these rules and regulations, and any modifications or additions thereto lawfully
made, and under such applicable rate schedule or schedules as may from time to time be lawfully fixed. Service supplied without main extensions
shall be in accordance with subsection 3-3-8(A) of this chapter.
2. Special Utility Extension: When to make service available to a prospective customer the utility would have to extend its mains or increase the
capacity of the mains or other facilities, a special utility extension agreement may be required.
3. Meter Readings: Where separate points of delivery exist for supplying service to a single customer or separate meters are maintained for
measurement of service to a single customer, the meter readings shall not be combined for purposes of measurement or application of the rate
schedule or schedules.
4. Minimum Service Size: The following tables shall be used to determine the minimum size service line for commercial customers. To use the tables
follow these steps:
Table I: a) The utility shall identify the class of the service; b) determine the appropriate unit of measure for the service; c) determine the minimum
fixture units per unit of measure.
Table II: a) Determine the developed length in feet of the cold water piping starting at the meter or the point where the service first enters the
premises, whichever is closer to the water main; b) find the appropriate developed length column using the higher number for length that fall between
two (2) columns; c) follow the column down to find the fixture units identified in table I; d) follow that row to the left to find the minimum service size.

Service length is measured from the point where the service line first enters the building or exterior meter pit to the point where the last fixture is serviced
including the length of all branch lines, but not less than forty feet (40') for any premises.
Service sizes larger than two inches (2") are determined by engineering calculation and code standards acceptable to the utility.
(B) Permits: A customer or prospective customer must furnish all necessary easements, rights of way and permits necessary to enable the utility to supply
the service required, except rights of way, easements and permits across and along public property.
(C) Utility's Responsibility: The utility is responsible only to the customer for supplying water service in accordance with conditions set forth in the service
agreement with the customer, irrespective of ownership of the premises served. The utility shall not be responsible for inconvenience, damage or injury
to persons or property resulting from the utility's discontinuance of service to the premises upon customer's notice or in accordance with subsection (J)
or (L) of this section.
(D) Use Of Service: The utility agrees, by accepting the application for service, to furnish water service for the purposes specified, at metered rates unless
otherwise specified on the applicable rate schedule.
If a customer utilizes the water or water service for other purposes than for which it was intended, that customer is in violation of his service agreement.
All customers are prohibited from providing water or other service to other individuals or entities from the utility's system without receiving permission,
in writing from the utility. In no instance may the customer extend his water facilities across or under a street, alley, lane, court or avenue or other public
or private space, existing under different ownership, in order to obtain a rate advantage by taking water service for two (2) or more premises through
one source or meter.
(E) Seasonal, Short Term Or Construction Service: For any seasonal, short term or construction service, the utility may require the customer to pay in
advance the cost of connecting and disconnecting and installing and removing the facilities required for rendering such temporary service. Service will
be supplied under the rate schedule or schedules in effect at that time.
(F) Temporary Service: For any temporary service the customer must pay in advance the cost of installing and removing all of the facilities required for
rendering such temporary service.
(G) Free Service: The utility will not render free service or service at rates other than provided for in the approved schedules of this chapter.
(H) Renting Of Rooms: Where rooms of a residential building are rented to the public, for domestic purposes only, and such rooms do not contain separate
living facilities as prescribed for a residential dwelling unit, and such rooms are rented by the owner, occupying the building, the residential rate shall
apply to all rooms occupied by the owner of the residence and his family, together with additional rooms, not exceeding four (4).
(I) Discontinuance Of Service By Customer: Customer shall give the utility at least twenty four (24) hours' notice, Sundays and holidays excluded, to
terminate service, unless a longer notice of termination is provided for in the service agreement.
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 28/283
(J) Termination Of Service By Utility:
1. The utility may terminate service, upon not less than ten (10) days' notice, to any customers for violation of any provision of a service agreement rate
schedule, or these rules and regulations, including failure to pay bills within the specified period.
(a) The notice of termination shall be in writing and shall state the reason for the proposed termination, the procedure which the customer may follow
to dispute the proposed termination, and any other appropriate information necessary to fully inform the customer.
2. The utility may terminate service, without notice, to any customer when a dangerous condition is found to exist on customer's premises which
endangers the utility's service or equipment.
3. Whenever service is terminated under this rule, the utility shall not be required to restore service until a settlement has been made. The utility may
also require customer to pay all costs of terminating and reestablishing service, but not less than ten dollars ($10.00).
(K) Utility's Right To Refuse Service:
1. The utility may refuse service to any delinquent customer owing the utility for service, until such past balance has been paid or satisfactory
arrangements have been made by delinquent customer with the utility for paying same. These same provisions shall apply and the utility may refuse
service to any other member of the same household or firm when application by this member in the opinion of the utility may be a means for evading
payment of the delinquent service bill.
2. The utility may decline service to any customer that has constructed or caused to be constructed a "customer's installation" that does not meet
minimum utility recognized installation specifications for material or workmanship.
3. The utility may decline to serve or discontinue service to any customer until he has complied with all state and city regulations governing water
service and with the rules and regulations of the utility.
(L) Tampering Or Unauthorized Use Of Service:
1. The utility may discontinue service, without notice, to any customer when any evidence of tampering with meter or interfering with the proper
functioning thereof or any unauthorized use or diversion of service is found.
2. Whenever service is discontinued under this rule, the utility shall not be required to restore service until a settlement has been made. In cases where
the meter seal is broken, or the working parts of the meter have been tampered with, or the meter damaged, the utility may render a bill for the
current month based on the average of the preceding two (2) similar months' use, together with full costs of repairing and replacing the meter and
may refuse to furnish further water service until the account is paid in full. The utility may require as a condition of restoring service that customer
make, at his own expense, such changes in his piping system as may be necessary to provide for a meter location and installation satisfactory to the
utility.
(M) Suspension Of Service For Repairs And Changes: When it is necessary for the utility to make repairs or to change its water collecting, storage,
transmission or distribution system, meters or other property, utility may, without incurring any liability therefor, suspend service for such period as may
be reasonably necessary, and in such manner as to minimize the inconvenience to customers. The utility will make all reasonable efforts to notify
customers of such suspension of service.
(N) Water Utility System; Maintenance And Repair; Utility Personnel Only: With the exception of special installations approved by the utility, no person, or
other entity, other than agents, representatives or employees of the utility, shall maintain or repair the utility's water utility system. (Ord. 1630, 12-4-
1995)
(O) Irrigation Or Other Outdoor Use Restricted: The superintendent of the utility is hereby authorized, directed and empowered, whenever in his opinion
the necessities of the situation require such action, to restrict and/or wholly prohibit use of the utility's water to supply for garden, lawn or other outdoor
irrigation or use, subject to approval by the city manager or city commission. Such restriction and/or prohibition shall become effective twenty four (24)
hours after notice thereof shall be made public by the local news media. (Ord. 1630, 12-4-1995; amd. Ord. 1663, 1-3-2000; Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
(P) Irrigation, Nonemergency Use: The utility may specify the hours and days during which sprinkling or irrigation will be permitted and may publish notice
thereof in newspapers at the start of the sprinkling or irrigation season, or whenever conditions require a change in present sprinkling or irrigation
practices. The utility shall prominently post, within its local office, a notice advising the public of the hours and days within which sprinkling or other
irrigation is permitted. Wastage of irrigation water is prohibited either with or without specified sprinkling or irrigation times.
(Q) Violation Of Utility Rules; Sprinkling And Irrigation Use; Nonemergency Notice To Customers: At such time when the utility, through its agents,
employees or representatives, determines that a customer is in violation of the utility's regulations in regard to sprinkling or irrigation, the utility shall
deliver to such customer a copy of the notice of hours and days of sprinkling and irrigating, and shall advise the customer that he is in violation of the
rule. If the customer is found in violation of the rule a second time in any one irrigation or sprinkling season, he will be notified by certified mail, with
return receipt, that another violation will result in discontinuance of service. If the customer is found in violation of the rule a third time in any one
irrigation or sprinkling season, service shall be discontinued without notice and the installation of a meter required prior to restoration of service.
(R) Violation Of Regulations, Nonpayment Of Water Charges: For violation of any of these regulations or for nonpayment of water charges, as provided in
the utility's schedule of rates and charges, the utility has the right to disconnect water service following ten (10) days' written notice to the customer and
twenty four (24) hours' written notice delivered to the premises. After service has been discontinued, the same shall not be reinstated until all
delinquent charges are paid. Costs of all disconnects and/or subsequent reconnects shall be borne by the customer.
(S) Meter Services; Billing; Payment Of Charges; Delinquent Charges: All meters will be read quarterly. Metered services, shall be billed for actual water
consumed based on rates and charges provided in this chapter. Payment is due upon receipt of the bill and will be considered delinquent if not paid
within thirty (30) days after it has been received. If the bill is not paid after it has become delinquent, the water service will be disconnected after ten
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 29/283
(10) days' written notice to the customer and twenty four (24) hours' written notice delivered to the premises. Service shall not be reinstated until
delinquent charges are paid, together with the cost incurred by the utility in disconnecting or subsequently reconnecting the line.
(T) Flat Rate Services; Billing; Payment Of Charges; Delinquent Charges: All flat rate service shall be billed monthly in advance, on or about the first day of
each month, based on rates and charges provided in this chapter. Payment is due upon receipt of the bill, and will be considered delinquent if not paid
within thirty (30) days after it has been received. If the bill is not paid after it has become delinquent, the water service will be disconnected after ten
(10) days' written notice to the customer and twenty four (24) hours' written notice delivered to the premises. Service will not be reinstated until
delinquent charges are paid, together with the cost incurred by the utility in disconnecting and subsequently reconnecting the line. (Ord. 1630, 12-4-
1995)
3-3-7: CUSTOMER'S RESPONSIBILITY:
(A) Permits: The customer must obtain and furnish to the utility all necessary permits to enable the utility to supply service, except permits for public space
which will be obtained by the utility.
(B) Depth Of Service Pipe: The customer's service pipe must be laid, at the customer's expense, below street grade and on the customer's premises, at a
depth that prevents freezing.
(C) Backflow Prevention And Cross Connection Control: At such times when the utility determines that it is necessary to protect the utility's water system
against contamination or pollution resulting from backflow of objectionable fluids from the consumer's premises or water service, the utility may require
the installation of backflow prevention devices. The type of device used shall be determined by the utility. The consumer shall pay all costs related to
the installation of such device and be responsible for the maintenance of the installed device.
(D) Stop And Waste Valve: At some convenient point inside the building and so located that it cannot freeze, a stop and waste cock must be placed by the
customer so that the water can be readily shut off from within the building and the water pipes drained to prevent freezing.
(E) Maintenance Of Customer's Fixtures And Service Line: Waste of water is prohibited and customers must keep their fixtures and service pipes in good
order at their own expense. All waterways must be closed when not in use. Leaking fixtures must be repaired immediately without waiting for notice
from the utility. Water service may be discontinued by the utility after ten (10) days' written notice, if wastage of water is continued.
Customers must maintain the service line downstream of the curb box or property line, whichever is greater.
(F) Connection To Mains: No customer, or agent of the customer, is permitted to make any connection to the utility's mains, or to turn the water off or on to
any premises, without permission of the utility.
(G) Service To Others: A separate service pipe must be installed by the customer to supply each residence or business premises and the customer must
not permit the connection of any piping which will permit water service to be made available to any other premises without the permission of the utility.
(H) Damage To Utility's Property: The customer shall be responsible for all damage to or loss of utility's property located upon his premises, including
damage by hot water, unless occasioned by circumstances beyond his control or by negligence of the utility. The use of water upon the premises of the
customer is at the risk of the customer, and the responsibility of the utility shall cease at the point of connection with the customer's service.
Utility property includes the meter, remote readout, utility's service line, and curb stop. Damage and loss include acts or construction which deny
reasonable access to utility's property.
(I) Damage To Customer's Property: The customer shall be responsible for the installation and maintenance of all piping, plumbing and equipment
connected, or to be connected, to the utility's distribution system. The utility shall not be liable for any loss or damage of any nature whatsoever caused
by or arising from the operation of the customer's piping or equipment or from any defect in the customer's equipment upon the premises of the
customer. The utility does not assume the duty of inspecting the customer's line, plumbing and equipment and shall not be responsible therefor, but the
customer shall grant permission for duly authorized employees or agents of the utility to make investigation, at reasonable times, of the use of water in
any premises served. (Ord. 1630, 12-4-1995)
(J) Private Water Systems: Private water systems shall not be connected to the utility's water system without written consent of the city commission. Such
consent shall be based upon the following findings: (Ord. 1630, 12-4-1995; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
1. Private water system is constructed as approved by the utility, in such a manner that it is capable of delivering potable water and has mechanical
devices that will prevent private water from entering the public water supply.
2. Private water system is regularly tested in a manner and schedule acceptable to the utility.
3. Private water system provides for a need which cannot be supplied by the utility's water system.
Customers using a private water system shall pay a fee for utility's water system standby equal to not less than the base rate provided in this
chapter.
Private water systems, not connected to the utility's water system, shall not be used to provide water for any use other than irrigation.
(K) Installation Of Service Line From Main To Point Of Delivery: The customer shall excavate and backfill trenches for service lines in accordance with title
9, chapter 5, "Excavations", of this code, and shall also pay a fee for service line materials supplied and installed by the utility. The fee shall be at the
applicable rate schedules in section 3-3-11 of this chapter. (Ord. 1630, 12-4-1995)
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 30/283
3-3-8: UTILITY'S INSTALLATION:
(A) Utility's Responsibility: The utility will tap the water main, install a corporation stop, set the curb stop and curb box, and install the connecting piping
between the corporation and curb stops, for all new water services, but will not be responsible for excavation and backfill. See subsection 3-3-7(K) of
this chapter.
Only utility employees or agents are authorized to connect the utility's mains to the customer's service pipe.
(B) Utility System Maintenance: Once service to any customer has been installed, the utility, at its own expense, shall maintain: 1) the utility's service lines
including excavation and backfill; 2) the meter assemblage and remote readout.
(C) Continuity Of Service: The utility will make reasonable effort to avoid interruptions of service, and when such interruptions occur, shall reestablish
service with reasonable diligence.
The utility shall not be liable to customers or others for failure or interruption of service due to acts of God, governmental regulations, court or
commission orders, acts of the public enemy, strikes or labor difficulties, accidents, weather conditions, acts of third parties, droughts or, without
limitation by the foregoing, any other cause beyond the reasonable control of the utility.
(D) Suspension Of Service For Repairs And Changes: When it is necessary for the utility to make repairs to or change its plant, transmission or distribution
system meters or other property, it may, without incurring any liability therefor, suspend service for such periods as may be reasonably necessary, and
in such manner as to minimize the inconvenience to customers.
(E) Adjustment Of Service Charge For Interruptions: Interruptions of service as covered by subsections (B) and (C) of this section shall not render the
utility liable beyond pro rata reduction in flat rate charge, minimum charge or similar charges for any month in which such suspensions exceed an
aggregate of twenty four (24) hours. (Ord. 1630, 12-4-1995)
3-3-9: METERING:
(A) Where Required: All customers receiving city water service, both inside and outside the city limits and whether new or existing, shall have a water
meter installed in a manner approved by the utility. (Ord. 1684, 4-2-2001)
(B) Meter Installation: All new metered water service shall include the installation of a meter with remote reading attachment. The meter shall be located at
some convenient and accessible point inside the premises and so located that it cannot freeze.
For installation within the city, the cost of the remote readout and meter of three-fourths inch (3/4") and smaller shall be borne by the utility. Customers
utilizing a meter in excess of a three-fourths inch (3/4") meter shall bear the costs of the larger meter, but will be credited an amount equal to the
present cost of a three-fourths inch (3/4") meter.
The customer shall also be responsible for any plumbing required to modify piping for installation of a meter in conformance with the utility's standards.
The utility shall be responsible for maintenance of the meter except as specified in subsection (C)2 of this section.
(C) Customer's Responsibility:
1. Customer shall exercise reasonable care in protecting the utility's meter and other utility owned equipment located on his premises. Only utility
employees or agents or persons authorized by law are permitted to inspect or handle same.
2. In the event it is impractical to place a meter inside the premises, the customer will be responsible for providing a meter vault that will protect the
meter from freezing. Customer shall bear all costs in replacing or repairing the meter should a meter freeze or be damaged by the customer.
(D) Final Connection: Final installation of the meter shall in all cases be made by the utility or agent.
(E) Meters Sealed: All meters will be sealed by the utility. The breaking of seals by unauthorized persons or other acts of tampering with meters is
prohibited.
(F) Access To Premises: The duly authorized employees and agents of the utility shall have access at all reasonable hours to the premises of a customer
for the purpose of reading or testing of meter, installing, removing or replacing utility property, and other purposes incidental to the supplying of service.
(G) Extra Meters: One meter only will be supplied for a single service. When a customer desires one or more secondary meters for various tenants in a
single building, the customer will be required to pay not less than five dollars ($5.00) per meter per month for each secondary meter. The bills based on
the readings of such secondary meters and all use from one service must be billed to, and paid by, one customer. The utility will, if so requested, advise
the customer of the monthly readings of the secondary meter.
(H) Type Of Meters: The utility shall, in its sole judgment, determine the size, type and make of any meter installed and may replace any meter at such
time as it determines necessary.
(I) Meter Tests: A customer may, upon depositing the estimated cost of the test thereof, require that a meter be removed and tested, in his presence, as to
its accuracy. Should the meter be found to be registering correctly, or in favor of the customer, then the cost of such test shall be borne by the
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 31/283
customer. If the meter is found to be fast, then the amount deposited for meter testing shall be refunded to the customer, and a reasonable adjustment
made for overcharges for a period not in excess of sixty (60) days prior to the date of the customer's request for a meter test. A meter registering not in
excess of plus or minus two percent (2%) of accuracy shall be deemed accurate.
The testing cost shall include the cost of removing, testing and reinstalling the meter; to include the cost of opening and closing the curb stop if required
for removal and reinstallation.
(J) Estimated Meter Readings: Whenever a meter shall fail to register the consumption of water, the utility will estimate the amount used by averaging the
use during the two (2) previous similar months.
(K) Ownership: Any water meter, after being installed in a service line, regardless of location or payments received from the customer, shall remain the
property of the utility.
(L) Failure To Install Meter When Required: Failure of the customer to install a water meter where required by this section or in any other situation
determined to be in the best interests of the utility, within sixty (60) days of written notice by the utility, shall result in discontinuance of water service by
the utility until such time as the meter is installed. (Ord. 1630, 12-4-1995)
3-3-10: EXTENSIONS:
(A) General:
1. Extension of mains will be permitted by the utility within its service area, where grades of streets and avenues have been established by law along
streets dedicated to public use, county roads, highways or other satisfactory right of way; provided that such extensions shall be permitted only upon
execution of a utility service agreement as approved by the city commission and under such terms as may be specified by the city commission.
2. Extensions beyond the service area will be considered by the utility only upon execution of a service area enlargement application as approved by
the city commission and under such terms as may be specified by the city commission. After the service area enlargement has been approved, a
utility service agreement shall be executed in accordance with this section. (Ord. 1630, 12-4-1995; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
(B) Conditions Of Extensions:
1. The utility must be capable of providing the service requested, as long as pressure conditions permit and sanitary conditions do not render the
extension inadvisable.
2. All areas contiguous or eligible for annexation shall be annexed before the service agreement is approved.
3. Applicants of all areas not eligible for annexation shall furnish waivers of annexation, waiving the right of applicants to protest annexation of the area
to the city when such annexation procedures are instituted by the city. Waivers must be legally binding, recorded with the county clerk and recorder,
Fergus County, Montana, and a copy thereof filed with the city clerk, and run with the land. For subdivisions created after the adoption of this chapter,
such waivers must be included in the covenants for such subdivision. For subdivisions existing at the time of adoption of this chapter, waivers shall
be in legal form, recorded as above, run with the land, and shall be signed by all of the owners of the land embraced by the application. (Ord. 1630,
12-4-1995)
4. All costs and expenses of the extension shall be paid for by the applicant with the following exceptions:
(a) The utility shall pay for the cost for additional facilities or increased main size required solely by the utility to serve future extensions. The amount
to be paid by the utility shall be limited to the increased costs of materials only. The amount shall be agreed to prior to construction.
(b) When it is necessary to extend through an undeveloped area to the development, the city may enter into an agreement with the applicant to
collect a payback charge from the area for a period not to exceed ten (10) years, such payback charges used to reimburse the applicant for costs
of making such improvements. In no case shall the amount reimbursed exceed the actual cost of construction of the extension through the
undeveloped area. The city will administer collection of payback charges and may collect a reasonable administration fee, payable from such
payback charges. The city shall be under no obligation to enter into any such agreement with any applicant. All agreements shall be subject to the
approval of the city commission. (Ord. 1713, 7-3-2006)
5. The customers connected to any extension shall pay for services at those rates currently in effect and shall be governed by the water service
regulations currently in force.
6. All improvements constructed from the utility's facilities to the point of delivery shall be built to the utility's standards for design and construction of
public works.
7. Prior to construction of any residence, building or structure in the area covered by the application, a building permit for each building, residence or
structure must be obtained from the city and shall comply with the building codes, zoning ordinance and subdivision regulations then in force.
8. The applicant shall comply with the city's existing thoroughfare plan and comprehensive storm drainage plan.
9. The applicant shall indemnify and hold the utility harmless from any and all damages or liability arising either directly or indirectly from furnishing said
services. (Ord. 1630, 12-4-1995)

3-3-13: WATER SYSTEM BONDS; EXECUTION:
Bonds issued for the construction, repair or maintenance of the water system of the city shall be forthwith prepared for execution under the direction of the
city clerk and the bond purchaser, and when so prepared shall be executed on behalf of the city by the signatures of the city manager and city treasurer
and countersigned by the city clerk, and the interest coupons appurtenant thereto shall be executed and authenticated by the printed, engraved or
lithographed facsimile signatures of such officers. If requested by the original purchaser of the bonds, a copy of the legal opinion to be rendered by bond
counsel, authenticated by the certificate and facsimile signature of the clerk, shall be printed on the reverse side of each bond, and the last paragraph of
the bond form hereinabove set forth shall be amended by the clerk to include a statement that the city commission has caused the clerk's certificate with
respect to said legal opinion to be executed and authenticated by the clerk's facsimile signature. The printed bonds shall be delivered to the treasurer, and
after registering the bonds in the manner specified in section 11-2318, Revised Codes of Montana, 1947, the treasurer shall cause them to be delivered to
the purchasers thereof, upon payment of the purchase price as specified in the contract of sale made and executed. (Ord. 1483, 3-3-1982; amd. Ord.
1663, 1-3-2000; Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
