3-3-14: WATER SYSTEM IMPROVEMENT FUND:
The premium, if any, and accrued interest from date of issue to date of delivery of bonds issued shall be credited to the revenue bond account of the water
system fund hereinafter created. The par value of the bonds shall be credited and paid into a special fund which is hereby created and shall be maintained
by the city clerk and treasurer upon the books of the city, separate from all of its other funds, designated as the water system improvement fund, and shall
be deposited and secured as provided in section 3-3-15 of this chapter. From this fund there shall be paid as incurred all such items as constitute, in
accordance with sound practices, proper costs of the bond undertaking, as provided in the plans and specifications therefor; including, but without
limitation, all engineering, inspection, fiscal and legal expenses, the cost of lands and easements, the reimbursement of any advances heretofore made by
the city, and all other expenses heretofore incurred and to be incurred in connection with the financing and construction of such undertaking. All other
monies granted to or appropriated by the city for the undertaking shall likewise be credited to this fund. The monies in the fund shall be used only for the
purposes set forth in this section, except that if any monies shall remain after the completion of the undertaking and after payment of all costs thereof, such
remaining monies shall be transferred to the water system fund. (Ord. 1483, 3-3-1982)
3-3-15: WATER SYSTEM FUND:
So long as any of the principal of or interest on any bonds issued for the maintenance and/or construction of the waterworks system of the city shall be
outstanding and unpaid, or until there shall have been set apart in the revenue bond account established in subsection (B) of this section, a sum sufficient
to pay when due, or to redeem prior to maturity, the entire principal of such bonds remaining unpaid, together with interest accrued and to accrue thereon
to maturity or to the earliest date upon which they may be redeemed according to their terms, the city irrevocably covenants with the holders of each and
all bonds that all of the gross revenue derived from the operation of its water system will be accounted for, applied and disposed of in the manner provided
in this section, and will be deposited and secured as provided for in this chapter. Such gross revenues are hereby defined to include all income and
receipts derived from rates, charges and rentals imposed for connections with and for the use of such system, including all additions thereto and
betterments and replacements thereof originally or subsequently constructed or acquired, or for the benefits provided by the facilities of the system, or
from sales of property acquired in connection therewith, and all penalties and interest on such rates, charges and rentals, but shall not include any special
assessments levied for the construction of water mains or other improvements. All gross revenues shall be paid daily, as received by the city, into the
water system fund, which fund shall at all times be segregated and maintained by the city clerk and treasurer on the books of the city as a separate and
special fund. This fund shall be subdivided into the separate accounts described below and the gross revenues received in the fund shall be appropriated
once in each calendar month, or as often as collections permit, but in no event less than once in each calendar quarter, which appointment is hereinafter
referred to as the "periodic apportionment". The gross revenues received in the fund shall be credited to the respective accounts and accounted for therein
and expended therefrom as follows: (Ord. 1483, 3-3-1982)
(A) Operating Account: On each periodic apportionment there shall first be set aside and credited to the operating account, as a first charge on the gross
revenues, such amount as may be required over and above the balance then held in the account to pay the reasonable and necessary operating
expenses of the system which are then due and payable, or are to be paid prior to the next periodic apportionment. The term "operating expenses"
shall mean the current expenses, paid or accrued, of operation, maintenance and current repair of the water system and its facilities as calculated in
accordance with sound accounting practice, and shall include, without limitation, administrative expenses of the city relating solely to the water system,
premiums for insurance on the properties thereof, labor and the cost of materials and supplies used for current operation and for maintenance, and
charges for the accumulation of appropriate reserves for current expenses which are not recurrent monthly, but may reasonably be expected to be
incurred in accordance with sound accounting practices. Such expenses shall not include any allowance for depreciation or renewals or replacements
of capital assets of the system and shall not include any portion of the salaries or wages paid to any officer or employee of the city, except such
portions as shall represent reasonable compensation for the performance of duties necessary to the operation of the water system. There shall also be
credited to this account all additional sums collected since the last periodic apportionment, until there has been accumulated therein an operating
reserve in the amount of three thousand five hundred dollars ($3,500.00), which sum shall be maintained by additional transfers upon each periodic
apportionment whenever necessary, or may be augmented by transfers of additional amounts from the surplus account described below if determined
by the city commission to be necessary to meet contingencies arising in the operation and maintenance of the system. Monies in the operating account
shall be used solely for the payment of current operating expenses of the water system as herein defined.
(B) Revenue Bond Account: The net revenues of the municipal water system, as referred to herein, are hereby defined to include the entire amount of
such gross revenues remaining upon each such periodic apportionment, after crediting to the operating account the amount required in subsection (A)
of this section, including sums required to create and maintain the operating reserve at the minimum amount therein stated. Upon each periodic
apportionment there shall be set aside and credited to the revenue bond account out of the net revenues an amount equal to not less than one-twelfth
(1/12) (or if the periodic apportionment is not monthly, then that fraction which is obtained by dividing the number of months since the last periodic
apportionment by 12) of the total sum of the principal and interest to become due within the then next succeeding twelve (12) months on all bonds
outstanding and on all bonds refunding the same (exclusive of principal and interest for the payment of which funds have been placed in escrow); and
of the remaining net revenues on hand there shall also be credited to the revenue bond account a sum equivalent to one thousand two hundred fifty
dollars ($1,250.00) for each month since the last periodic apportionment, until there shall have been accumulated in the account an additional reserve
which shall thereafter be maintained by the transfer of additional net revenues whenever necessary, in an amount at all times at least equal to the
maximum amount of principal and interest to fall due on all bonds within any subsequent fiscal year. Monies from time to time held in the revenue bond
account shall be disbursed only to meet payments of the principal and interest on such bonds as such payments become due, and the reserve therein
shall be used only to pay maturing principal and interest when other monies within the account are insufficient therefor; provided, that if in any periodic
apportionment there is apportioned to such reserve an amount in excess of the amount required to be apportioned, that excess may be credited
against the amount required in a subsequent apportionment or may be transferred by resolution of the city commission to any other account in the
water system fund, and if the maximum amount of principal and interest to fall due on all outstanding bonds within any subsequent fiscal year is less
than the amount accumulated and on hand in such reserve, such excess may likewise be transferred by resolution of the city commission to any other
account in the water system fund; provided, further, that on any date when all outstanding bonds are due or prepayable by their terms, if the amount
then on hand in the revenue bond account, including the reserve, is sufficient to pay all such bonds and the interest accrued thereon in full, it may be
used for that purpose. If any payment of principal or interest becomes due when monies in the revenue bond account are temporarily insufficient
therefor, such payment shall be advanced out of any net revenues theretofore segregated and then on hand in the replacement and depreciation
account or the surplus account.
(C) Replacement And Depreciation Account: There shall next be set aside and credited upon each such apportionment to the replacement and
depreciation account such portion of the net revenues of the system, in excess of the current requirements of the revenue bond account which portion
of the net revenues is referred to herein as "surplus net revenues", as the city commission shall determine to be required for the accumulation of a
reasonable allowance for depreciation of the system and for the replacement or renewal of worn out or obsolete properties comprised therein. Monies
in this account shall be used only for the purposes above stated, or, if so directed by the city commission, to redeem revenue bonds which are
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 35/283
prepayable according to their terms, or to pay principal or interest when due thereon as required by subsection (B) of this section; provided, that in the
event the city shall hereafter issue bonds over and above the amount heretofore authorized, for the purpose of financing the construction and
installation of additional improvements or additions to the water system, surplus net revenues from time to time received may be segregated and paid
into one or more separate and additional accounts for the payment of such bonds and interest thereon, in advance of payments required to be made
into the replacement and depreciation account. (Ord. 1483, 3-3-1982; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
(D) Surplus Account: Any amount of the surplus net revenues from time to time remaining after the above required applications thereof shall be credited to
the surplus account, and the monies from time to time in that account, when not required to restore a current deficiency in the revenue bond account as
provided herein, may be used for any of the following purposes and not otherwise:
1. To redeem and repay bonds payable from the net revenues when and as such bonds become prepayable according to their terms; or
2. To purchase such bonds on the open market, at a price to yield the city a net return, based on the dollar amount of interest payable to the respective
maturities of bonds so purchased, or to the earliest dates upon which they are prepayable according to their terms, which bonds shall be canceled
forthwith upon being so purchased; or
3. To be held as a reserve for redemption and prepayment of bonds payable from the net revenues which are not then, but will later, be prepayable
according to their terms; or
4. To pay for repairs of or for the construction and installation of improvements or additions to the water system; or (Ord. 1483, 3-3-1982)
5. To restore the operating reserve or increase the same when determined to be necessary by the city commission. (Ord. 1483, 3-3-1982; amd. Ord.
1664, 1-3-2000)
No monies shall at any time be transferred from the surplus account or any other account of the water system fund to any other fund of the city, nor
shall such monies at any time be loaned to other municipal funds or invested in warrants, special improvement bonds or other obligations payable
from other funds. (Ord. 1483, 3-3-1982)
3-3-16: DEPOSIT AND INVESTMENT OF FUNDS:
The treasurer shall cause all monies pertaining to the water system fund and the water system improvement fund to be deposited as received with one or
more depository banks duly qualified in accordance with the provisions of section 16-2618, Revised Codes of Montana, 1947, in a deposit account or
accounts which shall be maintained separate and apart from all other bank accounts of the city so long as any bonds issued and the interest thereon shall
remain unpaid; and, the balance in such accounts, except such portion thereof as shall be guaranteed by federal deposit insurance, shall, at all times be
secured to its full amount by bonds or securities of the types set forth in said section 16-2618. No monies shall at any time be withdrawn from such deposit
accounts except for the purposes of the water system fund and the water system improvement fund as defined and authorized herein; except that monies
from time to time on hand in either of these funds in excess of amounts required to be paid from such fund within the next succeeding twelve (12) months,
may, at any time, in the discretion of the city commission, be invested in securities which are general obligations of the United States of America, maturing
not more than five (5) years from the date of such investment; and, provided further, that monies pertaining to the surplus account of the water system fund
may, in the discretion of the city commission, be invested in any securities which are general obligations of the United States of America or are general
obligations of the city. The income received from any such investments shall be credited to the fund and account from whose monies the investment was
purchased, and handled and accounted for in the same manner as other monies in that fund or account. (Ord. 1483, 3-3-1982; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
3-3-17: POLICY STATEMENT:
It is the policy of the city to ensure that new developments or projects are adequately served by the public water system, and further, that the costs of
upgrading or renovating the system to accommodate such developments or projects be equitably and fairly apportioned between existing and anticipated
users of the system.
(A) Applicability: The terms of this section apply to any single development or project whereby it is estimated that the water requirements for such
development or project would exceed the existing capacity or unduly burden the existing water system, making it necessary or advisable to upgrade or
renovate any portion of the system.
This section does not apply to situations whereby a project or development causes an extension of service, except in situations where any portion of
the existing system requires upgrading or renovation, notwithstanding the fact that an extension of service occurs.
(B) Assessment: The developer, or other person or entity which builds or constructs any applicable development or project, shall pay a fee to the city
based upon the projected twenty (20) year design flow of water through the renovated or upgraded system. The amount of the fee shall be a
percentage of the total cost of upgrading or renovating the system equal to the percentage of the twenty (20) year design flow through the upgraded or
renovated system by the development or project.
Costs incurred in excess of the assessment fee will be paid by the utility from the replacement fund described in subsection 3-3-15(C) of this chapter.
(C) Projections And Estimates: The utility is solely responsible for making projections or estimates of flow rates. Such projections and estimates shall be
based upon recognized generally accepted practices or methods.
(D) Payment, Connection Fees: Payment of the fee assessed herein shall be made prior to the commencement of construction of the required upgrading
or renovation. Upon payment of the assessed fee, any connection charges, which would otherwise be owing to the utility, shall be waived. (Ord. 1516,
7-2-1984)
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 36/283
Chapter 4
TELEPHONIC ALARM SYSTEMS
3-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
"Telephonic alarm system" shall mean any mechanism, equipment or device which is designed to operate automatically through the use of public
telephone facilities to transmit a signal, message or warning to another location. (Ord. 1424, 12-19-1977)
3-4-2: PERMIT REQUIRED:
(A) No person shall operate or maintain a telephonic alarm system which automatically transmits an audible signal to any city police department or fire
department telephone line without first obtaining a permit as required by this chapter.
(B) Any person who presently has and maintains a telephonic alarm system which automatically transmits an audible signal through the Lewistown police
department or fire department telephone line shall, within thirty (30) days after the effective date of this chapter, obtain a permit as required by this
chapter. (Ord. 1424, 12-19-1977)
3-4-3: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT:
Applications for permits to install, maintain or operate a telephonic alarm system which is intended to automatically transmit an audible signal through the
police department or fire department telephone line shall be filed with the chief of the concerned department on forms supplied by the city, together with an
application fee of five dollars ($5.00). Said applications shall set forth the name, address and telephone number of both the installer of the system and the
person or business on whose premises the system will be installed, as well as a description of the system and the location where it is proposed to be
installed. The chief of the concerned department shall approve such application if he finds that:
(A) The use of said alarm system to transmit an audible signal to the police department or fire department telephone line will not interfere with the orderly
conduct of city business.
(B) The person installing the system maintain an adequate service organization to repair, maintain and otherwise service telephonic alarm systems sold or
leased by him. The police chief or fire chief may impose reasonable conditions on the exercise of said permit. (Ord. 1424, 12-19-1977)
3-4-4: RIGHT OF INSPECTION:
The chief of the concerned department shall have the right to inspect any telephonic alarm system on the premises where it is intended to function prior to
issuance of any permit for its operation and he may cause an inspection of such system to be made at any time after issuance of a permit to determine
whether it is being used in conformity with the terms of the permit and the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 1424, 12-19-1977)
3-4-5: RESTRICTED NUMBERS:
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to install, operate or maintain a telephonic alarm system which automatically transmits an audible
signal to the police department or fire department telephone line except to such telephone number or numbers as designated by the permit issued under
the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 1424, 12-19-1977)
3-4-6: REVOCATION:
The chief of the concerned department may revoke a permit issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter after giving written notice to the permit holder
and an opportunity for the permit holder to be heard if he determines that the telephonic alarm system installed pursuant to said permit has been installed,
maintained or operated in violation of the provisions of this chapter, or of any term or condition of said permit, or for failure to pay the fees specified in
section 3-4-7 of this chapter. (Ord. 1424, 12-19-1977)
3-4-7: PERMIT FEES:
Each permit holder shall pay to the city on or before July 1 of each year, a fee in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00) to reimburse the city for the cost of
providing special telephone lines to receive calls from telephonic alarm systems and other expenses of operation.
Each permit holder from the fire department shall be responsible for the actual cost to the city for manpower, equipment and apparatus responding to a
malfunction or a false alarm of such private fire alarm system. (Ord. 1424, 12-19-1977)
Chapter 5
AMBULANCE SERVICE
3-5-1: ESTABLISHMENT:
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 37/283
Pursuant to the authority found in section 7-34-101, Montana Code Annotated, the city has established in the past and has maintained an ambulance
service; for the purpose of which is to provide emergency medical service in and around Lewistown and Fergus County, Montana. (Ord. 1579, 12-18-1989)
3-5-2: ADVISORY COMMITTEE:
There shall be an advisory committee to the Lewistown ambulance service, composed of five (5) members, nominated by the city manager and approved
by the city commission, who shall hold their positions for a period of two (2) years. The terms of the members shall be staggered, so that each year, on
July 1 two (2) members will be appointed. The city manager shall be a member of the committee, and shall so serve during his term of office as city
manager. (Ord. 1579, 12-18-1989; amd. Ord. 1663, 1-3-2000; Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
The advisory committee shall have representation from the Central Montana Hospital, the Lewistown city commission, the Fergus County board of
commissioners and the public at large. (Ord. 1579, 12-18-1989; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
The presiding officer of the advisory committee shall be the city manager. The ambulance director shall attend all meetings and advise or report to the
committee. (Ord. 1579, 12-18-1989; amd. Ord. 1663, 1-3-2000)
The advisory committee shall meet as needed, and may establish rules of procedure or policies to govern its operation or the operation of the Lewistown
ambulance service. All such rules or policies shall be submitted to the city commission for approval. (Ord. 1579, 12-18-1989; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
3-5-3: AMBULANCE DIRECTOR:
The ambulance director shall be subject to appointment by the city manager and approval of the city commission. Such position shall have the status as a
department head. (Ord. 1579, 12-18-1989; amd. Ord. 1663, 1-3-2000; Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
3-5-4: EMPLOYEES:
The ambulance director shall be the immediate supervisor of the emergency medical technicians (EMTs) and ambulance service employees. The EMTs
shall be certified or approved in accordance with the requirements of the Montana board of medical examiners and the National Association of Emergency
Medical Technicians. (Ord. 1579, 12-18-1989)
3-5-5: FEES AND CHARGES:
The advisory committee shall set or establish fee schedules for the various types of services provided by the Lewistown ambulance service. Such fee
schedules shall be subject to city commission approval.
The Lewistown city commission finds that prompt and full payment of recipients of services is essential to the viability and continued operation of the
Lewistown ambulance service. Such service is vital to the well being of the residents of Lewistown and Fergus County. Consequently, the known failure of
service recipients to timely and fully pay for services received at the rates then in effect, shall constitute a misdemeanor, and shall be punishable as
provided by the general penalty section of this code1. Nothing in the section shall allow contravention of medicare or medicaid regulations or policies. (Ord.
1579, 12-18-1989; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
3-5-6: INTERFERENCE WITH EMTs:
It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly interfere, hinder or otherwise obstruct those employees of the Lewistown ambulance service who are
engaged in responding to or providing emergency medical or associated services. Such conduct will be punishable as provided by the general penalty
section of this code2. (Ord. 1579, 12-18-1989)
Title 4
BUILDING REGULATIONS
Chapter 1
BUILDING CODE
4-1-1: BUILDING CODE ADOPTION AND ENFORCEMENT:
(A) Adoption Of Building Codes: The current editions of the building codes and all accompanying appendices, amendments and modification adopted by
the building codes bureau, Montana department of labor and industry (or its successor), as set out in the administrative rules of Montana, as amended
from time to time by the building codes bureau, shall be adopted by reference by administrative order of the public works director as authorized by
section 50-60-301(1)(b), Montana Code Annotated except for any exceptions noted in this chapter or any regulations not applicable to local
government jurisdictions. These codes are applicable to all buildings within the building code enforcement area of the city of Lewistown, Montana,
including, but not limited to, residential buildings containing less than five (5) dwelling units or their attached-to structures, any farm or ranch building,
and any private garage or private storage structure used only for the owner's own use as provided by section 50-60-102(1)(a), Montana Code
Annotated.
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 38/283
1. The adopted building codes shall regulate the erection, construction, enlargement, alteration, repair, moving, removal, demolition, conversion,
occupancy, equipment, use, height, area and maintenance of all buildings and/or structures in the city and its jurisdictional area, providing for
issuance of permits and collection of fees and penalties.
2. One copy of each code shall be on file in the office of the city clerk.
3. Any codes or amendments adopted by the building codes bureau which apply to local government jurisdictions, including the adoption of the latest
editions of the model technical codes or applicable administrative rules of Montana, shall become effective in the city upon order of the public works
director within ten (10) days after the date that the bureau notifies the city of the amendments.
(B) Abatement Of Dangerous Buildings Code Adopted: The uniform code for the abatement of dangerous buildings, 1997 edition, is adopted.
(C) International Energy Conservation Code Adopted: The 2003 edition of the international energy conservation code, regulating and governing energy
efficient building envelopes and installation of energy efficient mechanical, lighting and power systems in the city of Lewistown and providing for the
issuance of permits and collection of fees therefor is adopted.
(D) International Existing Building Code Adopted: The 2003 edition of the international existing building code, regulating and governing the repair,
alteration, change of occupancy, addition, and relocation of existing buildings, including historic buildings, in the city of Lewistown and providing for the
issuance of permits and collection of fees therefor is adopted.
(E) Penalties: Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of these codes hereby adopted or fail to comply therewith, or who shall violate or fail to
comply with any order made thereunder, or who shall build in violation of any detailed statement of specifications or plans submitted and approved
thereunder, or any certificate or permit issued thereunder, and from which no appeal has been taken, or who shall fail to comply with such an order as
affirmed or modified by the city commission or by a court of competent jurisdiction, within the time fixed herein, shall severally for each and every such
violation and noncompliance respectively, be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than three
hundred dollars ($300.00) or by imprisonment for not less than three (3) days nor more than thirty (30) days or by both such fine and imprisonment.
The imposition of one penalty for any violation shall not excuse the violation or permit it to continue; all of such persons shall be required to correct or
remedy such violations or defects within a reasonable time; and when not otherwise specified, each ten (10) days that prohibited conditions are
maintained shall constitute a separate offense.
The application of the above penalty shall not be held to prevent the enforced removal of the prohibited conditions.
(F) Repeal Of Conflicting Ordinances: All former ordinances or parts thereof conflicting or inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter are hereby
repealed.
(G) Severability: If any provision of this chapter or the application thereof to any person or circumstances is held invalid, such invalidity shall not affect the
other provisions of this chapter which may be given effect without the invalid provisions or application, and, to this end, the provisions of this chapter
are declared to be severable.
(H) Date Of Effect: This chapter shall take effect and be in force thirty (30) days from and after its passage and approval on second reading. (Ord. 1701, 2-
7-2005)
4-1-2: BUILDING OFFICIAL:
The office of building official is hereby created and the executive official in charge shall be known as the building official, who shall be appointed by the city
manager. His appointment shall continue during good behavior and satisfactory service. He shall not be removed from office except for cause after full
opportunity has been given him to be heard on specific charges. The fire chief, in the absence of other appointment, shall be ex officio building official.
During temporary absence or disability of the building official the appointing authority shall designate an acting building official. (Ord. 1652, 1-4-1999)
4-1-3: QUALIFICATIONS OF BUILDING OFFICIAL:
To be eligible to appointment, the candidate for the position shall be in good health, physically capable of making the necessary examinations and
inspections. He shall not have any interest whatever, directly or indirectly, in the sale or manufacture of any materials, process or device entering into or
used in or in connection with building construction, alterations, removal and demolition. (Ord. 1082, 12-23-1957)
4-1-4: DUTIES:
(A) The building official shall devote part time to the duties of his office. He shall receive applications required by this code, issue permits and furnish the
prescribed certificates. He shall examine premises for which permits have been issued and shall make necessary inspections to see that the provisions
of law are complied with and the construction is prosecuted safely. He shall enforce all provisions of the building code. He shall, when requested by
proper authority, or when the public interest so requires, make investigations in connection with matters referred to in the building code and render
written reports on the same. To enforce compliance with law, to remove illegal or unsafe conditions, to secure the necessary safeguards during
construction, or to require adequate exit facilities in buildings and structures, he shall issue such notices or orders as may be necessary.
(B) Inspections required under the provisions of the building code shall be made by the building official or his duly appointed assistant. The building official
may accept reports of inspectors or recognized inspection services, after investigation of their qualifications and reliability. No certificate called for by
any provision of the building code shall be issued on such reports unless the same are in writing and certified to be a responsible officer of such
service.
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 39/283
(C) The building official shall keep comprehensive records of applications, of permits issued, of certificates issued, of inspections made, of reports
rendered, and of notices or orders issued. He shall retain on file copies of required plans and all documents relating to building work so long as any
part of the building or structure to which they relate may be in existence.
(D) All such records shall be open to public inspection for good and sufficient reasons at the stated office hours, but shall not be removed from the office of
the building official without his written consent.
(E) The building official shall make written reports to his immediate superior once each month, or more often if requested, including statements of permits
and certificates issued, and orders promulgated. (Ord. 1082, 12-23-1957)
4-1-5: COOPERATION OF OTHER OFFICIALS:
The building official may request and shall receive so far as may be necessary in the discharge of his duties, the assistance and cooperation of other
officials of the municipality. (Ord. 1082, 12-23-1957)
4-1-6: RIGHT OF ENTRY:
The building official, in the discharge of his official duties, and upon proper identification, shall have authority to enter any building, structure, or premises
at any reasonable hour. (Ord. 1082, 12-23-1957)
4-1-7: BOARD OF APPEALS:
(A) General: In order to hear and decide appeals of orders, decisions or determinations made by the building official relative to the application and
interpretation of this code, there shall be and is hereby created a board of appeals consisting of three (3) members who are qualified by experience and
training to pass on matters pertaining to building construction and who are not employees of the city. The building official shall be an ex officio member
of and shall act as secretary to the board but shall have no vote on any matter before the board. Members of the board of appeals shall be appointed
by the city commission and shall hold office at its pleasure. The board shall adopt rules of procedure of conducting its business, and shall render all
decisions and findings in writing to the appellant with a duplicate copy to the building official.
(B) Limitations Of Authority: The board of appeals shall have no authority relative to interpretation of the administrative provisions of any code nor shall the
board be empowered to waive requirements of any code. (Ord. 1652, 1-4-1999)
Chapter 2
PLUMBING CODE
4-2-1: ADOPTION OF PLUMBING CODE:
A certain document, one copy of which is on file in the office of the city clerk being marked and designated as the "Uniform Plumbing Code, 1979 Edition",
was amended and published by International Association of Plumbing and Mechanical Officials and is hereby adopted as the plumbing code of the city
controlling the erection, installation, operation, addition, repair, relocation, replacement, maintenance or use of any plumbing system within the city,
providing penalties for violation of the regulations, provisions, conditions and terms of such uniform plumbing code, and said uniform plumbing code
referred to and adopted is made a part hereof as if fully set out in this chapter. (Ord. 1467, 11-3-1980)
4-2-2: LICENSE AND BOND REQUIRED:
Any person, firm or corporation wishing to engage in the business of plumbing in the city may, at any regular meeting of the city commission make
application to be accompanied by a copy of certificate of examination of state license together with information as to the location of the place of business
past and present. The license fee for plumbing shall be forty seven dollars ($47.00) per year or unexpired part thereof ending in all cases on December 31.
Prior to the issuance of said license the applicant shall file thereafter and keep on file in the office of the city clerk, and in full force and effect at all times, a
surety bond executed by a surety company duly authorized to transact business in the state and running to the city, in the sum of five thousand dollars
($5,000.00), to be approved by the city commission, conditioned to the effect that such person, firm or corporation shall perform all work in connection with
plumbing and fixtures and installations connected therewith in a skillful and workmanlike manner, using only suitable and proper materials, equipment and
appliances and shall comply with all of the provisions of this code relating thereto and shall indemnify and save harmless the city and any person, firm or
corporation, resident or property owner within the city against any and all loss or damage said city, person, firm, corporation, resident or property owner
may suffer on account of any work performed in said business within said city when caused or resulting from any malfeasance or nonfeasance or
negligence in connection with any of the activities or conditions upon which the license applied for is granted. (Ord. 1643, 2-16-1998)
Chapter 3
GAS PIPING
4-3-1: APPLICATION OF REGULATIONS:
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 40/283
The provisions of this chapter shall apply to all installations, extensions, additions, alterations, maintenance, and repairs of gas piping, equipment and
appliances on a consumer's premises from the outlet of the utility's gas meter. (Ord. 1064, 9-24-1956)
4-3-2: INSPECTOR:
Under this chapter, the building inspector of the city shall enforce the provisions hereof and for the purpose of enforcement shall have the right to enter any
and all buildings and premises at all reasonable times to inspect gas piping, equipment, and appliances. (Ord. 1064, 9-24-1956)
4-3-3: LICENSE AND BOND REQUIRED BY GAS FITTERS:
Any person engaging in the business of installing, maintaining or repairing gas piping, equipment or appliances, shall first apply to the clerk for a license to
engage in such business and do such work and shall pay to the city a license fee as follows:
The sum of ninety five dollars ($95.00) the first time the license is issued and forty seven dollars ($47.00) for each consecutive year thereafter.
The license fee for gas fitters shall be for each year or unexpired part thereof ending in all cases on December 31. Any license not renewed on or before
January 30 of each year shall revert to ninety five dollars ($95.00).
No person shall install gas piping, equipment, or appliances unless said person shall have first complied with all of the provisions of this chapter with
regard to said license as set forth hereinabove.
Prior to issuance of said license, the applicant shall file and thereafter keep on file in the office of the clerk in full force and effect at all times, a bond
executed by a surety company duly authorized to transact business in this state and running to the city in the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) to
be approved by the city commission, conditioned to the effect that such person, firm, or corporation shall perform all work in connection with the
installation, maintenance, and repair of gas piping, equipment, and appliances in a skillful and workmanlike manner, using only suitable and proper
materials, equipment, and appliances and shall comply with all the provisions of this code relating thereto and shall indemnify and save harmless the city
and any person, firm or corporation, resident or property owner within the city against any and all loss or damage said city, person, firm, corporation,
resident or property owner may suffer on account of any work performed in said business within said city when caused or resulting from any malfeasance
or nonfeasance or negligence in connection with any of the activities or conditions upon which the license applied for is granted. (Ord. 1645, 2-2-1998)
4-3-4: INSPECTIONS:
Every person, firm, or corporation shall make application to the inspector, furnishing required plans and specifications, and obtain a permit from said
inspector before installing, extending, or altering any gas piping, equipment or appliances for the conveyance or use of natural or artificial gas on a
consumer's premises from the outlet of the utility's gas meter. Said permit form to be provided by the inspector.
It shall be unlawful for the gas utility or any employee or agent thereof, or any other person to turn on gas at the meter into any new system of gas piping,
or into any old system of gas piping which has been extended or altered, on a consumer's premises beyond the utility's gas meter until the inspector has
inspected the gas piping, equipment, and appliances to ensure the tightness of the system, the proper and safe installation of piping, equipment, and
appliances and the use of safe and proper materials, equipment, and appliances, and has approved such installation.
The inspector shall endorse on the back of the copy of the permit on file in his office the date of such inspection and approval. The utility shall, upon
demand of the inspector, turn gas on at any time for the purpose of inspection and test.
It shall be unlawful for any person, except an agent of the gas utility, to turn on gas at the meter into any new system of gas piping or into any old system
of gas piping after it has been turned off for any reason. (Ord. 1064, 9-24-1956)
4-3-5: CONFORMANCE TO GOOD PRACTICE:
(A) All gas piping, equipment, and appliances for the conveyance and use of natural or artificial gas shall be installed to conform with generally accepted
good practice. The standards for "Installation of Gas Piping and Gas Appliances in Buildings" as adopted and amended from time to time by the
American Gas Association, while not exclusive, shall be deemed to be generally accepted good practice.
(B) It shall be unlawful to turn gas into or use any gas piping, equipment, or appliances until the same has been inspected and approved by the inspector
as provided in this chapter.
(C) Concealed unions or bushings of any type will not be permitted.
(D) Rubber hose connections or fittings arranged for rubber hose connections for gas heaters or similar appliances shall not be permitted.
(E) All gas consuming appliances shall be suitably vented.
(F) Piping shall be of a size and so installed as to provide a supply of gas sufficient to meet the maximum demand of all appliances served by that piping
without undue loss of pressure between the meter and the appliance or appliances.
(G) Standard full weight wrought iron or steel pipe, free from defects, shall be used in conveying gas from meter to appliances, except that approved
seamless, well annealed, nonferrous tubing with approved fittings may be used for permanent connections of small stationary appliances such as
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 41/283
radiant fires installed in fireplaces. All fittings for wrought iron or steel pipe (except stopcocks or valves) shall be of best quality malleable iron. Threads
shall be in accordance with the American pipe thread standard. (Ord. 1064, 9-24-1956)
4-3-6: METER TESTS:
All piping, equipment, and appliances shall be tested for tightness before being used, either by a meter turn on test or an air pressure test, as follows:
(A) Meter Turn On Test: All gas outlets shall be closed and gas shall be turned into the system and the hand on the test dial of the meter carefully watched
to ascertain that no gas is passing through the meter. This test shall be applied for a reasonable length of time, but in no case for less than fifteen (15)
minutes.
(B) Air Pressure Test: Air pressure of not less than three (3) pounds per square inch above the atmospheric pressure shall be applied to the system for a
period of not less than ten (10) minutes. In case of concealed piping, the air pressure test must be used, with pressure at not less than six (6) pounds
per square inch above atmospheric pressure.
All testing apparatus shall be furnished by the installer. Piping shall be completely roughed in and ready for testing prior to the time for inspection. (Ord.
1064, 9-24-1956)
4-3-7: UNSAFE CONDITIONS:
Whenever an inspection shall reveal a condition unsafe to life or property, the inspector shall notify the consumer of what is necessary to correct the
unsafe condition and shall not permit gas to be turned on until all such conditions have been corrected, remedied and made safe. The inspector may make
subsequent inspections and tests of gas piping, gas installations and gas appliances, when he believes, or has reason to believe, that any appliances,
piping or venting are in an unsafe condition to life or property and the inspector shall order the gas utility to discontinue the supply of gas to any consumer
when any such condition is found and until the same is remedied. (Ord. 1064, 9-24-1956)
4-3-8: DISPUTE BETWEEN GAS UTILITY AND CONSUMER:
Whenever there shall arise between a gas utility and a consumer a dispute relative to the safety of any installation or appliance, the matter shall be
referred to the inspector who shall examine the same or cause it to be examined and make final determination thereon. (Ord. 1064, 9-24-1956)
4-3-9: FEES FOR INSPECTION:
There shall be paid to the building inspector for the making of each inspection by the inspector of any gas installations, gas piping, gas fixtures and
appliances the following amounts:
(A) For the inspection of gas installations within the city from the outlet of the utility's gas meter on a consumer's premises the sum of five dollars ($5.00);
and for each additional appliance, fifty cents ($0.50) per appliance.
(B) For the inspection of gas installation outside of the limits of the city from the outlet of the utility's gas meter on a consumer's premises the amount of
seven dollars fifty cents ($7.50); and for each additional appliance, fifty cents ($0.50) per appliance.
Fees shall be paid upon taking out permit required hereinbefore. (Ord. 1383, 7-21-1975, eff. 8-19-1975)

All persons installing electric wire or appliances for the transmission of electrical energy for lights, heat or power in any building within the city, except

license is issued and forty seven dollars ($47.00) for each consecutive year thereafter. All licenses shall be issued for one year and obtained on or before
January 30 of each year and will expire on December 31 of the current year. Any license not renewed on or before January 30 of each year shall revert to

ninety five dollars ($95.00). At time of application, applicant must show proof of valid Montana state electrical license, either master or journeyman, as one
