PERSONAL SERVICES
(Rep. by Ord. 1700, 12-6-2004)
Chapter 4
PUBLIC SERVICES
(Rep. by Ord. 1700, 12-6-2004)
Chapter 5
REGISTRATION CERTIFICATE
5-5-1: PURPOSE:
Any business exempted from the provisions of this title with regards to the obtaining of a business license shall nevertheless obtain a registration
certificate from the city to ensure that the building, store, or office complies with other ordinances and regulations enacted for the purpose of protecting the
health, safety, and welfare of the public. The registration certificate is a certificate for a premises or occupation at a specific premises acknowledging
compliance with uniform safety codes or other ordinances and regulations enacted for the purpose of protecting health, safety, and welfare of the public.
The certificate is not intended, and shall not be used, to regulate or infringe upon the conduct of a business or profession and is not intended, and shall not
be used, to regulate, infringe or prohibit the practice of religion or religious beliefs. (Ord. 1700, 12-6-2004)
5-5-2: PROCEDURE FOR ISSUANCE OF CERTIFICATE:
(A) Prior to issuing a registration certificate, the applicant shall:
1. Be in compliance with all zoning, building and fire codes and have permanent water and sewer service provided by the city.
2. Submit a completed application as specified by the city accompanied by the full amount of the applicable fee.
(B) The applicant may change location provided:
1. The applicant complies with all zoning, building and fire codes.
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 56/283
2. The applicant obtains a new certificate for the change of location. The applicant may transfer the certificate to another person in accordance with
established procedures.
(C) When a person is carrying on two (2) or more different classifications of business at a single place of business which require obtaining both a city
business license and city registration certificate, the person shall be required to obtain both a city business license and registration certificate, however
the combined fee for all such licenses/registration certificates shall be equivalent to the highest single license fee or registration certificate applicable.
(Ord. 1700, 12-6-2004)
5-5-3: REGISTRATION CERTIFICATE FEE:
(A) The registration certificate fee shall be defined by resolution adopted by the city commission.
(B) New businesses, excluding nonresident merchants, established within the last ninety (90) days of the calendar year shall not pay the initial annual
renewal fee.
(C) No rebate or refund of any certificate fee, or part thereof, shall be made. (Ord. 1700, 12-6-2004)
5-5-4: REGISTRATION FEE; RENEWAL:
All registration certificates shall expire on December 31 of the year in which the certificate is issued, unless otherwise specified. (Ord. 1700, 12-6-2004)
5-5-5: LATE CHARGE:
(A) Failure to renew the registration certificate shall result in a delinquent charge as determined by resolution.
(B) Each day that any violation of this chapter occurs or continues may constitute a separate offense and may be punishable as a separate violation. (Ord.
1700, 12-6-2004)
5-5-6: DUTIES OF LICENSEE OR CERTIFICATE HOLDER:
(A) Every licensee or certificate holder under this title shall permit all reasonable inspections of the business premises by public authorities to carry out the
intent of this title.
(B) Every licensee or certificate holder under this title shall post the certificate or special license on the premises or carried on the person where an
individual license is required. (Ord. 1700, 12-6-2004)
5-5-7: PENALTY:
Failure to obtain a registration certificate shall subject the violator to the general penalty provided by section 1-3-1 of this code. In addition, a civil judgment
for the amount of the license fee due and unpaid, plus penalty may be entered against the defendant. (Ord. 1700, 12-6-2004)
5-5-8: CERTIFICATE REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION:
(A) The certificate may be revoked or suspended when the certificate holder violates this title.
(B) The following procedure will be followed in revoking or suspending a certificate:
1. A written notice shall be provided to the certificate holder at least fifteen (15) days prior to revocation or suspension. The notice shall state the
reason(s) for the action.
2. The certificate holder may request a review of the proposed action within fifteen (15) days of the receipt of notice.
3. When a review is requested, a meeting shall be set between city staff and the requesting party.
(C) If conditions are determined to cause an immediate threat to health or safety, the city shall immediately suspend the certificate until such condition is
remedied. (Ord. 1700, 12-6-2004)
5-5-9: APPEAL:
Any certificate holder shall have the right to file a written appeal to the city commission. (Ord. 1700, 12-6-2004)
5-5-10: SEVERABILITY:
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 57/283
If any part of this chapter or title is for any reason held to be invalid or unconstitutional, such decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions
thereof. (Ord. 1700, 12-6-2004)
Chapter 6
SALESMEN
5-6-1: RESIDENT SALESMAN:
(Rep. by Ord. 1700, 12-6-2004)
5-6-2: NONRESIDENT SALESMAN:
Any person not a bona fide resident of the city carrying on business by the sale of any product or merchandise within the city to persons other than
businesses without maintaining a fixed and regular place of business, or any person not a bona fide resident of the city carrying on a business by the sale
of any product or merchandise door to door at residences within the city shall obtain a nonresident salesman's license. (Ord. 1479, 12-21-1981)
5-6-3: ADDITIONAL REQUIREMENTS FOR NONRESIDENT SALESMAN'S LICENSE:
In addition to providing the information necessary to complete the basic application for a city business license, an applicant for a nonresident salesman's
license shall:
(A) Give a brief descriptive list of the products or merchandise to be offered for sale by him.
(B) State whether the total value of any sale to be made by him will exceed twenty five dollars ($25.00).
(C) Be required to read and sign a statement stating that the applicant has read sections 30-14-501 through 30-14-508, Montana Code Annotated, entitled
"personal solicitation sales".
(D) If the total value of any sale to be made by the applicant will exceed twenty five dollars ($25.00), the applicant shall be required to show the licensing
official that the applicant has in the applicant's possession sufficient copies of such notices as are required by section 30-14-505, Montana Code
Annotated. The licensing official shall make available a copy of sections 30-14-501 through 30-14-508, Montana Code Annotated, for reading by the
applicant. (Ord. 1700, 12-6-2004)
5-6-4: LIMITATIONS OF LICENSE:
(Rep. by Ord. 1700, 12-6-2004)
5-6-5: NONRESIDENT MERCHANT:
Any person carrying on business by the selling at retail of any product or merchandise from a regular and fixed place of business outside of the city
through an agent or representative to the resident public of the city from a location or locations within the city shall obtain a business license from the city.
(Ord. 1700, 12-6-2004)
Chapter 7
TRANSPORTATION
(Rep. by Ord. 1700, 12-6-2004)
Chapter 8
AMUSEMENTS
5-8-1: AMUSEMENT LICENSE:
Any person carrying on business by or including the offering of any form of amusement or entertainment to the public for profit within the city, or advertising
by public display or parade the existence thereof, shall obtain a business license prior to the commencement of any activity within the city. (Ord. 1700, 12-
6-2004)
5-8-2: ADVANCE LICENSING:
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 58/283
(Rep. by Ord. 1700, 12-6-2004)
5-8-3: POLICE PROTECTION:
In addition to paying the license fee, persons obtaining an amusement business license may be required to pay such additional amount of money as the
city manager may require to reasonably compensate the city for the additional costs of police protection or assistance necessitated by the amusement to
be licensed. (Ord. 1700, 12-6-2004)
Chapter 9
SECONDHAND AND JUNK DEALERS
5-9-1: REGISTER REQUIRED:
Every person that carries on the business of dealer in secondhand goods, or junk dealers in the city, must at the time of the transaction enter in a register
kept for that purpose, in the English language, an accurate description of any and all property sold to him, together with the name and residence of the
seller, and the date of such purchase, and leave sufficient space at the place of the entry for further record, and must, thereafter, upon the sale of any such
property so purchased, enter in such register at the same place at the time of sale, the name and address of any and all purchasers of the property, and
such entries must show the amount paid for and received for the property, and such records must be kept up to date. This register shall, upon request by
any police officer of the city, be produced for inspection by them; and any and all property purchased by such secondhand dealer or junk dealer while
remaining in their possession shall, upon request of such officer, be produced for inspection. (Ord. 1700, 12-6-2004)
5-9-2: PURCHASE FROM MINOR:
No dealer in secondhand goods or junk dealers shall purchase any property from a minor without the written consent of the parent or guardian of such
minor. (Ord. 905, 7-18-1949)
Chapter 10
PAWNBROKERS
5-10-1: DEFINITION:
"Pawnbroker" means a person engaged in conduction or carrying on the business of loaning money for the person or for another, upon personal property,
personal security, pawns, or pledges, or engaged in the business of purchasing articles of personal property and reselling or agreeing to resell the articles
to the vendors or their assigns at prices agreed on at or before the time of purchase. (Ord. 1700, 12-6-2004)
5-10-2: SURETY BOND:
Every person so licensed shall, at the time of receiving such license, enter with two (2) sufficient sureties, approved by the city manager or attorney, in a
joint and several bond with the city in the penalty of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), conditioned for the due observances of all such provisions of this
code as may be passed or enforced respecting pawnbrokers or loan brokers or keepers of loan offices, at any time during the continuance of such a
license; and no pawnbroker shall engage or be interested in any secondhand store or business during the continuance of such license. (Ord. 1624, 6-5-
1995; amd. Ord. 1663, 1-3-2000)
5-10-3: PAWNBROKER TO KEEP REGISTER:
(A) Every pawnbroker or junk dealer must keep a register, in which must be entered a description of every article pawned to him or purchased by him,
with:
1. The date of the pawning or purchasing;
2. Date when the article was redeemed;
3. The name of the person by whom the same was pawned or by whom purchased; and
4. The amount loaned thereon or paid therefor.
(B) In case of the sale of an article pawned or pledged, the pawnbroker must enter upon the register:
1. The name of the purchaser;
2. The time of the sale; and
3. The price paid therefor. (Ord. 1624, 6-5-1995)
5-10-4: PAWNBROKER TO GIVE MEMORANDUM:
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 59/283
Every pawnbroker, or loan broker, or keeper of a loan office shall at the time of each loan, deliver to the person pawning or pledging any goods, article or
things, a memorandum or note signed by him containing the substance of the required registry. No charge shall be made or received by any pawnbroker
or loan broker or keeper of a loan office for such entry, memorandum or note. (Ord. 1624, 6-5-1995)
5-10-5: DAILY REPORT TO THE CHIEF OF POLICE:
It shall be the duty of every pawnbroker or dealer to deliver daily to the chief of police, a report of all personal property and other valuable things received
on deposit or purchased during the preceding day. This report shall be on a form as provided by the chief of police and shall include a complete description
and serial number, if applicable, of each item. It shall include the name of the person pawning or selling the items along with his/her address and complete
physical description, including the following: date of birth, social security number, driver's license number, if different, state of license, height, weight, color
of eyes, and hair. A print of the right index finger will be placed on the form, if no picture ID card is presented. And no personal property received on
deposit, purchased or pledged shall be sold or permitted to be redeemed or removed from the places of business for a space of twenty four (24) hours
after the copy and statement required to be delivered to the chief of police shall have been delivered as required by this section. (Ord. 1624, 6-5-1995)
5-10-6: HOURS WHEN OPEN:
No pawnbroker or dealer shall receive on deposit or pledge any personal property or other valuable thing before the hour of seven o'clock (7:00) A.M., or
after the hour of eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. (Ord. 1624, 6-5-1995)
5-10-7: DEALING WITH MINORS:
No pawnbroker or dealer shall take or receive in pawn, or pledge for money loaned any property, bonds, notes, securities, articles, or other valuable things
from any person under the age of eighteen (18) years, or the ownership of which is in or claimed by any person under the age of eighteen (18) years, or
which may be in the possession of or under the control of any person under the age of eighteen (18) years. (Ord. 1624, 6-5-1995)
5-10-8: INTOXICATED PERSONS:
No pawnbroker or dealer shall take any article in pawn from any person appearing to be intoxicated. (Ord. 1624, 6-5-1995)
5-10-9: AGE REQUIREMENT:
No person licensed as aforesaid shall employ any person under the age of eighteen (18) years to take pledges in pawn. (Ord. 1624, 6-5-1995)
5-10-10: PAWNBROKER TO SURRENDER STOLEN PROPERTY:
When a peace officer informs a pawnbroker or dealer who buys and sells secondhand merchandise that property pawned or purchased by the pawnbroker
or dealer is stolen property, the pawnbroker or dealer who buys and sells secondhand merchandise shall hold the property for thirty (30) days unless
demanded by a peace officer. The peace officer shall give the pawnbroker or dealer a receipt for any property surrendered by the pawnbroker or dealer.
(Ord. 1624, 6-5-1995)
5-10-11: DISPOSAL OF STOLEN PROPERTY:
A pawnbroker or dealer who buys and sells secondhand merchandise and allows stolen property to be sold, bartered, or otherwise disposed of after a
peace officer has requested him to hold the property for thirty (30) days, as provided, commits the offense of theft. (Ord. 1624, 6-5-1995)
5-10-12: CHIEF OF POLICE TO REPORT:
It shall be the duty of the chief of police to report to the city commission any failure to comply with any provisions of this chapter, and they may revoke the
license of such person. (Ord. 1624, 6-5-1995; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
Chapter 11
AUCTIONEERS
5-11-1: REQUIREMENTS FOR SALE:
It shall be unlawful for any person acting as an auctioneer, under the provisions hereof, to make any misrepresentation whatsoever, regarding any article
or property sold or offered for sale by him, or to substitute anything for the article or property sold or offered for sale. It shall be the duty of any person so
acting as an auctioneer, under the provisions hereof, to state publicly, in the hearing of the purchaser, the actual character and quality of the article or
property sold, or offered for sale, and every person acting as an auctioneer in the city, and selling goods at public auction in said city, shall receive back
from any purchaser any article or property misrepresented by him in any way, and shall return to the purchaser the purchase price thereof. (Ord. 1109, 3-
16-1959)
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 60/283
5-11-2: AUCTIONS ON STREETS PROHIBITED:
Nothing herein contained, nor any license issued hereunder, shall authorize and it shall be unlawful for any person so acting as an auctioneer, under the
provisions hereof, to offer for sale at public auction any goods, wares or merchandise in any street, avenue, alley or public place in the city, or to so act as
such auctioneer so as to obstruct or encumber any street, avenue, alley or public place in the city. (Ord. 1109, 3-16-1959)
5-11-3: LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE:
Any person desiring to act as an auctioneer in the city shall first obtain a license for each and every day that person desires to act as such auctioneer;
provided, any auctioneer who is a permanent resident of the city and has resided within the city for thirty (30) days preceding next application for license,
and has established a place of business within the city, may obtain an annual license. (Ord. 1700, 12-6-2004)
Chapter 12
ROOMING HOUSES
5-12-1: DEFINITION:
A "rooming house" within the meaning of this chapter shall include every building or structure kept, used or maintained as or advertised as or held out to
be an inn, hotel or public lodging house or place where sleeping accommodations are furnished for hire to guests whether with or without meals in which
five (5) or more rooms are used for the accommodation of such guests and shall include all such places hereinabove mentioned where such sleeping
accommodations are furnished either by day, week, night or month. (Ord. 387, 10-16-1916)
5-12-2: POSTING OF LICENSE:
Every person to whom a rooming house license shall hereafter be issued, under the provisions of this chapter, shall keep such license posted up on a
conspicuous and public place in such rooming house. (Ord. 387, 10-16-1916)
5-12-3: REGISTER:
Every person keeping, conducting, running or managing a rooming house in the city shall keep a permanent register therein, in which shall be entered the
names of each and every person occupying any room in such rooming house, and the residence of each such person so occupying any room therein,
together with the number of the room occupied by such person, and it shall be the duty of such person so keeping, conducting, running, managing or
having charge of a rooming house in the city to see that such entry is made in said register before any person begins to occupy any room therein, and to
cancel such registration immediately upon such room being vacated. (Ord. 387, 10-16-1916)
5-12-4: REGISTER OPEN TO INSPECTION:
The register shall be kept in a prominent and conspicuous place in such rooming house, and shall be open to inspection by any member of the police force
or any other legally qualified and acting officer of the law of the city, at any hour of the day or night. (Ord. 387, 10-16-1916)
5-12-5: REGULATIONS:
No person keeping, conducting, running or managing any rooming house in the city shall allow, permit or sanction intoxicating liquors to be sold, given
away or dispensed in, upon or about such rooming house, or allow, permit or sanction any person to sign or cause to be signed fictitious names to any
register kept therein or allow, permit or harbor any prostitute, lewd woman, or woman of loose or lax morals, to resort to any of the rooms in any such
rooming house, or allow or permit any man or woman to resort thereto for the purpose of prostitution or for any other immoral purpose, or allow, permit or
sanction in said rooming house wanton, lewd or obscene language, acts or gestures, or any indecent or immoral exhibitions or exposures of the person of
any male or female, or allow or permit any woman in a drunken condition or allow or permit any unseemly, indecent, immoral act, thing or speech, or any
disorderly conduct, or allow or sanction or remain in, at or about the said rooming house, and it is the duty of said person keeping, conducting or managing
said rooming house to report the said persons so conducting themselves, as heretofore set forth, to the proper authorities of the city within twenty four (24)
hours. (Ord. 387, 10-16-1916)
Chapter 13
BILLPOSTERS
5-13-1: BOND:
Any person desiring to engage in the foregoing occupations, or any part thereof, shall first file with the city commission a bond with sufficient sureties to be
approved by the city commission, in the penal sum of two hundred dollars ($200.00), conditioned that the person licensed to engage in any of the above
occupations will save and protect harmless the said city from any and all damage in the prosecution of said business and will conform to all of the
provisions of this code regulating said business. (Ord. 414, 7-2-1917; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
5-13-2: ERECTION OF BILLBOARDS:
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 61/283
No person shall engage in the billposting, sign and bulletin business without having first erected, in a safe and secure manner, as hereinafter provided,
billboards or signs and bulletin boards on the locations and at the points where said billposting or sign display advertisements are to be exhibited. (Ord.
414, 7-2-1917)
5-13-3: PERMIT TO CONSTRUCT BILLBOARD:
No person shall erect or reconstruct any billboard without first securing a permit so to do from the building inspector in accordance with the provisions of
this chapter. The term "billboard" shall, for the purpose of this chapter, include all structures which are erected, maintained or used for the public display of
posters, painted signs or reading matter, except such as are attached to the roof or walls of buildings and excepting such as are less than forty (40) square
feet in area. No single billboard shall exceed more than twelve feet (12') from the lower edge to the upper edge and an average open space of at least
eighteen inches (18") in height shall be kept and maintained between the bottom edge of any such billboard and the level of the ground. No billboard shall
be placed at a distance less than three feet (3') from any building; provided, however, that in granting a permit for erecting a billboard the building
inspector, at his discretion, may or may not require an open space of not to exceed three feet (3') to be left between said billboard and an adjoining
building.
Every person to whom a permit is issued for the erection of a billboard shall, during the time such a billboard is maintained, keep it in good repair and in a
safe and stable condition. (Ord. 414, 7-2-1917)
5-13-4: NOTICE TO REPAIR BILLBOARDS:
Whenever any billboard is found to be in an unsafe condition by the building inspector, he shall notify the person maintaining such billboard to take down
or repair the same. (Ord. 414, 7-2-1917)
5-13-5: UNLAWFUL POSTING OR ADVERTISING:
No person shall paste, post, paint, print, nail or otherwise fasten any handbill, sign, poster, advertisement or notice of any kind whatsoever, or cause the
same to be done on any curbstone, flagstone or any other portion or part of any sidewalk or street, or upon any tree, lamppost, telegraph pole, telephone
pole, hydrant, bridge, pier or upon any structure within the limits of any street without the express consent of the city commission, and no person shall
paste, post, paint, print, nail or otherwise fasten any handbills, sign, poster, advertisement or notice of any kind, or cause the same to be done, upon any
private walls, window, door, gate, fence, advertising board or sign, or upon any other private structure or building, unless he is the owner thereof without
the consent in writing of the owner of such wall, window, door, gate, fence, advertising board or sign, or other private building or structure. (Ord. 414, 7-2-
1917; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
When any handbill, sign, poster, advertisement or notice of any kind shall be found pasted, posted, painted, printed, or otherwise fastened on any
curbstone, flagstone, or any other portion or part of any sidewalk, or upon any tree, lamppost, telegraph pole, telephone pole, hydrant, bridge, pier, or upon
any private wall, window, door, gate, fence, advertising board or sign, or any private building or structure, in any way, the finding of such handbill, sign,
poster, advertisement or notice shall be prima facie evidence that it was pasted, posted, painted, printed, nailed, or otherwise fastened, contrary to the
provisions of this section by the person thereby advertised. (Ord. 414, 7-2-1917)
5-13-6: WASTE MATERIALS PROHIBITED ON STREETS:
No person shall scatter, daub, or leave any paste, glue or other like substance used for affixing bills upon any public sidewalk or pavement, or scatter or
throw any old bills or other waste material removed from billboards upon the surface of any private property. (Ord. 414, 7-2-1917)
5-13-7: PROHIBITED POSTING:
No person shall post, paint or affix any sign or advertisement upon any structure, save those which have been erected and are suitable billboards, signs or
bulletin boards, for the affixing and display of said advertisements. (Ord. 414, 7-2-1917)
5-13-8: POSTING OF LEGAL NOTICE:
Nothing contained in this chapter shall be construed to apply to the posting of legal notices by public officers or attorneys, in the manner and in the places
prescribed by law, nor to the circulation and distribution by any person of advertisements of his own business nor with the rights of any daily or weekly
newspaper to distribute its papers throughout the city. (Ord. 414, 7-2-1917)
5-13-9: NAME OF FIRM TO BE ON BILLBOARD:
No permit shall be issued to any applicant for permission to erect a billboard or signboard, unless such applicant shall agree to place and maintain on the
top of such billboard, or sign, the name of the person owning same or who is in possession, control or charge thereof. It shall be the duty of the building
inspector or other officer, to see to it that the name of the person owning or in possession, charge or control of said billboard or bulletin board is placed
upon such billboard or bulletin board forthwith upon the erection thereof, and is kept thereon at all times while such billboard or sign and bulletin board is
maintained. (Ord. 414, 7-2-1917)
5-13-10: VEHICLE REQUIREMENTS:
Every person licensed to carry on the business or occupation of billposting, sign or bulletin painting, distributing, card and banner tacking or any similar
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 62/283
business, shall forthwith cause the name of the owner and the number of the license to be plainly painted in letters at least four inches (4") in height in a
conspicuous place on the outside of each side of any vehicle used in said business, and shall keep the same plain and distinct at all times when used
during the continuance of such license; but, upon the expiration of such license, unless renewed, such person shall immediately cause said name and
number to be erased from said vehicle, and shall not allow said vehicle to be used with said name and number thereon. (Ord. 414, 7-2-1917)
Chapter 14
PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS
5-14-1: NUISANCE DECLARED:
The practice of going in and upon private property and/or residences in the city, by solicitors, peddlers, hawkers, itinerant merchants and transient vendors
of merchandise, not having been requested or invited so to do by the owner or owners, occupant or occupants of said private residences, for the purpose
of soliciting orders for the sale of goods, wares and merchandise and/or for the purpose of disposing of and/or peddling or hawking the same, is hereby
declared to be a nuisance and as such to be unlawful and punishable as such nuisance as hereinafter provided. (Ord. 901, 5-16-1949)
5-14-2: ENFORCEMENT BY POLICE DEPARTMENT:
It shall be the duty of the police department of the city to suppress and abate any nuisance defined in this chapter. (Ord. 901, 5-16-1949)
5-14-3: PENALTY FOR VIOLATION:
Any person creating a nuisance as defined in this chapter, or who shall violate any provision hereof, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon
conviction thereof, shall be fined not less than five dollars ($5.00), nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00), and if such fine is not paid, shall be
confined in the city jail, one day for each two dollars ($2.00) or part thereof of such fine. (Ord. 901, 5-16-1949)
5-14-4: EXCEPTIONS:
The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to the sale or soliciting of orders for sale or disposal of farm and garden produce when so offered by the
actual grower or producer thereof; provided that nothing contained in this section shall relieve such grower or producer from obtaining the proper license
and/or permit provided for in this code. (1961 Code)
Chapter 15
BEER AND WINE REGULATIONS
5-15-1: ADOPTION:
The city hereby adopts chapters 3, 4 and 6, title 16, Montana Code Annotated, Montana liquor, beer and wine act of the state of Montana, and its police
officers are hereby required to enforce said law and this act shall be governing in all respects for all acts and omissions herein had. (Ord. 1484, 3-5-1982)
5-15-2: DUTY OF CITY OFFICERS TO ENFORCE MONTANA LIQUOR, BEER AND WINE ACT:
The city hereby recognizes the right, among officers, reserved by the Montana liquor, beer and wine act to the several cities and incorporated towns of this
state to enact ordinances for the enforcement of said act. To that end, the penal provisions of said chapters are hereby adopted as the law of this city, and
the police court of this city is hereby vested with the jurisdiction and the duty is hereby imposed upon the city attorney, chief of police, and police
magistrate of this city to enforce the same. (Ord. 1484, 3-5-1982)
5-15-3: PROHIBITING ALL, EXCEPT CERTAIN ACTS OR OMISSIONS PROHIBITED BY THE SAID CHAPTERS, OR BY
REGULATIONS OF THE DEPARTMENT OF REVENUE:
All acts or omissions, except and save those relating to persons maintaining or operating any railroad car or train as a common carrier for the
transportation of passengers, which are prohibited or declared unlawful by the Montana liquor, beer and wine act or by such regulations as may be made
by the department of revenue which shall have the full force and effect of law, are hereby prohibited and declared unlawful. (Ord. 1484, 3-5-1982; amd.
Ord. 1648A, 2-2-1998)
5-15-4: PENALTIES IN ACT IN PART ADOPTED AND IN PART MODIFIED:
Violations of said act for failure of any person regulated thereby, are subject to the penalty provided in said act. (Ord. 1484, 3-5-1982)
5-15-5: CONCURRENCE WITH LOCAL OPTION:
The municipality hereby recognizes that its power to enforce the liquor, beer and wine act and to license the places of business where beer or wine is sold
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 63/283
is dependent upon the electors of the county in the exercise of the right accorded by them by said act to determine whether or not the sale of liquor, beer
and wine, as therein provided for, shall be permitted within the limits of said county; and, in that end, if such electors should determine, as therein provided,
that the sale of beer and wine shall not be permitted within the limits of said county, then this chapter shall stand suspended and inoperative until and
unless such electors reverse their decisions; and, as often as, and upon every reversal or decision, this chapter shall stand either effective or suspended
and inoperative in concurrence with the vote of the electors upon the question of whether or not the sale of beer or wine, as in said act provided, shall be
permitted within the limits of said county. (Ord. 1484, 3-5-1982)
5-15-6: MONTANA LIQUOR, BEER AND WINE ACT:
The phrase "Montana liquor, beer and wine act" as used herein is defined as chapter 6, title 16, Montana Code Annotated, referred to as the "Montana
alcoholic beverage code". (Ord. 1484, 3-5-1982)
5-15-7: MUNICIPAL LICENSE REQUIREMENT; LICENSE FEE:
(A) Under and by virtue of the power granted to the commissions of the cities and towns of this state, and in aid of the police power and regulations of the
municipality and in exercise of the authority reserved by the "Montana alcoholic beverage code" to the cities and incorporated towns of this state, it is
hereby ordained that any person, who desires to engage in the business of selling beer and wine in the municipality under the provisions of the act in
the character of places hereinafter mentioned, and as defined by the act shall, notwithstanding the fact that the person conducting such place has
obtained a license from the department of revenue, first apply for and obtain a license therefor from the municipality, as herein provided, and if such
license is granted, shall pay therefor an annual license fee as determined by resolution of the city commission.
(B) All licenses issued in any year shall expire on December 31 at twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight of such year; provided, in case the holder of any such
license shall be in default for the payment of such license fee, or any part thereof, the license shall immediately terminate.
(C) A transfer of any such license may be made on application to the municipality, accompanied by satisfactory evidence of an approval of the transfer of
the license issued by the department of revenue of this state for such business.
(D) Where a license hereunder is issued for a period commencing subsequent to the first of any current year for which such license may be issued, a pro
rata fee only shall be charged for the balance of such current year, but nothing herein shall be construed to entitle any licensee hereunder to a refund
of any portion of the license fee in the event of licensee discontinuing such business or the suspension or revocation of licensee's license, prior to the
expiration of such year. (Ord. 1700, 12-6-2004)
5-15-8: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Every person required by this chapter to obtain a license must, before commencing such business, file with the finance officer an application, in writing,
directed to the city commission of the municipality. Such application shall be substantially the same form which shall be prescribed by the department of
revenue to carry out the provisions of the Montana liquor, beer and wine act and must be accompanied by satisfactory evidence that the applicant is the
owner and holder of a subsisting license or permit issued by the department under the provisions of the act and the same location for which application for
license is being made. Such application must be accompanied with the license fee specified for the business applied for, and if such applicant is an agent,
such applicant must accompany such application with the principal's acknowledgment of such. (Ord. 1700, 12-6-2004)
5-15-9: ISSUANCE OF LICENSE ENDORSEMENT:
Upon the filing of the application prescribed herein, accompanied by the evidence required, and upon payment of the license fee, the clerk shall issue and
deliver to the applicant a license to carry on the business for which the applicant owns and holds a subsisting license, issued to such applicant for such
business at such location by the department, and the same shall refer to this chapter by its number and as the "Lewistown, Montana, beer and wine
regulations". The clerk shall endorse upon each application and accompanying documents, if any, in the clerk's office, and shall keep an appropriate index
thereof, which shall show the date filed, the name of the applicant and the character and location of the business and an appropriate file number, if any, by
which the application and accompanying documents, if any, may be found. (Ord. 1700, 12-6-2004)
5-15-10: DISPLAYING OF LICENSE:
Any and all licenses under the provisions of this chapter shall be, at all times, prominently displayed in the place of business of such license. (Ord. 1484, 3-
5-1982)
5-15-11: OPENING AND CLOSING HOURS:
Hereafter all licensed establishments wherein alcoholic beverages are sold, offered for sale or given away at retail shall be closed during the following
hours:
On any day between two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. During such hours all persons except the owner and employees of such licensed
establishment shall be excluded therefrom. (Ord. 1484, 3-5-1982)
5-15-12: POLICE MAGISTRATE TO REPORT CONVICTIONS:
In the case of the conviction of any licensee hereunder of any violation of this chapter in the police court of this municipality, the police magistrate shall,
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 64/283
within ten (10) days thereafter, whether or not an appeal has been taken from the judgment of conviction, transmit to the department of revenue of the
state, a certified copy of the record of conviction. (Ord. 1484, 3-5-1982; amd. Ord. 1648A, 2-2-1998)
5-15-13: REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF LICENSE:
If any license issued by the department of revenue under the provisions of the "Montana liquor, beer and wine act" shall be revoked, or shall be suspended
under the provisions of said act, the companion license issued under the provisions of this chapter shall be automatically revoked or suspended for the
said period, and in the event such action by the department of revenue shall, on appeal, be modified or set aside, the suspension or revocation of the
license issued under the provisions of this chapter shall likewise be automatically affected. (Ord. 1484, 3-5-1982; amd. Ord. 1648A, 2-2-1998)
5-15-14: SALE OF, RESTRICTIONS:
It shall be unlawful for any licensee or any other person to sell, dispose of or give away alcoholic beverages to any person who shall appear to be in an
intoxicated or disorderly condition, or to allow such person to be or remain in or upon his premises or to be employed therein. (Ord. 1551, 5-19-1986)
5-15-15: INSPECTION AND REGULATIONS FOR POLICE POWER:
Every person shall be subject to regulations, inspection, control and supervision under the general police power of the municipality, and all laws in force, or
which may hereafter be adopted in and of such police power and regulation, and each and every license shall be subject to suspension and revocation as
hereinabove provided. (Ord. 1484, 3-5-1982)
Chapter 16
LIQUOR REGULATIONS
5-16-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words and phrases when used in this chapter shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them:
ACT: Chapters 3 and 6, title 16, Montana Code Annotated of the state of Montana.
CLUB: A national fraternal organization with permanent quarters or rooms, except college fraternities, or an association of individuals organized for social
purposes and not for profit, with a permanent membership and in existence two (2) years.
COMMISSION: The city commission of this municipality.
INTERDICTED PERSON: A person to whom the sale of liquor is prohibited under the laws of the state.
LICENSE: A license issued by this municipality to a qualified person under which it shall be lawful for the licensee to sell or dispense liquor at retail as
provided in this chapter.
LIQUOR: All kinds of liquor sold by and/or in the state liquor store.
STATE LIQUOR STORE: A liquor store established and operated by the Montana liquor control board under the laws of the state of Montana.
All other words and phrases used in this chapter, the definitions of which are not herein given, shall be given the ordinary meanings. (1961 Code; amd.
Ord. 1486, 5-3-1982; Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
5-16-2: LICENSE FEE; REFUND OF:
Licenses may be issued to qualified applicants as herein provided, whereby the licensee shall be authorized and permitted to sell liquor at retail in
accordance with the provisions of this chapter. Qualified applicants shall include persons, hotels, clubs, and fraternal organizations.
Each licensee under the provisions of this chapter shall pay an annual license fee for each license as determined by resolution of the city commission.
Provided, however, that where a license hereunder is issued for a period commencing subsequent to the first of the current year a pro rata charge may be
made therefor, but nothing herein shall be construed to entitle any licensee hereunder to any refund of any portion of the license fee in the event of the
discontinuing of such business, or the suspension or revocation of licensee's license, except that the licensee shall be entitled to a pro rata refund in the
event that licensee's business is discontinued by virtue of the act, being, by referendum petition, rendered inoperative and awaiting such time as it may be
passed upon at any election.
The license fees herein provided for are exclusive of and in addition to other license fees chargeable in this municipality. However, persons, organizations
or businesses obtaining a license under this chapter shall not be required to pay an additional fee for licenses obtained for the sale of beer and wine. (Ord.
1700, 12-6-2004)
5-16-3: APPLICATION:
Prior to the issuance of a license as herein provided, the applicant shall file with the clerk an application in writing, signed by the applicant, and directed to
the city commission, which application shall specify the location by street and number of the premises where the business is to be carried on under the
license applied for, the names of the persons conducting the business of the same if a partnership, and if the same is a fraternal order such fact must
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 65/283
therein be set forth. The application must be accompanied by satisfactory evidence that the applicant has the licenses as herein provided for. Such
application must be accompanied with the license fee in the preceding section specified for the business applied for.
Upon the filing of the application described in the preceding paragraph, accompanied by the evidence thereby required, and upon the payment of the
required license fee, the clerk shall issue and deliver to the applicant a license to carry on the business for which the applicant owns and holds subsisting
licenses in respect to the same premises for which license is applied for as provided. Provided however, that the clerk at his discretion, may hold the
application for license until the next regular meeting of the city commission following his receipt of such application and accompanying documents to the
city commission, which may, in its discretion, decline to issue such license, if in the judgment of the city commission, it shall be for the best interests of this
municipality to refuse such license. Upon such refusal the license fee paid by the applicant and all documents filed by him, other than such licenses, shall
be returned to the applicant. (1961 Code)
5-16-4: NONTRANSFERABLE; EXCEPTION:
Every license issued under this chapter shall set forth the name of the person to whom issued and the location by street and number of the premises
where the business is to be carried on under such license. If it is a partnership it shall set further names of the persons conducting the business. Such
license shall be signed by the licensee and shall be nontransferable; provided, however, that a transfer of any such license may be made on application to
the city commission, accompanied by satisfactory evidence of the consent of the Montana liquor control board to such transfer of the license by it issued
under said act. Such license shall be posted in a conspicuous place on the premises in respect to which it is issued and shall be exhibited to any member
of the police department.
Every license issued under the provisions of this chapter is separate and distinct, and no person, except the licensee therein named, shall exercise any of
the privileges granted thereunder and all the licenses are applicable only to the premises in respect to which they are issued. All licenses shall expire on
December 31, at twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight, of each year. (1961 Code)
5-16-5: QUALIFICATIONS:
No person, club, or fraternal organization shall be entitled to a license under this chapter unless such person, club, or fraternal organization shall have in
respect to the same premises for which a license under this chapter is sought:
(A) A subsisting license issued under said act.
(B) A subsisting beer license under the laws of Montana; and
(C) A subsisting beer license issued under the laws of this municipality. (1961 Code)
5-16-6: RESTRICTIONS:
(A) No licensee shall sell, deliver, or give away, or cause or permit to be sold, delivered or given away, any liquor to:
1. Any minor actually under the age of nineteen (19) years.
2. Any intoxicated person or any person actually, apparently or obviously intoxicated.
3. An habitual drunkard.
4. An interdicted person.
(B) Hereafter all licensed establishments wherein alcoholic beverages are sold, offered for sale, or given away at retail shall be closed during the following
hours:
1. On any day between two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. During such hours all persons except the owner and employees of such
licensed establishments shall be excluded therefrom. (Ord. 1486, 5-3-1982)
(C) It shall be unlawful for any licensee to sell or keep for sale and/or have on his premises for any purpose whatever, any liquor, except that purchased
from a state liquor store, and any licensee found in possession of, or selling and keeping for sale any liquor which was not purchased from a state
liquor store, shall, upon conviction, be punished, and if the city commission shall be satisfied that any such liquor was knowingly sold or kept for sale
within the licensed premises by such licensee, or by his agents, servants or employees, it shall be mandatory that the city commission immediately
revoke the license of such licensee. (1961 Code; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
5-16-7: EXCEPTIONS FOR SALE OF:
It shall be unlawful for any person who has not been issued a license under this chapter to sell or keep for sale any alcoholic liquor; provided, however,
that nothing herein contained shall be deemed to apply to those engaged in the sale of liquor:
(A) At the various state liquor stores;
(B) In any dining or buffet car operated by any railroad in connection with regularly operated train service, when the person serving such liquor is in the
employ of said railroad and is acting within the scope of his employment in so doing; provided, a license has been issued to said railroad under said act
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 66/283
by the Montana liquor control board, and the same, or a duplicate thereof, is displayed in such car. (1961 Code)
5-16-8: INVESTIGATION; REVOCATION:
(A) The city commission may, upon its own motion, and shall upon a written verified complaint of any person, investigate the action and operation of any
licensee hereunder, and shall have the power to temporarily suspend and/or permanently revoke a license issued under this chapter for violation of any
provision of this chapter.
(B) Upon the filing with the city commission of a verified complaint charging the licensee with the commission of any act which would be cause for the
suspension or revocation of a license, within one year prior to the date of filing said complaint, the city commission shall forthwith issue a citation
directing the licensee to appear before the city commission within ten (10) days after the date of the service of said citation and filing his verified answer
to the complaint, showing cause, if any, why his license should not be suspended or revoked. Service of the citation may be effected by mailing a true
copy thereof, with a true copy of the complaint, by registered mail, addressed to the licensee at his last address on record, or by the chief of police of
this municipality. Failure of the licensee to answer shall be deemed an admission by him of the truthfulness of the charge made and thereupon the city
commission shall be authorized to forthwith suspend or revoke the license.
(C) Upon the filing of the answer, the city commission shall fix the time and place of the hearing on the charges made, which hearing shall be in the city
commission chambers of the municipality, and not less than five (5) days' notice of said hearing shall be given to the complainant and licensee. The
notice of hearing shall be served in the same manner as is the citation herein provided for. With the notice of the hearing to the complainant, there shall
be attached a true copy of the answer of the licensee. If either party has appeared by counsel, the notice shall be given in like manner to the counsel of
said party. The city commission shall hear the evidence presented, which may be in the form of oral testimony, affidavits or both. After the hearing has
been concluded, the city commission shall, within ten (10) days, render its decision in writing, stating the reasons therefor. Notice of the decision, with a
copy thereof, shall be served upon the parties, or their counsel, in the manner herein provided as to other notices. When the city commission shall have
revoked or canceled a license, the city commission shall notify the licensee by registered mail, to the address of such licensee, of its action, giving
reason thereof. Should the action of the city commission be arbitrary or capricious, anyone aggrieved thereby shall by appropriate proceedings, be
entitled to have the action of the city commission reviewed by the district court of the state, in and for this county.
(D) After suspension or revocation of a license the city commission shall have the power to renew the same if in their discretion, a proper showing therefor
has been made. (1961 Code; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
5-16-9: INSPECTION OF PREMISES:
The city commission, or any duly authorized representative thereof, or the city manager, chief of police or any member of the police department of this
municipality, shall have the right at any time to make an examination of the premises of such licensee as to whether this chapter is being complied with.
(1961 Code; amd. Ord. 1663, 1-3-2000; Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
Chapter 17
TRADE STIMULATORS
5-17-1: LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE:
No trade stimulator, including punchboards, pull cards, articles and similar devices shall be exhibited nor shall any person, firm, association or corporation
be interested in the exhibiting of the same, or exhibit the same or cause same to be exhibited without having affixed thereon in a conspicuous place a use
stamp tax placed thereon by the exhibitor showing the payment of such use tax. Said use tax shall, at such time be simultaneously canceled by said
exhibitor indicating by unerasable writing over the face thereof, identified by his initials and the date of cancellation on each stamp. Such use tax stamp
shall show that a special tax has been paid thereon at the true rate hereby levied and imposed in the amount of four percent (4%) of the value of the total
number of such tabs, tickets, pellets, punches or similar things on the board or the full cash return of such trade stimulators to the exhibitor, as computed
by the purchase price posted by the exhibitor as the going price of each numbered ticket, variegated symbol, token or its equivalent. (Ord. 1452, 11-19-
1979)
5-17-2: TREASURER TO PROVIDE STAMPS:
The city treasurer is hereby authorized and empowered to provide such use tax stamps in such design, title, forms and denominations as will be
appropriate, is hereby charged with the duty of selling the same for cash and to collect the money therefor, and shall, within thirty (30) days from such sale,
place the proceeds from the sale of such use tax stamps in the general fund of the city; provided, however, that, out of said proceeds the city manager and
city commission do and they are hereby authorized and directed to pay on claims regularly prescribed against the city and approved by the city manager
and city commission, the costs and expenses of administering the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 947, 4-23-1951; amd. Ord. 1663, 1-3-2000; Ord. 1664,
1-3-2000)

5-18-1: RECORDS TO BE INSPECTED:
The books and records of any small loan business or company licensed under the provisions of this chapter shall be open to inspection by the clerk, the
