5. Video Gambling Devices:
(a) For all licenses, the fees for each individual video gambling device are:
(1) Per year one hundred dollars ($100.00) for all such devices which are regulated and licensed by the state of Montana, pursuant to title 23,
chapter 5, part 6, Montana Code Annotated, except electronic keno machines. Such license fees are to be prorated and nonrefundable.
(2) Per year one hundred dollars ($100.00) for all such other video gambling devices, including electronic keno machines. Such license fees are to
be prorated and are nonrefundable. (Ord. 1565, 7-6-1987)
(C) Application For Renewal Of A Gaming License Fee: An application for the renewal of a duly issued, valid and subsisting gambling license shall be
accompanied by a nonrefundable twenty five dollar ($25.00) investigation fee for each individual applicant, except churches and nonprofit
organizations.
(D) One Day Special Gambling License Fees:
1. Nonprofit organizations and churches may, in lieu of an annual license, obtain special licenses for each day of operation as follows:
(a) Authorized card games:
Per table - $10.00 per day.
(b) Bingo:
Per day - $10.00.
2. Other qualified persons may obtain a special license for bingo for the following fee:
Per day - $20.00.
(E) Work Permit Application Fee: Upon application for a work permit as hereinafter defined and required, the city treasurer shall collect a nonrefundable
fee of fifty dollars ($50.00), to be paid into the general fund.
(F) Work Permit Fee: At the time of issuance or renewal of a work permit as hereinafter defined and required, an annual license fee of twenty five dollars
($25.00) shall be collected.
(G) Application For Renewal Of Work Permit Fee: An application for the renewal of a duly issued, valid and subsisting work permit may be required to be
accompanied by a twenty five dollar ($25.00) fee by order of the governing board upon request of the police chief, where considerable additional
information requiring investigation is contained in the application for renewal.
(H) Fees To Be Paid And Applications To Be Delivered To City Or County Treasurer Thirty Days Prior: All fees and all applications mentioned herein shall
be paid and delivered to the city treasurer. All applications for renewal or modification of a gaming license, shall be submitted at least thirty (30) days
prior to the expiration of said license or the anticipated change or activity. (Ord. 1377, 11-4-1974, eff. 12-4-1974)
6-9-4: LICENSING AND WORK PERMIT QUALIFICATIONS:
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 99/283
(A) Licenses And Permits May Be Issued: Gaming licenses may be issued to qualified applicants as herein provided, whereby the licensee may be
authorized and permitted to provide gaming equipment and card tables for authorized gaming games, to operate and conduct authorized gaming
games, and to share in the proceeds as appropriate to the organizational form of the licensee and as indicated in the application. Work permits may be
issued to qualified applicants as herein provided, whereby the permittee shall be authorized and permitted to operate and conduct authorized gaming
games as employees of licensed persons upon licensed premises for an hourly or weekly consideration.
No person shall permit the operation or conduct of any gaming game on his premises until he has obtained a gaming license and his agents and
employees involved in gaming have obtained work permits. No agent or employee involved in gambling shall work in that capacity until he has obtained
a work permit.
(B) Persons Unqualified To Hold Licenses Or Work Permits: No license or work permit shall be issued to:
1. A person who has been convicted of being the keeper or is keeping a house of ill fame;
2. A person who has been convicted of pandering or any gaming offense or other crime or misdemeanor opposed to decency and morality, under the
laws of the federal government or any statement of the United States;
3. A person whose license or work permit issued under this regulation or the ordinance or regulation of any other city, town or county in this state
relating to gaming, has been revoked for cause;
4. A person who at the time of application for renewal of any license or work permit issued hereunder would not be eligible for such license or work
permit upon a first application.
5. A person who is not a citizen of the United States or who has not been a resident of the state of Montana for at least one year immediately preceding
the filing of the application for license or work permit;
6. In the case of applicants for licenses, a person who is not the legal owner or operator of the gambling business or establishment to be licensed,
except for nonprofit organizations and churches, unless the governing body determines the owner or operation should make application.
7. Minors and incompetents.
8. Employees of agencies charged with enforcing policies or regulating gaming activities.
(C) Unqualified Locations: A gaming license may be denied if the governing body deems that the place or location for which the license is sought is
unsuitable for the conduct of gaming operations.
(D) All Persons Financially Interested To Make Application: Applications for licenses shall be in the names of all persons financially interested, directly or
indirectly, or to be financially interested, directly or indirectly, in the business to be conducted pursuant thereto and the names of all such persons shall
appear on such licenses. A disqualification of any one or more such persons to hold such licenses, shall disqualify all thereof. This requirement shall
not apply to nonprofit organizations or churches unless the governing body determines it necessary.
(E) Applicants To Disclose True Owner Of Premises: In all cases in which the premises wherein or whereon the gaming operation for which a gambling
license is sought are not wholly owned by the applicant, the applicant shall furnish to the board a statement of the name and address of the owner or
owners of such premises, a copy of all agreements whereby the application is entitled to possession of the premises and such other information as the
governing body may require.
(F) Applicants To Disclose Persons With Security Interest In Property: In all cases in which the premises are wholly or partly owned by the applicant, the
application shall furnish to the board complete information pertaining to the interests held by any person other than the applicant, including interest held
under any mortgage, deed of trust, bonds, or debentures, pledge of corporate stock, voting trust agreement or other device whatever, together with
such other information as the board may require. This requirement shall not apply to nonprofit organizations or churches unless the governing body
determines it necessary.
(G) Changes In Ownership Of Interests In Premises To Be Reported: Every licensee shall furnish to the governing body complete information pertaining to
any change of ownership of any such interest in the premises wherein or whereon the licensed gaming is operated at least thirty (30) days before the
date of such change; or if the licensee is not a party to the transaction effecting such change of ownership immediately upon acquiring knowledge of
such change of ownership or any contemplated change of ownership.
(H) Leases Be Reported: A licensee shall report to the governing body all leases of premises used or to be used for gaming purposes to which it is a party
not later than thirty (30) days after the effective date of the lease and shall include the following information:
1. The name, address and brief statement of the nature of the business of the lessor;
2. A brief description of the material terms of the lease and a copy of said lease;
3. A brief description of any business relationships between the licensee and the lessor other than by the lease;
4. Any other information the governing body may request.
The governing body may require any lessor to be found suitable if the governing body finds the relationship between the operating licensee and the
lessor pursuant to the lease or otherwise is so close that the lessor and licensee constitute but one economic entity.
(I) All Persons With Interests May Be Required To Apply For Licenses: If in the discretion of the governing body, a landlord, financier, or lessor by reason
of the extent of his holding, his inherent control financially or his influence effect or control on or over the gaming operation, which cannot and should
not be separated from the gaming operation regardless of the form of organization, it may require that all such individuals be included, as, comply with
all requirements as, and be considered applicants in the license application. Without limiting the generality of the foregoing, such a situation may be
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 100/283
deemed to exist in any instance where an owner of premises leases the same to operators under terms which are not in accordance with the usual and
accepted business practice.
(J) Licenses May Be Denied Because Of Ownership: The governing body may deem that premises are unsuitable for the conduct of gaming operations by
reason of ownership of any interest whatsoever, direct or indirect, in such premises by a person who is unqualified or disqualified to hold a gaming
license regardless of the qualifications of the person who seeks or holds a license to operate gaming in or upon such premises.
(K) Out Of State Gaming Interest: No person who at the time of applying for a gaming license or work permit owns, controls, or has any interest of any kind
in any gaming establishment or game outside of the state of Montana, or is employed by or in any such game or establishment, or has any association
by name or in any other manner whatsoever in or with any such game or establishment, whether such be legal or illegal shall be eligible to receive a
gaming license or work permit. (Ord. 1377, 11-4-1974, eff. 12-4-1974)
6-9-5: LICENSING PROCEDURE:
(A) Gaming A Privilege: It is the declared policy of the city of Lewistown that all premises on which authorized gambling games are conducted or operated
are licensed and controlled so as to better protect the public health, safety, morals, good order and welfare of the inhabitants of the city of Lewistown.
Any gaming license or work permit which is issued is a revocable privilege, and no person holding such a license is deemed to have acquired any
vested rights therein.
An applicant for a gaming license or work permit is seeking the granting of a privilege, and the burden of proving his qualifications to receive any
license or work permit is at all times on the applicant. An applicant must accept any risk of adverse public notice, embarrassment, criticism, or other
action of financial loss which may result from action with respect to an application and expressly waive any claim for damages as a result thereof.
(B) Applicants May Assert Constitutional Rights: An applicant may claim any privilege afforded by the constitution of the United States or of the state of
Montana in refusing to answer questions by the governing body. However, a claim of privilege with respect to any testimony or evidence pertaining to
an application may constitute sufficient grounds for denial.
(C) Applications For Issuance Or Renewal Of A Gaming License: All applications for gaming licenses shall be made to the governing body upon blanks
supplied by the governing body. Upon receipt of such application and the appropriate application fee, the governing body will make or cause to be
made an investigation as to the qualifications of the applicant and the suitability of the premises for operating a gambling game. If, upon such
investigation, it appears that the applicant is qualified under the law and that the premises are suitable for conducting gambling games under the laws
of the state and the rules and regulations of the body, the governing body will issue a gambling license if all other requirements of the laws and these
rules and regulations are fulfilled. However, the governing body may, in its discretion, decline to authorize a license or permit if in the judgment of the
governing body it will be in the best interests of the public to refuse such license.
As a prerequisite to filing an application for issuance of a gaming license, all of the following must be completed and presented:
1. Application form under oath for the individual or business entity, along with the appropriate application fee.
2. Personal history record under oath, including criminal record for each individual, partner, joint venturer, trustee or corporate officer who has any
financial interest, direct or indirect, in the business entity, said personal history to be deemed a part of the application form.
3. Fingerprint cards for each individual, partner, or corporate officer.
4. One copy of each of the following if applicable:
(a) Articles of incorporation and certification of incorporation;
(b) Partnership agreement;
(c) Trust agreement;
(d) Joint venture agreement;
(e) Purchase agreement;
(f) Lease agreement;
(g) Bill of sale;
(h) Management agreement;
(i) Stockholders lists (of all corporate owners, direct or indirect).
As a prerequisite to filing an application for renewal of a gaming license, only those items required, filed or requested for issuance of the license which
are at the time of application for renewal incorrect, no longer applicable, or to be newly applicable need be presented showing all omissions,
additions, deletions or changes of any kind.
(D) Application For Modification Of A Gaming License: A duly issued, valid and subsisting gaming license may be modified by the governing body upon
application and payment of fees by the license holders, where said modification would not in the governing body's judgment preclude issuance of a
gaming license to the applicant.
(E) Additional Information May Be Required: Each applicant shall promptly furnish the governing body with all additional information pertaining to the
application or to the applicant which the board may require. Failure to supply the information requested within five (5) days after the request has been
received by the applicant, shall constitute grounds for delaying consideration of the application.
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 101/283
(F) Separate Applications For Each Establishment: A separate application is required for each establishment for which a license is sought, irrespective of
the ownership of such establishment.
(G) Governing Body May Limit Number Of Individuals On Application: The governing body may, whenever it deems a public interest to so require in any
particular case, limit the number of individuals who may be named in any initial application for a license or in any application to add new parties to, or
for approval of new interests under an existing license.
(H) Governing Body May Summon And Examine Applicants: The governing body may summon any person named in an application to appear and testify
before it or its agents at such time and place as it may designate. All such testimony may be under oath and embrace any matter which the governing
body or its agents may deem relevant to the application. Failure to so appear and testify fully at the time and place designated unless excused, shall
constitute grounds for denial of the application without further consideration by the governing body.
(I) Notice: Notice by letter will be given by the governing body to all applicants of the time and place when their application for a gaming license will come
before the governing body for consideration. Such applicants are expected to attend the meetings of the governing body. Applicants may be
represented at the meetings by counsel. The governing body will notify the applicant in writing of the disposition of his application. (Ord. 1377, 11-4-
1974, eff. 12-4-1974)
6-9-6: OPERATION OF GAMING ESTABLISHMENTS:
(A) Public To Be Protected: It is the policy of the governing body to require that all licensed establishments wherein gaming is conducted in this county, be
operated in a manner suitable to protect the public health, safety, morals, good order and general welfare of the inhabitants of this city.
Responsibility for the employment and maintenance of suitable methods of operation rests with the licensee and wilful or persistent use or toleration of
methods of operation deemed unsuitable, will constitute grounds for license revocation or other disciplinary action.
(B) Unsuitable Methods Of Operation: The governing body deems that any activity on the part of any licensee, his agents or employees which is inimical to
the public health, safety, morals, good order and general welfare of the people of this city is operating in an unsuitable manner and shall be grounds for
disciplinary action by the governing body in accordance with the Montana gambling laws and the regulations of the governing body. Without limiting the
generality of the foregoing, the following acts or omissions may be determined to be unsuitable methods of operation:
1. Failure to exercise discretion and sound judgment to prevent incidents which might reflect on the repute of this county.
2. Permitting persons who are visibly intoxicated or otherwise not in full control of their faculties to participate in gaming activity.
3. Complimentary service of intoxicating beverages in the gaming area to persons who are visibly intoxicated.
4. Failure to conduct advertising and public relations activities in accordance with decency, dignity, good taste, honesty and inoffensiveness.
5. Catering to, assisting, employing or associating with, either socially or in business affairs, persons of notorious or unsavory reputation, or who have
extensive police records, or a person who has defied congressional investigation committees, or other officially constituted bodies acting on behalf of
the United States or any state or persons who are associated with or support subversive movements or the employing either directly or through a
contract or any other means of any firm or individual in any capacity where the repute of this county is liable to be damaged because of the
unsuitability of the firm or individual or because of the unethical methods of operation of the firm or individual.
6. Employing in any gambling operation, other than churches and nonprofit organizations, any person who has not obtained a work permit as defined
and provided in this chapter.
7. Employing in any capacity in or about any licensed establishment any person who has been denied a gaming license on the grounds of unsuitability
or whose past activities and reputation would tend to bring discredit on this county.
8. Employing in any gaming operation any person whom the governing body or any court has found guilty of cheating or using any improper device in
connection with any game, whether as a licensee, dealer or player at a licensed game; as well as any person whose conduct of a licensed game as
a dealer or other employee of a licensee resulted in revocation or suspension of the license of such licensee.
9. Employing in any gaming operation any person who has been convicted of pandering, any gaming offense, or any crime or misdemeanor opposed to
decency or morality, under any law of the United States or any state of the United States.
10. Allowing more than seven (7) players at any one card table.
11. Allowing more than table stakes.
12. Permitting games to be played by the use of credit extended by the house to a player or between players.
13. Not posting rules of game in accordance with section 62-705, Revised Codes of Montana, 1947, or not posting the value of colors of chips used in
play.
14. Violating any state gaming or liquor or beer laws.
(C) Licensees May Not Refuse To Open Records To Official Inspection: No applicant or licensee shall neglect or refuse to produce records or evidence or
to give information upon proper and lawful demand by an authorized agent of the governing body or shall otherwise interfere or attempt to interfere with
any proper or lawful efforts by the governing body or any agent of the governing body to procure such information.
(D) Governing Body May Summon And Examine Licensees And Their Agents: The governing body may summon any licensee or his agents or employees
to appear to testify before it or its agents with regard to the conduct of any licensee or the agents or employees of any licensee. All such testimony shall
be under oath and may embrace any matters which the governing body or its agents may deem relevant to the discharge of their official duties. Any
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 102/283
person so summoned to appear shall have the right to be represented by counsel. Any testimony so taken may be used by the governing body as
evidence in any proceeding or matter then before it or which may later come before it. Failure to so appear and testify fully at the time and place
designated unless excused, shall constitute grounds for the revocation or suspension of any license held by the persons summoned, his principal
employer.
(E) No Unauthorized Gambling Games Permitted: No licensee shall permit any game other than those specifically enumerated in sections 62-703, 62-727,
Revised Codes of Montana, 1974, or these regulations, to be operated on the premises for which the license has been issued.
(F) Law Enforcement Personnel Not To Be Employed: No licensee shall employ any person in any capacity while that person is in the employment of a law
enforcement agency.
(G) Premises To Be Open To Law Enforcement Inspection: The governing body or its duly authorized representative or any peace officer shall have the
right at any time to make an examination of the premises and to check the licensee's books, records, and gaming equipment.
At all times when any person or persons other than the licensee or his employees are within or upon the premises licensed for gambling games, such
premises shall be open to immediate inspection by any peace officer, and any authorized representative of the governing body. Such persons shall
have immediate access to the premises and all parts thereof. Doors of licensed premises shall not be locked while persons other than the licensee or
his employees are within or upon such licensed premises.
(H) Card Table Operations: Each card table shall have assigned to it a person whose duty shall be to supervise the game, and ensure that it is played
strictly in accordance with Montana law and the terms of this chapter.
Every operator and employee of a card room licensee shall at all times when on duty have a work permit and wear an identification badge, containing
his photograph, name, age, address and description.
Every poker and panguingue table shall have inscribed on its top surface a large "P" in a letter style at least six inches (6") high.
(I) Hours Of Operation: No gaming establishment may operate as such between the hours of one o'clock (1:00) A.M. and eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. (Ord.
1377, 11-4-1974, eff. 12-4-1974)
6-9-7: FISCAL AND ACCOUNTING REGULATIONS:
(A) Records To Be Kept: Every licensee shall keep complete and accurate records of all transactions pertaining to gambling in the licensed establishment.
All accounting records shall be retained for a period of three (3) years unless written permission to do otherwise is obtained from the governing body.
All accounting records shall be retained within the boundaries of the city of Lewistown unless written approval of the governing body is obtained to
store outside of the county. Records shall be available for examination by any peace officer, and agents of the governing body upon request made to
such licensee management personnel as are in charge of the establishment during normal business hours. The licensee shall provide adequate
working space for the peace officer, or the agents of the governing body to make such an examination. The peace officers and agents of the governing
body have the power to inspect, copy or have photostatic copies made of any records of the licensee which relate to the operation of the gaming
establishment.
(B) Records To Reflect Gross Income And Expenses: Every holder of a gaming license shall maintain records adequate to reveal gross income and
expense relating to gaming operations; such records shall indicate, but not be limited to, value of chips distributed and redeemed, salaries,
complimentary drink costs, and other expenses and income.
(C) Financial Statement May Be Required: The governing body may order a copy of the licensee's financial statement as prepared by independent public
accountants reporting all activities in the city and its activities without the city if required by the governing body. If in the opinion of the governing body
an independent audit is necessary, it shall be required.
(D) Business Records To Be Kept:
1. Corporate licensees shall keep available for inspection:
(a) A certified copy of articles of incorporation and any amendments thereof;
(b) A current copy of the bylaws;
(c) A current list of officers and directors;
(d) Minutes of all meetings of stockholders and directors;
(e) A current list of all stockholders, including their names and addresses and the number of shares held by each and date acquired;
(f) A complete record of all transfers of stock;
(g) A record of amounts paid to the corporation for issuance of stock and other capital contributions.
2. Partnerships shall maintain individual accounts in the general ledger for each partner showing separately:
(a) Dates of capital contributions and percent of interest held;
(b) Withdrawals of partnership funds or assets;
(c) Salaries paid to each partner.
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 103/283
3. A sole proprietorship shall maintain adequate records to reflect original investment, subsequent additions thereto and withdrawals therefrom. (Ord.
1377, 11-4-1974, eff. 12-4-1974)
6-9-8: TRANSFERS OF OWNERSHIP OF GAMING LICENSE OR FINANCIAL INTEREST THEREIN:
(A) Transfers To Be Approved: Licenses may be assigned or transferred as to ownership or location and financial interests in licenses may be assigned or
transferred as to ownership with the approval and consent of the governing body which must be obtained before any assignment or transfer is effective.
The holder of a license shall first make application to the governing body for the governing body's consent and approval. Assignees shall conform with
the provisions of this act pertaining to applications for new licenses. (Ord. 1377, 11-4-1974, eff. 12-4-1974)
6-9-9: OFFICIALS HOLDING LICENSES:
(A) Certain Officials Not To Hold Licenses: No gaming license shall be issued or held by any person holding office in or employed by any agency of the city
of Lewistown, state of Montana, when the duties of such office or agency have to do with the enforcement of the gaming laws and these regulations or
any person receiving pension benefits as a result of such employment. The regulation applies specifically but without limiting its effect to any person
employed in the office of the city attorney or any peace officer as defined by Montana law. (Ord. 1377, 11-4-1974, eff. 12-4-1974)
6-9-10: CORPORATE LICENSES:
(A) Foreign Corporations: No gaming license shall be issued to a foreign corporation unless both of the following requirements are met:
1. The corporation has been authorized to do business in Montana for a period of one year prior to making application for a gaming license; and
2. A majority of the issued stock of said corporation is owned by qualified persons who have been residents of the state of Montana for a period of one
year immediately before making application for a gaming license.
(B) Corporate Applications: A corporate application shall be accompanied by a sworn statement showing the names of all the owners of all issued stock of
such corporation, together with the amount of stock owned by each stockholder and the residence addresses of said owners. Additionally, it shall
include the names of all shareholders of the corporate applicants' corporate shareholders unless specifically relieved in writing by the governing body
of the duty to do so. The corporate applicant shall also notify the governing body of any individual financial interest, direct or indirect. (Ord. 1377, 11-4-
1974, eff. 12-4-1974)
6-9-11: ONE DAY SPECIAL LICENSES:
(A) One Day Special Licenses May Be Issued: One day special licenses may be issued, upon payment of the license fee, to nonprofit organizations and
churches upon proper application (initially as a new application and subsequently as a renewal application); additionally, in the case of bingo, may be
issued upon payment of license fee to any qualified person who has applied (initially as a new application and subsequently as a renewal application),
paid the investigation fee (initially or whenever more than 1 full year has passed since issuance of the last 1 day special license to the applicant,
$50.00; otherwise $25.00), and has been approved.
(B) All Regulations Apply: Every requirement of these regulations pertaining to regular licenses applies with equal effect to one day special licenses. (Ord.
1377, 11-4-1974, eff. 12-4-1974)
6-9-12: WORK PERMITS:
(A) Work Permits Required: No person shall be employed or work in a gaming operation without first obtaining a work permit.
(B) Work Permits To Be Issued By Chief Of Police; When: Employees in all gambling operations, except those operated by a licensed church or nonprofit
organization, must obtain a work permit from the chief of police who shall within a reasonable time either issue or deny a work permit. Applications for
such work permits may be obtained from the city treasurer and shall be submitted, to the appropriate treasurer with the required fee, under oath and
contain such information as may be deemed by the chief of police necessary to determine whether the applicant is a proper person to be employed in a
card room.
No work permit shall be issued to any person who is not a citizen of the United States and who has not been a resident of the state of Montana for at
least one year. The chief of police may deny in writing to such applicant a work permit, if in his opinion good cause appears why such a person should
not be permitted to be employed in a card room. Said work permit when issued shall be valid for one year.
(C) Application For Renewal Of Work Permit: The holder of a duly issued, valid and subsisting work permit may renew said permit by filing an application
for a work permit upon which all omissions, additions, deletions or corrections are indicated, thereby updating the applicant's original or subsequent
supplemental applications. The sheriff or chief of police may then consider the application as provided for an application for a work permit.
(D) Chief Of Police To Print And Photograph Applicants: No person shall be issued a work permit unless such person has first furnished the chief of police
his fingerprints on fingerprint impression cards and his photograph. The photographs must be satisfactory to the law enforcement agency and must
have been taken not earlier than three (3) months before the date of registration.
(E) Permittees To Wear Identification: Every operator and employee of an operator of a card room license hereunder shall at all times when on duty have
his permit on his person and identification badge, containing his photograph, name, age, address, and description, displayed on his person.
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 104/283
(F) Permittees To Report Changes In Place Of Employment: Permittees shall notify the chief of police of changes of place of employment immediately
upon the change. Failure to comply with this requirement constitutes grounds for the immediate suspension of the work permit. (Ord. 1377, 11-4-1974,
eff. 12-4-1974)
6-9-13: REVOCATIONS AND SUSPENSIONS:
(A) Law Enforcement Personnel May Suspend A License Or Work Permit For Cause, Notice Of Appeal: The chief of police or city attorney shall have the
right for cause to suspend any gaming license or card room work permit issued hereunder and take possession of such license or permit for any
period, not to exceed thirty (30) days.
The action of the chief of police, or city attorney in so suspending the license or permit shall be subject to an appeal to the governing body. Notice of
such appeal shall be filed with the city clerk as provided in subsection (D) of this section; otherwise the action of the chief of police or city attorney in
suspending the gaming license or card room work permit shall be final and conclusive.
(B) Cause, Defined: The "cause" referred to in the preceding subsection means probable cause to believe that these regulations or any federal, state or
local law or ordinance has been violated by the licensee or card room work permit holder.
(C) Revocation, Suspension Or Limitation Of License Or Work Permit; Notice Of Hearing: The governing body may revoke, suspend or limit in any manner
a license or work permit after a hearing upon written request of the city attorney. Notice of said hearing shall be given all interested parties five (5) days
prior to such hearing.
(D) Appeals To Governing Body: Any person excepting to any suspension of a license or a permit held by him pursuant to the provisions of these
regulations, or to any action taken by an official concerning such permit, may appeal in writing to the governing body by filing with the city clerk a
written notice of such appeal, setting forth the specific grounds thereof. Such notice must be filed within ten (10) days after the action appealed from
has occurred.
The city clerk shall forthwith set said matter for hearing before the governing body and cause notice thereof to be given to appellant not less than five
(5) days prior to such hearing. At such hearing appellant shall show cause, on the grounds specified in the notice of appeal, why the action excepted to
should not be approved. Such hearing may, by the governing body, be continued over from time to time, and its findings on the appeal shall be final
and conclusive in the matter.
(E) Court Contest Of Official Acts: Nothing herein shall be construed to affect or deny an aggrieved person's rights to litigate any act authorized herein and
undertaken by the properly designated parties before a court of competent jurisdiction. (Ord. 1377, 11-4-1974, eff. 12-4-1974)
6-9-14: JOINT COMMISSION:
(A) Joint Commission Authorized, Membership: In the event Fergus County, Montana, or other incorporated cities within Fergus County, Montana,
authorized and create to act for, and in the place of, the city of Lewistown in all matters pertaining to gambling, upon approval of the city commission,
the city of Lewistown is authorized to become a member of such joint commission and be subject to all of the terms, conditions and provisions of such
joint commission, including acquiescing in the composition of such joint commission and being subject to all of the powers, regulations and
interpretations of such joint commission. (Ord. 1377, 11-4-1974, eff. 12-4-1974; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
6-9-15: SEVERABILITY:
(A) Severability: It is the intent of the governing body that if a part of these regulations are invalid, all valid parts that are severable from the invalid part
remain in effect. If part of this regulation is invalid in one or more of its applications, the part remains in effect in all valid applications that are severable
from the invalid applications. (Ord. 1377, 11-4-1974, eff. 12-4-1974)
6-9-16: PENALTY:
In the event of a violation of any part or parts of this chapter, in addition to the other remedies provided herein, the legal authorities of the city of Lewistown
can deem such violations to be a misdemeanor and upon the conviction thereof, defender can be punished in accordance with the ordinances of this code
of Lewistown, Montana. (Ord. 1377, 11-4-1974, eff. 12-4-1974)
Chapter 10
SNOW AND ICE REMOVAL
6-10-1: DUTY OF OWNER:
It shall be the duty of the owner or tenant of any premises within the city limits to keep the sidewalk in front of and abutting his premises free and safe for
pedestrians and with all reasonable dispatch to remove snow, ice, slush, mud and other threats to safe foot travel, and to prevent the accumulation of the
same upon such sidewalks. The sidewalks abutting such owner's or tenant's premises must be cleared by such owner or tenant from the night's
accumulation of snow or ice or other impediment before nine o'clock (9:00) A.M., following such accumulation thereof. And it shall be the duty of such
tenant or owner of said premises occupied by him to keep the sidewalks in front of the premises free and safe for pedestrians, and to prevent the
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 105/283
continuance and accumulation of the materials described herein upon such sidewalks. In no case shall the snow and ice or other such materials removed
from parking lots, filling stations, motels, etc., within the business district of said city be dumped or deposited within the adjoining streets, avenues or alleys
or public highways. (Ord. 1402, 1-19-1976, eff. 2-18-1976)
6-10-2: DEPOSITS ON STREETS:
It shall be unlawful for the owner of any business establishment within the limits of the city to remove snow, ice or slush from said business premises,
adjacent thereto, driveways or parking lots owned or under the control of said business premises and deposit said material so removed within or upon the
adjoining street, avenue or alleys of the city, and a violator of this section shall be subject to punishment as is hereafter provided. (Ord. 1402, 1-19-1976,
eff. 2-18-1976)
6-10-3: HIRING REMOVAL:
The owner or tenant of any such business premises shall not be prevented from removing the accumulation of snow, ice and slush from said business
premises and disposing of same in such a manner that is not contrary to any ordinance of this city, statute or regulation of the state and its political
subdivisions; providing however, that if such owner or tenant contracts for or hires the removal of the materials defined herein, the person so removing
such materials shall be licensed as is hereafter provided. (Ord. 1402, 1-19-1976, eff. 2-18-1976)
6-10-4: SNOW REMOVAL LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall engage in the business of snow removal within the city without first obtaining a license therefor from the city commission; applications for
license shall be made with the office of the city clerk on such form as is prescribed therefor; the license fee shall be nineteen dollars ($19.00) per annum
payable in advance, ending in all cases on December 31. (Ord. 1649, 2-2-1998)
6-10-5: VIOLATION A MISDEMEANOR:
A violation of any of the sections of this chapter shall be deemed a misdemeanor and punishable in accordance with the general penalty provisions of this
code. (Ord. 1402, 1-19-1976, eff. 2-18-1976)
6-10-6: NOTICE TO REMOVE:
The city shall have the privilege of notifying any owner, tenant or occupant of property described in section 6-10-1 of this chapter, to remove or otherwise
correct the objectionable matter therein legislated against, which notice shall consist of verbally notifying the tenant of the premises or the owner of the
premises, telling them that they have a period of twenty four (24) hours from and after receipt of such notice to correct or otherwise remove the objections
specified. (Ord. 1402, 1-19-1976, eff. 2-18-1976)
6-10-7: FAILURE TO REMOVE:
Upon failure of the owner, tenant or occupant of said premises to remove the objectionable material, after notice as stated in section 6-10-6 of this chapter,
the city shall then have the right to remove such snow and ice and assess the cost of removal against the said property abutting the sidewalk; such
assessment shall be a lien upon such real property until paid. (Ord. 1402, 1-19-1976, eff. 2-18-1976)
Chapter 11
BURGLARY, ROBBERY AND FIRE ALARM CONTROL SYSTEMS
6-11-1: TITLE:
This chapter shall be known as THE BURGLARY, ROBBERY AND FIRE ALARM CONTROL ORDINANCE. (Ord. 1463, 11-3-1980)
6-11-2: PURPOSE AND SCOPE:
(A) The purpose of this chapter is to protect the emergency services of the city of Lewistown from misuse.
(B) This chapter governs burglary, robbery and fire alarm systems, requires permits, establishes fees and the punishment of violations, and establishes a
system of administration. (Ord. 1463, 11-3-1980)
6-11-3: DEFINITIONS:
ALARM INSTALLER: The business of any individual, partnership, corporation, or other entity of selling, leasing, maintaining, servicing, repairing, altering,
replacing, moving or installing any alarm system or causing to be sold, leased, maintained, serviced, repaired, altered, replaced, moved or installed any
alarm system in or on any building, structure or facility. The alarm installer must be licensed by the state of Montana and have a city of Lewistown general
business license.
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 106/283
ALARM SUBSCRIBER: The person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind in control of any building, structure or
facility wherein an alarm system is maintained.
ALARM SYSTEM: Any assembly of equipment, mechanical or electrical, whose primary function is to summon a law enforcement or fire department
response to the occurrence of an illegal entry or other activity requiring urgent attention.
AUTOMATIC DIALING DEVICE: A device which is interconnected to a telephone line and is programmed to select a predetermined telephone number and
transmit by voice message or code signal an emergency message indicating a need for emergency response.
CHIEF: The chief of the respective departments. Burglary and robbery alarms are the concern of the chief of police and the fire alarms are the concern of
the fire chief.
EMERGENCY COMMUNICATIONS CENTER: The city of Lewistown law enforcement department dispatch center used to receive emergency and general
information from the public to be dispatched to the respective emergency service departments utilizing the center.
FALSE ALARM: An alarm signal eliciting a response by law enforcement or fire department when a situation requiring a response by either department
does not in fact exist. It does not include an alarm signal caused by violent conditions of nature or other extraordinary circumstances not reasonably
subject to control by the alarm business operator or alarm subscriber.
INTERCONNECT: To connect an alarm system including an automatic dialing device to a telephone line, either directly or through a mechanical device
that utilizes a telephone for the purpose of using the telephone line to transmit a message upon the activation of the alarm system.
LOCAL GOVERNMENT: The local government of the city of Lewistown.
PRIMARY TRUNK LINE: A telephone line servicing the dispatch center that is designated to receive emergency calls.
TELEPHONIC ALARM SYSTEM: Any mechanism, equipment or device which is designed to operate automatically through the use of public telephone
facilities to transmit a signal, message or warning to another location such as burglar, robbery and fire alarms. (Ord. 1463, 11-3-1980)
6-11-4: ALARM SUBSCRIBER'S PERMIT REQUIRED:
(A) Every alarm subscriber shall obtain an alarm subscriber permit for each system for the chief's office upon the effective date of this chapter or prior to
the use of an alarm system. Application for burglary, robbery or fire alarms subscriber's permit and a ten dollar ($10.00) fee shall be filed with the
chief's office on or before July 1 of each year. Each permit shall bear the signature of the chief and be for one year period. The permit shall be
physically displayed where the alarm system is being used and shall be available for inspection by the chief.
(B) The chief of the concerned department shall have the right to inspect any telephonic alarm system on the premises where it is intended to function
prior to issuance of any permit for its operation and he may cause an inspection of such system to be made at any time after issuance of a permit to
determine whether it is being used in conformity with the terms of the permit and the provisions of this chapter.
(C) A revoked subscriber's permit shall be obtained from the chief's office by filing an application and paying the fee as follows:
First revoked permit in the permit year $ 50.00
Second revoked permit in the permit year 100.00
Third and each additional revoked permit
in the permit year
200.00
Each permit shall bear the signature of the chief and shall bear the same expiration date as the revoked permit. The permit shall be physically upon the
premises using the alarm system and shall be available for inspection by the chief of the concerned department.
(D) A twenty five dollar ($25.00) charge will be made in addition to the fee provided in subsection (A) of this section to a subscriber who fails to obtain a
permit within sixty (60) days after the effective date of this chapter, or who is more than sixty (60) days delinquent in renewing a permit.
(E) An alarm subscriber required by federal, state or local government statute regulation, rule or ordinance to install, maintain and operate an alarm
system shall be subject to this chapter provided:
1. Any permit issued shall be designated a special alarm subscriber's permit.
2. A special alarm subscriber's permit for a system which has four (4) or more false alarms in a permit year shall not be subject to revocation under
section 6-11-5 of this chapter, but the holder of the permit shall pay a fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) with the submission of the report required
by section 6-11-5 of this chapter and the cost of response upon the fourth false alarm.
3. For each false alarm over four (4) in a permit year, upon written demand therefor by the chief, the holder of a special subscriber's permit shall pay a
fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) with the submission of the report required by section 6-11-5 of this chapter and cost of response.
4. Holders of special subscriber's permits for fire alarm systems only will be subject to revocation only after an excess of six (6) false alarms in a permit
year under section 6-11-5 of this chapter and will also be subject to costs incurred under section 6-11-5 of this chapter.
5. The payment of any fee provided for in subsections (E)2, (E)3 and (E)4 of this section shall not be deemed to extend the term of the permit.
6. An alarm subscriber which is a governmental military unit shall be subject to this chapter; but a permit shall be issued without payment of a fee and
shall not be subject to revocation, payment of additional fees, or the imposition of any penalty provided herein. (Ord. 1463, 11-3-1980)
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 107/283
6-11-5: FALSE ALARMS; COSTS INCURRED; PERMIT REVOCATION:
(A) Any alarm system which has four (4) or more false alarms within a permit year shall be subject to permit revocation as provided herein.
(B) If the chief records four (4) or more false alarms within the permit year for any alarm system:
1. The chief shall notify the alarm subscriber and the alarm installer providing service or inspection to the subscriber by certified mail of such fact and
direct that subscriber to submit a report to the chief within ten (10) days of receipt of the notice describing actions taken or to be taken to discover
and eliminate the cause of the false alarms.
2. If the alarm subscriber submits a report as directed the chief shall determine if the actions taken or to be taken will prevent the occurrence of false
alarms. If he determines that the actions will prevent the occurrence of false alarms, he shall notify the alarm subscriber and the relevant alarm
installer in writing that the permit will not be revoked at that time and that if one more false alarm occurs within the permit year, the permit may be
summarily revoked. (Ord. 1463, 11-3-1980)
3. If no report is submitted, or if the chief of the concerned department determines that the actions taken or to be taken will not prevent the occurrence
of false alarms, the chief shall give notice by certified mail to the subscriber that the permit will be revoked without further notice on the tenth day
after the date of the notice if the subscriber does not file a written request within that period for a closed hearing before the Lewistown city
commission. (Ord. 1463, 11-3-1980; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
4. If a hearing is requested, written notice of the time and place of the hearing shall be served on the subscriber by the chief at least ten (10) days prior
to the date set for the hearing, which shall be set for not more than twenty one (21) nor less than ten (10) days after the filing of the request for
hearing. (Ord. 1463, 11-3-1980)
5. The hearing shall occur before the city commission and the chief. The alarm subscriber shall have the right to present written and oral evidence,
subject to the right of cross examination. If the city commission determines that four (4) or more false alarms have taken place, the city commission
shall issue written findings to that effect and an order revoking the subscriber's permit. (Ord. 1463, 11-3-1980; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
6. An alarm subscriber shall immediately discontinue use of the alarm system upon being notified of the revocation of a permit.
7. An alarm subscriber whose permit has been revoked may apply for a revoked subscriber's permit as provided in section 6-11-4 of this chapter. The
chief shall not be required to issue a revoked subscriber's permit unless he is satisfied that the subscriber's system has been properly serviced and
its deficiencies corrected. The chief may impose reasonable restrictions and conditions upon the subscriber before issuing a revoked subscriber's
permit.
(C) Each permit holder from the fire department shall be responsible for the actual cost to the city for manpower, equipment and apparatus responding to a
malfunction or a false alarm of such private fire alarm system. (Ord. 1463, 11-3-1980)
6-11-6: SUBSCRIBER INSTRUCTIONS:
(A) Every alarm installer selling, leasing or furnishing to any subscriber an alarm system which is installed on premises located in the area subject to this
chapter shall furnish the subscriber with instructions that provide information enabling the subscriber to operate the alarm system properly and for
obtaining service for the alarm system at any time.
(B) Standard form instructions shall be submitted by every alarm business to the chief within sixty (60) days after the effective date of this chapter. If the
chief of the concerned department reasonably finds such instructions to be incomplete, unclear or inadequate, he may require the alarm business to
revise the instructions to comply with this section and then to distribute the revised instructions to its alarm subscribers.
(C) Alarm systems must be installed by licensed alarm installers.
(D) Any burglary, robbery or fire alarm system equipped with an external bell, horn, siren or other noisemaking device shall be equipped with an automatic
silencing device which shall silence the alarm within fifteen (15) minutes after the activation of the alarm. This does not apply to fire reporting devices.
(Ord. 1463, 11-3-1980)
6-11-7: AUTOMATIC DIALING DEVICE; CERTAIN INTERCONNECTIONS PROHIBITED:
(A) It is unlawful for any person to program an automatic dialing device to select a primary trunk line; and it is unlawful for an alarm subscriber to fail to
disconnect or to reprogram an automatic dialing device which is programmed to select primary trunk line within twelve (12) hours of receipt of written
notice from the chief's office that it is so programmed.
(B) Within sixty (60) days after the effective date of this chapter, all existing automatic dialing devices programmed to select a primary trunk line shall be
reprogrammed or disconnected.
(C) It is unlawful for any person to program an automatic dialing device to select any telephone line assigned to the local government. It is also unlawful for
an alarm subscriber to fail to disconnect or reprogram such a device within twelve (12) hours of receipt of written notice from the chief's office that an
automatic dialing device is so programmed.
(D) A special exception can be granted by the chief permitting the use of telephone dialers providing the alarm subscriber can justify to the chief the need.
(Ord. 1463, 11-3-1980)
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 108/283
6-11-8: CONFIDENTIALITY; STATISTICS:
(A) All information submitted in compliance with this chapter shall be held in the strictest confidence and shall be deemed a public record exempt from
disclosure pursuant to state statute. Any violation of confidentiality shall be deemed a violation of this chapter. The chief shall be charged with the sole
responsibility for the maintenance of all records of any kind whatsoever under this chapter.
(B) Subject to the requirements of confidentiality, the chief shall develop and maintain statistics having the purpose of assisting alarm system evaluation for
use by members of the public. (Ord. 1463, 11-3-1080)
Title 7
FIRE REGULATIONS
Chapter 1
FIRE LIMITS
7-1-1: FIRE DISTRICT LIMITS:
All the area lying within the city limits, as depicted on the official map on file with the city clerk's office, shall be known as the fire district. (Ord. 1631, 4-15-
1996)
Chapter 2
FIRE PREVENTION CODE
7-2-1: ADOPTION OF FIRE CODE:
(A) The international fire code, 2009 edition, including appendices B and C, as published by the International Code Council, is adopted by reference as the
fire code of the city of Lewistown. It regulates and governs the safeguarding of life and property from fire and explosion hazards arising from the
storage, handling and use of hazardous substances, materials and devices, and from conditions hazardous to life or property in the occupancy of
buildings and premises as herein provided; provides for the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefor; and each and all of the regulations,
provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of the fire code on file in the office of the Lewistown city clerk are hereby referred to, adopted, and made a
part hereof, as if fully set out, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, set by ordinance.
(B) The following sections of the fire code are revised as set out below:
Section 101.1. Insert: [City of Lewistown, Montana]
Section 108. Board Of Appeals. Delete entire section including 108.1, 108.2, 108.3.
Section 109.3. Insert: [Misdemeanor, $500.00, 6 months] so that such section shall read as follows:
"Violation Penalties. Persons who shall violate a provision of this code or shall fail to comply with any of the requirements thereof or who shall
erect, install, alter, repair or do work in violation of the approved construction documents or directive of the fire code official, or of a permit or
certificate used under provisions of this code, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of not more than $500.00 or by imprisonment
not exceeding 6 months, or both such fine and imprisonment. Each day that a violation continues after due notice has been served shall be
deemed a separate offense."
Section 111.4. Insert: [not less than $100 or more than $500.00]
Section 903.3.5. Water Supplies. Insert: [A minimum safety factor of 10% but not less than 5 psi shall be provided in any automatic sprinkler system
hydraulic calculation.] so that such section shall read as follows:
"903.3.5 Water Supplies. Water supplies for automatic sprinkler systems shall comply with this section and the standards referenced in section
903.3.1. A minimum safety factor of 10% but not less than 5 psi shall be provided in any automatic sprinkler system hydraulic calculation. The
potable water supply shall be protected against backflow in accordance with the requirements of this section and Montana state adopted plumbing
code."
Section 906.1. Delete exception to section 906.1, #1.
"906.1 Where Required. Portable fire extinguishers shall be installed in the following locations.
1. In new and existing group A, B, E, F, H, I, M, R-1, R-2, R-4 and S occupancies.
