7-2-3: DUTIES OF BUREAU OF FIRE PREVENTION:
(A) The fire prevention bureau (bureau) shall enforce all city fire regulations including, but not limited to, international fire code. The bureau shall be
operated by the fire marshal under the supervision of the chief of the fire department. The fire chief and fire marshal are authorized to issue citations for
fire regulation violations.
(B) The fire marshal is in charge of the bureau and shall be appointed by the chief of the fire department on the basis of examination to determine his
qualifications.
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 110/283
(C) The chief of the fire department may detail such members of the fire department as inspectors as shall from time to time be necessary.
The chief of the fire department, when necessary, shall recommend to the city manager the employment or contracting as independent contractors, of
technical inspectors who, when such authorization is made, shall be selected following determination of their fitness for the position or job. An
employment position shall be open to members or nonmembers of the fire department.
(D) A report of the bureau shall be made annually and transmitted to the chief of the fire department. It shall contain all proceedings under this code, with
such statistics as the chief of the fire department may wish to include therein. The chief of the fire department shall also recommend any amendments
to the code which, in his judgment, shall be desirable. (Ord. 1734, 5-16-2011)
7-2-4: LIMITS OF DISTRICTS IN WHICH STORAGE OF FLAMMABLE LIQUIDS IN OUTSIDE ABOVEGROUND TANKS IS TO BE
PROHIBITED:
(A) The limits in which storage of flammable liquids in outside aboveground tanks is prohibited are hereby established as follows: Within the corporate
limits of the city.
(B) The limits in which new bulk plants for flammable or combustible liquids are prohibited are hereby established as follows: Within the corporate limits of
the city. (Ord. 1734, 5-16-2011)
7-2-5: LIMITS IN WHICH BULK STORAGE AND DISTRIBUTION OF LIQUEFIED PETROLEUM GASES IS TO BE RESTRICTED:
(A) The limits referred to in the international fire code in which bulk storage of liquefied petroleum gas is restricted, are hereby established as follows:
Within the corporate limits of the city.
(B) It shall be unlawful for any person or business within the city limits to dispense liquefied petroleum gas from bulk to any portable liquefied petroleum
container.
1. Exception: Transfer of liquefied propane gas from bulk to a portable liquefied petroleum container may be authorized by a permit issued by the
bureau following review and approval by the fire chief and fire marshal provided the storage, system, or process does not violate any other city
ordinance. The permit may be immediately suspended or revoked if, in the opinion of the fire chief or fire marshal, an unsafe condition or process
exists.
(C) Any bulk storage of liquefied petroleum gas located within the city limits must comply with the requirements set forth in the currently adopted fire code.
(Ord. 1734, 5-16-2011)
7-2-6: MOTOR VEHICLE ROUTES FOR VEHICLES TRANSPORTING EXPLOSIVES, BLASTING AGENTS, HAZARDOUS
MATERIALS, OR OTHER DANGEROUS ARTICLES:
All vehicles transporting explosives, blasting agents, hazardous materials or other dangerous articles through the city must remain on numbered state or
U.S. highways and proceed through using the most direct route with the exception that any vehicle traveling west or east through the city shall use the
truck bypass. All such vehicles are prohibited from traveling on Main Street from First Avenue west to the truck bypass. (Ord. 1734, 5-16-2011)
7-2-7: LIMITS OF DISTRICTS IN WHICH STORAGE OF EXPLOSIVES AND BLASTING AGENTS IS PROHIBITED:
The limits in which storage of explosives and blasting agents is prohibited, are hereby established as follows: Within the corporate limits of the city.
(A) Exceptions:
1. Small arms ammunition and primers.
2. Explosives used by local, state, and federal law enforcement agencies. (Ord. 1734, 5-16-2011)
7-2-8: MODIFICATIONS:
The chief of the fire prevention bureau shall have the power to modify any of the provisions of the fire code upon application in writing by the owner or
lessee, or his duly authorized agent, when there are practical difficulties in the way of carrying out the strict letter of the code; provided, that the spirit of the
code shall be observed and public safety is not adversely affected. The particulars of such modification, when granted or allowed, and the decision of the
chief of the fire prevention bureau thereon shall be entered upon the records of the bureau and a signed copy shall be furnished the applicant. (Ord. 1734,
5-16-2011)
7-2-9: APPEALS:
Whenever the chief of the fire prevention bureau shall disapprove an application or refuse to grant a permit applied for, or when it is claimed that the
provisions of the code do not apply, or that the true intent and meaning of the code has been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the applicant may
appeal the decision to the Lewistown fire department within thirty (30) days from the date of the decision appealed.
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 111/283
The scope of review on appeal is limited to whether the code was misinterpreted or misapplied. The appellant bears the burden of proof and may present
relevant evidence to support his contentions. The chief of the fire prevention bureau shall consider any evidence or supporting information presented and
issue a written decision based upon an application of the code and include appropriate code based references.
If the appellant is not satisfied by the decision of the bureau chief he may request further review. At the discretion of the fire chief, a committee may be
formed including, but not limited to, the fire chief, bureau chief, city manager, and building official. This committee's responsibility is to determine if the
bureau chief's interpretation and/or application of the code is correct. The committee shall not have the authority to waive any portion of the code. (Ord.
1734, 5-16-2011)
7-2-10: NEW MATERIALS; PROCESSES OR OCCUPANCIES WHICH REQUIRE PERMITS:
The city building official, the chief of the fire department and the chief of the fire prevention bureau shall act as a committee to determine and specify, after
giving affected persons an opportunity to be heard, new materials, processes, or occupancies which shall require permits, in addition to those now
enumerated in the adopted codes and regulations.
The chief of the bureau shall keep such list in his office and distribute copies thereof to interested persons. (Ord. 1734, 5-16-2011)
7-2-11: KEY BOXES REQUIRED:
(A) Authority Of Fire Prevention Bureau: The bureau is authorized to require the installation on certain structures of a secure key box in such accessible
locations as he may determine are necessary. The key box shall be of a type approved by the bureau and shall contain such keys as he may require to
gain access to areas around and within structures.
(B) Required In Certain Buildings: Secure key boxes shall be required to be installed as follows:
1. Buildings; General: All new commercial buildings constructed or moved into the city and all existing commercial buildings which undergo remodeling
in excess of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) after the effective date hereof shall install a key box at a location approved by the bureau.
Exception: Subject to bureau approval, key boxes required may be excluded in single story buildings requiring only one exit.
2. All Buildings Equipped With Elevators: In addition to any other keys required by this section, the key box shall contain one set of elevator control
keys if elevators are equipped with fire department bypass switches.
3. Multi-Family Dwellings: To include, but not limited to, apartments with three (3) or more occupancies which have common corridors; apartment
complexes which have more than three (3) occupancies with at least one occupancy either above or below the lowest level of fire department
access; condominiums; group homes; or retirement homes. These occupancies will be equipped with a key box on all new construction or when
existing structures undergo remodeling costing one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or more.
In addition to any other keys required by this section, the key box shall contain keys to gain access to the interior of the structure, common areas,
utility/mechanical rooms, and apartments as well as other areas requiring immediate access for fire department operations as determined by the
bureau or fire chief.
4. Lodging Occupancies: Lodging occupancies include, but are not limited to, hotels, motels, inns and boarding houses. These occupancies will be
equipped with a key box if there is no responsible party stationed and monitoring at a constantly attended location to immediately allow access to
bureau or fire department personnel.
In addition to any other keys required by this section, the key box shall contain keys for the utility/mechanical rooms, areas containing fire protection
system controls, and all rooms.
(C) Administration:
1. An application for a key box may be obtained from the fire department. The applicant may be required to submit a diagram of the building indicating
proposed locations.
2. An application fee for each structure not to exceed fifty dollars ($50.00) may be established by the fire chief.
(D) Installation:
1. Location: Key boxes should be installed on the exterior of the structure at or near the recognized public entrance. All locations shall be approved by
the bureau prior to installation.
2. Height: The key box shall be located at a height of not less than six feet (6') and not more than twelve feet (12') above final grade.
3. Access To Key Box: No steps, displays, signs or other fixtures, or structure protrusions shall be located near the box that would allow unauthorized
persons to access the box without assistance. No structure, material or obstacle shall be allowed that may prevent immediate access to the key box
by fire department personnel.
4. Master Key Provided To Fire Department: The key box shall be installed on or before final inspection of the building or within a reasonable amount of
time as determined by the bureau. The building owner/manager shall provide the fire department a master key to the key box and supply all keys
required by this section for placement into the key box.
5. Box Contents: The key box shall contain keys for the following described areas and all keys placed therein shall be labeled so as to be easily
identified by fire department personnel in the field:
(a) The main entrance door; mixed occupancies and strip shopping center keys shall be provided only for occupancies where system control valves
or fire alarm system panels exist.
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 112/283
(b) Mechanical, electrical, furnace, and boiler rooms.
(c) All areas or rooms containing fire protection systems.
(d) Keys to fire protection devices (e.g., pull stations, alarm panels, control valve locks, etc.).
(e) Elevator keys, if required (4 stories or more).
(f) Other rooms, specified during plans review process, which are needed for fire department operations as determined by the bureau or fire chief.
(g) Keys to locked points of ingress whether on the interior or exterior of such buildings.
(h) Keys to gates in yards affiliated with the structure involved. (Ord. 1734, 5-16-2011)
7-2-12: PENALTIES:
(A) Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of the code hereby adopted or fail to comply therewith, or who shall violate or fail to comply with any
order made thereunder, or who shall violate any provision of the fire regulations, or who shall build in violation of any detailed statement of
specifications or plans submitted and approved thereunder, or any certificate or permit issued thereunder, and from which no appeal has been taken, or
who shall fail to comply with such an order as affirmed or modified by the fire chief or fire marshal or by a court of competent jurisdiction within the time
fixed therein, shall severally for each and every such violation and noncompliance respectively, be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of not
less than twenty dollars ($20.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment for not less than three (3) days nor more than six (6)
months or by both such fine and imprisonment. The imposition of one penalty for any violation shall not excuse the violation or permit it to continue; all
of such persons shall be required to correct or remedy such violations or defects within a reasonable time as determined by the fire chief or fire
marshal. Each day after due notice has been served shall constitute a separate offense.
(B) The application of the above penalty shall not be held to prevent the enforced removal of prohibited conditions. (Ord. 1734, 5-16-2011)
7-2-13: VALIDITY AND SEVERABILITY:
If any portion of the fire regulations conflicts with any other locally adopted code/ordinance, the more restrictive shall govern. The provisions of this chapter
shall not be deemed to nullify any provisions of local, state, or federal law.
If any provision of this chapter or the application thereof to any person or circumstances is held invalid, such invalidity shall not affect the other provisions
of this chapter which may be given effect without the invalid provisions or application, and, to this end, the provisions of this chapter are declared to be
severable. (Ord. 1734, 5-16-2011)
Chapter 3
FIREWORKS
7-3-1: FIREWORKS PROHIBITED:
The discharge, storage, or sale of all explosives and fireworks designed and intended for pyrotechnic display, and the discharge of all firearms or other like
devices, using blank cartridges or caps containing chlorate or potash mixture, is prohibited within the city limits; provided, that the fire chief or fire marshal
may permit the public display of fireworks by a properly qualified individual under the direction and supervision of experts in the handling of fireworks;
provided, also, that display shall be of such character and so located that such display shall not be hazardous to surrounding property or endanger any
person. (Ord. 1735, 5-16-2011)
7-3-2: SALE OR STORAGE OF FIREWORKS OUTSIDE CITY LIMITS:
The following provisions are applicable within three (3) miles of the city limits:
(A) Permit Required: Anyone engaged in the retail sale, wholesale, or storage of fireworks must obtain a permit from the bureau, issued for a period of one
year. Applications for a permit must be filed with the bureau at least thirty (30) days prior to the issuing of the permit and must give detailed descriptions
of the proposed care and storage of said materials and of the structural conditions.
(B) Approval: Permits may be issued only after inspection of the premises by bureau or fire department personnel. The permit shall contain any
appropriate restrictions, stipulations or findings. The permit shall be posted in an unobstructed location on the sale or storage premises. The bureau
shall retain a copy of the permit.
(C) Additional Restrictions:
1. No person under the age of eighteen (18) shall be employed to sell fireworks or otherwise work in any establishment wherein fireworks are stored or
offered for sale unless supervised on site at all times by a responsible person of at least eighteen (18) years of age.
2. No fireworks may be discharged within one hundred feet (100') of a fireworks retail sales location.
3. No fireworks may be discharged in a manner or during conditions that would allow it to come within one hundred feet (100') of a retail sales location.
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 113/283
4. No smoking shall be allowed within fifty feet (50') of a fireworks sales location. At any place where fireworks are sold or displayed, a sign reading
"NO SMOKING" must be posted in letters at least four inches (4") in height and one-half inch (1/2") in stroke where customers are most likely to read
it.
5. Retail sale of fireworks conducted from stands shall be located at least three hundred feet (300') from a church or hospital, fifty feet (50') away from
flammable liquid dispensing device or installation, fifty feet (50') from other inhabited buildings, and thirty feet (30') from any public roadway.
6. Parking of vehicles used to transport division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives or flammable and combustible liquids is prohibited within one hundred feet
(100') of a retail fireworks stand.
7. Stands shall be equipped inside with at least one pressurized water extinguisher with a minimum rating of 2A or one garden hose connected to a
water supply and charged with water.
8. Any stand constructed to admit members of the public inside shall have a minimum of two (2) unobstructed exits remotely located from each other.
9. All weeds, dry grass, and combustible material shall be cleared for a minimum distance of twenty five feet (25') in all directions from the stand.
10. Electrical wiring shall be in a safe condition, and if found upon inspection to be unsafe shall be upgraded to comply with the applicable provisions of
the national electrical code adopted by the state of Montana.
11. Open flame devices of any kind are prohibited in retail fireworks stands, and within fifty feet (50') of the stand.
12. Fireworks may not be altered or used in a manner inconsistent with their intended use, inconsistent with their manufacturer's instructions, or in a
manner which could cause injury to any person or property.
(D) Dates Of Sale: No person, firm or corporation may offer fireworks of any kind for sale at retail before June 24 and after July 5.
(E) Inspection: Retail fireworks stands shall be subject to inspection by fire department personnel. Violations shall be handled in accordance with city fire
regulations and Montana Code Annotated section 50-61-115. The fire chief or fire marshal may take immediate action to safeguard life and property, to
include the issuance of an order in accordance with Montana Code Annotated section 50-62-102 and/or issue citations in accordance with these fire
regulations.
(F) Insurance Required: Each operator, owner or proprietor of any fireworks stand or fireworks display shall, prior to obtaining a permit for the sale or
display of fireworks, furnish a certificate of insurance for general liability as a condition of their obtaining a permit. Failure to provide proof of such
coverage shall be grounds for denial of a permit. "General liability insurance" is hereby defined to include coverage for premises and operations,
independent contractor working on the insured's behalf, and oral or written contractual liability, and all persons carrying such insurance shall be
required to carry minimum liability of seven hundred fifty thousand dollars ($750,000.00) per incident and one million five hundred thousand dollars
($1,500,000.00) per occurrence. (Ord. 1735, 5-16-2011)
Chapter 4
GENERAL FIRE REGULATIONS
7-4-1: FIRE ALARM:
The reporting of a fire shall be determined as a fire alarm. A fire alarm shall be deemed and construed as being any act as follows: The giving, signaling or
transmission to fire department dispatch, any public fire station, company or to any officer or employee thereof, whether by telephone, spoken word or
otherwise, information to the effect that there is a fire at or near the place indicated by the person giving, signaling or transmitting such information.
It shall be unlawful to impede or prohibit the immediate evacuation of all persons within a structure or property where a fire is discovered, an audio or
visual fire alarm system activates, or where a severe and imminent fire or life safety hazard exists.
Exception: Bureau approved institutional occupancies (e.g., detention or hospital care) where structures and systems are designed for defense of
occupants in place and complying with international building code construction requirements for defense in place. (Ord. 1736, 5-16-2011)
7-4-2: OPEN BURNING, RECREATIONAL FIRES AND BONFIRES:
(A) Intent: To provide for public safety and property protection with regard to open burning, recreational fires and other outdoor combustion within the city.
(B) Definitions:
APPROVED: Authorized by the fire chief, fire marshal, or fire chief's designee in accordance with fire regulations.
BONFIRE: An outdoor fire utilized for ceremonial, religious, pleasure, warmth, or similar purposes which exceeds the allowable size of a recreational
fire.
OPEN BURNING: The burning of materials wherein products of combustion are emitted directly into the ambient air without passing through a stack or
chimney from an enclosed chamber. Open burning does not include road flares, smudge pots and similar devices associated with safety or
occupational uses typically considered open flames, recreational fires or use of portable outdoor fireplaces. For the purpose of this definition, a
chamber shall be regarded as enclosed when, during the time combustion occurs, only apertures, ducts, stacks, flues or chimneys necessary to
provide combustion air and permit the escape of exhaust gas are open.
PORTABLE OUTDOOR FIREPLACE: A portable, outdoor, solid fuel burning fireplace that may be constructed of steel, concrete, clay or other
noncombustible material. A portable outdoor fireplace may be open in design, or may be equipped with a small hearth opening and a short chimney or
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 114/283
chimney opening in the top.
RECREATIONAL FIRE: An outdoor fire burning of materials other than rubbish where the fuel being burned is not contained in an approved
commercially produced/available: incinerator, outdoor fireplace, portable outdoor fireplace, barbecue grill, barbecue pit, or similar device and has a total
fuel area of three feet (3') (914 mm) or less in diameter and two feet (2') (610 mm) or less in height intended for pleasure, religious, ceremonial,
cooking, warmth or similar purposes.
(C) Prohibited: Open burning, recreational fires and bonfires are prohibited within the city. Exceptions:
1. Outdoor Fireplaces And Like Appliances: Fires are permitted and approved within commercially produced/available incinerators, outdoor fireplaces,
portable outdoor fireplaces, fire pits, barbecue grills, barbecue pits, and similar devices:
(a) When they are consistent with the device/appliance listing and/or manufacturer's instructions; and they do not violate any other locally adopted
code/ordinance.
(b) When a minimum thirty six inch (36") clearance is maintained between the device/appliance (having enclosed combustion chamber) and
combustibles unless otherwise permitted or required by the product's listing. Devices or appliances that do not have an enclosed combustion
chamber must maintain clearances equal to those of a recreational fire unless otherwise stated in the product's listing.
(c) Unless, in the judgment of the fire chief or his designee the device is unsafe, being used in an unsafe manner, or being used in unsafe conditions.
2. Recreational Fires: A recreational fire may be conducted:
(a) A minimum of twenty five feet (25') from structures and ten feet (10') from property lines, but not under power lines, trees, or other combustible
materials. This dimension should be increased if the proximity to combustibles creates the potential for the recreational fire to spread.
(b) Where conditions that would permit spread of a recreational fire to within twenty five feet (25') of a structure, ten feet (10') from a property line, or
under combustible materials/power lines have been eliminated prior to ignition of the recreational fire.
(c) In a homemade/unlisted (noncommercially available/produced) incinerator, outdoor fireplace, fire pit, portable outdoor fireplace, barbecue grill or
barbecue pit when it is constructed of and surrounded by wholly noncombustible materials.
3. Bonfires: A bonfire may be conducted only with a permit from Lewistown fire department.
(a) Bonfire location, size, and fuels must be approved by the fire department. A permit must be obtained from the fire department prior to ignition of
the bonfire.
(b) Bonfires must be positioned a minimum of fifty feet (50') from any structure or combustible material and a minimum of ten feet (10') from property
lines. Bonfires may not be located under combustible materials or power lines.
(c) Conditions that would permit spread of a bonfire to within fifty feet (50') of a structure, ten feet (10') from a property line or under combustible
materials/power lines must be eliminated prior to ignition of the bonfire.
(d) Only clean burning fuels such as unpainted, untreated wood or charcoal may be used.
4. Combustion Regulations: All the above forms of combustion:
(a) Must be constantly attended by a competent adult of at least eighteen (18) years of age, until completely extinguished (not smoldering - cold).
Attendees must have immediate access to communications should an emergency occur. Fire emergencies must be reported to Central Montana
dispatch (911).
(b) May be required to be extinguished if they produce hazardous fire gases or smoke that is offensive to others.
(c) Must have a functional water source and garden hose, appropriately sized extinguisher, or other comparable means of fire extinguishment
immediately available at all times.
(d) May be prohibited based on hazardous conditions such as severe weather or drought.
(D) Permits: Permits may be obtained by contacting Lewistown fire department.
(E) Liability For Damages: A person who sets or leaves a fire that spreads and damages or destroys property of any kind not belonging to the person (or
threatens to do the same) is liable for all damages caused by the fire and all costs and expenses incurred, but not limited to, expenses incurred in fire
suppression and investigation.
(F) Sources Of Combustion Prohibited: Chemically treated products, yard waste, garden vegetation, leaves, painted wood, glued wood (including plywood,
particle board, wafer board, etc.), or combustibles that produce hazardous or offensive quantities of smoke/gases shall not be used as a source of
combustion.
(G) Authority: Lewistown fire or police department personnel shall have the authority to order the immediate extinguishment of open burning, recreational
fires, bonfires, outdoor fireplaces, portable outdoor fireplaces, barbecue grills, barbecue pits or other forms of combustion should personnel determine
that they are being used in an unsafe, inappropriate or offensive manner; or a device/appliance is being used in a manner not consistent with its listing
or manufacturer's instructions.
(H) Penalty: Any person who shall violate any provision of this chapter shall be subject to a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00), or more than five
hundred dollars ($500.00), and incarceration in the Fergus County Jail for a term not to exceed six (6) months, or both such fine and incarceration.
(Ord. 1736, 5-16-2011)

Title 8
HEALTH AND SANITATION
Chapter 1
EATING AND DRINKING ESTABLISHMENTS
8-1-1: CODES ADOPTED:
The United States public health service ordinance and code regulating eating and drinking establishments recommended by the United States public
health service be and the same is hereby adopted as the ordinance and code regulating eating and drinking establishments in the city; that the
recommended ordinance and code of the United States public health service of 1943, in addition to the sanitary code of the Montana state board of health,
is hereby declared to be the ordinance and code of the city in its entirety as though written herein and set out and is hereby made a part hereof with the
exception of section 12 pertaining to penalties, which said section is provided for in this code, a copy of said code with the amendment herein shall be filed
with the clerk as the official code of the city. (Ord. 945, 4-23-1951; amd. 1961 Code)
8-1-2: INSPECTION REQUIRED:
All establishments shall be inspected and approved by the health department before a license is issued by the clerk. (1961 Code)
Chapter 2
MILK
8-2-1: ADOPTION OF PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE MILK CODE:
The production and handling of milk and milk products sold for ultimate consumption within the municipality or its jurisdiction, all inspections, the issuing
and revoking of permits and the serving of milk to the public shall be regulated by the adoption of the U.S. public health service milk code, published by the
U.S. department of health, education, and welfare (1953), three (3) copies of which are now on file in the office of the clerk and said code is hereby
adopted and incorporated as if fully set out at length herein. (1961 Code)
8-2-2: PERMITS:
Under section 3 of the U.S. public service milk code permits shall be in the sum of ten dollars ($10.00) per year, payable in advance. (1961 Code)
8-2-3: DAIRIES; LICENSE; FEE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or offer for sale any milk, cream or any dairy products within the city, without first securing a license so to do from
the treasurer, and before said treasurer shall issue said license, the granting of said license must be approved by the health officer, and the person making
application for said license must in addition thereto, present a license issued to said person from the livestock sanitary board, and the license fee to be
charged by said treasurer upon the issuance of a license shall be as follows:
Two dollars ($2.00) per annum for one cow.
Two dollars ($2.00) per quarter for two (2) cows up to five (5) cows.
Three dollars ($3.00) per quarter for five (5) cows up to ten (10) cows.
Four dollars ($4.00) per quarter for ten (10) cows up to twenty (20) cows.
Five dollars ($5.00) per quarter for twenty (20) cows and over.
Provided, further, that any person who does not own any cows but sells milk, cream or dairy products or offers to sell the same in said city shall pay a
license fee of two dollars fifty cents ($2.50) per quarter in advance.
All license fees shall be paid quarterly and in advance, except in the case of the owner of one cow, who shall pay the license fee annually in advance.
(Ord. 628, 3-21-1927; amd. Ord. 729, 10-10-1932)
Chapter 3
MEAT AND MEAT PRODUCTS
8-3-1: MEAT TO BE APPROVED:
The city commission hereby determines that it is for the best interests of the health and general welfare of the inhabitants of the city that all "meat" or meat
products, as herein defined, offered for sale, displayed for sale, sold or served commercially by any person shall bear the official stamp, emblem or legend

8-3-2: DEFINITIONS:
The following words, phrases, names and terms shall be construed respectively to mean:
MEAT: The flesh and all edible parts capable of being used for human food and consumption of cattle, calves, sheep, swine and goats.

Chapter 4
GARBAGE
8-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
GARBAGE: All putrescible waste except sewage and body wastes, including vegetable and animal offal and carcasses of dead animals, but excluding
recognizable industrial byproducts and shall include all such substances from public and private establishments and from all residences.
REFUSE AND TRASH: Shall include known putrescible wastes, rubbish, and debris of whatsoever nature. (Ord. 1281, 9-18-1967)
8-4-2: CONTAINERS; LIMITATIONS:
The owner of each household or place of business having waste material, such as garbage, refuse, or trash, shall be required by this chapter to provide
proper cans or containers for such garbage or waste material: (Ord. 1281, 9-18-1967)
(A) Said cans or containers shall be provided with tight fitting covers. Such cans and covers shall be watertight. (Ord. 1284, 11-20-1967)
(B) All cans shall be placed on a rack or foundation not less than twelve inches (12") aboveground. Cans and covers shall be secured to prevent tipping or
loss.
(C) Multiple dwellings or business places having large quantities of garbage may use covered boxes or receptacles other than metal cans with the written
approval of the sanitation department.
(D) Magazines and newspapers shall be tied in neat bundles or placed in cardboard boxes securely fastened and placed near containers. Tree branches
and shrubbery cuttings shall be securely tied in bundles not exceeding four feet (4') in length, grass clippings shall be securely fastened in small
containers. (Ord. 1169, 10-16-1961)
8-4-3: UNLAWFUL TO BURN GARBAGE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to burn garbage, refuse or trash within the corporate limits with the exception of leaves, grass, weeds and cuttings from
lawns and gardens for which a permit must be had from the fire chief. (Ord. 1169, 10-16-1961)
8-4-4: ACCUMULATION OF GARBAGE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to allow garbage, refuse, or trash to accumulate on private property, or in streets and alleys within the city, for a period of
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 117/283
over ten (10) days, and such accumulation of garbage, refuse or trash shall be deemed a nuisance. (Ord. 1169, 10-16-1961)
8-4-5: SPILLING OR SCATTERING UNLAWFUL:
It shall be unlawful for any person to spill or otherwise scatter or permit to be scattered on the streets and alleys of the city any garbage, refuse or trash,
and such person is required to immediately pick up or remove said garbage, refuse or trash. (Ord. 1169, 10-16-1961)
8-4-6: CITY HEALTH DEPARTMENT:
The city health department has the authority to examine and investigate all complaints pertaining to violations of this chapter; the city health department on
its own initiative can examine and investigate all matters pertaining to garbage and garbage containers; the city health department, upon investigation,
shall first notify the owner of each household or place of business which is in violation of this chapter, and give them notice to correct the violation; said
notice shall not exceed a period of seven (7) days; the city health department shall have the authority to condemn any can or container in violation by
placing a notice of condemnation thereon; said notice of condemnation shall be firmly attached to the can or container in violation. (Ord. 1281, 9-18-1967)
8-4-7: GARBAGE COLLECTION RESTRICTED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to pick up garbage or refuse from the condemned container or can; it shall be unlawful for any party to in any manner
tamper with, dispose of or remove the condemnation tag from the can or container without the express permission of the city health department. (Ord.
1281, 9-18-1967)
8-4-8: PENALTY:
Any violation of sections 8-4-6 and 8-4-7 of this chapter shall be deemed a misdemeanor or violation of this code and is subject to the penalty prescribed
by title 1, chapter 3 of this code. (Ord. 1281, 9-18-1967)
8-4-9: OWNER RESPONSIBLE:
The owner of any real property within the limits of the city of Lewistown shall a responsible for any accumulation of garbage and refuse upon his property,
notwithstanding the fact that said premises may be occupied by persons other than said owner. Such responsibility shall extend to such property whether
or not the same is occupied and whether or not the said owner can indicate that another person is responsible therefor. (Ord. 1368, 6-3-1974)
8-4-10: REMOVAL OF GARBAGE BY CITY:
In the event that the city of Lewistown is required to, or does, for any reason, collect and remove garbage and refuse from private premises or from streets
and alleys adjacent to said private premises, and it can be determined that such garbage and refuse originated upon private premises, then and in that
event the city shall have the right, in addition to removing such refuse and garbage, to assess the cost thereof against the offending property. Such
assessment shall be certified to the county treasurer and taxed against the real estate and shall be a lien against such real estate until paid. (Ord. 1368, 6-
3-1974)

Chapter 6
REFUSE IN BUILDINGS; SANITARY CONDITIONS
8-6-1: REFUSE IN BUILDINGS; STAGNANT WATER:
It shall be unlawful for any person to permit or suffer to be in or accumulate in, or upon any yard, lot, place or premises or upon any street or sidewalk
adjacent to or abutting upon any lot, block, place or premises or in any building or shed owned or occupied by him or for which he may be agent within the
limits of the municipality any stagnant water or impure water, refuse, vegetable decay or decaying substance, garbage or filth of any kind, nor suffer such
yard, lot, place, building or premises to be or to remain in such condition as to cause or create a nuisance or offensive smell or to pollute or render
unhealthful the atmosphere or the premises or thereby to be, become, cause or create a public nuisance. (1961 Code)
8-6-2: ANIMALS AND FOWL:
It shall be unlawful and deemed a nuisance, for any person to permit or house upon any yard, lot, place or premises or upon any street or sidewalk within
the limits of the city, any animal or fowl which causes an unsanitary condition or an offensive odor. (Ord. 1174, 3-5-1962)
8-6-3: DEAD ANIMALS AND FOWL:

It shall be unlawful and deemed a nuisance, for any person to place or fail to remove, if responsible for, any dead animal, fowl, or portion thereof, within the

and state law. (Ord. 1174, 3-5-1962)
8-6-4: VEHICLES CAUSING UNSANITARY CONDITIONS OR OFFENSIVE ODOR:
