Chapter 7
LITTER REGULATIONS
8-7-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms, phrases and words shall have the meanings given herein:
FOODS, DRINKS AND LIKE ITEMS: Only those items prepared and sold for immediate consumption and in which it is reasonably conceivable that the
container is to be thrown away or discarded. They will in no instance mean the usual packaged foods or drinks usually sold in grocery stores or markets for
home preparation and consumption.
TO LITTER: The throwing, scattering, deposition, or dropping of any waste materials, such as paper, containers, boxes, bottles, cans, wrappers, or like
items of whatsoever material or whatsoever use, upon any street, public way, alley, public premises, and/or sidewalks, or upon private premises. (Ord.
1201, 4-1-1963)
8-7-2: LITTERING FROM VEHICLES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to litter, throw, toss, drop or push any of the materials mentioned in section 8-7-1 of this chapter from any car, truck,
public conveyance, and/or other type of vehicle, either moving or standing still upon any street, alley or public parking lot, or any private premises. (Ord.
1201, 4-1-1963)
8-7-3: LITTERING BY PEDESTRIANS:
It shall be unlawful for any pedestrian to litter, discard, throw, toss, place or drop any of the materials mentioned in section 8-7-1 of this chapter upon any
street, alley, public grounds, public parking lot or sidewalk, or any private premises, except in specially designated containers or places. (Ord. 1201, 4-1-
1963)
8-7-4: THROWING OR BREAKING:
It shall be unlawful for any person to throw and break, or attempt to break any bottle or other glass object against a building, on a street, alley, sidewalk, or
parking lot, or any private premises, and to leave the broken sections thereupon. (Ord. 1201, 4-1-1963)
8-7-5: POSTING OF LITTER REGULATIONS:
It shall be required of all places of business engaged in selling at retail, foods, soft drinks, beer, coffee or like items where the container is usually to be
discarded after consumption of the product, such as hot lunches, sandwiches, coffee, soft drinks, beer, ice cream, and like items, to post in a conspicuous
place near where said items are displayed or dispensed, a copy of the first four (4) sections of this chapter. The copy shall be supplied by the city at the
time of purchasing a city license. (Ord. 1201, 4-1-1963)
8-7-6: PENALTY:
Any person violating the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to a fine of not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00). (Ord. 1201, 4-1-1963)
Chapter 8
NUISANCE WEEDS
8-8-1: NUISANCE WEEDS DEFINED:
"Nuisance weeds" means and includes all uncontrolled growth of vegetation of every kind and nature over twelve inches (12") in height, not grown for
purposes of landscaping or food production. "Noxious weeds", as defined by state law, are not included in this definition. (Ord. 1737, 7-18-2011)
8-8-2: WEEDS PROHIBITED:
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 119/283
(A) No owner or owners of any lot, place, or area within the city, or the agent or tenant of such owner or owners, shall permit nuisance weeds on such lot,
place, or area and one-half (1/2) of any road or street lying next to such lands or boulevard abutting thereon. The existence of such nuisance weeds
shall constitute a public nuisance.
(B) Public wildland parks and recreational trails are excluded from this chapter unless vegetation is deemed a fire hazard by the fire marshal. (Ord. 1737,
7-18-2011)
8-8-3: NOTICE TO DESTROY:
When nuisance weeds exist on any lot, place, or area within the city, notice shall be given in writing to the owner or owners or tenant or agent of such
owner or owners, of such lots, areas, or places. The written notice shall specify the location of nuisance weeds and shall state that such constitutes a
public nuisance. The notice shall further state that such nuisance weeds must be removed or exterminated within ten (10) days of the date of mailing, and
upon failure or neglect to do so, the city may proceed to have such weeds removed or exterminated and assess the costs thereof to the property. (Ord.
1737, 7-18-2011)
8-8-4: ACTION UPON NONCOMPLIANCE:
Upon the failure, neglect or refusal of any owner or owners, or agent or tenant thereof, to exterminate or remove such nuisance weeds growing, lying or
located upon the owner or owner's property or upon the one-half (1/2) of any road or street lying next to the lands, or any boulevard abutting thereon,
before the expiration of ten (10) days from the mailing of the written notice specified in the preceding section, the city public works director or the city fire
marshal is hereby authorized to exterminate or cause the removal of such nuisance weeds. The bill of costs of extermination or removal, plus a ten
percent (10%) administrative fee, shall be submitted to the city clerk. The city clerk may direct the city attorney to take any reasonable action in an attempt
to collect such charges; or in addition or in lieu of such collection efforts, the city clerk shall cause such charges to be assessed against the property. (Ord.
1737, 7-18-2011)
Chapter 9
COMMUNITY DECAY
8-9-1: PURPOSE:
(A) It shall be a violation of this chapter to own or maintain any public nuisance or community decay within the city.
(B) This chapter applies to the whole of the city and any areas which may hereafter be annexed to the city. (Ord. 1650, 9-8-1998)
8-9-2: DEFINITIONS:
AGENCY: The city agency designated to enforce the community decay ordinance.
COMMUNITY DECAY: A public nuisance created by allowing rubble, debris, junk, or refuse to accumulate resulting in conditions that are injurious to
health, indecent, offensive to the senses, or obstruct the free use of property so as to interfere with the comfortable enjoyment of life or property.
COMMUNITY DECAY STANDARDS: Those standards which may be adopted by the city commission in order to provide guidance to the enforcing agency
as to the application of this chapter.
PERSON: An individual, firm, partnership, company, association, corporation, city, town, or any other entity whether organized for profit or not.
PUBLIC NUISANCE: A nuisance which affects, at the same time, an entire community or neighborhood or any other considerable number of persons,
although the extent of the annoyance or damage inflicted on individuals may be unequal.
PUBLIC VIEW: Any point, six feet (6') above the surface of the center of any public road, property or right of way, from which the community decay can be
seen.
SHIELDING: Refers to fencing or other manmade barriers to conceal a facility from public view. It also refers to natural barriers. Any shielding barrier must
conform to all local zoning, planning, building and protective covenant provisions or applicable city ordinance. Any shielding is to be of sufficient height that
none of the violation on the premises is visible to public view. (Ord. 1650, 9-8-1998)
8-9-3: AGENCIES; POWERS AND DUTIES:
The city commission hereby designates the city manager or his designee(s) in consultation with the city-county planning board as the person and agencies
which shall have the following powers and duties:
(A) The duty to inspect when there has been a complaint by more than one person that "community decay" is present in an area.
(B) The power to formulate applicable standards by which to enforce this chapter.
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 120/283
(C) The power to determine whether this chapter applies after an inspection of the property or area. The violation must be in public view.
(D) The duty to send a written notice of violation to the owner of the property in violation of this chapter.
(E) The power to enter upon the property in violation after written notice and a show cause hearing, if applicable, for the specific purpose of abating the
violation.
(F) The power to assess the property owner for the actual costs of an abatement made by the agency. (Ord. 1650, 9-8-1998)
8-9-4: COMMUNITY DECAY AND SHIELDING STANDARDS:
(A) Community Decay Standards: It shall be a violation of this chapter to allow any of the following conditions to exist within "public view", as defined within
this chapter, on any land or property in the city:
1. The piling or spreading of straw, hay, grass trimmings or similar material unless the material is to be used as soil conditioner or mulch and the
material is plowed into the ground or otherwise mixed and covered with clean soil within sixty (60) days from placement upon a lot or field.
2. The dumping, piling, or stacking of bricks, concrete blocks, waste wood, and/or similar material on open lots or fields, unless said material is stacked
in neat piles and all waste material from the cleaning of such items, such as mortar, wood splinters, broken and unusable bricks, is removed to a
licensed solid waste disposal facility or to some other location which has been approved by the agency within a reasonable period approved by the
agency. Should such an operation be an ongoing continuous business, it shall be located in an area properly zoned for such a salvage business and
shall be shielded from public view. Shielding shall meet the shielding standards outlined within these community decay standards and/or city zoning
regulations.
3. The storage or large accumulation of cardboard boxes, broken packing boxes, paper, or other similar items on lots or fields.
4. The piling, dumping or depositing of any dirt, demolition wastes including wood, bricks, concrete, used road blacktop and other similar materials on
any open lots or fields, unless such material is to be utilized for fill material to fill a coulee or land depression. If such material is used as fill material,
all such material shall be completely covered with clean fill material once every ten (10) days and the fill area shall be adequately fenced to restrict
access to the area. Failure to comply with the periodic cover and access control requirements shall constitute a violation of this chapter.
5. The storage and accumulation of iron, metal, component vehicle and machine parts, junk vehicles, household appliances, barrels and other
salvaged metal items, unless such material is stored in an approved, licensed, and shielded motor vehicle wrecking facility. If such material is being
accumulated as part of an ongoing, active salvage business other than an approved licensed motor vehicle wrecking facility, the salvage business
must be located in a properly zoned area for such a business and shall be shielded from public view. Shielding shall meet the shielding standards
outlined within these community decay standards and/or city zoning regulations.
The standards set forth herein are for guidance only and are not intended nor shall the same be considered the sole or exclusive standards
establishing a violation.
(B) Shielding Standards:
1. All plans for shielding shall be approved by the agency prior to commencing construction of shielding.
2. When fences are used for shielding the boards may be spaced and/or slanted to reduce wind load. The space between boards when viewed from
broadside shall not be more than one and one-half inches (11/2") and the interval between spaces shall not be less than seven and one-half inches
(71/2"). Rough dimensional lumber or better is acceptable. Chainlink fences with standard fiberglass or other inserts are acceptable, provided the gap
between adjacent slats does not exceed one and one-half inches (11/2").
3. Shielding with shrubs and trees shall provide a similar degree of shielding at all times of the year. Dirt berms are acceptable for shielding purposes,
provided the berm slopes are graded smooth and seeded with an adequate grass seed formula.
4. Other types of fencing of equivalent permanence, attractiveness, and shielding qualities, including corrugated metal, are also acceptable.
5. No more than one of the approved shielding materials shall be used on any one side of a shielding fence.
6. The fencing is to be maintained by the property owner or occupant in a neat and workmanlike manner and shall be replaced when necessary. (Ord.
1650, 9-8-1998)
8-9-5: NOTIFICATION; VIOLATION:
(A) Upon the agency's own information or upon written complaint by a member of the public that a public nuisance has been created by allowing rubble,
debris, junk, or refuse to accumulate resulting in conditions that are injurious to health, indecent, offensive to the senses, or obstruct the free use of
property, the agency shall inspect the property alleged to be in violation of this chapter. Upon inspection the agency shall determine whether there is a
violation of this chapter. (Ord. 1696, 3-1-2004)
(B) If there appears to be a violation of this chapter, the agency shall notify the owner of the property in writing of the violation. This notice shall be sent by
certified mail. This notice shall include a statement specifically describing the violation.
(C) The notice of violation to the owner shall specify that the owner has thirty (30) days from receipt of such notice within which to become in compliance
with this chapter by means of removal or shielding of the conditions.
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 121/283
(D) The owner may, after notification of violation, submit a plan of abatement to the agency which shall include: 1) type of abatement or shielding if
allowed; 2) date for commencement of action; and 3) reasons, if appropriate, why abatement cannot be started within the thirty (30) days. The agency
may accept such plan and defer further proceedings under this chapter pending abatement.
(E) After thirty (30) days or the date agreed to by owner and agency, not to exceed ninety (90) days, the agency shall determine whether the violation has
been abated by the owner.
(F) If the owner has failed to act, the agency shall send a notice setting a date and time for hearing before the city court notifying the owner to appear to
show cause why the violation has not been abated.
(G) A show cause hearing will be held by the city court. Both the city agency and the owner may give evidence. At the end of the hearing, the court shall
determine if proper notification was made and if the violation exists. The owner shall be ordered to abate it within a reasonable time.
(H) If, after a show cause hearing, the owner has not complied with the court ordered abatement, the agency may send written notification by certified mail
and allow ten (10) days further to complete abatement. Ten (10) days after receipt of notice by owner, the agency may enter upon the owner's property
with the specific purpose of abating or shielding the violation, whichever the agency deems appropriate.
(I) The agency may assess the property owner/user for the actual costs of the abatement.
(J) Nonpayment of the assessment by the agency may be taken as a lien upon the property and is enforceable as is nonpayment of property taxes. (Ord.
1650, 9-8-1998)
Title 9
PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY
Chapter 1
TRAFFIC CONTROL
9-1-1: CONSTRUCTION OR MAINTENANCE WORK; TRAFFIC REGULATIONS:
The building official is authorized to establish regulations governing the control of traffic through and around areas of construction or maintenance work
being done within the public right of way. Said regulations shall be maintained on file in the office of the building official. The scope of said traffic control
regulations shall include, but not be limited to, the size, coloring, wording, illumination and placement of warning devices such as signs, barricades,
warning lights and such other devices as may be deemed appropriate. (Ord. 1455, 7-7-1980)
9-1-2: TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES REQUIRED:
Traffic control devices shall be properly placed as required by regulations of the building official before any construction or maintenance work is begun. All
such devices shall then remain until the work is completed and can be used by normal traffic without damage. (Ord. 1455, 7-7-1980)
9-1-3: LIMITATION OF CONSTRUCTION OR MAINTENANCE WORK:
The building official is authorized, with regard to all construction or maintenance work being done within the public right of way, to limit or otherwise control
such construction or maintenance work as follows:
(A) Length of time in which work must be completed.
(B) Day or days of the week during which such work may be accomplished.
(C) Time of day during which such work may be accomplished.
(D) Length and width of area which may be used as work zone.
(E) Width of street which may be blocked.
(F) Methods by which work may be accomplished.
(G) Maximum wheel loads to be allowed, depending upon the load carrying capabilities of individual streets.
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 122/283
(H) Type of equipment which may be used to accomplish work. (Ord. 1455, 7-7-1980)
9-1-4: REMOVAL OF TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES PROHIBITED:
Whenever any traffic control device is placed upon a street, traffic lane, alley or sidewalk of the city by any official or employee of the city in the course of
his duty, or by a contractor working in, on, or above any street, alley or sidewalk of the city, no person shall move or remove such traffic control devices.
(Ord. 1455, 7-7-1980)
9-1-5: BARRICADED AREAS; ENTRY PROHIBITED:
No unauthorized person shall walk upon or drive upon that portion of the street, traffic lane, alley or sidewalk which has been properly barricaded to
prohibit such use. (Ord. 1455, 7-7-1980)
9-1-6: CONSTRUCTION AND MAINTENANCE WORK DEFINED:
Construction and maintenance work, as used with this chapter, shall include street openings, diggings, excavations, street construction and repairs,
sidewalk, curb and gutter construction and repair, building erection or repair, and any or all work performed in the city. (Ord. 1455, 7-7-1980)
9-1-7: CITY TO PLACE TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES:
If any person fails to provide the safety devices required by this chapter, such devices shall be installed and maintained by the city. Any cost incurred shall
be paid by such person. (Ord. 1455, 7-7-1980)
9-1-8: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Violation of this chapter shall be deemed a misdemeanor and any person violating the provisions of this chapter may be fined in an amount not exceeding
five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment not to exceed six (6) months for any one offense. (Ord. 1455, 7-7-1980)
Chapter 2
TREES AND SHRUBBERY
9-2-1: DEFINITIONS:
PARK TREES: Trees, shrubs, bushes, and all other woody vegetation in public parks having individual names, and all areas owned by the city, or to which
the public has free access as a park.
STREET TREES: Trees, shrubs, bushes, and all other woody vegetation on public right of way lying between property lines on either side of all streets,
avenues, or ways within the city.
TREE TOPPING: The severe cutting back of limbs to stubs larger than three inches (3") in diameter within the tree's crown to such a degree so as to
remove the normal canopy and disfigure the tree. (Ord. 1731, 3-7-2011)
9-2-2: TREE SPECIES TO BE PLANTED:
The park and tree board develops and maintains a list of desirable trees for planting along public right of way in three (3) size classes based on mature
height: small (under 20 feet), medium (20 to 40 feet) and large (over 40 feet). Efforts shall be made to ensure a sufficient diversity of tree species. Lists of
trees suitable for planting will also be created by the park and tree board. (Ord. 1731, 3-7-2011)
9-2-3: SPACING:
The spacing of street trees on public right of way will be in accordance with section 9-2-2 of this chapter, and no closer than as follows: small trees, fifteen
feet (15'); medium trees, twenty five feet (25'); and large trees, thirty five feet (35'); except in special plantings approved by the park and tree board. (Ord.
1731, 3-7-2011)
9-2-4: DISTANCE FROM CURB AND SIDEWALK:
The distance trees may be planted from curbs or curb lines and sidewalks will be in accordance with section 9-2-2 of this chapter, and trees shall not be
planted closer than two feet (2') for small trees or medium trees to any curb or sidewalk. (Ord. 1731, 3-7-2011)
9-2-5: DISTANCE FROM STREET CORNERS AND FIRE HYDRANTS:
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 123/283
No street tree shall be planted within twenty five feet (25') of any street corner, measured from the point of nearest intersecting curbs or curb lines. No
street tree shall be planted within ten feet (10') of any fire hydrant. (Ord. 1731, 3-7-2011)
9-2-6: UTILITIES:
No street tree, other than those species accepted as small trees by the park and tree board, may be planted under, or within ten feet (10') of any overhead
utility wire. (Ord. 1731, 3-7-2011)
9-2-7: PUBLIC TREE CARE:
(A) The owner or person in control of property is charged with care, maintenance and full responsibility for trees and all vegetative growth on adjacent
streets, alleys, boulevards and public ways consistent with these regulations.
(B) The city shall have the right to plant, prune, maintain and remove trees, plants and shrubs within the lines of all streets, alleys, avenues, lanes, squares
and public grounds, as may be necessary to maintain rights of way, clear vision zones, unobstructed view, traffic control signs and devices and to
ensure public safety or to preserve or enhance the symmetry and beauty of such public grounds. Upon recommendation of the park and tree board the
city may remove or cause or order to be removed, any tree or part thereof which is in an unsafe condition or which by reason of its nature is injurious to
sewers, electric power lines, gas lines, water lines, or other public improvements, or is affected with any injurious fungus, insect, or other pest. This
section does not prohibit the planting of street trees by adjacent property owners providing that the selection and location of trees is in accordance with
section 9-2-2 of this chapter through this section and section 9-2-15 of this chapter. (Ord. 1731, 3-7-2011)
9-2-8: PRUNING STANDARDS:
All tree pruning on public property shall conform to commonly accepted horticultural practices for tree care operations. (Ord. 1731, 3-7-2011)
9-2-9: TREE TOPPING:
It is unlawful for any person, firm, or city department to top any street tree, park tree, or other tree on public property. Trees severely damaged by storms or
other cause or trees under utility wires or other obstructions where other pruning practices are impractical may be exempted. (Ord. 1731, 3-7-2011)
9-2-10: PRUNING AND CORNER CLEARANCE:
Every owner of a tree overhanging any street or right of way within the city shall maintain such tree so as to not unduly obstruct the light from any street
lamp or view of any street intersection and to provide clear space of at least thirteen feet (13') above street surface and eight feet (8') above the sidewalk
surface. Owners shall remove all dead, diseased or dangerous trees, or broken or decayed limbs which constitute a menace to the safety of the public.
Tree limbs that grow near high voltage electrical conductors shall be maintained clear of such conductors by the electric utility company in compliance with
any applicable franchise agreements. A utility tree trimming policy must be reviewed by the utility company and park and tree board prior to any trimming
by the utility company. The city shall have the right to prune any tree or shrub on private property when it interferes with the proper spread of light along
the street from a streetlight, interferes with visibility of any traffic control device or sign or sight triangle at intersections or otherwise presents a hazard to
life or property. In the event the city determines such pruning is necessary, the city will provide the landowner with at least seven (7) days' written notice of
the violation and the city's intended action. If the violation is not corrected within the time provided, or any extension thereof agreed to by the city, the city
may cause such pruning and removal of debris to be accomplished and the owner shall be responsible for such costs. Any costs not paid may be collected
as an assessment on the property as other property taxes. (Ord. 1731, 3-7-2011)
9-2-11: DEAD OR DISEASED TREE REMOVAL ON PRIVATE PROPERTY:
The owner of property shall cause the removal of any dead or diseased tree which may constitute a nuisance or hazard to life or property or harbor insects
or disease which constitute a potential threat to other trees within the city. Removal shall be done at the owner's expense. In the event of failure of an
owner to comply with such provisions, the city shall have the authority to enter the property and remove such trees and charge the cost of removal on the
owner's property tax notice. (Ord. 1731, 3-7-2011)
9-2-12: PROTECTION OF TREES:
In order to maintain the overall forest on public property, reasonable efforts shall be made to replace trees that are removed and to protect quality trees
that are endangered. Trees removed by decision of the park and tree board or by natural causes shall be replaced somewhere in the forest on a one for
one basis. The location and species of any replacement tree shall be determined by the park and tree board. Trees of desirable species and good health
shall be protected as much as possible from damage during construction, sidewalk repair, utility work above and below ground and other similar activities.
The zone of protection shall include the ground beneath the canopy of the tree. (Ord. 1731, 3-7-2011)
9-2-13: INTERFERENCE WITH PARK AND TREE BOARD:
It is unlawful for any person to prevent, delay or interfere with the city, the park and tree board, or any of its agents, while engaged in the planting,
cultivating, mulching, pruning, spraying, or removing of any street trees, park trees, or trees on private grounds, as authorized in this chapter. (Ord. 1731,
3-7-2011)
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 124/283
9-2-14: LICENSE AND INSURANCE:
It is unlawful for any person or firm to engage in the business or occupation of pruning, treating, or removing any tree within the city without a city license,
provided, however, that no license shall be required of any public service company including electric utilities and their agents and contractors or city
employee in the course of their designated duties. Before any license shall be issued, each applicant shall first file evidence of possession of liability
insurance in the minimum amounts of seven hundred fifty thousand dollars ($750,000.00) per claim and one million five hundred thousand dollars
($1,500,000.00) per occurrence indemnifying the city or any person injured or damaged resulting from the pursuit. (Ord. 1731, 3-7-2011)
9-2-15: AUTHORITY OF ADJOINING PROPERTY OWNER TO PLANT OR CARE FOR TREES ON BOULEVARDS OR
PARKWAYS:
Permission is given to the owners of real estate to improve their premises by planting and properly caring for trees in the boulevards adjoining their
property after obtaining permit for such purpose from the city. Such trees shall in no case interfere with the full use of the streets for public purposes, and
no person shall plant any tree within the limits of any parkway, street or alley in the city without having first obtained a written permit from the city. It shall
be the duty of the property owner to make a request in writing to the city, stating the variety and precise location of each tree proposed to be planted. The
permit shall specify the location and variety of each tree. (Ord. 1731, 3-7-2011)
9-2-16: REMOVAL, CUTTING AND INJURY:
No person shall remove, destroy, cut, deface, or in any way injure or interfere with any street tree or park tree without a permit from the public works
department. (Ord. 1731, 3-7-2011)
9-2-17: INTERFERENCE WITH TREES BY HOUSE MOVER, PERMIT REQUIRED:
It is unlawful for any person to move any building, equipment or other object along any street, avenue or alley in the city, where such movement may
interfere with or injure any tree or shrub in any street, avenue, alley or public place, including parks and parkways without first obtaining a permit from the
public works department. The application for such permit and the permit issued shall specify the particular building, equipment or object to be removed and
the particular route to be followed. Any damage to trees or shrubs caused by such movement shall be assessed to the permittee. (Ord. 1731, 3-7-2011)
9-2-18: PROCEDURE FOR TEMPORARY REMOVAL:
A permit shall be required for the temporary removal of trees or shrubs on public property made necessary due to construction, movement of structures or
for any other purpose. A permitted removal shall be performed at the expense of the permittee or person or entity causing the same. Any cost associated
with removal, replacement or for the damage of any tree or shrub shall be assessed against, and paid by, the permittee. (Ord. 1731, 3-7-2011)
9-2-19: INSECTS AND DISEASES DECLARED NUISANCE:
All insect pests and diseases known to be injurious to fruit, shade and ornamental trees and shrubs and all trees, shrubs and vegetable growth infested or
infected therewith constitute a menace, and are hereby declared to be a public nuisance and such nuisance shall be abated by the owner. (Ord. 1731, 3-7-
2011)
9-2-20: SPRAYING:
Every person who is owner or in possession, control or the manager of any lot, block or parcel of land upon which there are any fruit, shade or ornamental
trees or shrubs which are infested or infected with any insect pests or diseases known to be injurious to such fruit, shade or ornamental trees or shrubs,
shall, within three (3) days, upon written order of the city, spray or cause the same to be sprayed in such manner and with such pesticide approved by the
city. Any person failing to comply with any such order shall be deemed guilty of maintaining a nuisance. (Ord. 1731, 3-7-2011)
9-2-21: REVIEW BY CITY COMMISSION:
The city commission shall have the right to review the conduct, acts, and decisions of the city park and tree board. Any person may appeal from any ruling
or order of the park and tree board to the city commission who may hear the matter and make final decisions. (Ord. 1731, 3-7-2011)
9-2-22: ABATEMENT OF VIOLATIONS:
Any tree, shrub or plant which is maintained in violation of any provision of this chapter is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and such shall be
immediately abated by the owner of the property.
(A) If there appears to be a violation of this chapter, the city shall notify the owner of the property in writing of the violation. This notice shall be sent by
certified mail. This notice shall include a statement specifically describing the violation. Notice may be personally served by a designated city
employee.
(B) Unless a shorter time is provided for in this chapter, the notice of violation to the owner shall specify that the owner has twenty (20) days from receipt of
such notice within which to become in compliance with this chapter.
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 125/283
(C) The owner may, after notification of violation, submit a plan of abatement to the city which shall include: 1) type of abatement proposed; 2) date for
commencement of action; and 3) reasons, if appropriate, why abatement cannot be completed within the twenty (20) days from the receipt of notice.
The city may accept such plan and defer further proceedings under this chapter pending abatement.
(D) After twenty (20) days or the date agreed to by owner and city, not to exceed sixty (60) days, the city shall determine whether the violation has been
abated by the owner.
(E) If the owner has failed to act or correct the nuisance, the city shall send a notice setting a date and time for hearing before the city court notifying the
owner to appear to show cause why the violation has not been abated.
(F) A show cause hearing will be held by the city court. Both the city and the owner may give evidence. At the end of the hearing, the court shall determine
if proper notification was made and if the violation exists. If a violation exists, the owner shall be ordered to abate it within a reasonable time and allow
the city to inspect the same for compliance. The court is also authorized to allow the city to enter the owner's property and abate the nuisance if the
nuisance is not abated as directed by the court.
(G) If, after a show cause hearing, the owner has not complied with the court ordered abatement, the city may enter upon the owner's property with the
specific purpose of abating the violation.
(H) The city may assess the property owner/user for the actual costs of the abatement.
(I) Nonpayment of the assessment by the city may be taken as a lien upon the property and is enforceable as is nonpayment of property taxes. (Ord. 1731,
3-7-2011)
9-2-23: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of the ordinance codified in this chapter shall be, upon conviction or a plea of guilty, subject to a civil fine not to exceed
one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each violation. Each day that the violation exists shall be deemed a separate violation for purposes of this section. (Ord.
1731, 3-7-2011)
9-2-24: EXISTING TREES:
Trees, shrubs or plants existing on the date hereof are excluded from the requirements of sections 9-2-2 through 9-2-5 of this chapter. However, all other
provisions of this chapter shall apply. (Ord. 1731, 3-7-2011)
Chapter 3
STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND CURBS
9-3-1: IMPROVEMENTS; PERMIT REQUIRED; APPEAL:
A permit shall be required for any demolition, repair, construction or improvement on or of any street, sidewalk, curb or gutter. The permit shall be obtained
from the building official by the person actually performing the construction. All applications therefor shall be made in duplicate on the form prepared by the
building official. Any applicant deeming himself aggrieved may appeal the decision of the building official to the city commission. However, he shall do no
such work pending the appeal, except in strict accordance with the directions of the building official. (Ord. 1722, 10-20-2008)
9-3-2: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT:
Application for the permit required by section 9-3-1 of this chapter shall give a description of the property to be served and such other information as may
be required by the building official, for the proper direction of the work, and must be signed by the owner or his authorized agent. (Ord. 1456, 7-7-1980)
9-3-3: PERMIT FEES:
At the time when the application for a permit, as required by section 9-3-1 of this chapter is made, the applicant shall pay the building official the following
fees for sidewalk, curb and gutter:
(A) First fifty feet (50'), five dollars ($5.00).
(B) Every additional twenty five feet (25') or portion thereafter, two dollars ($2.00).
In the event grades are requested for both sidewalk, curb and gutter, only the fee for one item shall be required. There shall be no permit fee charged
for street construction or repair. (Ord. 1456, 7-7-1980)
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 126/283
9-3-4: REMOVAL OF WORK DONE WITHOUT A PERMIT:
Any work constructed without obtaining a permit as required by this chapter shall be subject to removal upon notice by the building official and no liability
shall be placed on the building official or upon the city for such action. (Ord. 1456, 7-7-1980)
9-3-5: CONSTRUCTION; COMPLIANCE WITH CITY SPECIFICATIONS:
It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to build or construct any sidewalk, private work or curb in any street, avenue or alley or to build or
construct any improvement of any nature whatsoever in any street, alley or avenue unless the same is constructed in compliance with the current
standards, specifications and plans on file in the office of the building official and approved by the city commission. (Ord. 1456, 7-7-1980; amd. Ord. 1664,
1-3-2000)
9-3-6: CONSTRUCTION; GRADE, WIDTH AND SLOPE DESIGNATIONS:
Sidewalks or curb construction on improved or graded streets must conform with the established grade and sidewalk line; on all other streets, sidewalks
must be laid to the proper sidewalk line, and otherwise to the satisfaction of the building official. Driveway crossings into private property shall be of the
form and construction as specified by the building officials. All sidewalks hereafter to be built or constructed in the city shall be of the width established by
the building official, such widths to be on file in the office of the building official. All sidewalks shall rise one-fourth inch to the foot (1/4" to 1') from the curb
grade to the property line. (Ord. 1456, 7-7-1980)
9-3-7: CONSTRUCTION; WHEELCHAIR RAMPS, PARKING METERS, SIGNS, PAVEMENT RESTORATION AND BACKFILL:
(A) Wheelchair Ramps: Any person constructing sidewalks shall construct complete wheelchair ramps at street corners as directed by the building official,
either as a portion of new sidewalk construction or replacement of existing sidewalk. Complete wheelchair ramps shall be constructed whenever any
portion of sidewalk is constructed or replaced within the limits of the curb radius. A complete wheelchair ramp consists of the curb and gutter radius and
sidewalk constructed within the radius in compliance with the current standards and specifications on file in the office of the building official. Any and all
costs associated with such construction shall be the responsibility of the person performing the construction.
(B) Parking Meters, Signs, Pavement Restoration And Backfill: It shall be the duty of any person constructing sidewalk, curb or streets to reset any and all
parking meters, signs or other appurtenances, to repair or replace any pavement or other street surfacing material removed or disturbed, and to backfill
curbs, sidewalks and streets as directed by the building official. Any and all costs associated with such construction shall be the responsibility of the
person performing the construction. (Ord. 1495, 10-18-1982)
9-3-8: REPAIRS; OWNERS' DUTY:
It shall be the duty of the owners and tenants of any premises within the limits of the city to keep the sidewalk in front of and adjoining their premises in
good, safe and substantial condition, and the owners shall see that all breaks or unsoundness of any character resulting from natural deterioration, or from
any cause whatsoever, is repaired with all possible dispatch and when by reason of the construction or repairs of sidewalks from any cause whatsoever
any sidewalk or section thereof is removed or rendered dangerous or impassable to the public, such spaces or openings shall be securely fenced, and
from dark until sunrise safety lights shall be maintained thereon, while such dangerous condition exists. Any sidewalk, curb or gutter which is removed
shall be replaced by the owner. (Ord. 1722, 10-20-2008)
9-3-9: REPAIRS; WHEN REQUIRED; ENFORCEMENT; INJUNCTION:
It shall be the duty of the building official to enforce the provisions of this chapter, and immediately report any broken, defective or unsafe sidewalk to the
owner of the premises in front of which such defect exists and shall notify him to repair the same forthwith. Upon the refusal or neglect of the owner of any
premises to remove the obstructions as necessary to prevent accidents, the building official may forthwith proceed with same, and the full cost of the repair
or removal of such obstructions shall be corrected or assessed as provided in section 9-3-10 of this chapter. Absence of notice to owners to repair or
remedy a dangerous walk or to remove obstructions therefrom shall not constitute a valid excuse against the payment of any fine or damages by such
owners or occupants, and nothing contained in any of the preceding sections shall be so construed as to release to owners or occupants of real estate
from the duty of keeping the sidewalks in front or adjoining their respective premises at all times in a safe and passable condition and in good and
thorough state of repair, but such duty is hereby expressly enjoined and imposed upon all such owners and occupants. (Ord. 1456, 7-7-1980)
9-3-10: CONDEMNATION:
Any sidewalks which are now, or which may, by reason of natural deterioration or decay, or by reason of unevenness, steps, rapid slopes or from any
cause whatsoever become dangerous to the public safety, may be condemned by the building official, and shall be subject to immediate removal,
remodeling, rebuilding, repair or construction, as in his judgment may be most expedient, and the cost thereof shall be a lien upon the lot abutting upon
such sidewalk and may be enforced or the amount may be recovered against the owner by a suit before any court of competent jurisdiction or may be
assessed and collected as a special tax against such lot. (Ord. 1456, 7-7-1980)
9-3-11: PRIVATE USE:
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to use any street, sidewalk or public place as space for the display of goods or merchandise for sale,
or to write or make any sign or advertisement on any such street or sidewalk. Provided, however, during certain special business occasions, the city
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 127/283
commission shall allow a variance to businesses within the business section of the city to use such spaces in a reasonable manner for a display of goods
or merchandise for sale. (Ord. 1456, 7-7-1980; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
9-3-12: OBSTRUCTIONS:
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to cause, create or maintain any obstruction of any street, alley or sidewalk or other public way,
except as may be specified by ordinance or by the building official. (Ord. 1456, 7-7-1980)
9-3-13: VIOLATIONS; PENALTY:
Violation of this chapter shall be deemed a misdemeanor and any person violating the provisions of this chapter may be fined in an amount not exceeding
five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment not to exceed six (6) months for any one offense. (Ord. 1456, 7-7-1980)
Chapter 4
CEMETERY MARKERS
(Rep. by Ord. 1686, 11-5-2001)
Chapter 5
EXCAVATIONS
9-5-1: APPLICATION REQUIRED:
Excepting where such person is operating under a contract with the city involving the opening of a public way, any person desiring to excavate in or cut
through or tear open the surface of any street, avenue, alley, sidewalk, boulevard, or other public way within the city, shall first file his written application
with the building official. The application shall state the object sought, the purpose for which the public way is to be excavated in, cut through, or broken
open, the proposed area of such opening and the exact location thereof. (Ord. 1469, 12-15-1980)
9-5-2: APPLICATION; PERMIT FEE:
The application shall be accompanied by the applicable following fee payable to the city:
(A) For an opening not exceeding forty feet (40') in length, there shall be and is a minimum fee of twenty dollars ($20.00).
(B) For an opening exceeding forty feet (40') in length, there shall be and there is a fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) plus twenty five cents ($0.25) per linear
foot in excess of forty feet (40') in length. (Ord. 1469, 12-15-1980)
9-5-3: PERMIT; REFUSAL; ISSUANCE:
The building official may, in his discretion, grant or refuse to grant such permit. The refusal of the building official to grant any such permit is subject to
review by the city commission. The applicant shall accomplish the proposed work in the time allowed by the building official, shall thoroughly backfill any
such excavation or opening and restore the surface thereof to the condition it was prior to such excavation or opening. (Ord. 1469, 12-15-1980; amd. Ord.
1664, 1-3-2000)
9-5-4: EMERGENCY CONDITIONS:
Any person maintaining pipes, lines or other underground facilities in or under the surface of a street, avenue, alley, sidewalk, boulevard or other public
way may proceed with an opening without first submitting an application when emergency conditions demand the work be done immediately; provided, an
application could not have been submitted reasonably beforehand. However, the person shall thereafter submit an application on the first regular business
day of the city offices and said application shall be retroactive to the date when the work was begun. (Ord. 1469, 12-15-1980)
9-5-5: PERFORMANCE MAINTENANCE BOND:
(A) Each applicant upon receipt of a permit shall provide the city with a bond in the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) which shall be executed by a
surety company authorized to do business in the state, conditioned to save the city harmless and reimburse the city for any additional cost incurred in
restoring said excavation due to nonperformance by the bond holder.
(B) Should any applicant be properly and sufficiently bonded through the requirements of other provisions of the code, this bond may be waived at the
discretion of the building official. (Ord. 1469, 12-15-1980)
9-5-6: INSURANCE REQUIRED:
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 128/283
Before any permit to open any public way is granted, such applicant shall furnish satisfactory evidence that there has been issued to the applicant and is in
full force and effect, public liability insurance for bodily injury in the amount of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for each person and three
hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for each accident and for property damage not less than fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) with an aggregate of
one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for all accidents. (Ord. 1469, 12-15-1980)
9-5-7: OPENINGS IN NEW STREETS:
(A) When the city shall improve or pave any street, the building official shall give notice to all persons owning properties abutting on the street to be
improved or paved, and to all public utilities, and authorities operating in the city, and all such persons, utilities and authorities shall make all
connections as well as needed repairs thereto which would necessitate excavation of the street within a reasonable time as set by the building official.
(B) No application shall be considered by the building official which will allow the opening or excavation in a paved or improved street surface less than five
(5) years old unless the applicant can clearly demonstrate that public health or safety requires the proposed work, or unless an emergency condition
exists. (Ord. 1469, 12-15-1980)
9-5-8: NOTICE TO PROPERTY OWNERS, POLICE AND FIRE AUTHORITIES:
If the work to be undertaken by the permittee is such that it will affect the use of properties abutting or adjoining the project, the building official shall
require the applicant to submit a list of names of the owners and/or occupants of such properties. Upon receipt of such list, the building official shall notify
the police and fire authorities of all street opening applications he accepts, including the beginning and completion dates. (Ord. 1469, 12-15-1980)
9-5-9: STREET OPENING REGULATIONS:
(A) No opening or excavation in any street shall extend beyond the centerline of the street before being backfilled and the surface of the street temporarily
restored except at the discretion of the building official. (Ord. 1469, 12-15-1980)
(B) No more than two hundred fifty feet (250') measured along the curb shall be opened in any street at any one time, except as authorized by the city
commission. (Ord. 1469, 12-15-1980; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
(C) Monuments of concrete, iron or other lasting materials set for the purpose of locating or preserving the lines of any street or property subdivision, or a
precise survey reference point or a permanent survey bench mark within the city shall not be removed or disturbed or caused to be removed unless
permission to do so is first obtained in writing from the building official. Permission shall be granted only upon condition that the applicant shall pay all
expenses incident to the proper replacement of the monument.
(D) When the work performed by the applicant interferes with the established drainage system of any street, provision shall be made by the applicant to
provide proper drainage to the satisfaction of the building official.
(E) When any earth, gravel or any other excavated material is caused to roll, flow or wash upon any street, the applicant shall cause the same to be
removed from the street within a reasonable time as set by the building official. In the event the earth, gravel or other excavated material so deposited
is not removed, the building official shall cause the material to be removed and the cost incurred shall be paid by the permittee or deducted from his
deposit.
(F) Every applicant shall place around the project such barriers, barricades, lights, warning flags and danger signs as shall be determined by the building
official to be necessary for the protection of the public, whenever any person fails to provide the safety devices required by the building official, such
devices shall be installed and maintained by the city. Any cost incurred shall be paid by the applicant or deducted from his deposit.
(G) Access to private driveways shall be provided except during working hours when construction operations prohibit the provision of such access. Free
access must be provided at all times to fire hydrants.
(H) Excavated materials shall be kept trimmed up so as to cause as little as possible inconvenience to pedestrians. Temporary wooden plank walks shall
be installed by the applicant as directed by the building official.
(I) Work authorized by permit shall be performed between the hours of seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. Monday through Saturday
unless the applicant obtains written permission from the building official to do the work at any earlier or later hour.
(J) In granting any permit, the building official may attach such other conditions thereto as may be reasonably necessary to prevent damage to public or
private property or to prevent the operation from being conducted in a manner hazardous to life or property or in a manner likely to create a nuisance.
(K) All pavement cuts, openings and excavations shall be properly made, backfilled and surfaced by the applicant according to city specifications.
(L) The building official shall be notified by the applicant of the date and time at which the backfilling will begin. No backfillings will be performed unless the
building official or any appointed inspector is present. All inspection cost shall be borne by the applicant and shall be based on a schedule of charges
on file in the office of the building official.
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 129/283
(M) Upon completion of all work accomplished under the provisions of the permit, the applicant shall notify the building official. The applicant, in accepting
and acting under a street opening permit granted under the provisions of this section, agrees to assume full responsibility for injury to persons or losses
or damage to property incurred by reason of or arising out of any act or omission of such permittee in making such excavation, cut or opening or in
failing to properly barricade, guard and warn the public of such excavation or trench, and further agrees to assume full responsibility for injury to
persons or losses or damage to property incurred by reason of or arising out of any settlement of a restored area occurring within two (2) years of the
date of completion of the permanent resurfacing.
(N) If any settlement in a restored area occurs within two (2) years of the date of completion of the permanent surfacing, it shall be considered as
conclusive evidence of defective backfill. Upon failure or refusal of such building official to do so, any expense incurred by the city in correcting such
settlement shall be paid by the permittee. (Ord. 1469, 12-15-1980)
9-5-10: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Violation of this chapter shall be deemed a misdemeanor and any person violating the provisions of this chapter may be fined an amount not exceeding
five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment not to exceed six (6) months for any one offense. (Ord. 1469, 12-15-1980)
Chapter 6
LEWISTOWN FLOOD PROJECT RESERVOIR REGULATIONS
9-6-1: FLOOD PROJECT RESERVOIR REGULATIONS:
(A) The following rules and regulations have been devised in the interest of safety and the protection of property, for public health, and as a measure to
achieve the fullest possible recreational use of the Lewistown flood project reservoirs. These regulations apply to the water surface of the reservoirs
and to those portions of the surrounding lands which have been specifically reserved for recreational use. These rules and regulations shall apply to
Hanson Creek Dam as well as East Fork Dam, unless otherwise provided.
1. Dock, Pier, Boathouse, Mooring Permit: No boathouse or landing float, pier, or other docking or mooring device shall be installed without a written
permit issued by the Montana department of fish and game and the city of Lewistown.
2. Safety Equipment Requirements: Each craft must be provided with the following:
(a) Paddle or oars.
(b) Efficient life preservers equal in number to the number of persons being carried.
(c) Metal boats of any type must have sufficient air chambers, tanks, or flotation gear to provide the necessary buoyancy to support the boat and its
rated number of passengers in case of accident or other emergency.
3. General Rules:
(a) No boat shall approach the face of the dam nearer than a straight line which would extend from the point where the high water intersects each
end of the dam, such area to be marked with buoys.
Further instructions may be designed when necessary.
(b) All boats must be operated in such a manner as not to endanger the lives or property of other persons or to inconvenience the occupants of other
boats.
(c) Boats may be operated only from daylight to dark.
(d) No boats for hire shall be allowed on the reservoir.
4. Safety Rules And Procedures:
(a) The number of people riding in a boat shall not exceed its rated capacity.
(b) Boats which, in the opinion of the representatives of the Montana fish and game commission, whose opinion shall be final, are not properly
constructed, operated or maintained, will not be permitted to be placed upon or remain on the waters of the reservoirs.
(c) All boats shall be securely anchored or tied when not in use. Boats found floating loose on the reservoir may be taken up and the owner or user
shall be liable to the city of Lewistown or Montana fish and game commission for any expense incurred in making the boat secure.
(d) Boat regattas and racing are prohibited on the reservoirs.
(e) The operation of motor propelled boats on East Fork Dam shall be limited to a controlled no wake speed. "No wake speed" is defined as a speed
whereby there is no "white" water in the track or path of the vessel or in created waves immediate to the vessel.
(f) Only manually operated boats and electrically operated boats will be allowed on Hanson Creek Dam during daylight hours.
(g) Any person violating any of the foregoing regulations may be ordered to remove his personal property from the reservoir and adjacent lands
controlled by the city of Lewistown. In addition he shall pay penalties as may be provided by law for such infraction of the rules.
5. Restricted Waters: The city of Lewistown or the Montana department of fish and game may exclude public use or trespass of any kind within
designated areas when such action is necessary to protect life, property or public health. Such areas shall be posted sufficiently to inform the public.
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 130/283
6. Swimming: Swimming and wading are permitted in the East Fork Dam Reservoir, at designated areas and at designated times. Swimming and
wading are not permitted on Hanson Creek Dam.
7. Picnicking: Picnicking is permitted only in the areas designated for such use. Outside fires may be kindled only in the fire grates provided. The area
must be cleaned by picnickers after use.
8. Hunting And Fishing: Hunting of migratory waterfowl only is permitted on East Fork Dam. Fishing is permitted upon both dams upon compliance with
the laws, rules and regulations prescribed by the state of Montana, but are subject to such additional regulations as may be issued by the city of
Lewistown in order to protect the reservoirs or other features. No hunting shall be allowed on Hanson Creek Dam. Also, no hunting shall be allowed
in East Fork Dam where it creates a safety hazard in regard to the lives or property of recreational area visitors nor shall hunting or fishing be allowed
in an area close to the dams which shall be designated.
9. Ice Fishing: Any person who has placed or causes to be placed an ice fishing shelter on the surface of East Fork Dam or Hanson Creek Dam or any
person who shall use the same shall be governed by the following rules:
(a) An ice fishing shelter shall be any form of hut or shelter constructed of canvas, cardboard, paper, plastic, poles or boards, sheet metal, pressed
wood or any other material, except those shelters or windbreaks constructed of snow or ice only.
(b) Each shelter must be marked with name and address of owner, painted or otherwise permanently affixed to shelter in legible letters not less than
two inches (2") in height and plainly visible from outside of shelter.
(c) Each shelter of closed type construction shall have a door readily opened from the outside for inspection by any officer, while the shelter is
occupied.
(d) No person shall occupy or use or fish from inside an ice shelter if such shelter does not have the name and address of the owner thereon, as
required by these regulations.
(e) Ice fishing shelters in their entirety shall be removed from the area each day.
(f) No person shall fish through a hole in the ice which has been cut larger than ten inches (10") in diameter.
If a fisherman desires a larger hole, it must be protected by an ice fishing shelter and when said ice fishing shelter is removed, the hole must be
clearly marked with a wooden marker at least eighteen inches (18") high.
(g) It shall be the responsibility of the owners and users of each ice shelter to keep the immediate area free from rubbish or debris. All litter and
rubbish shall be gathered by each ice fisherman and either deposited in designated containers or taken with the ice fisherman daily when he
leaves the area.
(h) It shall be prohibited for any person to throw or deposit in the waters of East Fork Dam or Hanson Creek Dam, or place the same on the ice
covering said waters, any rubbish, garbage or any substance likely to injure any person or to cause an unsightly or unsanitary condition either in or
upon said water, or shoreline adjacent thereto.
(i) No cars or trucks or other motor vehicles are permitted on the ice at any time.
10. Snowmobiling: The operation of snowmobiles will be permitted only on the ice on East Fork Dam and Hanson Creek Dam. Such operation may
only be made from November 1 through March 31, weather permitting. Snowmobiles shall not be operated on any area other than upon the ice of
East Fork Dam recreation area. At any time that the city of Lewistown or the state fish and game commission believes there to be a danger with
regard to the operation of snowmobiles upon the ice the same may be closed during the period of such danger. Notice of such closure will be made
through the local news media in the city of Lewistown, Montana.
11. Firearms: The carrying of firearms is prohibited on the reservoirs except when and where hunting is allowed in connection with subsection (A)8 of
this section.
12. Motor Vehicles: The driving of any motor vehicle, ATV or motorbike, except over regular roads or other places indicated for their use, is prohibited.
All such motor vehicles shall be operated only by licensed drivers. All trailers, motor homes, campers, motorcycles, ATVs or other vehicles shall be
properly registered, licensed and insured.
13. Sanitation: Refuse, garbage, rubbish or waste of any kind shall not be thrown into the reservoirs or on any portion of the lands within the
recreational area, but such shall be taken up and removed by the person or persons creating the same. Private water closets, lavatories, sinks,
drains or other devices for discharging waste, shall not be installed in any manner within the recreational area.
14. Fires:
(a) Fires shall be lighted only in designated places.
(b) No lighted cigarette, cigar, pipe heel, match or other burning material, shall be thrown into any grass, leaves, tree mold, or other combustible or
inflammable material.
(c) Use of fireworks, firecrackers or explosives is prohibited.
15. Camping: Overnight camping shall be allowed only on East Fork Dam in the designated areas of the land adjacent to the reservoir. Overnight
camping is limited to fourteen (14) consecutive days in the area. No vehicle, camper, motor home, tent or campsite may be left unattended for more
than twenty four (24) hours. Vehicles or campsites in violation of this requirement shall be towed or removed from the property at the owner's
expense. No overnight camping shall be allowed on any of the land adjacent to Hanson Creek Dam.
Campers at East Fork Dam shall keep their campground clean and free of all combustible materials and rubbish. All garbage and refuse shall be
placed in receptacles provided for that purpose.
All campers at East Fork Dam shall pay a fee for the use of any campsite as determined by resolution of the city commission. Such fee shall be paid
for each twenty four (24) hour period, or part thereof, per campsite, wherein the campsite is used. Such fee shall be deposited or paid in accordance
with posted regulations in advance of the intended use.
16. Preservation Of Public Property And Natural Features: The destruction, injury, defacement, removal or disturbance of any public building, sign,
equipment, marker, or other structure, or of any tree, flower, vegetation, rock, mineral formation, or of any ruins or relic, or any other public property
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 131/283
of any kind is prohibited.
17. Construction Of Facilities And Changing Reservoir Shoreline: The installation or construction of any facility on lands adjacent to the reservoir or any
change in the shoreline is prohibited unless approval has been given by the city of Lewistown of plans for such installation, construction or change
required or requested.
18. Private Notices And Advertisements: Private notices and advertisements shall not be posted, displayed or distributed on the reservoir.
19. Order: No person who is under the influence of intoxicating liquor or narcotic drugs shall be permitted upon the lands adjacent to the reservoir, or in
the water, or in a boat upon the waters of the reservoirs.
20. Disorderly Conduct: Persons who render themselves obnoxious by disorderly conduct or by bad behavior shall be removed from the lands adjacent
to the reservoirs. Quiet hours shall be observed between twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight and seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. each day.
21. Waiver Of Liability: The main purpose of the reservoirs is to impound the waters for flood control and for recreation. Accordingly, any person at any
time going in or upon the lands or waters thereof, whether as a visitor, hunter or fisherman, shall assume all risks arising or resulting in injury or
death to himself or damage to or destruction of property, resulting directly or indirectly, wholly or in part, and from use of said reservoirs and lands or
appurtenant structures, or their construction, operation and control by the city of Lewistown or by the Montana fish and game commission or by
Fergus County.
22. Private And Commercial Uses: No person, firm or corporation, or their representatives, shall engage or solicit any business within the city owned
lands of the reservoirs.
23. Discrimination In Public Use: The administrators of public accommodations within the areas are prohibited from:
(a) Publicizing such facilities in any manner that would directly or inferentially reflect upon or question the acceptability of the patronage of any
person or persons because of race, creed, color or national origin; and
(b) Discriminating against any person or persons because of race, creed, color or national origin by refusing such person or persons any use of
facilities or privileges, which are offered to or enjoyed by the general public.
24. Animals: Except for organized animal sporting events approved in advance by the city or for use with permitted hunting purposes, all dogs or other
animals shall be securely restrained by a leash or kept within a kennel at all times. All animals shall be properly vaccinated for rabies. Vicious, unruly
or nuisance animals are prohibited. All animal waste shall be picked up and removed from the campground.
(B) Any person or persons found guilty of violating any of the orders, rules or regulations herein prescribed shall upon conviction be punished by a fine of
not less than seventy five dollars ($75.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment in the county jail for a period not to exceed six
(6) months, or both such fine and imprisonment. Each twenty four (24) hour period wherein the violation exists shall constitute a separate violation for
purposes of this penalty. (Ord. 1705, 7-18-2005)
Chapter 7
CEMETERY REGULATIONS
9-7-1: SALE OF CEMETERY PLOTS:
The following procedures shall be followed by the city in any future sale of cemetery plots in the Lewistown cemetery: (Ord. 1418, 7-18-1977)
(A) All deeds issued by the city will contain the following restrictive covenant:
This deed is not transferable by said grantee to any third party or parties and can only be transferred by said grantee back to the City of Lewistown.
The City will accept conveyance of the plot herein described but will only reimburse the seller sixty percent (60%) of the current selling price of
comparable plots, for said plot, regardless of the price assessed by said City on plots at the time the same be reconveyed.
(Ord. 1583, 5-7-1990)
(B) The only party entitled to convey or contract for burial sites will be the city. (Ord. 1418, 7-18-1977)
9-7-2: PAYMENT OF COSTS:
The following procedures shall be followed by the city for opening and closing of gravesites and for payment of the purchase price of cemetery lots and the
costs of opening and closing of the gravesites:
(A) The city shall be the sole party authorized to open and close gravesites and set headstones within the Lewistown city cemetery. (Ord. 1686, 11-5-2001)
(B) All arrangements for the purchase or selection of cemetery lots, and all arrangements for the scheduling and payment of gravesite opening and
closing, shall be made directly with the city clerk's office. The foregoing shall not prevent funeral establishments from showing vacant lots to their
clients, however, such establishments shall have no authority to bind or otherwise commit the city to the sale or transfer of any vacant cemetery lot.
(C) The full purchase price of any cemetery lot, and the full cost of opening and closing of gravesites shall be due and payable prior to occupancy of such
lot. However, in cases where the city can be assured of prompt and full payment, either by assumption of payment responsibility by other persons or by
a funeral establishment, or by other such assurances, the city may extend the due date of the full cost of lots and opening and closing costs to ninety
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 132/283
(90) days after occupancy. In such cases, if full payment is not received within the time specified, the city shall seek collection by any method
authorized by law. Such amount shall accumulate interest from the date due at the maximum rate authorized by law. Any person responsible for such
delinquency shall not be authorized to make arrangements for purchase of any other cemetery lot or arrangements for payment of any other opening
and closing.
Notwithstanding the foregoing, in exceptional cases due to hardship, the city may enter into an installment payment agreement with any person for any
term, upon such conditions as may be agreeable.
Notwithstanding the foregoing, any person may contract to purchase a cemetery lot over time when such lot is not to be immediately occupied. In such
situations a written agreement shall be executed specifying the terms of payment. Such agreement shall include a provision for accelerated payment
when the lot is to be occupied prior to full payment by installment. The installment agreement provided for in this agreement may include payment of
opening and closing costs, however, such amount shall be finally fixed at the time of occupancy. (Ord. 1558, 3-2-1987)
9-7-3: BURIAL REGULATIONS:
The following rules and regulations shall apply to the regular operation of said cemetery: (Ord. 1418, 7-18-1977)
(A) Funerals may be held Monday through Saturday. Funerals may be held on Sunday or legal holidays only on an emergency basis to be determined by
the city manager or public works director. (Ord. 1686, 11-5-2001)
(B) The sellers of vaults are hereby charged with the duty of installing the same.
(C) Should any equipment be used in the cemetery which is not owned by the city, the same must comply with occupational safety and health act (OSHA)
safety regulations and codes.
(D) Any person, other than the city employees, performing work in the city cemetery shall carry minimum liability, medical and death insurance and shall
hold the city harmless for any and all damages which may arise from their presence or work in said cemetery.
(E) Any flowers which are placed on or near graves shall be in such a manner as not to interfere with the maintenance and operation of the cemetery. If
said flowers are found to interfere they will be removed by city employees. Should any question arise concerning the installation of any type of flowers,
the cemetery employees shall determine the issue.
(F) Any flowers that are placed at or near graves, during Memorial Day weekend, shall be removed not later than seven (7) days after Memorial Day.
Failure to remove said flowers will require the city employees to remove and dispose of same.
(G) No vehicles will be allowed off of existing roads except under the direction of the caretaker.
(H) All tombstones shall be displayed in rows and no footstones shall be installed unless they are at ground level. There shall be only one body placed in a
grave except in the case of an infant being buried with his mother. (Ord. 1418, 7-18-1977)
(I) An outside enclosure or vault liner shall be required for all caskets, urns or other containers used for the interment of a body. The construction of the
outside enclosure or vault liner shall be of materials that will not deteriorate in the future and thus allow the grave area to settle and cause a
depression. Urns for cremains made out of materials that will not deteriorate shall not be required to have an outside enclosure or vault liner.
(J) The following fees shall be charged for the purchase of cemetery lots and for the opening and closing of graves:

9-7-4: PERPETUAL CARE AND MAINTENANCE FUND:
There is established within the city a cemetery permanent care and maintenance fund (the fund) to assist in the future care and maintenance of the
Lewistown city cemetery.
(A) All proceeds from the sale of any lots in the city cemetery shall be set aside at the rate of forty percent (40%) of the monies received into the fund.
(B) All monies set aside into the fund shall be maintained in a nonexpendable trust fund within the city and invested in a manner prescribed by law for
cities and towns.
(C) The principal of the fund may not be used. The interest earned from the investment of any monies in the fund may be used for the care and
maintenance of the Lewistown cemetery. Any interest earned within a fiscal year but not used for care and maintenance shall be added to and become
part of the principal of the fund. (Ord. 1703, 5-2-2005)
9-7-5: GRANITE MARKERS REQUIRED:
All monuments, markers, or headstones set in the Lewistown cemetery shall be of natural granite, or in case of a duplicate resulting from previous
purchase, marble may be used. (Ord. 1686, 11-5-2001)
9-7-6: INSTALLATION REQUIREMENTS:
All monuments, markers or headstones in the Lewistown cemetery shall be erected or installed by the city in a manner as directed by the cemetery
caretaker and public works director. (Ord. 1686, 11-5-2001)
