Chapter 8
CURB CUTS
9-8-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to standardize, regulate and control the location, size, type, construction, maintenance and quality of curb cuts, driveway
aprons and sidewalk driveway crossings in the city from the standpoint of proper design, safe and efficient entry to and exit from city streets to private
property, safety of vehicular traffic in the streets and safety of pedestrian traffic on the sidewalk area. (Ord. 1457, 7-7-1980)
9-8-2: PERMIT REQUIRED:
It is unlawful for any person either as owner, agent, contractor or employee to cut, break, remove, alter or install any curbing, driveway apron or sidewalk,
or cause to have cut, broken or removed, any curbing, driveway apron or sidewalk, or to install or cause to have installed any driveway, or any vehicular
access on any public right of way in the city without a permit. Permits shall be issued only to properly licensed contractors or to persons for their own
residence by the building official after payment of fees as provided in section 9-8-4 of this chapter.
At the time the permit application is made, the building official shall be advised of any parking meters, traffic or street signs, signal poles, streetlight poles,
fire plugs, trees or obstructions that will be affected by the placement or removal of the driveway or sidewalk. (Ord. 1457, 7-7-1980)
9-8-3: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT:
All applications for curb cuts shall give a description of the property to be served and such other information as may be required by the building official, for
the proper direction of the work and must be signed by the owner or his authorized agent.
Before commencing the construction, modification or repair of any curb cut, the contractor shall first obtain a written permit from the building official, and
such permit shall be upon the grounds at all times during the progress of the work and must be shown to any office in authority, on demand. (Ord. 1457, 7-
7-1980)
9-8-4: PERMIT FEE:
All applications submitted under provisions of this chapter shall be accompanied by a permit fee computed at the rate of twenty cents ($0.20) per one foot
(1') of driveway applied for, payable to the city to help defray costs of inspection of site and engineering costs. (Ord. 1457, 7-7-1980)
9-8-5: INSPECTOR FURNISHED BY CITY; NOTIFICATION REQUIRED:
The building official shall furnish an inspector to inspect every piece of curb, driveway and driveway apron to be constructed, whose duties shall be to
check the forms for alignment, grade and materials, and to see that work is done in accordance with the specifications of the city at the time of the
issuance of the permit.
The building official shall be notified at least twenty four (24) hours in advance of the time when the work is proposed to be started. (Ord. 1457, 7-7-1980)
9-8-6: DRIVEWAY WIDTH LIMITATIONS:
(A) Driveway width, as measured parallel with the edge of the traveled way, shall not exceed twenty feet (20') in residential areas nor thirty feet (30') in
commercial or industrial areas, except driveway widths for service stations and trucking businesses may be up to forty feet (40') when approved by the
building official, and shall be located in accordance with city specifications for driveways.
(B) The minimum distance between curb cuts shall be twenty five feet (25').
(C) Frontages of fifty feet (50') or less shall be limited to one driveway. Not more than two (2) driveways shall be provided to any single property tract or
business establishment, except where the property frontage exceeds six hundred feet (600') there may be one additional driveway for each additional
three hundred feet (300') of frontage. (Ord. 1457, 7-7-1980)
9-8-7: CONSTRUCTION, SPECIFICATIONS AND REGULATIONS:
Every curb cut and driveway apron constructed or altered in the street right of way shall conform to the following regulations:
(A) No driveway apron shall be constructed closer than five feet (5') to, nor shall it be so located as to interfere with intersecting sidewalks, utility facilities,
light standards, fire hydrants, catch basins, street signs, signals or other public improvements or installations.
(B) At an intersecting street or highway, the dimension measured parallel to the edge of the traveled way to provide adequate corner clearance shall be a
minimum distance of fifteen feet (15') from the intersecting property line.
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 135/283
(C) No curb cut or driveway apron shall be located so as to create a hazard to pedestrians or motorists, or to invite or compel illegal or unsafe traffic
movements.
(D) In any commercial or industrial zone, driveways shall be designed such that vehicles entering or egressing shall not be required to back from or into a
street right of way.
(E) Radii shall be three feet (3') for residential uses and five feet (5') for commercial or industrial uses.
(F) All parts of driveway aprons, including radii, shall be confined within the frontage for which the permit is issued.
(G) All driveways shall be so constructed so as not to impair drainage within the street or highway right of way nor alter the stability of the roadway
subgrade and at the same time not impair or materially alter drainage of the adjacent areas. All drainage structures required within the public right of
way and under the driveways as a result of the property being developed shall be installed in accordance with the standards of the city.
(H) The angle between any driveway apron and the street and/or curb line shall be ninety degrees (90) to the street tangent or on a radial line to the
street curve.
(I) All curb cuts and driveway aprons are to be constructed of Portland cement concrete of a quality and type as specified by the building official, and in
accordance with city specifications in effect at the time of such work.
(J) All work shall be done under the supervision of the building official, and in accordance with city specifications in effect at the time of such work.
(K) The licensed contractor or his agent doing the construction or alteration work shall maintain the premises in a safe manner and shall provide adequate
barricades and lights at his own expense to protect the safety of the public using the adjacent streets or sidewalks, and shall hold the city free from any
damages incurred by his operation.
(L) Any curb cut or driveway apron which has become abandoned or used through a change of the conditions for which it was originally intended shall be
closed and the owner shall replace any such curb cut and/or driveway apron with a standard curb and sidewalk to be constructed according to city
specifications in effect at the time of such work. In the event the owner does not make such replacement within sixty (60) days after written notice, the
city may do so at the expense of the owner.
(M) Specific controls not defined in this chapter shall be in accordance with the standards for private driveway regulations established by the American
Association of State Highway Officials and as applied by the discretion of the building official. (Ord. 1457, 7-7-1980)
9-8-8: DEVIATION FROM REQUIREMENTS:
Permission to deviate from the requirements and regulations of this chapter shall be granted by the city commission only where unusual conditions or strict
adherence to this chapter would cause undue and extreme hardships. (Ord. 1457, 7-7-1980; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
9-8-9: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Violation of this chapter shall be deemed a misdemeanor and any person violating the provisions of this chapter may be fined in an amount not exceeding
five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment not to exceed six (6) months for any one offense. (Ord. 1457, 7-7-1980)
Chapter 9
DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS
9-9-1: DEFINITIONS AND TERMS:
Terminology used within these standard specifications shall be as defined below or as defined in this code. Terminology not specifically defined will be as
defined by general use of the term within the particular area of the industry to which it refers. Terminology that is ambiguous or insufficiently defined will be
defined by the city attorney.
AASHTO: The American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials, and publications prepared by this association. Also known as AASHO.
ASTM: American Society for Testing and Materials and publications of this society.
AWWA: American Water Works Association and publications of this association.
ACCEPTANCE: Acceptance of plans, specifications, final construction, etc., shall be by motion, ordinance, resolution or other action expressed in writing
and signed by the authorized representative of the city.
APPROVAL: Approval or final approval shall mean the approval by motion, ordinance or resolution and indicated in writing, signed by the authorized
representative of the city.
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 136/283
CERTIFICATION: Certification of construction tests, materials, design, etc., shall mean that a duly licensed laboratory or person shall state in writing that
the test results, materials, design, etc., conforms to the requirements of the standard specifications of the city.
CITY: The city of Lewistown, Montana.
CITY COMMISSION OR COMMISSION: The city commission of the city of Lewistown, Montana.
CITY ENGINEER: The city engineer of the city of Lewistown or their consulting engineer.
CITY SUPERINTENDENT: The superintendent of any of the city departments including, but not limited to, the water, sewer and street departments.
EASEMENT: The right to use land, other than as a tenant, for a specific purpose; such right being held by someone other than the person who holds title
to the land.
ENGINEER (Registered Professional Engineer): A person licensed in conformance with the Montana professional engineers' registration act (sections 66-
2301 through 66-2347) to practice engineering in the state of Montana.
OWNER: In this section and sections 9-9-2 through 9-9-4 of this chapter, the owner of the land, subdivision or development area which is to be developed.
In section 9-9-5 of this chapter (and also the appendix) the owner is the city of Lewistown.
PROJECT: Any development or portion of a development such as, but not limited to, water systems, sewer systems, storm drain systems, streets,
sidewalks, curbs and gutters, etc., that is or will become public domain.
PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS: Any structure or facility constructed to serve the residents of a subdivision or the general public such as parks, streets or
roads, sidewalks, curbs and gutters, street lighting and water supply, sewage disposal, drainage or utility systems.
RIGHT OF WAY: A strip or parcel of land dedicated or acquired for use as a public way.
SANITARY SEWER SYSTEM: Any portion of the city sewer system including collection lines, trunk lines, lift stations, force mains and treatment facilities.
STATE: The state of Montana.
STORM DRAIN SYSTEM: Any system for the conveyance, transmission, management or dissipation of storm waters which might be constructed in or on
public lands or dedicated city streets, rights of way or easements.
STREET: Any street, highway, sidewalk, alley, avenue or other public way or public grounds in the city.
SUBDIVIDER: Any person, firm, corporation or other entity who causes land to be subdivided, or who proposes a subdivision of land.
WATER SYSTEM: Any portion of the water system of the city including supply, storage, transmission and distribution lines which are generally for the use
of the public. Individual service lines from the curb stop to the service taps are not included in the definition. (Ord. 1470, 12-15-1980; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-
2000)
9-9-2: NOTICES, FEES, PERMITS, BONDS AND GUARANTEES:
(A) General: All construction projects shall comply with the following requirements for notices, fees, permits, bonds and guarantees.
(B) Notices: Any construction on city right of way, city property or city easements that will disrupt normal operation of city owned public utilities, including
sewer, water and transportation facilities, will require notification in writing of each resident to be affected at least twenty four (24) hours before
construction is to begin. Disruptions that are expected to affect the general public or a substantial portion of the city shall be publicly announced in the
local news media at least twenty four (24) hours before the disruption is expected to occur. The notification must include the nature and estimated
duration of the expected disruption of service. Disruptions of service for water and sewer in excess of four (4) hours duration shall provide alternate
means of providing the affected services.
Existing city codes regarding notices shall remain in effect and requirements of said codes shall not be diminished by these provisions.
(C) Fees:
1. Fees For Review Of Plans And Inspection Of Construction: The owner of projects being developed for subdivision within the city or annexation to the
city shall pay appropriate fees for review of design and construction plans and for construction inspection of the improvements.
Fees shall be based on actual time spent in meeting with the owner, his representatives, affected government agencies, time spent in actual review
of plans and specifications, and time spent on construction inspection and testing on the project. Hourly rates shall be in accordance with the
following schedule which is subject to revision on an annual basis:
Registered professional engineer $24.00/hour
Assistant engineer 21.00/hour
Engineering technician 19.00/hour
Draftsman 15.00/hour
3 man survey crew 42.00/hour
2 man survey crew 32.00/hour
Stenographer 9.00/hour
Mileage will be charged at $0.25 per mile. Printing and other incidental costs will be billed at the cost incurred by the city.
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 137/283
(a) Deposit: A deposit to cover a portion of the anticipated costs of review and inspection shall be made by the owner of the project prior to initiation
of review of plans and specifications. The deposit shall be in lawful money of the United States, or a cashier's check, certified check, bank money
order or bank draft, in any case drawn and issued by a national banking association located in the state of Montana.
The amount of the deposit shall be determined by the city engineer, and generally shall be in the amount of one percent (1%) of the estimated
construction costs of the proposed improvements, but in no case shall the deposit be less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00).
(b) Payments: Payment for engineering review and construction inspection performed by the city or its representatives shall be due monthly within
thirty (30) days of issuance of a statement by the city to the owner. Failure to make payment for the services within the allotted time will result in
charging the amount of the statement against the deposit made by the owner. Should the amount of the balance of the deposit drop below the
estimated monthly charge for engineering review and inspection services, the city will discontinue review and inspection until such time that
payment is made. Final acceptance of any project will not be made by the city without engineering review and construction inspection.
The balance of any deposit made with the city for the purposes discussed above will be returned to the owner within thirty (30) days of issuance of
final written approval of construction of the project by the city.
2. Sewer Service Connection Fee: A fee shall be paid to the city for connection of each sewer service line to the collection system. The sewer service
fee shall be in accordance with title 4, chapter 6 of this code.
3. Street Excavations: Requirements and fees for street excavations are designated in chapter 5 of this title.
(D) Permits:
1. Water Permits: A permit for a service connection shall be acquired for any water service connection prior to beginning construction permits are
available through the office of the city engineer.
2. Sewer Permit: A permit for a service connection shall be acquired for any sewer service connection prior to beginning construction. Permits are
available through the office of the city engineer.
(E) Bonds: Application for permit for construction of improvements on public right of way or easements or lands intended for such use shall file bonds with
the city prior to commencing work in accordance with chapter 5 of this title.
Other bonding requirements as may be required by this code shall remain in effect.
(F) Guarantees: All public works projects shall provide guarantees as provided for under the following requirements: (Ord. 1470, 12-15-1980)
1. Guarantee Of Public Improvements: As a condition for granting approval of the final plans, the owner shall provide a public improvements agreement
guaranteeing the construction and installation of all required improvements within two (2) years after final approval of the final plans. Such guarantee
may include one or more such as, but not limited to, special improvement district (SID), performance or property bonds, private or public escrow
agreements, deposits of certified funds, or other similar surety agreements as may be required by the city commission.
As improvements are completed, the owner may apply to the city commission for a release of part or all of the collateral deposited with the city. Upon
inspection and approval, the city commission may release said collateral. If the city commission determines that any of such improvements are not
constructed in substantial compliance with specifications, it shall furnish the owner a list of specified deficiencies and shall be entitled to withhold
collateral sufficient to ensure such substantial compliance. If the city commission determines that the owner will not construct any or all the
improvements in accordance with all of the specifications, the city may withdraw and employ from the deposit of collateral such fines as may be
necessary to construct the improvements in accordance with the specifications. (Ord. 1470, 12-15-1980; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
2. Guarantee For Equipment, Materials And Workmanship: The owner shall guarantee all materials and equipment furnished and work performed for a
period of one year from the date of written acceptance of the work by the city engineer.
The guarantee for public improvements shall remain in full force and effect during the guarantee period.
The owner shall require that the respective manufacturer and equipment supplier guarantee the equipment furnished for a period of one year from
the date of written acceptance of the work by the city. Furthermore, the owner shall require that the manufacturer and equipment supplier agree in
writing that he will be responsible for the proper functioning of the equipment in cooperation with the city, and that, whenever necessary during the
installation period or tuning up period following the construction period, the manufacturer and supplier will supply, without additional cost to the city,
such superintendence and mechanical labor and any adjustments and additional parts and labor needed to make the equipment function
satisfactorily. (Ord. 1470, 12-15-1980)
9-9-3: DESIGN AND INSPECTION REQUIREMENTS:
(A) General: All projects involving the construction of systems or structures that will eventually be for the use of the public or projects located within city
property, right of way or easements shall be designed by a registered professional engineer. (Ref. Revised Codes of Montana 66-2349 registration
required.)
All plans shall be submitted to the city engineer for review and approval and shall bear the seal and signature of the design engineer. Plans not bearing
a seal and signature will not be reviewed or approved. (Ref. Revised Codes of Montana 66-2363 public works.)
Projects that are located outside of the city limits which are being planned for annexation shall be designed and constructed in accordance with the city
standards. Conformance with design and construction standards shall be a prerequisite to annexation.
Construction permits for excavation within streets, permits for water or sewer connections, or building construction permits will not be issued by the city
until the plans for public improvements associated with the subdivision or annexation are formally approved by the city or its designated representative.
All plans shall provide a block in the lower right hand corner for the purpose of noting the date of approval of the plans by the city and for the signature
of the city engineer.
Further design requirements for various types of work are specified below.
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 138/283
1. Water Systems: Water systems shall be designed in accordance with city standard specifications and drawings, Montana department of health and
environmental science requirements, requirements of the American Water Works Association and requirements of the insurance services offices of
Montana.
Approval of water system design will not be made without written approval of the design by the state department of health and environmental
sciences.
Written notice that the city will provide water and/or sewer service to any particular parcel of land does not relieve the owner of the land of the
obligation to fulfill the engineering requirements as discussed herein.
2. Sewer Systems: Sewer systems shall be designed in accordance with city standard specifications and drawings, Montana department of health and
environmental sciences requirements and the most current edition of "Recommended Standards For Sewage Works" as prepared by the Great
Lakes-Upper Mississippi River board of state sanitary engineers (ten state standards).
Final approval of sewer system design will not be made without written approval of the design by the state department of health and environmental
sciences.
3. Streets: Design of asphaltic pavement streets shall be in accordance with city standard specifications and drawings, and in accordance with design
procedures in the "Soils Manual For Design Of Asphalt Pavement Structures" and "The Asphalt Handbook" by the Asphalt Institute.
Soils survey and soils testing of the street subsurface conditions shall be performed by a registered professional engineer or a licensed testing
laboratory. Proposed pavement designs shall be submitted to the city for review and approval. The proposed pavement design shall include the soils
survey and test data, proposed traffic design flows, calculations made to determine proposed paving depth, a drawing of the proposed typical
pavement cross section, and specifications for materials to be used in construction.
Soils surveys shall use the AASHTO classification system. Subgrade support values shall be based on the California bearing ratio (CBR).
Street pavement designs shall be submitted to the city engineer for review and approval. Design calculations shall accompany the submittal and
request for pavement design approval. Soils test information shall be prepared by a registered professional engineer qualified in performing soils
tests or by a certified soils testing laboratory. Soils tests shall be made to determine the California bearing ratio for all types of soils encountered
within the project area. A soils survey shall be made to determine soils conditions to a depth of five feet (5') at intervals not less than one test hole for
every five hundred feet (500') of roadway. Logs of the test holes shall note as a minimum: soils type as determined by the AASHTO soils
classification system; moisture content; in-place density; and maximum dry density as determined by AASHTO T 180, method A or C.
Traffic design numbers may be estimated according to intended street use. Street dimensions shall meet or exceed the following requirements and
shall conform to the subdivision regulations in force at the time the project is submitted for approval by the city engineer:
Local
Access
Street
Residential
Through
Street

Road right of way width (feet) 60 60 80
Pavement width-face to face of curb 36 40 40-54
Curb type1 V/R V/R V/R

Minimum curb radius 15 feet 15 feet 15 feet
Minimum centerline curve radius 175 feet 175 feet 175 feet
Maximum grade 2 8 percent 8 percent 8 percent
Crown (cross slope) .02 - .06 .02 - .06 .02 - .06
Maximum cul-de-sac length 500 feet 500 feet 500 feet
Minimum paved cul-de-sac diameter 40 feet 40 feet 40 feet
1. Curb type to be approved by city, vertical or roll type.
2. Short lengths of roadway may be approved with steeper grades.
(a) Plans, specifications, test results and calculations submitted to the city engineer for review and approval shall include, but not necessarily be
limited to, the following:
(1) Soils survey data, including AASHTO classification, soils profile, Atterberg limits, in place moisture, moisture density relationship curves for
each type of soil, CSR, and a map showing location of soils sample sites.
(2) Detailed typical design pavement section, design calculations, specifications on materials to be used and plant mix design.
(3) Plan and profile drawings showing existing ground line, location and horizontal alignment of the street, vertical alignment of existing and
finished grade, existing and proposed public utilities in the street construction area. Any other existing or proposed features that may affect
street design shall also be shown on the drawings.
Three (3) sets of the above submittals will be required. One set will be returned to the owner with comments or approval upon completion of
review.
4. Storm Drain Systems: Storm drain or management systems shall be designed by a registered professional engineer and in accordance with city
standard specifications and drawings. The design of the storm drain or storm water management system shall be in accordance with generally
acceptable engineering practices. Design criteria shall be in accordance with the following unless alternate methods are approved in writing by the
city.
(a) Storm frequency will be such that flood damage to private or public property is not expected to occur on less than a twenty five (25) year interval.
Curbs and gutters, pipe sizes, inlets and retention basins shall be capable of handling a storm with a reoccurrence interval of two (2) years, without
overflowing.
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 139/283
(b) Storm intensities shall be derived from rainfall curves developed for the central Montana area, available at the city engineer's office.
(c) The rational formula shall be used to determine storm water runoff rates. Other methods will be considered only for extensive areas.
(d) Coefficients of runoff shall be in accordance with generally acceptable, recognized, coefficients developed expressly for use in the rational
formula. Runoff coefficients shall be based on total projected development of the drainage area.
(e) Calculations for runoff, pipe grades, pipe sizes, etc., shall be provided for review of the city engineer.
(f) Storm water runoff calculations shall consider water entering the project from outside sources.
(g) Plans and profile drawings of the proposed system shall be submitted for review. The plan and profile drawings shall show the location of the
project, the grade, size and material of the pipe, existing manmade and natural features within the construction area, existing and proposed utilities
within the project area, and detailed drawings of special construction items. Additional data may be required as determined by the project scope
and location.
Three (3) copies of design calculations, specifications and drawings shall be submitted to the city for review and approval. One copy will be
returned to the owner with comments or approval upon completion of the review.
(B) Construction Inspection And Testing Requirements: Construction inspection and testing shall be provided for all projects intended for conveyance to
the city for maintenance and operation. The fee for construction inspection and testing shall be in accordance with other sections of these
specifications and shall be the responsibility of the owner of the project.
Construction inspection and testing will be required on all public water lines, sewer lines, streets, storm drains, sidewalks, curbs and gutters, and any
other improvements made for the general use of the public.
The owner of the project may provide certification of inspection complete with individual test data in lieu of a portion of the inspection and test
requirements of this specification. Recognition and acceptance of the certification of inspection and test data will not be made by the city unless it is
submitted under the seal and signature of a currently licensed professional engineer or testing laboratory operating in the state of Montana.
The city reserves the right to perform additional inspection and testing on any project to verify compliance with standard specifications whether or not
the project owner provides certification of the inspection and testing.
Construction inspection and testing requirements for various types of work are discussed in more detail below.
1. Water Systems: The owner of the project shall provide manufacturer's shop drawings and certification of conformance of all materials with the
standard specifications. Materials shall include, but not be limited to, pipe, fittings, valves, corporation stops, hydrants, flexible couplings, water
service pipe, curb stops, valve boxes and curb stop boxes. This information shall be provided at least ten (10) days prior to beginning construction.
(a) Material Storage: Material storage sites shall be made available for inspection of materials and shall be inspected by city representatives.
(b) Moisture Density Requirements: Areas requiring backfill compaction shall have moisture density curves prepared for all backfill material. One
moisture density curve shall be prepared in accordance with the standard specifications for each type of material to be used in the backfill.
(c) Density Tests: Compaction density tests shall be taken on each two feet (2') of depth of the trench at intervals not exceeding two hundred feet
(200'). Tests indicating nonacceptable densities shall be repeated until the tests indicate that adequate densities have been attained.
(d) Gradation Test: A gradation test shall be submitted for each different source of materials for items such as pipe bedding, leveling courses,
concrete aggregate, etc.
(e) Pressure Tests: Certification of pressure tests shall be prepared for each length of pipe tested. Data to be included will be a minimum of the
following: date, weather conditions, location of test section of pipe (station to station), length of pipe tested, pipe material, pipe size, number of
couplings tested, time at start of test, time at end of test, pressure or feet of head at start of test, pressure or feet of head at end of test, amount of
water added during test or at end of test to maintain test pressure and how measured, calculated allowable leakage, and actual leakage.
Leakage tests at ties to the existing water system shall be certified in writing as being observed without leakage in accordance with the standard
specifications.
(f) Disinfection Tests: Certification of disinfection tests shall be prepared for each section of line that is disinfected in accordance with the standard
specifications. The certification shall contain as a minimum: the date of disinfection, location of the section disinfected, length of pipe disinfected,
size of pipe disinfected, pipe material, calculated storage capacity of pipe disinfected, type and strength of disinfectant, amount of disinfectant
used, time disinfection period began, time disinfection period ended, time duration of flushing the pipe, test results of at least three (3) chlorine
residual samples taken during the flushing period, test results of at least three (3) chlorine residual samples taken after the flushing period.
(g) Final Inspection: Upon completion of the project all hydrants shall be checked to see that they drain adequately. All valves shall be operated.
Valve boxes shall be checked for final grade, plumbness and debris. This final inspection shall be scheduled with the city engineer at least two (2)
days in advance of the inspection.
(h) Patch Tests: Tests on asphalt patches or other patch material shall conform to requirements for inspecting and testing for streets.
(i) Final Drawings: A set of reproducible tracings shall be prepared showing all changes encountered during construction and detailed dimensions to
all fittings, valves, hydrants, etc., as finally constructed. Actual locations, depths, dimensions and materials of any public utilities encountered
during construction shall also be shown on the drawings. The drawings shall be stamped "Record Drawings" and shall be transmitted to the city for
permanent retention.
(j) Acceptance Of The Project: Upon successful completion of the above inspection, testing and other requirements of the standard specifications
and city codes, the city engineer will issue, in writing, the acceptance of the project. No water valve shall be opened for any use other than
performing the required tests to serve water to the system from the existing city system without written acceptance of the project.
2. Sewer Systems: The owner of the project shall provide manufacturer's shop drawings and certification of conformance of all materials with the
standard specifications. Said shop drawings and certifications shall be provided to the city at least ten (10) days prior to beginning construction.
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 140/283
Materials to be certified shall include, but not necessarily be limited to, sewer pipe, pipe fittings, manholes, concrete for bases, manhole rings and
lids, manhole steps, bedding materials and mechanical equipment.
(a) Material Storage: Material storage sites shall be made available for inspection and shall be inspected by city representatives.
(b) Moisture Density Requirements: Areas requiring backfill compaction shall have moisture density curves prepared for all backfill material. One
moisture density curve shall be prepared in accordance with the standard specifications for each type of material to be used in the backfill.
(c) Density Tests: Compaction density tests shall be taken on each two feet (2') depth of the trench at intervals not exceeding two hundred feet
(200'). Tests indicating nonacceptable densities shall be repeated until the tests indicate that adequate densities have been obtained.
(d) Gradation Tests: A gradation test shall be submitted for each different source of materials for items such as pipe bedding, leveling courses,
concrete aggregate, etc.
(e) Pressure Tests: Certificate of pressure tests shall be prepared for each length of pipe tested. Data to be included will be a minimum of the
following: date, weather conditions, location of test section of pipe (station to station), length of pipe tested, pipe material, pipe size, number of
couplings tested, time at start of test, time at end of test, pressure or feet of head at start of test, pressure or feet of head at end of test, amount of
water added during test or at end of test to maintain test pressure and how measured, calculated allowable leakage and actual leakage.
(f) Final Inspection: Upon completion of the project and prior to putting the system into use, all sewer lines shall be observed by the city engineer for
alignment, grade, cleanliness of the lines and general compliance with the standard specifications. This final inspection of the project shall be
scheduled with the city engineer at least two (2) days in advance of the inspection.
(g) Patch Tests: Tests on asphalt patches or other patch material shall conform to requirements for inspection and testing for streets.
(h) Final Drawings: A set of reproducible tracings shall be prepared showing all changes encountered during construction and detailed dimensions to
all fittings, valves, hydrants, etc., as finally constructed. Actual locations, depths, dimensions and materials of any public utilities encountered
during construction shall also be shown on the drawings. The drawings shall be stamped "Record Drawings" and shall be transmitted to the city
engineer for permanent retention.
(i) Acceptance Of The Project: Upon successful completion of the above inspection, testing and other requirements of the standard specifications
and city codes, the city engineer will issue, in writing, the acceptance of the project. Use of the completed sewer system will not be permitted under
any circumstances other than performing the required tests without said written acceptance of the project. (Ord. 1470, 12-15-1980)
9-9-4: INSURANCE, LEGAL RESPONSIBILITY, PUBLIC CONVENIENCE AND SAFETY:
(A) Insurance: The owner of any development or project shall not commence any work until he obtains, at his own expense, all required insurance. Such
insurance must have the approval of the city attorney as to limit, form and amount.
1. Evidence: As evidence of specified insurance coverage, the city attorney may, in lieu of actual policies, accept certificates issued by the insurance
carrier showing such policies in force for the specified period. Each policy or certificate will bear an endorsement or statement waiving right of
cancellation or reduction in coverage without ten (10) days' notice in writing to be delivered by registered mail to the city.
2. Payment Of Damages: Nothing contained in these insurance requirements is to be construed as limiting the extent of the owner's responsibility for
payment of damages resulting from his operations.
3. Comprehensive General Liability Insurance: Before commencement of any public works project, the owner or his contractor shall submit written
evidence that he and all his subcontractors have obtained for the period of the project, full comprehensive general liability insurance coverage,
including vehicle coverage. This coverage shall provide for both bodily injury and property damage.
(a) Bodily Injury: The bodily injury portion shall include coverage for injury, sickness or disease and death, arising directly or indirectly out of, or in
connection with, the performance of work under any given project and shall provide for a limit of not less than five hundred thousand dollars
($500,000.00) for construction contracts under one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) or one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for construction
contracts over one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for all damages arising out of bodily injury, sickness or disease, and death of one or
more persons in any one occurrence.
(b) Property Damage: The property damage portion will provide for a limit of not less than five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) per
occurrence and one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) aggregate for all damages arising out of injury to or destruction of property of others arising
directly or indirectly out of or in connection with the performance of work under age given project and in any one occurrence including explosion,
collapse and underground exposure.
(c) Vehicle Comprehensive Liability: Including nonownership and hired car coverage as well as owned vehicles shall provide for a limit of not less
than two hundred fifty thousand dollars ($250,000.00) for bodily injury for each person and five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for each
occurrence. Property damage limits shall be one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for each accident.
(d) Indemnity: Included in such insurance will be contractual coverage sufficiently broad to insure the provisions of subsection (A)4 of this section.
4. Indemnity: The owner shall hold harmless, indemnify and defend the city, the city engineer and his consultants, and each of their officers and
employees and agents, from any and all liability claims, losses or damage arising or alleged to arise from the performance of the work described
herein, but not including the sole negligence of the city or its representatives.
(B) Responsibility:
1. Permits: The owner shall procure and pay for all permits, licenses and bonds necessary for the prosecution of this work and/or required for
municipal, state and federal regulations and laws, as pertains particularly to permits for transportation of materials and equipment, blasting or other
operations which are not a specific requirement of these specifications.
(a) Notices, Fees And Compliance With Rules And Regulations: The owner shall give all notices, pay all fees and comply with all federal, state and
municipal laws, ordinances, rules and regulations and building and construction codes bearing on the conduct of the work. All projects shall be
subject to the provisions of all pertinent ordinances of the city.
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 141/283
2. Laws To Be Observed: The contractor shall give all notices and comply with all federal, state and local laws, ordinances and regulations in any
manner affecting the conduct of the work, and all such orders and decrees as exist or may be enacted by bodies or tribunals having any jurisdiction
or authority over the work, and shall indemnify and save harmless the city against any claim or liability arising from, or based on, the violation of any
such law, ordinance, regulation, order or decree whether by himself or his employees.
3. Existing Construction: When new construction is adjacent to or crosses highways, railroads, streets or utilities under the jurisdiction of state, county,
city or other public agency, public utility or private entity, the owner shall secure written permission from the proper authority before executing such
new construction. The owner shall replace or repair all existing construction damaged in the execution of any project. The owner will be required to
furnish a release from the proper authority before final acceptance of the work.
(C) Public Convenience: The owner shall at all times so conduct his work as to ensure the least possible obstruction to traffic and inconvenience to the
general public and the residents in the vicinity of the work, and to ensure the protection of persons and property. No road or street shall be closed to the
public except with permission of the proper authorities. Fire hydrants on or adjacent to the work shall be kept accessible to firefighting equipment at all
times. Temporary provisions shall be made by the owner to ensure the use of sidewalks and the proper function of all gutters, sewer inlets, drainage
ditches and irrigation ditches, which shall not be obstructed.
(D) Safety: In accordance with generally accepted construction practices and the requirement of the occupational safety and health administration
standards, the owner shall be solely and completely responsible for conditions on the job site, including safety of all persons and property affected
directly or indirectly by his operations during the performance of the work. This requirement will apply continuously twenty four (24) hours per day until
acceptance of the work by the city and shall not be limited to normal working hours.
The duty of the city engineer to conduct construction review of the owner's performance is not intended to include review of the adequacy of the
owner's safety measures in, on or near the construction site.
1. Warning Signs And Barricades: The owner shall provide adequate signs, barricades, red lights and watchmen and take all necessary precautions for
the protection of the work and the safety of the public. All barricades and obstructions shall be protected at night by suitable signal lights which shall
be kept burning from sunset to sunrise. Barricades shall be of substantial construction and shall be painted such as to increase their visibility at night.
Suitable warning signs shall be so placed and illuminated at night as to show in advance where construction, barricades or detours exist.
2. Use Of Explosives: When the use of explosives is required in the work, they shall be handled, stored and used in compliance with the federal, state
and local laws. The owner shall use suitable mats or other protection where necessary, to prevent blasted material from flying onto adjacent property.
Only persons experienced in the use of explosives shall be permitted to use them on the work, and proper warning shall be given prior to shooting.
(Ord. 1470, 12-15-1980)
9-9-5: CONSTRUCTION SPECIFICATIONS:
(A) General: The first edition of the Montana public works standard specifications, October 1978, as amended herein, shall constitute the construction
specifications for the city.
(B) Amendments To Montana Public Works Specifications:
1. Delete from Section 21.01 A_PIPE- "called out in the proposal and/or plans" and insert "approved in writing by the City".
2. Delete from Section 22.02-VALVES- "Pacific States List No. 4".
3. Insert in Section 22.02-VALVES- "Mueller A-2370" instead of "Mueller A-2380".
4. Delete from Section 22.03-VALVE BOXES- "Pacific States Fig. 235".
5. Insert in Section 22.05-FIRE HYDRANTS- "Fire hydrants shall be Mueller 'Centurian' or an approved equal".
6. Delete from Section 23.04-MATERIALS- all references to polyethalene service pipe or tubing, or fittings.
7. Delete from Section 23.04-MATERIALS- all reference to Minneapolis pattern curb stops and boxes.
8. Insert in Section 23.04 D-CURB STOPS- "Mueller H-15204" instead of "Mueller H-15200".
9. Insert in Section 23.04 D-CURB STOPS- "Mueller H-13014 complete with lid and extension rod" in place of "Mueller H-10350 complete with lid and
plug".
10. Delete from Section 23.05-SERVICE LINE INSTALLATION- "Making the water main tap".
11. Insert in Section 23.07-TAPPING- the word "City" and delete the word "Contractor" in the first sentence.
12. Change Section 31.05 B-TV INSPECTION- to read as follows: "The owner may require any or all major extensions of sewer, sanitary or storm, to
be inspected by the use of a television camera before final inspection. The costs incurred in making the initial inspection shall be borne by a
contractor unless otherwise noted in the special provisions. A major extension of a main shall be any length over three hundred feet (300')".
13. Information for bidders shall provide that the owner reserves the right to reject any and all bids. (Ord. 1470, 12-15-1980)
Chapter 10
PARKS
9-10-1: PURPOSE:
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 142/283
The express purpose of this chapter is to ensure maximum public enjoyment of the parks and other public lands placed under the authority of the park and
recreation board. To this end, the rules and regulations contained herein are intended to promote the health, safety, and orderly use of the city parks and
lands by the public. (Ord. 1720, 6-2-2008)
9-10-2: APPLICATION AND ENFORCEMENT:
The terms of this chapter shall apply to all existing and hereafter acquired parks within or outside the boundaries of the city. It shall also apply to those
public lands within or outside the boundaries of the city, owned by the city, and placed under the authority of the park and recreation board by the city
commission. The park and recreation board shall have the authority to promulgate or approve rules and regulations for any specific park or public lands
placed under its jurisdiction, so long as such rules and regulations are not inconsistent herewith. The park and recreation board shall be responsible for
operation of such city parks, however, its authority may be delegated as it deems necessary. (Ord. 1720, 6-2-2008)
9-10-3: VIOLATIONS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to violate the rules and regulations contained herein, and any such violations shall be misdemeanors and shall be
punishable as provided in title 1, chapter 3 of this code. (Ord. 1572, 6-6-1988)
9-10-4: PROHIBITED ACTS:
(A) It shall be unlawful for any person to perform any of the following acts within city parks or public lands:
1. Wilfully mark, deface, disfigure, injure, tamper with, or displace or remove, any buildings, bridges, tables, benches, fireplaces, railings, paving or
paving material, water lines or other public utilities or parts or appurtenances thereof, signs, notices or placards whether temporary or permanent,
monuments, stakes, posts, or other boundary markers or other structures or equipment, facilities or park property or appurtenances whatsoever,
either real or personal.
2. Bring in or dump, deposit or leave any bottles, broken glass, ashes, paper, boxes, cans, dirt, rubbish, waste, garbage, or refuse, or other trash. No
such refuse or trash shall be placed in any waters in or contiguous to any park or public lands, or left anywhere on the grounds thereof, but shall be
placed in the proper receptacles where these are provided; where receptacles are not so provided, all such rubbish or waste shall be carried away
from the park by the person responsible for its presence, and properly disposed of elsewhere.
3. Disturb the peace.
4. Endanger the safety of any person by any conduct or act.
5. Commit any assault, battery, or engage in fighting.
6. Camp or otherwise stay overnight in any park or public lands, unless authorized by the park board or its authorized representative.
7. To drive or operate, leave, park, or repair any motor vehicle upon, across or onto any park or public lands. The foregoing shall not apply to vehicle
use in designated parking areas, or vehicle use by authorized city employees for purposes of park maintenance or operation.
8. To trespass or otherwise come upon the swimming pool area when the pool is closed or not under proper supervision.
9. To bring, leave or otherwise cause any domestic animal to come onto any park or public lands, except as specifically designated and specified by the
park and recreation board. The foregoing shall not limit or invalidate any other ordinance regarding animals.
10. To paste, glue, tack or otherwise post any sign, placard, advertisement, inscription or sign.
11. To build any fire except in established fireplaces or portable units brought in or set up for the purpose of fireplaces or broilers. Authorized fires shall
be attended at all times.
12. To discharge any firearm or other weapon.
(B) The park and recreation board shall have authority to establish other rules for the use of parks and public lands under its control which shall be
enforced as ordinances of the city. (Ord. 1720, 6-2-2008)
9-10-5: AMUSEMENT FOR GAIN:
No amusement for gain or for which a charge is made can be conducted in a park or on public lands without the consent of the park and recreation board,
and such amusement must be conducted in accordance with any ordinance or other laws pertaining thereto. (Ord. 1720, 6-2-2008)
9-10-6: GROUP ACTIVITIES:
Whenever any group, association or organization desires to use park or public lands facilities for a particular purpose, such as picnics, parties or theatrical
or entertainment performances, a representative of the group, association or organization, shall first contact the park and recreation board or its authorized
representative. The purpose of such contact is meant to be informational only, and is not intended to result in a reservation for exclusive use of any park or
portion thereof. The park and recreation board may adopt an application form to be used for such situations.
The park and recreation board or its authorized representative shall approve such group usage if it appears that the group, association or organization will
not interfere with the general use of the park/public lands by the individual members of the public and if the said group, association or organization meets
all other conditions contained in the application. The application may contain a requirement for an indemnity bond to protect the city from any liability of
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 143/283
any kind or character and to protect city property from damage, and shall contain such a provision if the swimming pool is to be utilized by the group.
Park usage shall be granted hereunder without charge. (Ord. 1720, 6-2-2008)
Chapter 11
STREET LIGHTING
9-11-1: PURPOSE:
This chapter is intended to establish a review process whereby the city can fully evaluate street lighting services within the city limits. By this process of
review, information will be gained which will direct city officials in the more efficient and equitable administration of such services. To achieve this purpose,
methods and procedures are hereby enacted in accordance with title 7, chapter 12, part 4, Montana Code Annotated, for the amendment or correction of
any resolution or proceedings relating to the creation or establishment of any of the city's lighting districts; for the amendment or correction of assessment
methods; for the exclusion and inclusion of property from and to existing lighting districts; for ensuring publication of notice and delivery of personal notice
to landowners entitled thereto; for amendment or correction of the apportionment of annual district wide costs; and for amendment or correction of any
other terms of resolutions or proceedings relating to the creation or existence of lighting districts within the city. (Ord. 1531, 4-15-1985)
9-11-2: REVIEW PROCESS:
(A) Physical Inventory: The city engineer is hereby directed to undertake and maintain an inventory of the various types or kinds and locations of
streetlights within the city. Such inventory shall be reflected or illustrated on a map of the city. In addition, the city engineer shall collect and maintain
annual cost information for the furnishing of electrical current, maintenance and installation of each kind or type of light.
A map shall also be prepared showing the boundaries of existing lighting districts.
(B) Physical Inventory Analysis And Preliminary Report: The inventory and cost information shall be analyzed and considered in relation to the location
and boundaries of existing lighting districts. The intent of the analysis shall be to identify inequities in cost or service levels throughout the city. In this
regard, the analysis shall consider the following:
1. The general character of lighting services throughout the city, and whether or not additional services shall be provided;
2. The general character of lighting services within each district and whether or not lights are distributed uniformly upon the streets, alleys or highways
within the district;
3. Whether any particular district includes lots or property that more appropriately should be placed in a contiguous district due to a higher or lower
level of service;
4. Whether any particular district does not encompass or include contiguous lots or property receiving a similar level of service, and if so, whether such
lots or property should be included within such district;
5. Whether areas within the city exist that are receiving lighting services, and should become part of a new lighting district or included in an existing
district;
6. Any other considerations deemed necessary by the city engineer. (Ord. 1531, 4-15-1985)
The city engineer shall report his findings to the city commission at a regular meeting. The meeting shall be open to the public. At least seven (7)
days prior to the meeting, a public notice or article shall appear in the Lewistown News Argus. The notice shall state the time and place where the
report of the city engineer will be considered by the city commission. In addition, the notice or article shall state generally the findings and
conclusions of the city engineer. (Ord. 1531, 4-15-1985; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
(C) Assessment Inventory: Prior to the final report, as specified herein, the office of the city treasurer shall gather and provide historical assessment
information, which shall include a listing of all tracts and lots within the city that were assessed for lighting services during the last fiscal year. Such
information shall also include the area in square feet of each lot or tract and the level of assessment for the last fiscal year.
(D) Legal Inventory: Prior to the final report, as specified herein, the city attorney shall review all resolutions of intent to create lighting districts and all
resolutions actually creating such districts. The review shall consider the legal sufficiency of such resolutions, the apportionment of district wide costs,
the assessment method of such districts, whether notice requirements of such resolutions were met, and any other information deemed necessary.
(Ord. 1531, 4-15-1985)
(E) Final Report: Based upon the inventory information described herein, the city engineer and city attorney shall prepare and present a final report to the
city commission. The final report shall identify and describe problems encountered in the efficient and equitable administration of lighting services
within the city. The final report shall include recommendations for amendment or change of existing lighting districts or for establishment or creation of
any new lighting districts. Any such recommendations shall fully consider annual costs of furnishing electrical current, maintenance and installation of
all existing or proposed districts. Recommendations shall be made concerning apportionment and assessment of districtwide costs. (Ord. 1531, 4-15-
1985; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
Also included shall be an estimate of annual costs for representative and individual lots or tracts within existing or proposed districts. The final report
shall also include recommendations on other matters deemed necessary to effectuate the purpose of this chapter. Public notice of the final report shall
be given in accordance with subsection (B) of this section. (Ord. 1531, 4-15-1985)
9-11-3: IMPLEMENTATION OF FINAL REPORT:
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 144/283
The final report and its recommendations, as approved or modified by the city commission, shall be implemented prior to the time set for the assessment
for the 1985_1986 fiscal year. Implementation shall be by resolution and may occur in various stages. Each existing or proposed district shall be treated
individually, subject to the procedures herein. (Ord. 1531, 4-15-1985; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
9-11-4: CREATION OF NEW DISTRICTS:
The creation of any new lighting district shall be subject to the procedures set forth in title 7, chapter 12, part 43, Montana Code Annotated. However, this
provision shall not preclude the amendment of resolutions relating to existing districts to include property therein, so long as the requirements of such
statutes, if applicable, are followed. (Ord. 1531, 4-15-1985)
9-11-5: ERRORS OR DEFECTIVE ESTABLISHMENT OF EXISTING DISTRICTS:
Should it be found that errors or omissions occurred in the acts or proceedings for establishment or creation of any existing district, the provisions of
section 7-12-4308, Montana Code Annotated shall control. The aforementioned section shall also govern irregularities or errors in proceedings occurring
under the terms of this chapter. (Ord. 1531, 4-15-1985)
9-11-6: RESOLUTION OF AN INTENTION TO RE-CREATE EXISTING DISTRICTS:
(A) Should it be deemed necessary to amend or change the boundaries of any existing district, or change the manner or apportionment or assessment by
any district, or to change or amend other provisions of resolutions relating to any district, such may be accomplished by the passage of a resolution
deemed a resolution of intent to re-create a special improvement lighting district. Such resolution shall, at a minimum, designate the number of the
district to be re-created, describe the boundaries of such district by metes and bounds, state the general character of services existing in such district
by the kind or type of streetlights, state the method of assessment of annual costs for property within the district, state the manner of apportionment of
annual costs, and shall state an approximate annual cost of maintaining such lights and electrical current therefor. (Ord. 1531, 4-15-1985)
(B) Upon having passed such resolution, the city commission shall give notice of such passage. The notice of passage shall be published once in the
Lewistown News Argus. The notice of such passage shall describe the general character of existing services, the estimated annual cost of maintaining
and supplying electrical current, a general description of the boundaries of such district, a general description regarding the manner of assessment or
apportionment, the time and place when the city commission will hear and pass upon a resolution for re-creation, and any other information necessary
for an informed public. The notice shall refer to the resolution on file in the office of the city clerk. (Ord. 1531, 4-15-1985; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
(C) At any time within fifteen (15) days after the publication of notice, any owner of property affected by the passage of the resolution, may make written
comments for or against the proposed re-creation. Such comments shall be presented to the city clerk who shall endorse thereon the date of its receipt.
(D) The notice of intention to re-create a lighting district need not be personally mailed to property owners within the district except as specified herein.
(Ord. 1531, 4-15-1985)
9-11-7: CONSIDERATION OF COMMENTS:
(A) At the next regular meeting after expiration of the time for receipt of comments, the city commission shall meet for the purpose of considering passage
of a resolution re-creating a special improvement lighting district. The city commission shall fully consider all comments received. In addition, the city
commission may allow oral or written comments at such meeting. (Ord. 1531, 4-15-1985; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
(B) All property owners in any proposed district, or property owners effected by passage of a resolution of an intention to re-create a special improvement
lighting district, shall be entitled to protest the re-creating of any district, however such right of protest shall be limited by the provisions of section 7-12-
4305, Montana Code Annotated. (Ord. 1531, 4-15-1985)
9-11-8: RESOLUTION RE-CREATING EXISTING DISTRICT:
(A) If no protest or comments have been received, or if any protest is deemed insufficient, the city commission shall acquire jurisdiction to pass a
resolution deemed a resolution re-creating a special improvement lighting district. Such resolution shall be in substantial compliance with the terms of
the resolution of intention. (Ord. 1531, 4-15-1985; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
(B) The due passage of a resolution of re-creation shall have the same effect as any initial resolution passed in accordance with the provisions of title 7,
chapter 12, part 4, Montana Code Annotated. Furthermore, any and all such previous resolutions or provisions of resolutions or amendments thereto,
pertaining to any property within the re-created district, shall be null and void. If any court having jurisdiction or other competent tribunal should declare
any resolution of re-creation or any part thereof to be illegal or void, then any previous resolution or provisions of such resolution pertaining to such
property shall be considered effective to replace only those portions of the resolution of re-creation declared invalid. (Ord. 1531, 4-15-1985)
9-11-9: PERSONAL NOTICE:
(A) Personal notice of an intent to re-create an existing lighting district need only be given to those property owners whose property is proposed to be
included within a re-created or newly created district, and where such property has never been a part of or included within any lighting district.
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 145/283
(B) In those situations where personal notice is required; such notice shall conform to the information requirements of section 9-11-6 of this chapter, and
shall be mailed, postage prepaid, to the address of such property owner entitled thereto. (Ord. 1531, 4-15-1985)
9-11-10: ADMINISTRATION AND RESERVE:
The city may assess an annual fee over and above the annual cost of maintaining and furnishing electrical current in any lighting district. Such assessment
shall be considered as a reserve, for purposes of making up deficiencies for nonpayment of assessments; covering the cost of installation of new lights, or
improvement of services within the district prior to the making of an annual assessment therefor; or any other appropriate purpose deemed necessary by
the city commission. In no event will such fee be greater than ten percent (10%) of the total annual cost to be assessed against the lighting district. Any
resolution of assessment passed in accordance with section 9-11-11 of this chapter shall specifically address the assessment allowed herein, to include
the amount and proposed uses of the assessment. (Ord. 1531, 4-15-1985; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
9-11-11: ANNUAL RESOLUTIONS OF ASSESSMENT:
(A) On or before the first Monday in October in each year hereafter, it shall be the duty of the city commission to pass and finally adopt resolutions levying
and assessing all of the property within each lighting district for the entire cost of maintenance, installation, administration and the furnishing of
electrical current to or for such lighting district. All of the lighting districts within the city may be addressed in a single resolution, so long as the
requirements of section 7-12-4328, Montana Code Annotated are met. Furthermore, the notice and hearing provisions of sections 7-12-4329 and 7-12-
4330, Montana Code Annotated shall be complied with. (Ord. 1531, 4-15-1985; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
(B) If all of the city's lighting districts are addressed in a single resolution, such resolution shall clearly specify the total annual assessment for each
individual lighting district.
(C) The annual resolutions or resolution of assessment shall contain a list in which shall be described each lot or parcel of land; such lot or parcel's square
footage or linear feet, depending upon the method of assessment, and the amount of the annual assessment against each such lot, or parcel. This list
may be computer generated and attached to any such resolution. (Ord. 1531, 4-15-1985)
9-11-12: LIGHTING DISTRICT FUNDS:
(A) For each lighting district created or re-created by the terms of this chapter, a fund shall be established which shall be known as the special
improvement lighting district no. fund, the number of which shall correspond with the number of the lighting district for which costs of maintenance and
supplying of electrical current are levied. (Ord. 1531, 4-15-1985)
(B) Through the process of review established by this chapter, the city commission may direct revision or correction of existing bookkeeping practices.
(Ord. 1531, 4-15-1985; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
9-11-13: CHANGED SERVICE TO EXISTING OR RE-CREATED LIGHTING DISTRICTS:
If it is determined by the city engineer that any streetlight or lights should be installed in or removed from any existing or re-created district, or that the level
of service be changed or improved in any way in any district, such shall be accomplished by the passage of a resolution. Any such action shall not
increase the total annual assessment for such district. However, any such costs may be paid from reserve funds. (Ord. 1531, 4-15-1985)
9-11-14: EFFECTIVE DATE:
This chapter shall become effective thirty (30) days after passage. The procedures herein, including the preparation of a preliminary or final report, may be
instituted from time to time as deemed necessary in accordance with the purpose of this chapter. Any of the procedures herein, which are instituted prior to
the effective date of this chapter, shall be recognized as valid and binding, so long as no resolution is passed prior to such effective date. (Ord. 1531, 4-15-
1985)
Chapter 12
STREET AND PUBLIC PLACE MAINTENANCE
9-12-1: DEFINITIONS:
The word "maintenance" as used in this chapter includes, but is not limited to, sprinkling, graveling, oiling, chip sealing, seal coating, overlaying, treating,
general cleaning, sweeping, flushing, snow removal and leaf and debris removal. (Ord. 1599, 5-20-1991)
9-12-2: METHOD OF MAINTENANCE:
All street, alley and public place maintenance to be done within the district or districts created by the city may be done by contract or by forces employed
by the city, or by both, in such manner as the city commission may elect. (Ord. 1599, 5-20-1991; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
9-12-3: METHOD OF PAYING FOR MAINTENANCE:
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 146/283
The city commission shall estimate, as near as practicable, the cost of said maintenance in each established district annually, not later than the second
Monday in August. The city commission shall pass and finally adopt a resolution specifying the district assessment option and levying and assessing all
the property within each established district with an amount equal to not less than seventy five percent (75%) of the entire cost of such work. (Ord. 1599,
5-20-1991; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
The resolution levying the assessment to defray the cost of maintenance shall contain or refer to a list in which shall be described the lot or parcel of land
assessed, with the name of the owner thereof if known, and the amount levied thereon set opposite.
Such resolution shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk for public inspection. (Ord. 1599, 5-20-1991)
A notice of intent to adopt such resolution, signed by the city clerk, stating that the resolution levying the special assessment to defray the cost of
maintenance in each established district is on file in the city clerk's office and subject to inspection for a period of five (5) days, shall be published at least
once in a newspaper published in the city. The notice shall state the time and place at which objections to the final adoption of the resolution will be heard
by the city commission. The time for the hearing shall be not less than five (5) days after the publication of the notice.
At the time so set, the city commission shall meet and hear all objections which may be made to such assessment or any part thereof and may adjourn
from time to time for that purpose and may by resolution modify such assessment, in whole or in part. (Ord. 1599, 5-20-1991; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
A copy of the resolution, certified by the city clerk, must be delivered to the city treasurer and the assessments shall be placed upon the tax roll and
collected in the same manner as other taxes and assessments. (Ord. 1599, 5-20-1991)
Chapter 13
PARADES
9-13-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter the following definitions apply:
CLASS A PARADE: An organized procession conducted on city streets consisting of ten (10) or more independent entries, individuals or organizations
unrelated to each other.
CLASS B PARADE: An organized procession conducted on city streets consisting of nine (9) or fewer independent entries, individuals or organizations
unrelated to each other.
PARADE PARTICIPANT: Any individual participating in a parade, or associated with or riding on any parade entry. (Ord. 1634, 10-21-1996)
9-13-2: PERMIT REQUIRED:
No parade may be conducted within the city unless a permit be first obtained. An application for permit to conduct a parade shall be made on forms
prepared by the city, not less than seven (7) days prior to the event. The city manager shall either grant or deny the application. (Ord. 1634, 10-21-1996;
amd. Ord. 1663, 1-3-2000)
9-13-3: OBJECTS NOT TO BE TOSSED BY PARADE PARTICIPANTS:
No parade participant may throw candy, gum, prizes or any other object to parade observers. Any candy, gum or other prizes desired to be disbursed to
the public during the parade shall be hand delivered. (Ord. 1634, 10-21-1996)
9-13-4: NO PARKING ON PARADE ROUTES:
No vehicle of any type may be parked on Main Street between 1st Avenue and 6th Avenue for two (2) hours prior to and during any class A parade.
(A) In addition to any fine which may be imposed, vehicles in violation of this section may be removed by the city, or by its direction, and the cost thereof
charged to the vehicle owner. (Ord. 1634, 10-21-1996)
9-13-5: NONPARTICIPANTS TO REMAIN ON SIDEWALKS:
During any parade, all parade nonparticipants shall remain on the public sidewalks or within the crosswalk of any connecting side street. (Ord. 1634, 10-
21-1996)
9-13-6: PARADE PARTICIPANTS TO EXERCISE DUE CARE:
All parade participants operating any vehicle or horsedrawn equipment or any other device of any nature, shall operate the same in a careful and prudent
manner and at a rate of speed no greater than is reasonable and proper under the conditions existing at the point of operation, taking into account the
amount and character of parade traffic, condition of brakes, weight of equipment, grade and width of street, condition of surface and freedom of obstruction
to the view ahead and to the side. The person operating any equipment or animaldrawn carriage shall operate the same so as to not unduly or
unreasonably endanger the life, limb, property, or other right of parade participants or other members of the public. (Ord. 1634, 10-21-1996)
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 147/283
9-13-7: PENALTY:
Any person in violation of any part of this chapter shall be fined in an amount not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) and not more than five hundred
dollars ($500.00). (Ord. 1634, 10-21-1996)
Chapter 14
COMMERCIAL DISTRICT SIDEWALK ENCROACHMENT PERMIT PROGRAM
9-14-1: PURPOSE AND INTENT:
(A) It is the intent of the city commission, in enacting the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, to:
1. Serve and protect the health, safety and welfare of the general public;
2. Regulate and control private uses and encroachments occurring upon public rights of way in commercial districts of the city by establishing distinct
criteria to permit and/or approve encroachments and exclusive uses;
3. Develop a fair and equitable program that will enhance the overall appearance, ambiance and environment of commercial districts within the city of
Lewistown. (Ord. 1741, 4-16-2012)
9-14-2: DEFINITIONS:
(A) The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context
clearly indicates a different meaning:
BLOCK FACE: One side of a street between two (2) consecutive intersecting rights of way, including alleys.
COMMERCIAL DISTRICT: Those areas designated by city ordinance as neighborhood commercial (NC), commercial (C-1, C-2 or C-3) or
manufacturing (M-1, M-2) or otherwise approved for commercial use by variance or conditional use.
COMMERCIAL USE: Any activity involving the sale of goods or services carried out for profit.
DIRECTOR: The director of planning and includes the director's authorized representative.
ENCROACHMENT: Any fixture or device including, but not limited to, a showcase, table, bench, rack, handcart, pushcart, sign, portable sign, stall,
newspaper dispensers and publication racks, seating area, fence, barrier, or partition which intrudes into or invades the public right of way other than
encroachments duly authorized, installed and maintained by the city including, but not limited to, street lighting, garbage receptacles, bike racks and
benches.
EXCLUSIVE USE: Any act undertaken by a private entity upon the public right of way of a commercial district that excludes the public from their normal
use and enjoyment of the public right of way.
PERMANENT: A period of six (6) months or more.
PORTABLE SIGN: Any sign not permanently attached to the ground or other permanent structure, or a sign designed to be transported, including, but
not limited to, signs designed to be transported by means of wheels and signs converted to A- or T-frames.
PUBLIC RIGHT OF WAY: Any area legally open to public use, including, but not limited to, and projecting vertically skyward above, public streets,
sidewalks, roadways, highways, parkways, alleys, or parks as well as areas surrounding and immediately adjacent to public buildings.
PUBLIC USE: Any normal use of the public right of way as distinguished from "exclusive use" as defined herein.
SIDE STREET: All streets within a commercial district that run in a north-south direction.
SIDEWALK: All the area legally open to public use as a pedestrian public way between the curb line and the legal property line of the abutting property.
SIDEWALK CAFE: Any group of tables, chairs, benches, barriers or partitions, trash containers and suitable decorative devices maintained upon any
part of the public right of way for use by an establishment with a valid food and drink permit in the sale to the public of food, refreshments, and
beverages of all kinds and is not a sidewalk vending cart.
SIDEWALK DISPLAY: Any showcase, table, bench, rack, sign, stall, or any other fixture or device used for the purpose of displaying, exhibiting,
carrying, transporting, storing, selling, or offering for sale any food, beverage, goods, wares, merchandise, event, or service upon a sidewalk.
SIDEWALK VENDING CART: Any handcart, pushcart, stall, or any other mobile device that is used for the purpose of displaying, exhibiting, carrying,
transporting, storing, selling, or offering for sale any food, beverages, goods, wares, or merchandise upon a sidewalk.
SPECIAL EVENT: Any occasion including, but not limited to, fairs, shows, exhibitions, citywide celebrations, and festivals taking place within a
specifically defined area of the city.
TEMPORARY: A period of less than six (6) months. (Ord. 1741, 4-16-2012)
9-14-3: ENCROACHMENT ON PUBLIC RIGHT OF WAY PROHIBITED:
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 148/283
Except as otherwise provided by this code, it is unlawful to obstruct the public rights of way of any district with debris, encumbrances or encroachments of
any kind. (Ord. 1741, 4-16-2012)
9-14-4: EXCEPTION FOR COMMERCIAL DISTRICTS:
(A) Vendors doing business in a commercial district shall be allowed to use city sidewalks as provided in this chapter.
(B) Encroachments duly authorized, installed and maintained by the city including, but not limited to, street lighting, garbage receptacles, bike racks and
benches shall be permitted. (Ord. 1741, 4-16-2012)
9-14-5: ENCROACHMENTS; PERMIT REQUIRED:
(A) Upon application, the director may authorize, subject to specific conditions as determined by the director, encroachments to occur upon sidewalks in a
