No vehicle shall be driven to the left side of the center of the street or roadway in overtaking and passing another vehicle proceeding in the same direction
unless such left side is clearly visible and is free of oncoming traffic for a sufficient distance ahead to permit such overtaking and passing to be completely
made without interfering with the safe operation of any vehicle approaching from the opposite direction or any vehicle overtaken. In every event the
overtaking vehicle must return to the right hand side of the street or roadway before coming within one hundred feet (100') of any vehicle approaching from
the opposite direction. (1961 Code)
10-10-78: FURTHER LIMITATIONS ON DRIVING TO LEFT OF CENTER OF STREET OR ROADWAY:
(A) No vehicle shall at any time be driven to the left side of the street or roadway under the following conditions:
1. When approaching the crest of a grade or upon a curve in the street or highway where the driver's view is obstructed within such distance as to
create a hazard in the event another vehicle might approach from the opposite direction.
2. When approaching within one hundred feet (100') of or traversing any intersection or railroad grade crossing.
3. When the view is obstructed upon approaching within one hundred feet (100') of any bridge, viaduct, or tunnel.
(B) The foregoing limitations shall not apply upon a one-way street or roadway. (1961 Code)
10-10-79: FOLLOWING TOO CLOSELY:
(A) The driver of a motor vehicle shall not follow another vehicle more closely than is reasonable and prudent, having due regard for the speed of such
vehicles and the traffic upon and the condition of the street or highway.
(B) The driver of any truck tractor, truck or motor vehicle drawing another vehicle when traveling upon a street or roadway outside of a business or
residence district and which is following another truck tractor, truck or motor vehicle drawing another vehicle shall, whenever conditions permit, leave
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 182/283
sufficient space so that an overtaking vehicle may enter and occupy such space without danger, except that this shall not prevent a truck tractor, truck
or motor vehicle drawing another vehicle from overtaking and passing any like vehicle or other vehicle.
(C) Motor vehicles being driven upon any street or roadway outside of a business or residence district in a caravan or motorcade whether or not towing
other vehicles shall be so operated as to allow sufficient space between each such vehicle or combination of vehicles so as to enable any other vehicle
to enter and occupy such space without danger. This provision shall not apply to funeral processions. (1961 Code)
10-10-80: REQUIRED POSITION AND METHOD OF TURNING AT INTERSECTIONS:
The driver of a vehicle intending to turn at an intersection shall do so as follows:
(A) Right Turns: Both the approach for a right turn and a right turn shall be made as close as practicable to the right hand curb or edge of the street or
roadway.
(B) Left Turn On Two Way Streets Or Roadways: At any intersection where traffic is permitted to move in both directions on each street or roadway
entering the intersection, an approach for a left turn shall be made in that portion of the right half of the street or roadway nearest the centerline thereof
and by passing to the right of such centerline where it enters the intersection and after entering the intersection the left turn shall be made so as to
leave the intersection to the right of the centerline of the street or roadway being entered. Whenever practicable the left turn shall be made in that
portion of the intersection to the left of the center of the intersection.
(C) Left Turns On Other Than Two Way Streets Or Roadways: At any intersection where traffic is restricted to one direction on one or more of the streets
or roadways, the driver of a vehicle intending to turn left at any such intersection shall approach the intersection in the extreme left hand lane lawfully
available to traffic moving in the direction of travel of such vehicle and after entering the intersection the left turn shall be made so as to leave the
intersection, as nearly as practicable, in the left hand lane lawfully available to traffic moving in such direction upon the street or roadway being
entered.
(D) Placing Of Marks, Buttons And Signs:
1. Local authorities in their respective jurisdictions may cause markers, buttons, or signs to be placed within or adjacent to intersections and thereby
require and direct that a different course from that specified in this section be traveled by vehicles turning at an intersection, and when markers,
buttons, or signs are so placed no driver of a vehicle shall turn a vehicle at an intersection other than as directed and required by such markers,
buttons or signs. (1961 Code)
10-10-81: STARTING PARKED VEHICLE:
No person shall start a vehicle which is stopped, standing or parked unless and until such movement can be made with reasonable safety. (1961 Code)
10-10-82: ADDITIONAL TURNING MOVEMENTS AND REQUIRED SIGNALS:
(A) The driver of a vehicle approaching an intersection shall yield the right of way to the vehicle on the right.
(B) The right of way rule declared in subsection (A) of this section is modified at through streets and highways and otherwise as stated in this chapter.
(Ord. 1260, 1-16-1967)
(C) No person shall stop or suddenly decrease the speed of a vehicle without first giving an appropriate signal in the manner provided herein to the driver
of any vehicle immediately to the rear when there is opportunity to give such signal. (Ord. 1177, 3-5-1962)
10-10-83: VEHICLE APPROACHING OR ENTERING INTERSECTION:
(A) The driver of a vehicle approaching an intersection shall yield the right of way to a vehicle which has entered the intersection from a different street or
highway.
(B) When two (2) vehicles enter an intersection from different streets or highways at approximately the same time, the driver of the vehicle on the left shall
yield the right of way to the vehicle on the right.
(C) The right of way rules declared in subsections (A) and (B) of this section are modified at through streets and highways and otherwise as stated in this
chapter. (Ord. 1177, 3-5-1962)
10-10-84: VEHICLE TURNING LEFT AT INTERSECTION:
The driver of a vehicle within an intersection intending to turn to the left shall yield the right of way to any vehicle approaching from the opposite direction
which is within the intersection or so close thereto as to constitute an immediate hazard, but said driver, having so yielded and having given a signal when
and as required by this act, may make such left turn and the drivers of all other vehicles approaching the intersection from said opposite direction shall
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 183/283
yield the right of way to the vehicle making the left turn. The provisions of this section shall not be applicable where it is otherwise directed by appropriate
signs or signals. (Ord. 1177, 3-5-1962)
10-10-85: VEHICLE ENTERING THROUGH STREET OR HIGHWAY OR STOP INTERSECTION:
(A) The driver of a vehicle shall stop as required by section 10-10-22 of this chapter at the entrance to a through street or highway and shall yield the right
of way to other vehicles which have entered the intersection from said through street or highway or which are approaching so closely on said through
street or highway as to constitute an immediate hazard but said driver having so yielded may proceed and the drivers of all other vehicles approaching
the intersection on said through street or highway shall yield the right of way to the vehicle so proceeding into or across the through street or highway.
(B) The driver of a vehicle shall likewise stop in obedience to a stop sign as required herein at an intersection where a stop sign is erected at one or more
entrances thereto although not a part of a through street or highway and shall proceed cautiously, yielding to vehicles not so obligated to stop which are
within the intersection or approaching so closely as to constitute an immediate hazard, but may then proceed. (Ord. 1177, 3-5-1962)
10-10-86: RECKLESS DRIVING:
(A) Any person who drives any vehicle upon a street or highway carelessly and heedlessly in wilful or wanton disregard of the rights or safety of others, or
without due caution and circumspection, and at a speed or in a manner so as to endanger or be likely to endanger any person or property, shall be
guilty of reckless driving.
(B) Every person convicted of reckless driving shall be punished upon a first conviction by imprisonment, in the city jail, for a period of not more than ninety
(90) days, or by fine of not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than three hundred dollars ($300.00), or by both such fine and imprisonment,
and on a second or subsequent conviction shall be punished by imprisonment, in the city jail, for not less than ten (10) days nor more than six (6)
months, or by a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or by both such fine and imprisonment. (Ord.
1177, 3-5-1962)
10-10-87: CARELESS DRIVING:
Any person who drives any vehicle upon any street or highway carelessly and heedlessly in disregard of the rights or safety of others or without due
caution and circumspection, or at a speed or in a manner so as to endanger or to be likely to endanger any person or property, but which offense shall be
of a lesser degree than that constituting reckless driving as provided by section 10-10-86 of this chapter shall be guilty of careless driving, and any person
who drives any vehicle upon any street or highway in a careless or heedless manner and thereby causes an accident, shall be guilty of careless driving.
(Ord. 1177, 3-5-1962)
10-10-88: SPEED RESTRICTIONS:
(A) Any person driving a vehicle on a street or highway shall drive the same at a careful and prudent speed, not greater than is reasonable and proper,
having due regard to the traffic, surface and width of the street or highway and of any other conditions then existing, and no person shall drive any
vehicle upon a street or highway at such a speed as to endanger the life, limb, or property of any person.
(B) Subject to the provisions of subsection (A) of this section, and except in those instances where a lower speed is specified in this code, it shall be prima
facie lawful for the driver of a vehicle to drive the same at a speed not exceeding the following, but in any case when such speed would be unsafe it
shall not be lawful:
1. Twelve (12) miles an hour when approaching within fifty feet (50') of a grade crossing or any railway when the driver's view is obstructed. A driver's
view shall be deemed to be obstructed when at any time during the last two hundred feet (200') of his approach to such crossing he does not have a
clear and uninterrupted view of such railway crossing, and of any traffic on such railway for a distance of four hundred feet (400') in each direction
from such crossing. (Ord. 1177, 3-5-1962)
2. The city commission may from time to time place signs along the streets in conspicuous places passing by the various schools in the city and all
vehicles shall proceed by the schools in accordance with the signs from the hours of eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. until six o'clock (6:00) P.M. (Ord. 1177,
3-5-1962; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
3. Twelve (12) miles an hour in any cemetery.
4. All trucks or pickups having a manufacturer's load capacity of over one thousand (1,000) pounds, fifteen (15) miles an hour; all other vehicles, twenty
(20) miles an hour. (Ord. 1177, 3-5-1962)
5. No driver of a motor vehicle shall operate the same at a speed exceeding twenty five (25) miles an hour. (Ord. 1203, 6-17-1963)
It shall be prima facie unlawful for any person to exceed any of the foregoing speed limitations. In every charge of violation of this section, the
complaint shall specify the speed at which the defendant is alleged to have driven, also the speed which this section declares shall be prima facie
lawful at the time and place of such alleged violations. (1961 Code)
10-10-89: NO DRIVING ON SIDEWALK:
The operator of a vehicle shall not drive within any sidewalk area except at a permanent or temporary driveway. (1961 Code)
10-10-90: STOP BEFORE ENTERING ARTERIAL HIGHWAY:
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 184/283
(A) The following streets are hereby declared to constitute arterial highways for the purpose of this chapter. All of Main Street, all of First Avenue North,
and any intersecting street now or hereafter designated by the erection of a stop sign by order of the city commission, or portion of any street so
designated. (1961 Code; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
(B) Every operator of a vehicle or other conveyance traveling upon any street within the city intersecting the above designated streets and avenues shall
bring such vehicle or conveyance to a full and complete stop at the place where such street meets the prolongation of the nearest property lines of
such arterial highway, subject, however, to the direction of any traffic officer or sign or any police officer at such intersection.
(C) The operator of any vehicle who has come to a full stop as required above, upon entering any arterial highway, as well as operators of vehicles on any
arterial highway, shall be subject to the usual right of way rule prescribed by law, and applicable to vehicles at intersections.
(D) The engineer is hereby authorized and required to place and maintain, or cause to be placed and maintained, on each and every street intersecting
any arterial highway designated above, and at or near the property line of every arterial highway, appropriate signs upon the street; such signs, devices
or marks to bear the word "Stop" and to be located in such position and to be provided with letters of a size to be clearly read and legible from a
distance of at least one hundred feet (100') along the street intersecting the arterial highway. (1961 Code)
10-10-91: DUTY TO STOP IN EVENT OF ACCIDENT:
The driver of any vehicle involved in an accident resulting in injury or death to any person or damage to property shall immediately stop such vehicle at the
scene of the accident, and shall give his name and address and registration number of his vehicle to the person struck, or to the driver or occupants of any
vehicle collided with, and shall render to any person injured in such accident reasonable assistance, including the carrying of such person to a physician or
surgeon for medical or surgical treatment, if it is apparent that such treatment is necessary or is requested by the injured person. (1961 Code)
10-10-92: DUTY TO REPORT ACCIDENTS:
It is the duty of the operator of any vehicle involved in an accident within the city resulting in personal injury, death, or property damage to immediately
make a report of such accident to the police headquarters of the city, or as soon as is possible after rendering such reasonable assistance as defined in
section 10-10-91 of this chapter. (Ord. 1177, 3-5-1962)
10-10-93: GARAGE KEEPER TO REPORT DAMAGED VEHICLES:
The person in charge of any garage or repair shop to which is brought any motor vehicle which shows evidence of having been involved in a serious
accident or struck by any bullet, shall report to police headquarters of the city within one hour after such motor vehicle has been received, giving the motor
number, manufacturer's number, name, and model, license plate number, and the name and address of the owner or operator of such vehicle. (1961
Code)
10-10-94: HORNS AND WARNING DEVICES:
Every motor vehicle, when operated upon a street or highway, shall be equipped with a horn in good working order, capable of emitting sound audible
under normal conditions from a distance of two hundred feet (200') or more, and it shall be unlawful, except as otherwise provided in this section, for any
vehicle to be equipped with, or for any person to use upon a vehicle, any siren, bell, or any compression or spark plug whistle which does not produce a
harmonious sound, or for any person at any time to use a horn otherwise than as a reasonable warning, or to make any unnecessary or unreasonably loud
or harsh sound by means of a horn or other warning device. Every authorized emergency vehicle shall be equipped with a bell, siren, or exhaust whistle of
a type approved by the chief of police. (1961 Code)
10-10-95: PREVENTION OF NUISANCES:
No person shall drive a motor vehicle on a street or highway unless such motor vehicle is equipped with a muffler in good working order and in constant
operation to prevent excessive or unusual noise and annoying smoke.
It shall be unlawful to use a "muffler cutout" on any motor vehicle on a street or highway.
No vehicle shall be driven or moved on any street or highway unless such vehicle is so constructed or loaded as to prevent its contents from dropping,
sifting, leaking, or otherwise escaping therefrom. (1961 Code)
10-10-96: RED OR GREEN LIGHTS IN FRONT OF VEHICLE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or move any vehicle upon a street or highway with any red or green light thereon visible from directly in front
thereof. This section shall not apply to police or fire department, or fire patrol vehicles, nor to any vehicles required or permitted by state law or regulations
to display small red or green clearance lamps on the front. (1961 Code)
10-10-97: STATE DRIVER'S LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any motor vehicle upon the streets or highways of the city without having first obtained and being the holder
of a valid state of Montana driver's license or permit, or to operate such motor vehicle without complying with the restrictions, if any, upon such driver's
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 185/283
license, or being otherwise authorized to operate a motor vehicle within the state of Montana by order of competent authority or by operation of law. (1961
Code)
10-10-98: VIOLATIONS:
Any violations of any of the provisions of this chapter, or of chapter 11, 12, 13, 14, or 15 of this title shall constitute a misdemeanor. (1961 Code)
Chapter 11
MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS
10-11-1: RESTRICTED USE:
It shall be unlawful for any person on roller skates, or riding or by means of any coaster, toy vehicle or similar device to go upon any street or roadway,
except while crossing a street, on a crosswalk, or on Main Street or on the sidewalks of said streets, except that the city commission may, by proper entry
in its minutes at any time, designate any street, including its intersections with other streets as a street set aside upon which the public may ride on sleds
or toboggans and cause any or all intersections where said street meets to stop before crossing said intersections for the purpose of protecting those
using said street for coasting upon sleds and toboggans, and providing further that the instructions on said signs so posted shall be obeyed by all vehicles
approaching the intersections of such street so designated for coasting, and that any person disobeying the instructions on said signs shall be subject to
penalties provided by this code. (1961 Code; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
10-11-2: DRIVING THROUGH PROCESSIONS:
It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle to drive between the vehicles comprising a funeral or other authorized procession while said procession
is in motion; provided, that said vehicles are conspicuously so designated. This provision shall not apply at intersections where traffic is controlled by traffic
control signals of police officers. (1961 Code)
10-11-3: BRAKES:
Every motor vehicle, when operated upon a street in the city shall be equipped with brakes adequate to control the movement of and to stop and to hold
such vehicle, including two (2) separate means of applying the brakes, each of which means shall be effective to apply the brakes to at least two (2)
wheels and so constructed that no part which is liable to failure shall be common to the two (2), except that a motorcycle need be equipped with only one
brake. All such brakes shall be maintained in good working order and shall conform to regulations not inconsistent with this section to be promulgated by
the city commission. (1961 Code; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
10-11-4: STATE LICENSE PLATES:
The owner of a motor vehicle shall register such vehicle with the motor vehicle department of the state of Montana, and shall further comply with all
provisions of the motor vehicle registration act. The owner shall display in a conspicuous place on such registered vehicle, the proper license plates which
must be legible at all times for a distance of one hundred feet (100'). (1961 Code)
10-11-5: DRIVING BY CERTAIN PERSONS PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of fifteen (15) years to operate any motor vehicle on the streets of the city. It shall be the duty of the
officers of the police department to arrest any person violating this provision and to take possession of the vehicle so driven and hold the same until the
satisfaction of any penalty imposed for such violation. The owner of a vehicle shall be held responsible for the operation of such vehicle by any person
under the age of fifteen (15) years. It shall be unlawful for any person learning to drive a motor vehicle to operate the same on any arterial street or
highway of the city. (1961 Code)
10-11-6: DRIVING THROUGH SAFETY ZONES:
It shall be unlawful for the operator of a vehicle at any time to drive the same over or through a safety zone as defined in this code. (Ord. 684, 10-21-1929)
10-11-7: BOARDING OR ALIGHTING FROM VEHICLES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to board or alight from any vehicle while such vehicle is in motion. (Ord. 684, 10-21-1929)
10-11-8: UNLAWFUL RIDING:
It shall be unlawful for any person to ride on any vehicle or upon any portion thereof not designed or intended for the use of passengers when the vehicle
is in motion. This provision shall not apply to an employee engaged in the necessary discharge of a duty or within truck bodies in space intended for
merchandise. (Ord. 684, 10-21-1929)
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 186/283
10-11-9: RAILWAY TRAINS NOT TO BLOCK STREET:
It shall be unlawful for the directing officer or the operator of any railway train or car to direct the operation of or to operate the same in such a manner as
to prevent the use of any street for purposes of travel for a period of time longer than ten (10) minutes, except that this provision shall not apply to trains or
cars in motion other than those engaged in switching. It shall be unlawful for any vehicle to stop within an intersection or on a crosswalk for the purpose of
receiving or discharging passengers. (Ord. 684, 10-21-1929)
10-11-10: MOTORIZED BICYCLES; MOTORCYCLES; PROTECTIVE HEADGEAR:
An operator and passenger under eighteen (18) years of age of any motorcycle, motorized bicycle, and other power driven two (2) or three (3) wheel
vehicles operated on the streets, alleys or public ways of the city shall wear protective head gear upon the head.
(A) "Protective head gear" shall be defined as a device worn upon the head designed to protect the head against a blow or from a fall. The device shall be
made of hard plastic or similar material with an interior designed to absorb shock. A chinstrap shall be attached thereto. Said chinstrap must be
fastened securely under the chin when the vehicle described herein is being operated.
(B) Specifically omitted from qualifying as protective head gear are caps or hats worn in normal course of use such as cold weather hats or caps, warm
weather hats or caps, baseball caps, skull caps, cowboy hats, stocking caps, and any other device worn upon the head for any purpose other than
specifically to protect the head from a blow or a fall.
A person convicted of the violation of this section shall be fined five dollars ($5.00). (Ord. 1417, 1977)
10-11-11: ENGINE EXHAUST BRAKING PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any person operating a vehicle in the city limits to use engine exhaust brakes or "Jacobs brakes" whereby engine compression is
released into the exhaust system by means of mechanical exhaust valves and thereby serving to slow a vehicle without using mechanical brakes.
A person convicted of the violation of this section shall pay a fine of fifty dollars ($50.00) for a first offense and a fine not to exceed two hundred dollars
($200.00) for subsequent offenses. (Ord. 1627, 8-7-1995)
Chapter 12
INTOXICATING LIQUOR; DRUGS
10-12-1: UNLAWFUL TO DRIVE:
(A) It is unlawful and punishable as provided in subsection (D) of this section for any person who is under the influence of intoxicating liquor to drive or be
in actual physical control of any motor vehicle upon the streets or roadways of this city.
(B) In any criminal prosecution for a violation of subsection (A) of this section relating to driving a vehicle while under the influence of intoxicating liquor, the
amount of alcohol in the defendant's blood at the time alleged as shown by chemical analysis of the defendant's blood, urine, breath or other bodily
substance shall give rise to the following presumptions:
1. If there was at that time 0.05% or less by weight of alcohol in the defendant's blood, it shall be presumed that the defendant was not under the
influence of intoxicating liquor;
2. If there was at that time in excess of 0.05% but less than 0.10% by weight of alcohol in the defendant's blood, such fact shall not give rise to any
presumption that the defendant was or was not under the influence of intoxicating liquor, but such fact may be considered with other competent
evidence in determining the guilt or innocence of the defendant;
3. If there was at any time 0.10% or more by weight of alcohol in the defendant's blood, it shall be presumed that the defendant was under the
influence of intoxicating liquor;
4. Percent by weight of alcohol in the blood shall be based upon grams of alcohol per one hundred (100) cubic centimeters of blood;
5. The foregoing provisions of this subsection (B) shall not be construed as limiting the introduction of any other competent evidence bearing upon the
question whether or not the defendant was under the influence of intoxicating liquor.
(C) It is unlawful and punishable as provided in subsection (D) of this section for any person who is an habitual user of or under the influence of any
narcotic drug or who is under the influence of any other drug to a degree which renders him incapable of safely driving a motor vehicle to drive a motor
vehicle within this city. The fact that any other person charged with a violation of this subsection is or has been entitled to use such a drug under the
laws of this state shall not constitute a defense against any charge of violating this subsection.
(D) Every person who is convicted of a violation of this section shall be punished by imprisonment in the city jail for not more than six (6) months or by a
fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or by both such fine and imprisonment. On the second
conviction, he shall be punished by imprisonment in the city jail for not less than ten (10) days nor more than six (6) months, to which may be added, at
the discretion of the court, a fine of not less than three hundred dollars ($300.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). On the third or
subsequent conviction, he shall be punished by imprisonment for a term of not less than thirty (30) days nor more than one year, to which may be
added at the discretion of the court, a fine of not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). (Ord. 1399,
11-3-1975)
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 187/283
10-12-2: CHEMICAL BLOOD, BREATH OR URINE TESTS:
(A) Any person who operates a motor vehicle upon the public streets or roadways of this city shall be deemed to have given consent, subject to the
provisions of this chapter, to a chemical test of his blood, breath, or urine for the purpose of determining the alcoholic content of his blood if arrested by
a peace officer for driving or in actual physical control of a motor vehicle while under the influence of intoxicating liquor. The test shall be administered
at the direction of a peace officer having reasonable grounds to believe the person to have been driving or in actual physical control of a motor vehicle
upon the public streets or roadways of this city while under the influence of intoxicating liquor. The arresting officer may designate which one of the
aforesaid tests shall be administered.
(B) Any person who is unconscious or who is otherwise in a condition rendering him incapable of refusal, shall be deemed not to have withdrawn the
consent provided by subsection (A) of this section.
(C) If a person under arrest refuses upon the request of a peace officer to submit to a chemical test designated by the arresting officer as provided in
subsection (A) of this section, none shall be given, but the arresting officer shall immediately make a written report under oath that he had reasonable
grounds to believe the arrested person had been driving or was in actual physical control of a motor vehicle upon the streets or roadways of this city
while under the influence of intoxicating liquor and that the person had refused to submit to the test upon the request of the peace officer. Said report
shall be forthwith sent to the Montana highway patrol board for the purposes provided in section 32-2142.2 Revised Codes of Montana, 1947. (Ord.
1399, 11-3-1975)
10-12-3: ADMINISTRATION OF TESTS:
(A) Only a physician or registered nurse acting at the request of a peace officer may withdraw blood for the purpose of determining the alcoholic content
therein. This limitation shall not apply to the taking of breath or urine specimens.
(B) The person tested may, at his own expense, have a physician or registered nurse, of his own choosing administer a test, in addition to any
administered at the direction of a peace officer, for the purpose of determining the amount of alcohol in his blood, breath or urine. The failure or inability
to obtain an additional test by a person shall not preclude the admissibility in evidence of the test taken at the direction of a peace officer.
(C) Upon the request of the person tested full information concerning the test taken at the direction of the peace officer shall be made available to him or
his attorney.
(D) No physician or registered nurse shall incur any civil or criminal liability as a result of the proper administering of a blood test when requested in writing
by a peace officer to administer such a test.
(E) If the test given under the preceding subsection is a chemical test of urine, the person tested shall be given such privacy in the taking of the urine
specimen as will ensure the accuracy of the specimen and, at the same time, maintain the dignity of the individual involved. (Ord. 1399, 11-3-1975)
10-12-4: RIGHT OF APPEAL TO COURT:
(A) Any person whose license or privilege to drive has been suspended, as hereinbefore authorized, the board shall immediately notify such person in
writing and such person shall have the right to file a petition within thirty (30) days thereafter for a hearing in the matter in the district court in the county
wherein such person shall reside and such court is hereby vested with jurisdiction and it shall be its duty to set the matter for hearing upon thirty (30)
days' written notice to the city attorney of the city wherein the appeal is filed and such city attorney shall represent the state, and thereupon the court
shall take testimony and examine into the facts of the case, except that the issues shall be limited to whether a peace officer had reasonable grounds
to believe the person had been driving or was in actual physical control of a vehicle upon the public streets or roadways of the city while under the
influence of intoxicating liquor, whether the person was placed under arrest and whether such person refused to submit to the test. The court shall
thereupon determine whether the petitioner is entitled to a license or is subject to suspension as heretofore provided.
(B) Upon the trial of any criminal action or proceeding arising out of acts alleged to have been committed by any person while driving or in actual physical
control of a motor vehicle while under the influence of intoxicating liquor, evidence of the amount of alcohol in the person's blood at the time of the act
alleged as shown by a chemical analysis of his blood, breath, or urine is admissible.
(C) If the person under arrest refused to submit to the test as hereinabove provided, proof of refusal shall be admissible in any criminal action or
proceeding arising out of acts alleged to have been committed while the person was driving or in actual physical control of a motor vehicle upon the
public streets or roadways of this city while under the influence of intoxicating liquor.
(D) The provisions of this act do not limit the introduction of any other competent evidence bearing on the question of whether the person was under the
influence of intoxicating liquor. (Ord. 1399, 11-3-1975)
10-12-5: USE OF DRUGS UNLAWFUL:
It is unlawful and punishable as provided in section 10-12-6 of this chapter for any person who is an habitual user of any narcotic drug or who is under the
influence of any other drug to a degree which renders him incapable of safely driving a motor vehicle to drive a motor vehicle within this city. The fact that
any person charged with a violation of this section is or has been entitled to use such a drug under the ordinances of this city shall not constitute a defense
against any charges of violating this section. (Ord. 1399, 11-3-1975)
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 188/283
10-12-6: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Every person who is convicted of a violation of this chapter shall be punished by imprisonment in the city jail for not more than six (6) months or by a fine
of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by both such fine and imprisonment. On a second conviction
he shall be punished by imprisonment in the city jail for not less than ten (10) days nor more than six (6) months, to which may be added, at the discretion
of the court a fine of not less than three hundred dollars ($300.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). On the third or subsequent conviction he
shall be punished by imprisonment for a term of not less than thirty (30) days nor more than one year, to which may be added at the discretion of the court,
a fine of not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). (Ord. 1399, 11-3-1975)
Chapter 13
AUTOMATIC SIGNALS
10-13-1: RULES REGULATING SIGNALS:
On any street intersection in the city where electrical traffic signals are now installed, or may hereinafter be installed by order of the city commission, traffic
along the streets meeting at such intersection, shall be controlled and governed at such intersection by the following rules: (Ord. 1130, 9-21-1959; amd.
Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
(A) 1. When the electric signal facing any line of traffic shows red, the leading car approaching such intersection shall come to a complete stop behind the
line marked for pedestrian crossing and before reaching such intersection, and cars to the rear of such leading car shall stop in a line behind such
leading car, and all such cars shall remain at a complete stop until the electric signal shall change from red to green except as provided in subsection
(A)2 of this section following:
2. It shall be lawful for any car or motor vehicle in the right hand or outside lane of any street or highway having two (2) lanes of traffic proceeding in
each direction, or any car or motor vehicle in the right hand lane of any street or highway having one lane of traffic each way, to turn to the right at
any intersection when the electric signal facing any line of traffic shows red; providing, that such car or motor vehicle shall first come to a complete
stop and further providing that the crosswalks and/or pedestrian safety zones facing any such car or motor vehicle and to the right of any such car or
motor vehicle are clear of pedestrian traffic.
3. The provisions of subsection (A)2 of this section shall apply to automobiles and motor vehicles only, and such other motor vehicles or cars covered
herein and shall in no event apply to pedestrians. (Ord. 1130, 9-21-1959)
(B) When the electric signal facing any line of traffic shows green, stopped cars and those approaching the intersection in such line of traffic may proceed
across such intersection or turn onto the intersecting street; providing that in turning on to such intersecting street, pedestrians crossing such
intersecting street on the green light shall have the right of way, while they remain within the lines of sidewalks projected.
(C) Pedestrians will be governed by above rules and shall cross such intersections, staying within the lines of the sidewalk projected on the green light and
remain on sidewalk when the red light shows. (Ord. 966, 2-4-1952)
Chapter 14
SPEED ZONES
10-14-1: ESTABLISHMENT:
There is hereby established in the city speed zones on the streets adjacent to and around the schools situated in said city, for the purpose of protecting the
school children and pedestrians.
The zones so established are identified as follows:
On 2nd Street from its intersection on the truck bypass to its intersection on 7th Avenue; on 7th from its intersection on 2nd Street to the intersection on 1st
Street; on 1st Street from its intersection on 7th Avenue to the truck bypass; included in said zone is Hilger Avenue from 1st Street to 2nd Street.
On Crystal Drive from its intersection on Flourite Drive to the intersection on Birch Street; on Birch Street from its intersection on Crystal Drive to the
intersection on Flourite Drive; on Flourite Drive from its intersection on Birch Street to its intersection on Crystal Drive.
On Ouelette Street from its intersection on Washington Street to the intersection on Boulevard Avenue; on Boulevard Avenue from its intersection on
Ouelette Street to its intersection on High Street; on High Street from its intersection on Boulevard Avenue to its intersection on Washington Street; on
Washington Street from its intersection on High Street to its intersection on Ouelette Street.
On 6th Avenue South from Main Street to its intersection at Spring Street; on 7th Avenue South from Main Street to its intersection on Spring Street; on
Janeaux Street from its intersection on 6th Avenue South to its intersection on 7th Avenue South; on Watson Street from its intersection on 6th Avenue
South to its intersection on 7th Avenue South; on Watson Street from its intersection on 6th Avenue South to its intersection on 8th Avenue South; on
Spring Street from its intersection on 6th Avenue South to its intersection on 8th Avenue South.
On 7th Avenue North from Boulevard Avenue to its intersection on Washington Street; on Washington Street from its intersection at 7th Avenue North to its
intersection on 6th Avenue North.
On Broadway Street from its intersection at 2nd Avenue North to its intersection at 1st Avenue North; on 1st Avenue North from its intersection at
Broadway Street to its intersection at Boulevard Avenue; on Boulevard Avenue from its intersection at 1st Avenue North to its intersection at 2nd Avenue
North; on 2nd Avenue North from its intersection at Boulevard Avenue to its intersection at Broadway Street.
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 189/283
On Main Street from its intersection at 10th Avenue South to its intersection at 9th Avenue North; on 9th Avenue North from its intersection at Main Street
to its intersection at Broadway Street; on Broadway Street from its intersection at 9th Avenue North to its intersection at 10th Avenue North.
Unless otherwise specified herein all intersections mentioned are included in said zones. (Ord. 1315, 10-6-1969)
10-14-2: ZONES TO BE MARKED:
All zones specified above shall be marked by appropriate painted lanes clearly defining the zones and official traffic signs shall be placed prior to the entry
of the zones which advise people driving motor vehicles that they are about to enter a school zone. (Ord. 1315, 10-6-1969)
10-14-3: PENALTY:
Any violation of this chapter shall be deemed a misdemeanor and subject to the penalty prescribed by title 1, chapter 3 of this code. (Ord. 1315, 10-6-
1969)
Chapter 15
JUVENILE TRAFFIC COURT
10-15-1: POLICE COURT SHALL BE THE JUVENILE TRAFFIC COURT:
The police court shall be the juvenile traffic court for all proceedings brought under city traffic code the unlawful operations of motor vehicles by children
under the age of eighteen (18) years. (Ord. 1316, 10-6-1969)
10-15-2: OPERATION OF MOTOR VEHICLES:
The provisions of the city traffic code shall be applicable to operation of motor vehicles by children under the age of eighteen (18) years only as limited and
made applicable by the provisions of this section. (Ord. 1316, 10-6-1969)
10-15-3: PENALTY:
Whenever, after a hearing before the juvenile traffic court, it shall be found that a child under the age of eighteen (18) years has unlawfully operated a
motor vehicle, the court may:
(A) Impose a fine, not exceeding fifty dollars ($50.00) provided that such child shall not be imprisoned for failure to pay such fine,
(B) May revoke the driver's license of such child, or suspend the same for such time as may be fixed by the court, and
(C) May order any motor vehicle owned or operated by such child to be impounded by the city probation officer for such time, not exceeding sixty (60)
days, as shall be fixed by the court, provided, however, that if the court shall find that the operation of such motor vehicle was without the consent of
the owner, then such vehicle shall not be impounded. Upon nonpayment of any fine herein provided for, the court may order that any motor vehicle
owned by said child or operated by said child with the consent of the owner shall be impounded until the fine shall be paid, or may order that the
driver's license of such child shall be taken up and held by city probation officer until payment of said fine, or cause both said motor vehicle and driver's
license to be taken up and impounded until such fine shall be paid. No child shall be committed to or held in any detention facility or jail by reason of
nonpayment of said fine. (Ord. 1316, 10-6-1969)
10-15-4: SUMMONS TO REPORT:
Whenever any child under the age of eighteen (18) years shall unlawfully operate a motor vehicle within the city limits in the presence of any peace officer
of the city, or county of Fergus or in the presence of any state highway patrolman, such officer may deliver to said child a form of notice, summons, or
warrant describing the nature of the offense, with instructions thereon to report to the juvenile traffic court of the city wherein the offense occurs; and the
court shall be informed thereof by a delivery of the copy of said notice, summons or warrant to the city probation officer, who shall in turn deliver the same
to the judge of the juvenile traffic court of the city. (Ord. 1316, 10-6-1969)
10-15-5: REQUIRED TO APPEAR:
Whenever the juvenile traffic court shall be informed that a child has unlawfully operated a motor vehicle, said child shall be required to appear before the
court and the court shall, after a hearing and investigation, take action as provided in section 10-15-3 of this chapter, or may dismiss the proceeding if it be
found and determined that it is for the best interest of the child so to do. (Ord. 1316, 10-6-1969)
Title 11
ZONING
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 190/283
Chapter 1
TITLE AND PURPOSE
11-1-1: TITLE:
This title shall be known and may be referred to as THE CITY ZONING TITLE for the city of Lewistown, Montana, June 15, 1989. (Ord. 1576, 5-1-1989,
eff. 6-15-1989)
11-1-2: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this title is to promote the health, safety, and general well being of the community by regulating the density of population; percentage of lot
that may be occupied; open space; height and size of buildings and structures; and location and use of buildings, structures and land for residence, trade,
industry and other purposes within the jurisdictional area. (Ord. 1576, 5-1-1989, eff. 6-15-1989)
11-1-3: ADOPTION OF COMPREHENSIVE PLAN:
The city-county planning board directed the preparation of a comprehensive plan for Lewistown, Montana, and recommended adoption of the same: that a
comprehensive plan for Lewistown, Montana, has been submitted and filed with the city clerk. (Ord. 1576, 5-1-1989, eff. 6-15-1989)
11-1-4: OFFICIAL ZONING MAP:
The city is hereby divided into zoning districts as shown on the official zoning map which, together with all explanatory matter thereon, is hereby adopted
by reference and declared to be a part of this title. (Ord. 1576, 5-1-1989, eff. 6-15-1989)
The official zoning map shall be identified by the signature of the mayor or city manager attested by the city clerk. It shall be dated and bear the words
"The Official Zoning Map of the City of Lewistown, Montana". (Ord. 1576, 5-1-1989, eff. 6-15-1989; amd. Ord. 1663, 1-3-2000)
Changes made in district boundaries shall be promptly entered on the official zoning map after amendment by the city commission. Amendments to the
official zoning map shall not become effective until adopted by the city commission. The assistant city engineer or designated official shall be responsible
for depicting zoning changes on the official zoning map. (Ord. 1576, 5-1-1989, eff. 6-15-1989; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
Regardless of the existence of purported copies of the official zoning map which may from time to time be published, the official zoning map shall be
placed in the city vault. Such map shall be the final authority as to the current zoning status of land inside the jurisdictional area. (Ord. 1576, 5-1-1989, eff.
6-15-1989)
No changes shall be made on the official zoning map or matter shown thereon except in conformity with the provisions set forth in chapter 13 of this title. In
the event the official zoning map is damaged or destroyed, the city commission may adopt a new official zoning map by resolution. No such map shall
have the effect of amending the original zoning map or any subsequent amendment thereof. (Ord. 1576, 5-1-1989, eff. 6-15-1989; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-
2000)
11-1-5: INTERPRETING DISTRICT BOUNDARIES:
(A) Boundaries within the jurisdiction indicated as appearing to follow the centerlines of streets, highways or alleys shall be construed to follow such
centerlines. Perimeter city boundaries shall encompass the entire street, highway or alley.
(B) Boundaries indicated as appearing to follow platted lot lines shall be construed as following such lot lines.
(C) Boundaries indicated as appearing to follow the city limits shall be construed as following city limits. (Ord. 1576, 5-1-1989, eff. 6-15-1989)
(D) Boundaries indicated as following railroad lines shall be construed to midway between the main tracks as designated by the city commission, and in
the event of change in the location of railroad lines, shall be construed as moving with the lines midway between the main tracks. (Ord. 1576, 5-1-1989,
eff. 6-15-1989; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
(E) Boundaries indicated as approximately following the centerlines of streams, rivers, canals, lakes or other bodies of water shall be construed to follow
such centerlines, and in the event of change in the location of streams, rivers, canals, lakes or other bodies of water, shall be construed as moving with
the actual body of water and following the centerline.
(F) Boundaries indicated as parallel to or extensions of features indicated in subsections (A) through (E) of this section shall be so construed. Distances
not specifically indicated on the official zoning map shall be determined by the scale of the map or by specific distances enumerated in an ordinance
amending the official zoning map. (Ord. 1576, 5-1-1989, eff. 6-15-1989)
(G) Where physical or cultural features existing on the ground vary with those shown on the official zoning map or where circumstances or controversies
arise over district boundaries, the city commission shall interpret the district boundary. (Ord. 1576, 5-1-1989, eff. 6-15-1989; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
11-1-6: INTERPRETING LAND USES:
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 191/283
If questions arise concerning the appropriate classification of a particular use or if a specific use is not listed, the city commission shall determine the
appropriate classification for that use.
In interpreting land use classifications, the city commission shall determine that neither the intent of the title nor the intent of the district will be abrogated
by such classification. (Ord. 1576, 5-1-1989, eff. 6-15-1989; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000)
11-1-7: APPLICATION OF DISTRICT REGULATIONS:
Within the various zoning districts as herein defined and as indicated on the official zoning map and subject to the requirements of chapter 3 of this title,
buildings or structures shall not be erected, reconstructed, or structurally altered, nor shall any land, building or structure be used for any purpose: a) as it
is allowed in the district in which such building, land or use is located or b) satisfies the requirements of chapter 5, "Nonconforming Uses", or chapter 6,
"Conditional Uses", of this title. (Ord. 1576, 5-1-1989, eff. 6-15-1989)
11-1-8: AREA OF JURISDICTION:
The zoning regulations of the city of Lewistown, Montana, are to be enforced within the corporate limits of the city of Lewistown. (Ord. 1576, 5-1-1989, eff.
6-15-1989)
Chapter 2
DEFINITIONS
11-2-1: GENERAL DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this title, certain terms or words used herein are defined:
The word "person" includes a partnership, firm, association, organization, trust, company or corporation as well as any individual; the present tense
includes the future tense; the singular number includes the plural and the plural number includes the singular; the word "shall" is mandatory and the word
"may" is permissive; the words "used" or "occupied" include the words "intended", "designated" or "arranged to be used or occupied"; and the word "lot"
includes the words "plot", "parcel" or "tract". Where further clarification is necessary or definitions are not provided, the Lewistown zoning commission may
define such terms.
ACCESSORY: The use of land, including use for wind powered electricity systems, or a subordinate building or a portion of a main building, such use
being secondary to or incidental to the principal use or structure and not conflicting with the primary use.
ADDITION: An increase in the square footage of a structure.
AGRICULTURE: The use of land for agricultural purposes, including farming, dairying, grazing, animal and poultry husbandry, and all uses customarily
incidental thereto.
AIRPORT, HELIPORT OR AIRCRAFT LANDING FIELD: Any runway, landing area or facility, whether publicly or privately owned and operated, which is
designed, used, or intended to be used either by public carriers or by private aircraft for landing and taking off of aircraft, including all necessary taxiways,
aircraft storage and tie down areas, hangars and other necessary buildings, and open space.
ALLEY: A passage or way open to public travel and dedicated to public use other than a public street affording generally a secondary means of vehicular
access to abutting lots and not intended for general traffic circulation.
ALTERATION: A change or rearrangement of the structural parts of existing facilities or the moving from one location to another.
ANTIQUE STORE: Any retail establishment in which the principal portion of the merchandise handled, offered for sale, or sold on the premises comprises
works of art and handicrafts valued because of their age.
APARTMENT HOUSE: A building designed for occupancy by three (3) or more families living separately from each other and containing three (3) or more
dwelling units.
ARTERIAL: A main route designated by the state of Montana in cooperation with the Lewistown city commission.
AUCTION HOUSE: A place where goods are consigned and offered for sale to the highest bidder.
AUTOMOBILE, BOAT AND TRAILER SALES AREA: An open area, other than a street, used for the display, sale or rental of new or used automobiles,
boats or trailers, and where only minor incidental repair is done.
AUTOMOBILE WRECKING: The dismantling or wrecking of motor vehicles or trailers, or the storage or sale of dismantled or partially dismantled, obsolete
or wrecked vehicles or their parts.
BAR, TAVERN, COCKTAIL LOUNGE: An establishment where alcoholic beverages are primarily sold and consumed on the premises.
BOARDING (LODGING OR ROOMING) HOUSE: A building, or portion thereof, other than a hotel, rest home or home for aged, where lodging and meals
are provided (exclusive of the operator's immediate family) for compensation.
BUILDING: Any structure built for support, shelter or enclosure of persons, animals, chattel or property of any kind.
BUILDING HEIGHT: The vertical distance from the "grade" to the highest point of the coping of a flat roof, or to the deck line of a mansard roof, or to the
average height of the highest gable of a pitch or hip roof.
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 192/283
BUILDING, PRINCIPAL: A structure to accommodate the primary use to which the premises are devoted.
BUSINESS AND PROFESSIONAL OFFICES: Offices to provide services, excluding trade.
BUSINESS OR COMMERCE: The purchase, sale, offering for sale or other transaction involving the handling or disposition of any article, service,
substance or commodity for profit or nonprofit.
CARPORT: A structure to house or to protect motor vehicles owned or operated by the occupants of the main building which is open for at least fifty
percent (50%) of the total area of its sides, included in calculation for maximum lot coverage.
CHILD/ADULT CARE CENTER: A building or dwelling unit within which a program of adult care and supervision of thirteen (13) or more children/adults is
conducted, including those children/adults domiciled on the premises.
CHURCH: A building designed and used for public worship by any religious body.
CITY COMMISSION: The legislative body of the city of Lewistown.
CLINIC: A building designed and used for medical, chiropractic, dental and surgical diagnosis and treatment of patients under the care of doctors and
nurses, but where no major surgery is performed.
CLUB: An incorporated or unincorporated association of persons organized for a social, political, educational, literary, religious or charitable purpose.
COMMUNITY RESIDENTIAL FACILITY: A group, foster or other home specifically provided as a place of residence for developmentally disabled or
handicapped persons who do not require nursing care, or any other facility as defined in section 76-2-411, Montana Code Annotated, 1985.
CONDOMINIUM: Ownership in common with others of a parcel of land and/or certain parts of a building, in addition to individual ownership of a particular
unit or apartment in such building.
DAYCARE HOME (Children/Adults): A use carried on within a house providing responsible care and supervision for not more than twelve (12)
children/adults including those children/adults domiciled on the premises.
DECK: An elevated platform extending horizontally proximate to a structure open to the sky.
DENSITY: The number of dwelling units per specified area.
DRIVE-IN RESTAURANT: A use whose retail character is dependent upon a driveway approach and parking space for motor vehicles so as to permit
consumption of food or beverages obtained on the premises in a vehicle.
DWELLING: A building designed exclusively for residential purposes, including one-family, two-family and multi-family units.
DWELLING, TYPES OF: (A) Dwelling, Single-Family: A building designed for occupancy by one family and containing one dwelling unit.
(B) Dwelling, Two-Family (Duplex): A building designed for occupancy by two (2) families and containing two (2) dwelling units.
(C) Dwelling, Multi-Family: A building designed primarily for occupancy by three (3) or more families living independently of each other and containing
three (3) or more dwelling units.
DWELLING UNIT: One or more rooms designed for or occupied by one family for living or sleeping purposes that may contain kitchen facilities.
EASEMENT: The explicit right to make limited use of another's property.
FAMILY: An individual or two (2) or more persons related by blood, marriage, or adoption, or other legal means, or a group of not more than three (3)
persons who are not related by blood, marriage or adoption, living together in a dwelling unit.
FENCE: A barrier composed of posts connected by boards, rails, panels or wire for the purpose of enclosing space for separating parcels of land. It may
include a masonry wall.
FLOODPLAIN OR FLOODWAY: In all cases of interpretation, designated floodplain and floodway definitions established by the Montana department of
natural resources and conservation shall apply1.
GARAGE, PRIVATE: An accessory building or an accessory portion of the main building, enclosed on not less than three (3) sides, and designed or
primarily used for the shelter or storage of vehicles owned or operated by the occupants of the main building or buildings, included in calculation for
maximum lot coverage.
GARAGE, PUBLIC: A building used for the care, repair or storage of motor vehicles, or where such vehicles are kept for remuneration, hire or sale. It may
include a service station which makes major or minor repairs.
GRADE (Adjacent Ground Elevation): The lowest point of elevation of the finished surface of the ground between the exterior wall of a building and a point
five feet (5') distant from such wall, or the lowest point of elevation of the finished surface of the ground between the exterior wall of the building and the
property line if it is less than five feet (5') distant from said wall. In case walls are parallel to and within five feet (5') of a public sidewalk, alley or other
public way, the grade shall be the elevation of the sidewalk, alley or public way.
GROSS FLOOR AREA: The total area of all floors of a building measured from exterior walls.
HOSPITAL: An institution specializing in providing clinical temporary and emergency services of a medical, chiropractic or surgical nature to human
patients and licensed by state law to provide facilities and services in surgery, chiropractic, obstetrics and general medical practice, and may provide
treatment of mental and nervous disorders, alcoholism and surgical/postsurgical treatment of mental cases. Nursing and convalescent homes are not
included.
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 193/283
HOSPITAL, ANIMAL: A building or premises for the medical or surgical treatment of wild and domestic animals or pets.
HOSPITAL, MENTAL: An institution that offers facilities, care and treatment for cases of mental and nervous disorders.
HOTEL: A building or portion thereof designed or used for six (6) or more guests where temporary lodging with or without meals is provided for
compensation. A dining room, banquet meeting hall, kitchen, plus accessory shops and services catering to the general public may be provided.
IMPROVEMENT: A modification that upgrades the property.
KENNEL, COMMERCIAL: A place where dogs or cats, other than those owned by the kennel owner, are kept and boarded for any period in excess of
twenty four (24) hours. Dog/cat breeding for the sole purpose of the sale of the offspring for profit may be conducted.
KENNEL, NONCOMMERCIAL: A place at, in or adjoining a private residence where dogs or cats are kept for the hobby of the householder. Dog/cat
breeding should not change the residential character of the neighborhood.
LABORATORY: A place adapted to conducting scientific experiments, testing and analyses.
LARGE WIND POWERED ELECTRICITY SYSTEMS: Have a rated capacity of over one hundred (100) kilowatts (kW) and are intended to produce
electricity for use on site and/or sale to a rate regulated utility company or other off site provider of electric power. Such systems may also be termed as
"commercial wind powered electricity systems".
LIVESTOCK AND FOWL: Livestock shall include all swine and grazing animals. Fowl shall include chickens, geese, ducks, turkeys, peacocks and other
poultry.
LOT: A single tract of land, no matter how legally described, whether by aliquot part, metes and bounds, certificate of survey, and/or by lot and block
designation as in a recorded plat, which at the time of applying for a building permit is designated by its owner or developer as the tract to be used,
developed or built upon as a unit of land under single ownership or control.
LOT COVERAGE: The total area of a lot covered by the principal and accessory buildings.
LOT FRONTAGE: That portion of the lot nearest the public street. For the purpose of determining yard requirements on corner lots and through lots, all
sides of a lot adjacent to public streets shall be considered frontage; yards shall also be considered frontage.
LOT OF RECORD: A single tract of land that has been recorded in the Fergus County clerk and recorder's office.
LOT, PROPOSED: A single tract of land to be created after adoption of the 1989 zoning ordinance.
LOT TYPES: (A) Corner Lot: A lot located at the intersection of two (2) or more streets. A lot abutting on a curved street or streets shall be considered a
corner lot if straight lines drawn from the foremost points of the side lot lines meet at an interior angle of less than one hundred thirty five degrees (135).
(B) Interior Lot: A lot other than a corner lot with only one frontage on a street other than an alley.
(C) Through Lot: A lot other than a corner lot with frontage on more than one street other than an alley. Through lots with frontage on two (2) streets
may be referred to as double frontage lots.
MANUFACTURED HOME: A transportable structure built on a chassis and designated to be used without a permanent foundation as a dwelling unit. The
phrase "without a permanent foundation" indicates that the support system is constructed with the intent that the manufactured home placed thereon may
be moved from time to time at the convenience of the owner.
MARQUEE AND AWNING: A fixed shelter used only as a roof and extending beyond a building line which is entirely supported by the building to which it
is attached.
MODIFICATION: Alteration of a structure with no resultant increase in square footage.
MODULAR HOME: A prefabricated structure designated to be used with a permanent foundation as a dwelling unit, excluding a chassis.
MOTEL: A group of attached or detached buildings containing individual sleeping units, and where a garage is attached or a parking space is conveniently
located at each unit for temporary use; it shall include motor courts and motor lodges.
NONCONFORMING USE: A use which lawfully occupied a building or land at the time this title or an amendment hereto became effective, and which does
not conform with the use regulations of the district in which it is located.
NURSING HOME: A building or portion thereof used for the housing of and caring for the ambulatory, aged or infirm by a healthcare staff.
OWNERSHIP, SINGLE: Individual, partnership or organizational control of land use held in common.
PARKING, OFF STREET: Refer to the standards for off street parking in chapter 8 of this title.
PARKING, PRIVATE: An open area other than a street used for the temporary parking of vehicles for profit or private business related use.
PARKING, PUBLIC: An open area other than a street used for the temporary parking of vehicles and available for public use.
PATIO: A ground level platform extending horizontally proximate to a structure open to the sky.
PERSONAL CARE HOME: A facility which provides residential services, such as laundry, housekeeping, meals and local transportation; personal
assistance services, such as dressing, grooming, walking, eating and similar routine living tasks; recreational activities; and supervision of self-medication.
Persons who need medical or physical restraints, are nonambulatory or bedridden, totally incontinent or less than eighteen (18) years of age may not
reside in a personal care facility.
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 194/283
PLANNED UNIT DEVELOPMENT: Refer to the standards and definitions established in the Lewistown subdivision regulations and chapter 11 of this title.
PLANNING BOARD: The Lewistown/Fergus County planning board as authorized under the provisions of section 76-1-101 Montana Code Annotated.
PLANNING DIRECTOR: The individual appointed by the Lewistown/Fergus County planning board in accordance with the Montana Code Annotated
(MCA) whose duties and responsibilities shall include direction and administration of planning department activities.
PORCH: A covered structure forming an entrance to a building, included in calculation for maximum lot coverage.
PRINCIPAL USE: The primary or predominant use to which the property is or may be devoted, and to which all other uses on the premises are accessory.
PROJECTION: The distance any part of a structure extends over public property or beyond the building setback line.
PUBLIC UTILITIES SERVICE INSTALLATION: A structure to control centralized public utilities services, such as electric substations, utility booster
stations for current or pressure, telephone satellite and others. Structures with offices as the main use are excluded.
PUBLIC UTILITY: A private business organization providing some public service, such as telephone, electricity, gas hookups and subject to special
governmental regulations or a governmental agency performing similar public services.
RECREATIONAL AREA, COMMERCIAL: An area operated for profit or nonprofit devoted to facilities and equipment for recreational purposes, whether
the use of such area is limited to private membership or whether open to the public upon the payment of a fee.
REHABILITATION CENTER: A place where individuals receive care to return to health or normal activity.
RETIREMENT HOME: A place of residence for families or individuals in apartment like quarters or condominiums which offers services to retired persons,
such as limited nursing facilities, minimum maintenance living accommodations and recreation programs and facilities.
RIGHT OF WAY: A strip of land dedicated or acquired for use as a public way.
SCHOOL, COMMERCIAL: A building where instruction is provided; it is operated as a commercial enterprise as distinguished from schools endowed
and/or supported by taxation.
SCHOOL, ELEMENTARY, JUNIOR AND SENIOR HIGH, INCLUDING PUBLIC, PRIVATE AND PAROCHIAL: An institution of learning which offers
instruction in various subject areas required to be taught in the schools by the Montana department of education.
SCHOOL OF HIGHER EDUCATION: A public or private institution for higher learning (beyond grade 12) providing instruction as approved by the Montana
department of education or a national collegiate or university accreditation agency.
SCRAP PROCESSING YARD: Any establishment or place of business which is maintained or used for storing, buying or selling salvageable waste
materials. Such materials may be compressed, shredded or otherwise processed for reuse on or off the premises.
SECONDHAND STORE: Any retail establishment in which the principal portion of the articles, commodities or merchandise handled, offered for sale or
sold on the premises is used or not new. Antique stores are exempted.
SERVICE STATION, AUTOMOBILE GASOLINE AND MOTOR FUELS: An occupancy which provides for a drive-in type business in which the following
services can be provided:
(A) The servicing of motor vehicles and operations incidental thereto but not necessarily limited to the retail sale of petroleum products and automotive
accessories; automobile waxing and polishing; tire changing and repairing; battery service, charging and replacement, and towing service.
(B) The following operation if conducted within a building: radiator cleaning and flushing; lubrication of motor vehicles; brake servicing and replacement
of brake cylinder, lines and brake shoes; wheel balancing; the testing, adjustment and replacement or servicing of carburetors, coils, condensers,
distributor caps, fan belts, filters, generators, points, rotors, spark plugs, voltage regulators, water and fuel pumps, water hoses, wiring, mufflers and
shock absorbers.
SETBACK: Distance from the property line.
SIDEWALK: Walkway to accommodate pedestrian traffic.
SIGN, BILLBOARD OR OTHER ADVERTISING DEVICE: Any structure or part thereof or device attached thereto or represented thereon, which shall
display or include any letter, word, model, banner, flag, pennant, insignia or representation used as or which is in the nature of an announcement, direction
or advertisement. The word "sign" includes the word "billboard" or any other type of advertising device, but does not include the flag, pennant or insignia of
any nation, state, city or other political unit. Types of signs are defined in the following categories:
Advertising Sign: A sign which directs attention to a business commodity, service or entertainment conducted, sold or offered on or off the premises.
Billboard: A type of advertising sign having more than one hundred (100) square feet of display surface which is either erected on the ground or
attached to or supported by a building or structure.
Business Sign: A sign which directs attention to the business or profession conducted on the premises. A "for sale", "to let" or "information" sign shall
be deemed a business sign.
SMALL WIND POWERED ELECTRICITY SYSTEMS: Have a rated capacity of up to and including one hundred (100) kilowatts (kW) and are incidental
and subordinate to a permitted use on the same parcel. A system is considered a small wind powered electricity system only if it supplies electrical power
solely for on site use, except that when a parcel on which the system is installed also receives electrical power supplied by a utility company, excess
electrical power generated and not presently needed for on site use may be used by the utility company as may be governed by applicable state statutes.
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 195/283
STREET: A public or recorded private thoroughfare which affords primary means of access to abutting property and is intended for general traffic
circulation.
STREET ADDRESS: Address determined by the main entrance to the structure.
STRUCTURE: A building which requires location on the ground or is attached to something having location on or in the ground, but not including fences or
paved areas.
THEATER, DRIVE-IN: An establishment to provide entertainment through projection of motion pictures on an outdoor screen for audiences whose seating
accommodations are provided by their own motor vehicles parked in spaces provided on the same site with the outdoor screen.
TRAILER OR MANUFACTURED HOME PARK: Land designed or used for the temporary or permanent parking of two (2) or more trailers or manufactured
homes, where the lot is rented to the occupant. Refer to the standards and definitions established in the Lewistown subdivision regulations and chapter 10
of this title.
TRAILER OR MANUFACTURED HOME SUBDIVISION: Land designed for exclusive manufactured home use, where the lot is intended to be sold to the
occupant. Refer to the standards and definitions established in the Lewistown subdivision regulations and chapter 10 of this title.
USABLE OPEN SPACE, YARD: That portion of the lot which is not built upon and, consequently, is not calculated in determining maximum lot coverage.
VARIANCE: An adjustment in the application of the specific regulations of this title to a particular piece of property which, because of special physical
circumstances applicable to it, is deprived of privileges commonly enjoyed by other properties in the same vicinity and district and which adjustment
remedies disparity in privileges.
WALKING DISTANCE: That distance measured along the shortest path accessible to foot traffic.
WHOLESALE ESTABLISHMENT: An establishment for the sale of goods and merchandise for resale instead of direct consumption.
YARD, FRONT: The narrowest part of the lot having street frontage and situated between a main building and street lot line. When a corner lot has two (2)
street frontages, the street address side shall be used to determine which frontage shall be considered the front.
YARD, REAR: A yard extending across the full width of the lot and situated between the main building and a rear lot line.
YARD, SIDE: A yard not designated as a front or rear yard. (Ord. 1576, 5-1-1989, eff. 6-15-1989; amd. Ord. 1664, 1-3-2000; Ord. 1727, 12-7-2009)
Chapter 3
ZONING DISTRICTS AND DISTRICT CLASSIFICATIONS
11-3-1: ZONING DISTRICTS:
To carry out the provisions of this title, the city is hereby divided into the following zoning districts in which the erection, construction, alteration,
reconstruction, repair or use of buildings, structures and land shall be regulated and restricted. The regulations in each district shall be uniform throughout
each district but may differ from those in other districts. (Ord. 1576, 5-1-1989, eff. 6-15-1989)
Zone Intent
FP floodplain
To regulate development and land use in areas subject to periodic flooding in order to protect property and public health and safety,
and to reduce public expenditures for flood protection and relief.
R-1
residential
one-family
A district to accommodate single-family dwelling units primarily.
R-1A
residential
one-family
A district to primarily accommodate single-family dwelling units.
R-1B
residential
one-family
A district to primarily accommodate single-family dwelling units with a maximum residential building height not to exceed thirty feet
(30').
R-2
residential
two-family
A district to accommodate single-family and two-family dwelling units primarily.
R-3
residential
multi-family
A district to accommodate multi-family dwelling units primarily.
RMO
residential
manufactured
home
A district to accommodate manufactured home dwelling units primarily.
NC
neighborhood
commercial
A district to provide convenience type commercial facilities within or adjacent to a residential neighborhood.
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 196/283
C-1 general
commercial
A district to provide community facilities offering a greater variety of goods and services than would normally be found in a
neighborhood oriented commercial center.
C-2 central
business
A district to provide retail and service outlets which serve the city or region.
C-3 highway
commercial
A district to provide areas for retail and service enterprises which require large lots and/or access to primary highway routes.
M-1 light
industrial
A district to accommodate a variety of warehouses and low impact industrial uses which are generally not compatible with other
commercial zones. Such districts should be located with access to major arterials and other transportation systems.
M-2 heavy
industrial
A district to accommodate high impact manufacturing, processing, fabrication and the assembly of products which, because of
operational size and/or excessive noise, odors, dust, or smoke associated with their operations, should be isolated from residential
or commercial districts.
P-I public
institutions
A district to reserve land for a variety of community facilities.
P-L public
lands
A district to reserve land owned exclusively by the public to meet their leisure and recreational needs.
(Ord. 1576, 5-1-1989, eff. 6-15-1989; amd. Ord. 1718, 4-21-2008)
11-3-2: DISTRICT CLASSIFICATIONS:
FP Floodplain:
Intent: To regulate development and land use in areas subject to periodic flooding in order to protect property and public health and safety, and to
reduce public expenditures for flood protection and relief. Refer to chapter 12, "Floodplain Regulations", of this title.
R-1 Residential One-Family:
Intent: A district to accommodate single-family dwelling units primarily.
Permitted Uses: Permitted uses in the R-1 district are as follows:
Accessory uses.
Automobile parking in connection with permitted residential uses.
Conditional uses provided in section 11-6-14 of this title subject to review and approval and to the procedures, conditions and requirements
prescribed.
Daycare homes.
Dwellings: single-family.
Golf courses, country clubs and community center buildings (operated by a public agency, neighborhood or homeowners' association).
Greenhouses for domestic uses.
Kennels (noncommercial).
Parks, playgrounds, play fields.
Temporary buildings for and during construction only.
Lot Area And Width: The lot area for any use in this district shall not be less than seven thousand two hundred (7,200) square feet, except lots of
record.
Lot Coverage: In the R-1 district, not more than thirty percent (30%) of the lot area shall be occupied by the principal and accessory buildings.
Yards: Every lot in the R-1 district shall have the following minimum yard requirements:
Front yard 25 feet
Rear yard 20 feet
Side yards 5 feet on each side
Side yards adjacent to street 10 feet
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 197/283
Building Height: Maximum residential building height shall be twenty five feet (25'). All other structures may exceed this height upon special review.
Off Street Parking:
(A) In the R-1 district, off street parking is required on the same building site with the building it is required to serve1.
(B) For any use other than residential, off street parking shall be provided in accordance with the requirements for off street parking in chapter 8 of
this title. (Ord. 1576, 5-1-1989, eff. 6-15-1989)
