feet (1,200') beyond the runway threshold, with its centerline being the continuation of the centerline of the runway.
(3) Defined Areas:
A. Runway Protection Area: Property of the trapezoid defined in subsection (C)1(c) of this section that lies within the airport property boundary.
B. Runway Influence Area: Property of the trapezoid defined in subsection (C)1(c) of this section that lies outside the airport property boundary.
(d) Airport Critical Area: The area enclosed by the lines shown on drawing 6 (established as a contour line 50 feet above the airport elevation). This
is an area critical to safe aircraft approaches and departures and will be protected as such.
(e) Remainder AAA Area: The remainder of the AAA area is that which lies outside the airport property area, runway protection area, runway
influence area and airport critical area but which lies within the outer limits of the airport affected area.
(D) Height Restrictions For Surfaces And Areas: Restricting the height of structures so as to protect the airport protects the health, safety and welfare of
the users of the airport as well as persons and property in the vicinity of the airport20. These areas and the regulations are intended to preserve the
utility of the airport and the public investment therein. When a surface or area overlap and one or the other is covered by more restrictive height
limitation, the more restrictive shall prevail. In order to comply with federal requirements and those found in section 67-7-203(1), Montana Code
Annotated, the Lewistown Municipal Airport hereby adopts the following height restrictions for the following areas:
1. Areas:
(a) Primary area:
(1) Objects greater than three inches (3") above grade shall be allowed only when constructed on low impact resistant supports with the frangible
point no higher than three inches (3") above grade.
(2) Objects that need to be located in this area because of their function shall be constructed at the lowest practical height.
(b) Airport property area:
(1) No objects greater than fifty feet (50') above the ground and/or four thousand two hundred seventeen feet (4,217') MSL. In addition, no
structures will be allowed within the building restriction line (BRL) shown on the airport layout plan.
(c) Airport critical area:
(1) No objects shall be permitted to penetrate the approach surfaces, be higher than fifty feet (50') above the ground and/or four thousand two
hundred seventeen feet (4,217') MSL.
(d) Runway influence area:
(1) No objects shall be permitted to penetrate the approach surfaces, be higher than fifty feet (50') above the ground and/or four thousand two
hundred seventeen feet (4,217') MSL.
(e) Runway protection area:
(1) No objects shall be permitted to penetrate the approach surfaces, be higher than fifty feet (50') above the ground and/or four thousand two
hundred seventeen feet (4,217') MSL.
(f) Remainder AAA area:
(1) Any structure or object proposed to be constructed that is greater than one hundred feet (100') AGL shall require a permit application for review
by the governing jurisdictional body.
2. Surfaces: No structure or object shall be permitted to penetrate the following defined surfaces:
(a) Horizontal surface: One hundred fifty feet (150') above the airport elevation. The airport elevation is four thousand one hundred sixty seven feet
(4,167') (MSL), therefore the height restriction limit is four thousand three hundred seventeen feet (4,317') (MSL).
(b) Conical surface: One hundred fifty feet (150') above the airport elevation plus one foot (1') in height for each twenty feet (20') of horizontal
distance measured from and normal to the periphery of the horizontal zone.
(c) Precision instrument approach surfaces: For each runway end, the elevation of the threshold centerline plus one foot (1') in height for each fifty
feet (50') measured perpendicularly from the end of the primary zone, extending ten thousand feet (10,000'); thence one foot (1') in height for each
forty feet (40') for an additional forty thousand feet (40,000').
(d) Nonprecision instrument approach surface: For each runway end, the elevation of the threshold centerline plus one foot (1') in height for each
thirty four feet (34') measured perpendicularly from the end of the primary zone, extending ten thousand feet (10,000').
(e) Utility nonprecision instrument approach surface: For each runway end, the elevation of the threshold centerline plus one foot (1') in height for
each twenty feet (20') measured perpendicularly from the end of the primary zone, extending five thousand feet (5,000').
(f) Transition surfaces: Begin at an elevation equal to the elevation of the nearest point on the runway centerline, and extend outward and upward at
right angles to the runway centerline or extended runway centerline, increasing one foot (1') in height for each seven feet (7') from the sides of the
primary zone and from the sides of all approach zones.
(E) Land Use In Areas21: The term "area(s)" as used in these regulations and as shown on sheets which are part of the AAA maps or drawings are set
forth in subsections (B) and (C) of this section. Regulation of land uses in these areas around the airport serves to protect the health and safety of
those on the ground and in the air. Well established accident data indicate land uses that concentrate people close to aircraft approach and departure
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 280/283
paths should be avoided. Land use regulations protect persons and property in the vicinity of the airport from airport related effects such as high
probability accident areas, noise, fumes, vibrations, light or any other effects from normal and anticipated normal airport operations22.
Permitted uses are those uses which are allowed, and obtaining a permit for these uses pursuant to these regulations serves as notification to the
administrative officer of those uses.
Conditional uses are those uses which may be allowed provided a permit is obtained pursuant to the procedures set forth in these regulations.
Conditional uses will be reviewed to a greater extent than permitted uses and may be limited in duration in the runway influence area. Conditional uses
outside the runway influence area but within the airport critical area will be allowed as long as they do not adversely affect aviation and/or public safety
as determined by the airport board following the guidelines and intent of these regulations. These conditional uses will not supersede any jurisdictional
zoning in place at the adoption of these regulations.
All other uses are prohibited, including sources of electromagnetic effects that may interfere with electronic navigational aids, and lights other than
navigational aids that glare upward or shine on or in the direction of the airport and bird attractants such as solid waste disposal sites, lagoons and
certain types of agriculture23. Under extraordinary circumstances some uses which are not permitted or listed as conditional uses may be allowed,
provided a variance is obtained pursuant to these regulations.
When the following areas overlap, the more restrictive uses apply:
1. Use Restrictions:
(a) Airport Runway Protection Areas And Primary Area:
(1) Permitted uses:
Agriculture (other than forestry or livestock).
Livestock, outside the airport's wildlife fence.
(b) Airport Property Area:
(1) Permitted Uses:
Agriculture (other than forestry or livestock), golf courses, tourism information centers and museums.
Aircraft maintenance, manufacturing, and testing facilities.
Aircraft operational facilities including, but not limited to, instrument landing systems, visual navigational aids, and related equipment;
communication facilities; weather service offices and equipment.
Aircraft runways, taxiways, ramps, parking areas and fuel storage facilities that are related to aviation activities only.
Flight schools, flying clubs and other schools or training facilities relating to aviation or air related transportation.
Hangars and buildings which may be used for the storage or maintenance of aircraft; airport snow removal, sweeping and other maintenance
equipment, and other aviation related or ancillary activities.
Offices and facilities for airport management, air charter, air taxi, crop spraying, aircraft sales or rentals, and air cargo processing facilities.
Offices and facilities for the operation and maintenance of air rescue, emergency and firefighting services.
Offices and facilities of federal, state and local government entities.
Terminal buildings which may house offices of airline companies, and other businesses and concessionaires.
(2) Conditional Uses: The following uses are conditional uses in this area and to the extent the area lies within the city, are subject to the
restrictions of this subsection (E)1, "Use Restrictions", and the permit requirements of section 11-6-1 of this title, conditional use permit:
Automobile racing facilities.
Boarding of livestock or other animals by governmental agencies.
Businesses not located in the terminal building, and those uses which are sanctioned by the Lewistown Municipal Airport board, but have not
been heretofore mentioned.
Driver education test track.
Firearm and sport shooting ranges.
Industrial development or use.
Light commercial development or use.
Live animal export facilities.
Municipal water storage tanks or towers.
Outdoor baseball/softball facilities, recreational trails and other public or private recreational uses, outside the airport's wildlife fence.
Residential airpark.

https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 281/283
Trees and shrubs less than fifty feet (50') above the ground and/or four thousand two hundred seventeen feet (4,217') mean sea level.
Under unique, extenuating circumstances, a temporary use, for up to one year, that complies with current building and fire codes.
(3) Prohibited Uses:
Trees, shrubs or structures greater than fifty feet (50') above the ground and/or four thousand two hundred seventeen feet (4,217') mean sea
level (MSL).
(c) Runway Influence Areas And Airport Critical Area:
(1) Permitted uses:
Agriculture (other than forestry or livestock).
Livestock outside the airport's wildlife fence.
Low density residential development with a maximum of one residence on a parcel of at least 2.5 acres in size in the runway influence area.
Residential development in the airport critical area will be governed by the jurisdictional subdivision regulations.
Retail and light commercial business that would not adversely affect aviation and/or public safety as determined by the airport board following
the guidelines and intent of these regulations.
Roadways, automobile parking areas, and railroads that satisfy height restrictions.
Structures in existence at the date of adoption of these regulations.
(2) Conditional uses:
Gravel pits and/or associated activities.
Motels/hotels outside the runway influence area.
(3) Prohibited uses:
Educational centers (including all types of primary and secondary schools, preschools, childcare facilities).

Hospitals, medical inpatient treatment facilities, nursing/convalescent home facilities.
Places of public assembly not previously listed will be prohibited in the runway influence area and addressed as a conditional use in the critical
area.
Places of worship will be prohibited in the runway influence area and addressed as a conditional use in the airport critical area.
Trees, shrubs or structures greater than fifty feet (50') above the ground and/or four thousand two hundred seventeen feet (4,217') mean sea
level (MSL).
(d) Remaining AAA Area Uses:
Land use within the AAA (other than that within the airport property areas, runway influence areas and airport critical area): Pursuant to these
regulations, property owners will not be regulated beyond height of structures, airspace for instrument approaches or electromechanical effects to
navigational aids.
2. Additional Restrictions: Notwithstanding any other provision of these regulations, no use may be made of land within any area established by these
regulations that creates an electromagnetic effect, makes it difficult for operators of aircraft to distinguish between airport lights and others, results in
glare in the eyes of operators of aircraft using the airport, impairs visibility in the vicinity of the airport, attracts flocks of birds or otherwise endangers
the landing, taking off, maneuvering, or operating of aircraft. (Ord. 1739, 2-6-2012)
11-16-5: NONCONFORMING USES24:
(A) Grandfather Clause: It is not the purpose or intent of these regulations to require removal or alteration of any existing structure or tree or to require the
cessation or alteration of a use that is lawfully in existence when these regulations become effective. However, it is assumed nonconforming uses will
not continue forever25. The following provisions are designed to reasonably address nonconforming uses or structures or trees.
1. Documentation Of Uses And Structures Or Trees Within The Airport Boundary And Critical Area: The administrative officer shall document, to the
best of the officer's ability and within a reasonable time after adoption of these regulations, those existing uses of land and the existence of structures
or trees found in the AAA within the airport boundary and critical area with an estimate of the height of structures or trees26.
(a) Nonconforming Uses Of Land: Any lawful use of land in existence when these regulations become effective may continue, but reconstruction of a
structure which contains a nonconforming use after destruction or substantial damage which affects that use may be prohibited. Any addition to or
remodel of a structure containing a nonconforming use requires a variance under these regulations.
(b) Nonconforming Structures Or Trees: Existing structures or trees may continue to exist but their expansion or additional growth is prohibited
unless a variance is obtained under the provisions of these regulations.
2. Substantial Damage To A Nonconforming Use: "Substantial damage" occurs when eighty percent (80%) or more of a structure or tree is deteriorated
or decayed or when that structure or tree has been torn down or destroyed27. The administrative officer has the authority to determine substantial
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 282/283
damage. A substantially damaged structure or tree, which is nonconforming, may not be reconstructed or replaced without first obtaining variance
under the provisions of these regulations and then obtaining a permit.
3. Maintaining Nonconforming Trees: After identification of trees in place at the time these regulations become effective, the county or city, as the case
may be, may trim those trees, at its expense, to maintain their heights at the time of identification28.
4. Marking Nonconforming Trees Or Structures: If the county or city, as per jurisdiction, elects to install, operate and maintain, at its own expense, lights
and markers necessary to warn pilots of a nonconforming use, the owners of those structures or trees shall allow this activity29.
5. Residential Land Uses: If land in an area in which residential use is not permitted by these regulations has been developed for that use or platted for
that use, the residential use may continue, but existing owners must be notified by the administrative officer that the lots are within an adopted AAA
within a reasonable time after its designation30. It is the responsibility of those owners to notify subsequent purchasers of the property that the
property is in an AAA and may be affected by these regulations. (Ord. 1739, 2-6-2012)
11-16-6: AMENDMENT OF REGULATIONS:
These regulations may be amended by following the same procedure for adoption as set forth in subsection 11-16-1(D) of this chapter and section 67-7-
201(5), Montana Code Annotated. If appropriate, other boards or commissions may be involved31. (Ord. 1739, 2-6-2012)
11-16-7: ADDITIONAL PROVISIONS:
(A) Acquisition Of Property Rights: Either Fergus County or the city of Lewistown may protect the Lewistown Municipal Airport by utilizing statutory rights
set forth in section 67-7-210, Montana Code Annotated.
(B) Relationship Of AAA Regulations To Zoning Ordinances: If a governing body has adopted a zoning ordinance or resolution and there is a conflict
between these regulations and the zoning ordinance or resolution, the more stringent limitation or requirement prevails32. (Ord. 1739, 2-6-2012)
Chapter 17
WIND POWERED ELECTRICITY SYSTEMS
11-17-1: SITING:
Small wind powered electricity systems are allowed as accessory uses in all zoning districts provided the following standards are met:
(A) In residential districts (R-1, R-2, R-3, RMO, and NC), wind powered electricity systems rated up to and including ten (10) kilowatts are allowed. The
maximum height shall be eighty feet (80'), as measured from finished grade to the top of the tower system, which includes the generating unit and the
highest vertical extent of any blades or rotors.
(B) In all other districts (C-1, C-2, C-3, M-1, M-2, P-I, P-L), wind powered electricity systems up to and including one hundred (100) kilowatts are allowed.
The maximum height shall be one hundred twenty five feet (125'), as measured from finished grade to the top of the tower system, which includes the
generating unit and the highest vertical extent of any blades or rotors.
(C) On parcels greater than one acre in size, except within residential districts, wind powered electricity systems up to and including one hundred (100)
kilowatts are also allowed as a primary use provided all other applicable provisions of this chapter are met. (Ord. 1727, 12-7-2009)
11-17-2: MINIMUM SETBACK REQUIREMENT:
Minimum setback from any property line for wind powered electricity systems eighty feet (80') or less in height shall be one hundred ten percent (110%) of
the tower height (i.e., 110% x tower height = minimum setback). Minimum setback from any property line for wind powered electricity systems more than
eighty feet (80') in height shall be two hundred percent (200%) of the tower height (i.e., 200% x tower height = minimum setback). (Ord. 1727, 12-7-2009)
11-17-3: PERMITS:
All wind powered electricity system installations are subject to applicable building, electrical, and mechanical permits issued by the city and shall be
located in compliance with any applicable federal aviation administration regulations and guidelines and Lewistown Airport height regulations. Turbines
must have been approved under a small wind certification program recognized by the American Wind Energy Association. (Ord. 1727, 12-7-2009)
11-17-4: REQUIREMENT FOR ENGINEERED DRAWINGS:
Building permit applications for wind powered electricity systems shall be accompanied by standard drawings of the wind turbine structure and a stamped
engineered drawing of the tower, base, footings, and/or foundation as provided by the manufacturer. A project specific engineered soil study shall be
required for wind powered systems in excess of twenty (20) kilowatts. (Ord. 1727, 12-7-2009)
7/1/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=567 283/283
11-17-5: NOISE:
Sound produced by a wind powered electricity system under normal operating conditions, as measured at the property line, shall not exceed the definition
of nuisance noise. Sound levels however, may be exceeded during short term events beyond the control of anyone such as utility outages and/or severe
windstorms. It is incumbent upon the property owner to demonstrate compliance prior to the issuance of any permits by the city. (Ord. 1727, 12-7-2009)
11-17-6: UTILITY NOTIFICATION:
No wind powered electricity system shall be installed until the city has been provided evidence that the utility company has been informed of the
customer's intent to install an interconnected customer owned generator. Off grid systems shall be exempt from this requirement. (Ord. 1727, 12-7-2009)
11-17-7: ENCLOSURE:
All tower installations other than single pole towers shall be enclosed by a fence or shall incorporate other effective measures sufficient to discourage
unauthorized climbing of the tower. (Ord. 1727, 12-7-2009)
11-17-8: COLOR:
Except when a special permit is issued by the zoning commission, tower colors should have a matted or nonreflective finish and be of neutral subdued
tones such as earth tones of green or brown. Gray, including naturally darkening galvanized gray, is also acceptable. Towers shall not be finished in bright
or vivid colors intended to draw attention to the structure or property. (Ord. 1727, 12-7-2009)
11-17-9: SIGNS:
The system tower shall not be used for signs or advertising of any kind. One sign, limited to four (4) square feet, shall be posted at the base of the tower.
The sign shall include a notice of no trespassing, a warning of high voltage, and the telephone number of the property owner/operator to call in case of
emergency. (Ord. 1727, 12-7-2009)
11-17-10: LIGHTING:
No lights shall be installed on the system, unless required to meet federal aviation administration regulations. (Ord. 1727, 12-7-2009)
11-17-11: CLIMBING APPARATUS:
All tower climbing apparatus shall be located at least twelve feet (12') above the ground and the system tower must be designed to prevent climbing within
the first twelve feet (12') above the ground. (Ord. 1727, 12-7-2009)
11-17-12: REMOVAL:
Tower systems that remain nonfunctional or inoperative for a continuous period of one year shall be deemed to be abandoned, shall constitute a public
nuisance and shall be removed by the owner/operator. (Ord. 1727, 12-7-2009)
11-17-13: PROHIBITED SYSTEMS:
Large wind powered electricity systems shall not be allowed, erected, operated or maintained within the city. (Ord. 1727, 12-7-2009)
